HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE 

BYLINE:  By Martin Filler; Martin Filler is the architecture critic of The New Republic and writes frequently for The New York Review of Books and House & Garden magazine.

 BODY:
LANDSCAPE DESIGN: A Cultural and Architectural History. By Elizabeth Barlow Rogers. (Abrams, $75.) In this magnum opus, Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, the founding president of the Central Park Conservancy and a longtime administrator of that celebrated oasis, stakes out and cultivates a breathtakingly vast terrain: the history of man-made landscape from Neolithic times to the present. Though Rogers focuses on a number of well-known gardens and parks -- from Hadrian's Villa of A.D. 118-38 outside Rome to Antonio Gaudi's Park Guell of 1900-14 in Barcelona -- her subject is less horticulture than the social interaction of various cultures with their natural settings. Encompassing city planning as much as garden design, this panoramic study is impressive not only for its encyclopedic scope but also for the author's authoritative command of so much diverse material and for her lucid writing. 
 It will become the standard survey for some years to come. The book, gloriously illustrated thanks to the intrepid photo research of John K. Crowley and Diana Gongora, is appropriately evenhanded in its emphases, with the exception of the classical gardens of Japan, which deserve more than the 15 pages allotted to them. Rogers is particularly strong on the modern era in America, giving due appreciation to the Garden City and New Town movements that flourished in the early 20th century and are approximated today by such efforts of the New Urbanism movement as the highly publicized town of Seaside, Fla. 
 Architecture in its broadest sense is the principle underlying Rogers's approach, and her carefully plotted organization suits her vast topic ideally. Time and again she makes impassioned pleas for the preservation of the planet's green heritage. "Our success in this endeavor will depend on many things," she writes, "including an understanding of the rich psychological and mythopoeic relationship of human beings to landscape throughout history." In those terms, it is impossible to think of a better synthesis than this magisterial overview. 
THE HOUSE BOOK. (Phaidon, $45.) The latest installment in Phaidon's successful "A to Z" series, this entertaining alphabetical compendium illustrates a single residence on each page, with one large color photograph and a small block of text. Written by a team of 35 contributors, those unsigned glosses run the gamut from shockingly inaccurate to gems of concision. Equally wide-ranging is the global roll call of domestic shelter, from the haus tambaran, or ceremonial house, of the Abelam people of New Guinea to the thatch-domed indlu of the Zulus of Natal. The high-style Western canon is fully represented also, from the Palace of Knossos on Crete (c. 1600 B.C.) to the House Near Bordeaux, by Rem Koolhaas of the Office for Metropolitan Architecture (1998).
Among the serendipitous pleasures of this eye-filling album are the random juxtapositions that occasionally pair designs with surprising affinities on facing pages, prompting memories of compare-and-contrast final-exam questions. The likenesses can be purely superficial, like the domed Breakfast Room of Sir John Soane's house in London (1812-13) vis-a-vis the retractable glass roof of Paolo Soleri's Dome House in Cave Creek, Ariz. (1949). But in other instances there's a new shock of recognition, as in the flat but intricately linear facades of a reed mudhif, or guest house, of the Madan (Marsh Arabs) of Mesopotamia and Benedetto da Maiano's masonry Palazzo Strozzi in Florence (1498-c. 1536). The striking similarities between the rondavel thatched huts of the Hutu people of Rwanda and the igloos of the Inuit in Greenland are made clearer across the spread. And the astonishing emergence of democracy during the 18th century is neatly signified by Johann Lucas von Hildebrandt's pompous Upper Belvedere Palace in Vienna (1721-22) confronting James Hoban's modest White House in Washington (1792-1801).
ARCHITECTS ON ARCHITECTS. Edited by Susan Gray. (McGraw-Hill, $39.95.) Practitioners of a wildly competitive art form, architects are always looking over their shoulders, not just at contemporaries with whom they must compete for jobs but also at the great predecessors against whom they'll be measured by history. The master builders that 24 present-day architects chose to write about for this revealing if somewhat repetitive collection tell as much about the authors as their subjects. Predictably, many of the participants (all men, with the exception of Diana Agrest) gravitated toward the big boys of modernism, and three architects are the focus of almost half the essays, with five on Le Corbusier, four on Paul Rudolph and two on Louis I. Kahn. 
Sometimes those pairings can seem willfully contradictory. It would have been far more interesting to find out what Richard Meier thinks about Le Corbusier, who has had such an overwhelming influence on his own aesthetic, than for him to draw tenuous analogies between his work and the diametrically different architecture of Frank Lloyd Wright. Likewise, there is more than a bit of irony in Michael Graves's praise for Le Corbusier, whom he routinely belittled in lectures earlier in his career. Much more edifying is Tadao Ando's epiphany on his first visit to Le Corbusier's Ronchamp chapel: "Because of the overwhelming spatial experience, which penetrated deep into my soul, I had to escape after staying less than one hour. I was awe-struck by a light unprecedented in my life."
Best among the other appreciations are Carlos Jimenez on Luis Barragan; Ricardo Legorreta on another Mexican, the little-remembered Jose Villagran; and Hugh Hardy on William van Alen, architect of the Chrysler Building. As Hardy writes of that idiosyncratic aluminum-spired skyscraper, "This iconic office building goes for broke, flaunting the exterior skin's independence as a costume pageant of pattern, gleaming profiles and symbolic panache. It's a theatrical gesture that identifies this as a building like no other, and gives New Yorkers proof that they are extraordinary." 
THE GENIUS OF ROBERT ADAM: His Interiors. By Eileen Harris. (Paul Mellon Center/Yale University, $85.) As an architect, the 18th-century Scottish multitasker Robert Adam had much less opportunity to build anew than to remodel existing buildings, and thus much of his prodigious energy was channeled into interior design. Though we think of the Gesamtkunstwerk, or total work of art, as a 19th-century concept, Adam anticipated it by orchestrating everything from urban planning to curtain trimmings with breathtaking assurance and demonic attentiveness. That is evident on every page of this sumptuous volume.
Written with complete command of archival source material by the architectural historian Eileen Harris, this minutely detailed study of 19 Adam houses in town and country is replete with the staggering sums his luxurious decorating schemes cost, as well as the names of the small army of artisans who executed them. Harris pursues an antiquarian, formalist investigation that overshadows much of the social history that would explain why Adam was indeed the genius her title proclaims him. No architect has ever possessed a shrewder intuition for the specific social uses to which his buildings would be put. Adam's knowledge of the complicated rituals and hierarchical needs of Britain's ruling class in a period of enormous change was the true secret behind his success, quite apart from the superlative quality of his art. 
FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT AND THE ART OF JAPAN: The Architect's Other Passion. By Julia Meech. (Japan Society/Abrams, $49.50.) One of the great self-taught connoisseurs of Japanese art in general and ukiyo-e (colored woodblock prints) in particular, Frank Lloyd Wright used his discerning eye both to apply the principles of Japanese design to his own work as well as to supplement his often erratic income. On his first trip to Japan, in 1905, Wright bought prints that he later sold back home, often to his own clients, including Darwin D. Martin of Buffalo, for whom he built one of his best prairie houses as well as an excellent print portfolio. 
Constantly upgrading his own holdings by deaccessioning lesser impressions for better ones, Wright was by no means in it only for the money; he steeped himself in the Japanese aesthetic as he lived with his prints. It is impossible not to see the architect's colorful, boldly outlined leaded-glass windows, asymmetrical development of interior space and dramatic compositional play of solids and voids as proceeding directly from his hoard of Hiroshiges, Hokusais and Utamaros. With all his ups and downs, Wright still owned some 6,000 prints at the time of his death in 1959.
"Frank Lloyd Wright and the Art of Japan: The Architect's Other Passion" was published to accompany the splendid exhibition of the same name that the art historian Julia Meech organized at the Japan Society Gallery in New York earlier this year. This handsome volume brims with wonderful pictures and illuminating anecdotes about Wright's mania for fine things; the forbearance of his loyal and generous patrons, whose trust he often stretched to the breaking point; and the boom-or-bust finances that kept his collection in a constant state of flux. Meech makes a convincing case for the centrality of the Japanese print in any full assessment of Wright's career, and if her proposition is hardly a new one, no commentator has yet done better than she in creating such a vivid picture of the architect's tireless pursuit of two-dimensional beauty. 
THE ARCHITECTURE OF R. M. SCHINDLER. Organized by Elizabeth A. T. Smith and Michael Darling. (Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles/Abrams, $65.) R. M. SCHINDLER. By Judith Sheine with new photography by Grant Mudford. (Phaidon, $59.95.) Though publicity alone cannot sustain an artistic reputation indefinitely, the degree to which the media can make or break an architectural career increased dramatically during the century just past. One of the chief victims of that trend was the immensely gifted Austrian architect Rudolph M. Schindler, who immigrated to the United States in 1913, worked with Frank Lloyd Wright for five years, supervised the master's work in Southern California and decided to resettle there. The double house and studio of 1921-22 that Schindler designed and built for himself, his wife and another bohemian couple on Kings Road in West Hollywood was constructed from concrete slabs poured in place on the site and tilted upward to form the outer walls. Low-cost, flexible and spatially innovative, that unconventional residence was justly described by the architectural historian Reyner Banham as "one of the most original and ingenious domestic designs of the present century -- and one of the most gratifyingly habitable." 
Nonetheless, Schindler lacked the public-relations skills and self-aggrandizing character of his fellow Viennese architect Richard Neutra, who claimed the lion's share of attention -- and of experimental commissions -- in the Los Angeles region at a time when it was the most receptive market for modern architecture in America. Though Schindler's output was more uneven than Neutra's, it was also more conceptually daring and emotionally richer -- reasons why a recent generation of talented California architects, especially the late Franklin D. Israel and Michael Rotondi, have revered Schindler as a spiritual father. So did his erstwhile drafting assistant Esther McCoy, who after the architect's death in 1953 mounted a successful journalistic campaign to elevate his critical stature.
The simultaneous appearance of two new Schindler monographs takes McCoy's cause a giant step farther. "The Architecture of R. M. Schindler," the catalog of the retrospective mounted by the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles and now on view in Vienna, is ravishingly illustrated and contains several penetrating essays, including Robert Sweeney's lively account of life in the Kings Road House. And Judith Sheine's "R. M. Schindler" provides a thorough, well-paced survey of his professional development, interweaving his biography and works to notable effect. 
LE CORBUSIER IN AMERICA: Travels in the Land of the Timid. By Mardges Bacon. (MIT, $59.95.) During the worldwide depression of the 1930's, those architects who could afford to travel hit the road not only to broaden their cultural horizons but also to drum up business. The ever-enterprising Charles-Edouard Jeanneret (better known by his pseudonym of Le Corbusier) made several international sojourns during the decade, and this absorbing account of his first visit to the United States, in 1935, is by far the most detailed yet published. Though ostensibly a lecture tour -- he spoke at the Museum of Modern Art, Columbia, Princeton, Vassar and Yale -- his true purpose was to find new commissions and absorb the lessons of the americainisme that was strongly affecting contemporary European architecture.
But it was far from all work and no play. Captivated by African-American culture, Le Corbusier in New York trekked up to Harlem's Savoy Ballroom, heard Louis Armstrong play in a Broadway nightclub and saw at least two performances of what he called opera negre: "Porgy and Bess," which had recently opened. And on college campuses he was sexually titillated and more than a bit frightened by the athletic, self-confident coeds he termed "Amazons," developing a crush on one statuesque Vassar student of "The Group" era by the name of Alma Clayburgh.
Although Le Corbusier found no jobs in America, he did take home to Paris several new ideas that he would apply in his own work, including the tension structures he admired here and the multifunctional skyscrapers that influenced his later tall building designs. He left a legacy on these shores as well, primarily in the "tower-in-a-park" housing projects of the postwar period that took their cues from his visionary urban planning schemes of the 1920's. The sociological problems that later befell those American public housing estates were used decades later to discredit their inspirer, though his own Unites d'Habitation in Europe are still sought-after addresses. Mardges Bacon, a professor of art and architecture at Northeastern University, conveys an authentic sense of the period in this exhaustively researched and engagingly written study of a telling episode in 20th-century architectural transformations. 
J. J. P. OUD. 1890-1963: The Complete Works. By Ed Taverne, Cor Wagenaar and Martien de Vletter. (Netherlands Architecture Institute/Distributed Art Publishers, $85.) At the peak of his career, in the early 1930's, the Dutch architect Jacobus Johannes Pieter Oud (rhymes with "proud") was regarded by many tastemakers -- including Philip Johnson and Alfred H. Barr Jr. of the Museum of Modern Art -- as the equal of Le Corbusier and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. Oud's pure white, sleek-lined, humanely proportioned low-rise buildings epitomized the early International style at its finest. No one at the time did better workers' dwellings, and projects like his Hoek van Holland Housing Scheme of 1924-27 in the Netherlands and row houses at the German Werkbund's Weissenhofsiedlung housing exhibition of 1927 in Stuttgart remain classics of low-budget, high-style modern design. Similarly esteemed is his Cafe de Unie of 1925 in Rotterdam, a landmark of the de Stijl movement with interiors by the artist Theo van Doesburg.
Then, with a single building, Oud wrecked his international reputation. His Shell headquarters of 1937-42 in The Hague was ornamented in a busy late-Art Deco manner that seemed a throwback to the folksy Amsterdam School of the 1920's. Though today a more inclusive view of modernism makes the International style prohibition of ornament seem silly, Oud's career-breaking structure was indeed a major clunker. He dug in against the stinging criticism, and played no important role in the postwar rebuilding of either the Netherlands or Europe at large. Toward the end of his career he returned to a lighter, cleaner manner reminiscent of his functionalist heyday, but never recaptured his former stature.
This monograph, the most complete to date, puts Oud's checkered development into its local and historical context, explaining the enlightened political circumstances that supported his publicly financed housing. It also suggests why contemporaneous developments in America lagged well behind the Dutch paradigm, and gives lie to the postmodernist canard that the International style was a soulless, oppressive conspiracy of technocrats bent on conformist social engineering. We should all be so lucky. 
WEEKEND UTOPIA: Modern Living in the Hamptons. By Alastair Gordon. (Princeton Architectural Press, $45.) The bloated postmodern McMansions that have despoiled the East End of Long Island over the past decade have reduced to a dim memory another local architectural tradition. In the optimistic aftermath of World War II, Long Island's South Fork became a "laboratory of leisure" for new forms of residential architecture. If not quite as significant as what was going on at the same time in Southern California with the houses of the Case Study program, the new vacation retreats of the Hamptons nonetheless contributed greatly to the acceptance of modern architecture on the East Coast.
Alastair Gordon, an architecture writer and longtime Hamptons summer resident, brings to vivid life a century in the architectural and social history of the East End, from its post-Civil War discovery as a summer colony to the demise of modernism and the revival of the Shingle Style in the late 1970's. Gordon resurrects such little-remembered pioneers as William Muschenheim, an M.I.T. graduate who worked in Germany in the 20's and came home filled with modern notions that he applied to a seaside house and bathing pavilions on his father's property in Hampton Bays. And who knew about the gracefully sited Carera beach house of 1940 in Montauk, designed with Prairie Style overhanging roofs by Antonin Raymond, a Czech-born Frank Lloyd Wright protege who had worked for the master in Japan.
Gordon shifts into high gear with the heady postwar years, which saw an influx of avant-garde New York artists to the East End, including Robert Motherwell, whose Quonset hut-like house of 1946 in East Hampton was designed by the early French modernist Pierre Chareau. Before long, Philip Johnson, George Nelson and Gordon Bunshaft were among the luminaries of midcentury modernism building on the dunes. So were lesser figures like Andrew Geller, whose determination to "unsquare the cube" resulted in eccentric designs like his Hunt house of 1959 on Fire Island, which resembled a huge box kite laid down on its side. And Geller's dreadful Elkin house of 1966 in Sagaponack, an angular mess that he called the "Reclining Picasso" but which neighbors saw as a train wreck, no doubt played a part in the subsequent retreat to tradition, however spurious and ill-executed the results have been. 
YOU HAVE TO PAY FOR THE PUBLIC LIFE: Selected Essays of Charles W. Moore. Edited by Kevin Keim. (MIT, $45.) With the exception of Robert Venturi, no American architect of the postwar period has written with more erudition, elegance, insight and wit than Charles W. Moore. Regrettably, since Moore's death in 1993 at the age of 68 his once formidable reputation has been in decline, along with that of the postmodernism he helped advocate (though, like Venturi, he hated the word and always insisted he'd rather be pre- something else).
Moore's classic essays of the 60's, when he also did his best designs and served as the influential dean of the architecture schools at Berkeley and Yale, have been anthologized elsewhere. But it is good to have a full complement of those seminal pieces available for those who may have missed them previously, as well as for several articles, lectures and interviews unpublished until now. In his 1965 essay "You Have to Pay for the Public Life," Moore charted important new territory by admiring Disneyland as a serious piece of urban planning, as well as eloquently defending California's often-maligned civic architecture. Two years later, in "Plug It In, Rameses, and See if It Lights Up, Because We Aren't Going to Keep It Unless It Works," he caught the hip sensibility of the moment not only in his title but also in praising the kitschy pleasures of the Madonna Inn in San Luis Obispo, Calif., a vernacular roadside extravaganza that epitomized what he called the "architecture of inclusion."
In his evocation of the spirit of place, Moore was peerless at extracting the essential qualities of a particular locale and explaining them to others, not least of all its inhabitants. "Southernness," written in 1975, is a superb brief introduction, as is his "Impressions of Japanese Architecture," published in 1978. And in "Architecture and Fairy Tales," a 1975 lecture printed here for the first time, Moore roams among many of his familiar touchstones -- from Baroque churches to Mexican villages -- as he takes his readers on an imaginary journey that captures to perfection his beguiling gifts as scholar, teacher and enchanter. 
SHIGERU BAN. (Princeton Architectural Press, $35.) Among the most interesting of the younger architects to emerge as Japan's bubble economy burst during the 1990's, Shigeru Ban, now 44, is one of those appealing cross-cultural figures whose work synthesizes the best of Western modernism and Japanese tradition. With his interest in lightweight construction, reminiscent of the classical architecture of his homeland, Ban is best known for his Curtain Wall House of 1995 in Tokyo. There he satirized the International style convention of a suspended, nonstructural glass facade by playfully replacing it with retractable glazing and an outer, two-story-high, white fabric curtain that wraps around the two street elevations and can be pulled back to fully open the interior in warm weather.
In a period when other architects have gravitated toward a host of new high-tech materials, Ban is fascinated by paper and cardboard, another throwback to Japanese precedent. He is equally concerned with making his expertise available for humanitarian purposes, and he has combined both impulses with admirable results. His cardboard-tube-framed emergency shelters for Rwandan refugees in 1995 solved several immediate problems brilliantly. With similar ingenuity, he took the large cardboard cylinders used for casting concrete columns and recycled them into temporary "log" houses (costing less than $2,000 each) for the victims of the 1995 Kobe earthquake. "Even in disaster areas," Ban writes, "as an architect I want to create beautiful buildings. . . . If I did not feel this way, it would be impossible to create meaningful architecture and to make a contribution to society at the same time." 
He can also use those humble materials with lyrical abandon, as in his Japan Pavilion of 2000 for the Hanover Expo in Germany, with its undulating paper-and-PVC roof supported by a lacy latticework of cardboard tubing. And the arborlike Paper Arch he erected over the Museum of Modern Art's Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden during the summer of 2000 was a worthy successor to the many inventive temporary structures displayed there over the years. Though this first English-language monograph on Ban's architecture can be a bit skimpy on factual detail -- one would like to know what fabric was used on the Curtain Wall House, for example -- it is a welcome introduction to an emerging talent who merits close attention.
