SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 76

LENGTH: 3522 words

HEADLINE: 2011 

BYLINE:  By Niall Ferguson; Niall Ferguson is a professor of political and financial history at the University of Oxford. He is the author of "The Cash Nexus" and a contributor to "The Age of Terror," to be published this month by Basic Books.

 BODY:
Take the long view. What will New York be like on Sept. 11, 2011? It's not difficult to imagine a rather wretched future. You need only visit one of those cities -- Jerusalem or Belfast -- that have been fractured by terrorism and religious strife to get a glimpse. Imagine a segregated city, with a kind of Muslim ghetto in an outer borough that non-Muslims can enter only -- if they dare -- with a special endorsement on their ID cards. Imagine security checkpoints at every tunnel and bridge leading into Manhattan, where armed antiterrorist troops check every vehicle for traces of explosives and prohibited toxins. 
 Does that mean you also have to count on even worse gridlock on the Van Wyck Expressway? No, because you also need to imagine a decline in the number of cars on the road. For by 2011, the third and final oil shock will have heralded the end of the internal-combustion era. 
Still, there will be some comfort to be found downtown. There, rising like a phoenix from the rubble of the World Trade Center, will be that gleaming monument to American resilience: the twin towers of the Nafta Center. Even if world trade couldn't be rebuilt after the Great Depression of 2002-03, at least the city's beloved landmark could. And the new towers will be even taller -- thanks to the antiaircraft turrets on top. 
In its immediate aftermath, the destruction of the World Trade Center looked like one of those events -- the assassination at Sarajevo, the bombing of Pearl Harbor -- that set history on a new course. Some excitable commentators began talking about "World War III" almost the same day the twin towers fell. That's one possible future. Much more likely, however, is the nightmare scene sketched above. That's because this outcome could arise out of already discernible trends, all of which predated Sept. 11, 2001. Tragic and spectacular though it was, that event was far less of a turning point than is generally believed. 
We should be wary, in fact, of ever attaching too much importance to any single event. It was not Gavrilo Princip alone who started World War I. In his great novel, "The Man Without Qualities," Robert Musil dismissed the idea that history moves in a straight line like a billiard ball, changing direction only when struck. For Musil, history was more like "the passage of clouds," constantly in flux, never predictable. That quality is what makes it impossible to predict where exactly we will be 10 years from now. 
Yet Musil's analogy of history and clouds illuminates something else. Though the weather is hard to forecast, the range of possible weathers is not infinitely large. It may not rain tomorrow, but we know that if it does, it will rain water, not boiling oil. It may not be quite as warm as yesterday, but we know that it will not be minus 50 degrees. 
In other words, Sept. 11 was the historical equivalent of a violent and unpredictable storm. But the storm did not alter the fact that summer was slowly shading into fall. In just the same way, the attacks on New York and Washington, however shocking, did not alter the direction of several underlying historical trends. In many respects the world will not be so very different in 2011 from the world as it would have evolved under the influence of those trends, even had the attacks not happened. 
The first deep trend is obvious enough: the spread of terrorism -- that is to say the use of violence by nonstate organizations in the pursuit of extreme political goals -- to the United States. This kind of terrorism has been around for quite a while. Hijacking planes is certainly not new: since the late 1960's, when the tactic first began to be used systematically by the Palestine Liberation Organization and its sympathizers, there have been some 500 hijackings. As for the tactic of flying planes directly at populous targets, what else were the 3,913 Japanese pilots doing who killed themselves and many more American servicemen flying kamikaze missions in 1944 and 1945?
All that was really new on Sept. 11 was that these tried-and-tested tactics were applied in combination and in the United States. Between 1995 and 2000, according to State Department figures, there were more than 2,100 international terrorist attacks. But just 15 of them occurred in North America, causing just seven casualties. It was the successful extension of international terrorism to the United States that was the novelty.
A novelty, yes, but hardly a surprise. Terrorism had been a fact of life in major cities around the world -- including New York's elder sister London -- for decades. The only surprising thing was that New York was spared for so long. Put it this way: if economics could be globalized, why not political violence? The two are in fact connected. Year after year it becomes easier for small bands of fanatics to perpetrate mass destruction because the means of destruction get cheaper and more readily available. The last time I checked, a used AK-47 assault rifle could be purchased in the United States for $700 and a new one for $1,395, almost exactly the price of the portable computer on which this article was written. 
In the same way, the real cost of a nuclear warhead -- and certainly the real cost of a kiloton of nuclear yield -- is lower today than at any time since the Manhattan Project achieved its goal. That cost two billion 1945 dollars. Converted into 2001 prices, that figure rises roughly tenfold, which is enough to buy more than 400 Trident II missiles. (Let's face it: if nukes were expensive, Pakistan wouldn't have them.) It seems reasonable to assume that the same process has reduced the cost of biological weapons like refined anthrax.
The bad news is that no amount of warfare against the states that harbor terrorists will rule out further attacks. The Western European experience of combating leftist and nationalist terrorism shows that the real war against terrorism has to be fought on the home front by domestic intelligence agencies, police forces and humdrum security guards around all potential targets.
So, welcome to the world of the daily security check, the fortnightly bomb scare and the annual explosion. Ten years from now, New York firefighters and Washington postal workers will feel the same weary resignation that Londoners developed during the I.R.A.'s bombing campaign.
The second trend that Sept. 11 did nothing to change is the economic downturn. The asset bubble of the late 1990's peaked a year and a half before the terrorists struck. And despite their proximity to Wall Street, the real crashes of Sept. 11 did not cause a metaphorical crash on the stock market -- just its temporary closure. 
Admittedly, in the immediate aftermath of the attacks, investors had to grit their teeth as prices threatened to go into free fall. Yet so far, the deflation of the late 1990's asset price bubble has been a gentle affair compared with the cataclysmic meltdown that followed the bubble of the 1920's. To give some orders of magnitude, a crash on the 1929-32 scale would take the Dow down from over 11,723 -- where it stood at its peak in January last year -- to about 1,266 by November next year. On Nov. 15, it stood at 9,872, less than 3 percent down from Sept. 10. When Alan Greenspan coined the phrase "irrational exuberance," the index was 6,473. In this light, the most striking thing about the economic consequences of Sept. 11 would seem to be their insignificance. A 3 percent drop in the Dow is nothing. Oil prices, too, have continued their yearlong decline. And there has been virtually no movement in long-term interest rates, which might have been expected at a time of increased political risk.
Nevertheless, the world economy has two serious economic weaknesses -- also predating Sept. 11 -- that cannot be ignored.
The first is the nonglobal nature of globalization. Far from being perfectly integrated, the world's markets for goods, capital and labor appear to have become remarkably segmented. Thus, the overwhelming bulk of American, Canadian and Mexican trade now takes place within the North American Free Trade Area, just as most European trade takes place within Europe. Back in 1913, international capital was truly international: about 63 percent of foreign direct investment in 1913 went to developing countries. But in 1996, the proportion was just 28 percent. Labor mobility is also distorted, with the United States able to cherry-pick the best-qualified and most-talented workers from European and Asian economies under its various visa programs while letting in many more unskilled (and untaxed) Latino workers through the Mexican back door.
This is one key reason that the process we call globalization has tended to result in widening inequality between nations. In the 1960's, the richest fifth of the world's population had a total income 30 times as great as the poorest fifth's; in 1998, the ratio was 74:1. In 1965, real gross domestic product per capita in Chad was one-fifteenth of the U.S.'s ; in 1990, one-fiftieth. If there was a substantial measure of convergence of incomes during the first age of globalization, in this age there is a pronounced divergence. And such inequality seems likely to increase the resentment felt in poorer countries toward the super-rich United States. (That said, we should not make the mistake of assuming that this poverty is the principal cause of support for organizations like Al Qaeda, most of whose recruits come from relatively prosperous backgrounds.)
Even more worrying is the medium-term outlook for global energy supplies. The rise of the S.U.V. as a status symbol shows how complacent Americans are about their supply of oil and petroleum. They should not be. True, oil prices are low right now: a barrel of West Texas crude sells for about $20, less than half the price (in real terms) as at the peak of the oil crisis in 1982. But what made prices go through the roof in the 1970's and early 1980's was political instability in the Middle East: the anti-Israel Arab oil embargo, the Iranian revolution and the Iran-Iraq war. It's no great stretch to imagine something similar happening again. (Even the demand-side shock of the recent U.S. boom trebled the oil price between December 1998 and October 2000's $33 peak.)
The realities are stark. The Middle East accounts for 31 percent of world oil production but just 6 percent of consumption. North America accounts for about 18 percent of world oil production but consumes 30 percent. Even more sobering, however, are the figures for world oil reserves: North America has just 6 percent of them; the Middle East 65 percent.
Feeling comfortable? Total U.S. energy consumption -- of which petroleum accounts for about two-fifths -- has risen about 27 percent since 1972, while oil reserves have fallen by about 30 percent. Right now, the United States depends on the Persian Gulf -- mainly Saudi Arabia -- for about 12 percent of its oil imports, but that figure is bound to rise as OPEC countries account for an ever-increasing share of the world's available oil.
The time frame may be much tighter than S.U.V. manufacturers realize. Kenneth S. Deffeyes of Princeton University predicts that global oil production will start to decline from 2004. At a conference at the Royal United Services Institute in London in October, experts warned that from 2008 supplies of non-OPEC oil will fall steeply -- reaching close to zero in 2040 -- and that, barring some major technological breakthroughs, there will be an effective world shortage from 2010.
Yet even that estimate could prove to be overoptimistic if there is a regime change in Saudi Arabia. Like "the coming oil crisis," the fall of the Saudi monarchy has been prophesied so often that many people have stopped believing it could ever happen. Don't be so sure. The position of the ruling dynasty increasingly resembles that of the shah of Iran in the late 1970's. Low oil prices may have been good for the West, but they have produced a significant fall in per capita income in Saudi Arabia, creating a reserve army of disenchanted young men who are the natural recruits of Al Qaeda. 
Make no mistake: radical Islam -- especially the Wahhabist strain found in Saudi Arabia -- is a revolutionary movement that has set the Middle East ablaze before now (in the 1880's for example, when a Sudanese holy man calling himself the "Mahdi," or "expected guide," emerged as the Victorian Osama bin Laden). A revolution in Saudi Arabia would be as traumatic a blow to the world economy as the Iranian revolution of 1979. 
The days of the S.U.V. -- perhaps even the days of the internal-combustion engine -- are therefore numbered. American car manufacturers have less than a decade to come up with an alternative and affordable energy source to gasoline. If they fail, the world economy could well find itself reliving the stagflation of the 1970's.
There is a third trend that has been at work for more than a decade: the transition of American global power from informal to formal imperialism.
Since 1945, the United States has largely been content to exercise influence around the world indirectly: exercising economic leverage through multinational corporations and international agencies like the International Monetary Fund and political power through "friendly" indigenous regimes.
As Britain discovered in the 19th century, however, there are limits to what can be achieved by informal imperialism. Revolutions can overthrow the puppet rulers. New regimes can default on their debts, disrupt trade, go to war with their neighbors -- even sponsor terrorism.
Slowly and rather unreflectively, the United States has been responding to crises of this sort by intervening directly in the internal affairs of faraway countries. True, it has tended to do so behind a veil of multilateralism, acting in the name of the United Nations or NATO. But the precedents set in Bosnia and Kosovo are crucial. What happened in the 1990's was that those territories became a new kind of colony: international protectorates underwritten by U.S. military and monetary might.
Since the United States and Britain went to war against Afghanistan -- with the avowed intention of replacing the Taliban regime -- I have found myself quoting Rudyard Kipling on "the White Man's Burden," particularly those lines (written just over a century ago) that enjoined Americans to fight what he called "the savage wars of peace" while at the same time filling "full the mouth of Famine." (Kipling would certainly have grasped the rationale of simultaneously dropping cluster bombs and food parcels.) Of course, no one today would be so politically incorrect as to call governing Afghanistan "the White Man's Burden." Even in his messianic speech at the Labor Party conference in October, British Prime Minister Tony Blair talked innocuously about "partnership," "the politics of globalization" and "reordering this world." Yet the underlying message of that speech was pure Kipling. 
There are good reasons to wonder how readily Americans will assume the Victorian burden, of course. The strengths of the U.S. economy may not be the strengths of a natural imperial hegemon. The British Empire relied on an enormous export of capital and people, but since 1972 the American economy has been a net importer of capital (to the tune of 15 percent of G.D.P. last year), and the United States remains the favored destination of immigrants from around the world, not a producer of would-be colonial emigrants. Moreover, Britain in its heyday was able to draw on a culture of unabashed imperialism dating back to the Elizabethan period. The United States -- born in a war against the British Empire -- will always be a reluctant ruler of other peoples. 
But reluctance isn't the same as renunciation. And the obvious lesson the United States can draw from the British experience of formal empire is that the world's most successful economy can do a very great deal to impose its preferred values on less technologically advanced societies. It is nothing short of astonishing that Great Britain was able to govern about a quarter of the world's population and land surface -- and to control nearly all of its sea lanes -- without running up an especially large defense bill (an average of just 3 percent of net national product between 1870 and 1913, lower for the rest of the 19th century). And today the United States is vastly wealthier relative to the rest of the world than Britain ever was. In 1913, Britain's share of total world output was a shade over 8 percent; the equivalent figure for the United States in 1998 was just under 22 percent. Nor should anybody pretend that, at least in fiscal terms, the cost of expanding the American empire -- even if it meant a great many little wars like the one in Afghanistan -- would be prohibitive. Last year, American defense spending stood at just 2.9 percent of G.D.P., compared with an average for the years 1948-98 of 6.8 percent. 
I have not yet raised one trend, much commented on -- the supposedly inescapable "clash" between a democratic West and an intolerant Islam. From this viewpoint, Sept. 11 was a moment of revelation rather than redirection, as America belatedly woke up to a struggle the Muslim world has been fighting for years. I don't buy this. 
Primarily that's because the most striking features of modern Islam are its amazing heterogeneity and geographical dispersion. Violence between ethnic or religious groups is not dividing the world into great blocs. As we have already seen in the Balkans (where we were inclined to side with the Muslims, don't forget), the tendency is for existing political units to fragment. So any clash of civilizations will occur not on conventional battlefields but in the streets of multicultural states like Bosnia -- or even cities like Bradford in England, where gangs of Muslim youths rioted last summer.
Think of it as deglobalization: for one of the great paradoxes of our time is that the economic integration of the world has coincided with its political disintegration. Excluding sub-Saharan Africa, there were 64 independent countries in the world in 1871. Forty-three years later, on the eve of World War I, imperialism had reduced the number to 59. But since World War II, there have been sustained increases. In 1946, there were 74 independent countries; in 1950, 89. By 1995, the number was 192. 
In this context, the main significance of movements like Islamic fundamentalism may lie in their centrifugal as opposed to centripetal effects. Rather than anticipating a clash between monolithic civilizations, we should expect a continued process of political disintegration as religious and ethnic conflicts challenge the integrity of existing multicultural nation-states. Civil war has, after all, been the most frequent kind of war since 1945: something like two-thirds of all postwar conflicts have been within rather than between states. From Yugoslavia to Iraq to Afghanistan, what the United States keeps having to confront is not a united Islam but a succession of fractured polities, racked by internecine war. (The same could be said about Somalia, Sierra Leone and Rwanda.) 
Why has economic globalization coincided with political fragmentation in this contradictory fashion? One possible answer is that globalized market forces increase regional inequalities within traditional nation-states. Another is that the superficial homogenization of popular culture -- through Hollywood, the pop-music industry and the Anglicization of technical communication -- promotes an accentuation of parochial identities as a kind of a reaction. But the best answer may be that as more and more ethnically heterogeneous countries adopt (with American encouragement) the combination of economic openness and political democracy, their rationale simply falls away. Central government loses its legitimacy as the planner of the economy, and ethnic minorities vote for separatist parties.
These, then, are the four deep trends shaping the early 21st century. First, the globalization of terrorism. Second, the approach of a second energy crisis. Third, the formalization of American imperialism. And finally, the fragmentation of the multicultural polity.
What are the implications for the world of Sept. 11, 2011? With the caveat that this is only one of a number of possible futures, let me repeat my earlier predictions. Terrorism will be a part of everyday life. Meanwhile, American troops will be patrolling both Kabul and Kosovo. And the divisions between ethnic and religious groups in the United States -- indeed throughout the world -- will be even more pronounced. So much for the bad news. The good news? There will be fewer S.U.V.'s clogging up the streets.
Let me conclude with a fifth prediction. Most people will regard all of these things as direct consequences of the terrorist attacks 10 years before. Indeed, The New York Times Magazine will carry an article saying that Sept. 11, 2001, was one of the great turning points of modern history. 
Wrong. The unpalatable truth is that it would all have happened anyway.

HEADLINE: Luxury In Hard Times 

BYLINE:  By Lynn Hirschberg; Lynn Hirschberg, a contributing writer for the magazine, writes regularly on fashion topics.

 BODY:
The second week of September was Fashion Week in New York, and Tom Ford, the designer of Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent, was in town to meet with investors and to host a glitzy party for the newly redesigned YSL store on Madison Avenue. "I'm a Virgo," Ford told me a week later. "So I see all the problems." As usual, he was obsessive about the store's decor. He moved a white stool, he worried that the handrail would give shoppers splinters and he set little marks on the stereo volume so the music would provide the proper ambience. The New York store, Ford reasoned, would set the YSL tone for the label nationwide. 
 Ford, who is 40, splits his time between homes in Paris and London -- and spends the rest of his time in the luxury neighborhoods of other great cities. He was the first designer to envision the world as a global marketplace that could be linked by a sensibility -- his sensibility -- and he systematically and effectively made Gucci the first real high-end global fashion brand. In only six years, Gucci has gone from $263 million to $2.26 billion in revenue, and that growth can be directly traced to a spending-happy, luxury-loving world population that has been attracted to Ford's sexy jet-set, vaguely 70's idea of the Gucci universe. He has the unique gift of being able to design an easily identifiable, must-have item that is different, but not too different, that will conjure a transforming image for a wide range of customers, whether they live in Tokyo, Moscow or Miami. Gucci appeals to more than just the fashion intelligentsia -- it is mass luxury, selling to aspirants at every price point, from the housewife who buys a Gucci wallet to the starlet who wears the line head to toe. 
 Because of his highly developed business perspective, Ford is sometimes considered not to be a pure designer. This perception of him as more businessman than fashion innovator irks him. Still, it's Ford's philosophy that Gucci, and now YSL, are not meant to be works of art; they are designed with an eye toward a much larger landscape. Through clothes and advertising and the decor of a store, Ford, perhaps more than any other designer, is trying to both gauge and manipulate mood, to anticipate and also control the global zeitgeist.
Which is why, on Sept. 11, Ford, who first saw the terrorist attack on television in his suite at the Carlyle Hotel, was horrified and dismayed, but also, as a businessman, quick to act and put it in perspective. Stuck in his room, Ford immediately canceled the YSL store party, and his investor meeting was postponed. "I get daily sales figures," Ford said, "and on Sept. 12, there was a big drop in our business all over the world. Precipitous. But the swing in fashion didn't start with Sept. 11. The recession in luxury started last season, about six months ago. What happened on Sept. 11 was the period at the end of the sentence. On Sept. 11, the 90's ended."
Ford says this calmly, matter of factly, in a soothing voice that must be reassuring to investors, store managers and customers alike. From the early days of Gucci, Ford recognized the power of branding not only everything that is Gucci (the clothing line, the stores, the perfume) but also himself. His appearance has not changed in 10 years -- his skin is always the exact same shade of nut brown; his jeans always hang just so and his white shirt is always unbuttoned to below his sternum, the cuffs open and ever so slightly too long. Ford has excellent manners -- remembers names, asks after your mother. As a former commercial actor, Ford knows which angles of his face are most flattering, and he also knows that admitting that he knows which angles of his face are most flattering is appealing. Narcissism revealed seems fastidious and self-aware rather than vain. 
"I'm not a fool," Ford explains. "No one ever likes the way they look, but I understand the power of a face attached to something. Fashion has always been that way. Designers were always charismatic personalities you wanted to be a part of, and that is one thing that will not change with Sept. 11."
Even though Ford and Gucci Group had a growing awareness of the impending downturn in the world's economy, they had, in the last two years, embarked on a program of rapid expansion. In 1999, following a lengthy takeover battle with rival luxury titan LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Gucci Group was allied with Francois Pinault, one of the richest men in France. Fueled by a $3 billion influx of cash from Pinault, Gucci Group went on a spending spree. Yves Saint Laurent was its first purchase in 1999, followed by Bottega Veneta (leather goods), Boucheron (jewelry), Sergio Rossi (shoes) and part ownership of the design houses of Stella McCartney, Alexander McQueen and Balenciaga, which is run by Nicolas Ghesquiere.
"We're treating fashion like the old studio system in Hollywood," Ford explains. "We have different sorts of stars, and I can help build and develop them. The old studios in Hollywood created a world that you aspired to. And aspirational things are so important, especially now when the world is so grim. Every field is now about compromise, and I want to fight against that." Ford pauses. "Of course, right now might not have been exactly the right moment to fight that battle. But what can you do? Let's just hope we don't have another collapse of the studio system."
Traditionally, luxury items are hit hard in a recession, and in the weeks following the attack on the World Trade Center, no one in America wanted to buy much of anything, let alone a Gucci handbag. Even if a customer had the cash, shopping seemed frivolous when so many had lost their lives or their loved ones. Prada, another luxury brand, indefinitely put off its long-scheduled I.P.O. and suspended construction of a store in Hong Kong. Fear of flying brought tourism to a virtual halt, and luxury strongholds like Hawaii and Las Vegas were severely hit. Sales of perfume, which is the fuel of the fashion industry -- a scent costs pennies to produce and, unlike a handbag or a suit, is affordable and never goes out of style -- were drastically affected by the downturn in travel. Duty-free shops in international airports account for half of all perfume sales and, in the wake of Sept. 11, they canceled orders. Similarly panicked by the expected downturn in their business, department stores like Bergdorf Goodman also tore up their outstanding fall orders, leaving prominent designers like Comme des Garcons and Christian Lacroix with clothes en route to New York without a buyer in sight. Domenico De Sole, Gucci's chairman and chief executive, successfully fought their Neiman Marcus cancellations, insisting that the stores honor their commitments, but less powerful brands were turned away.
Financial analysts were unwilling to be doomsayers, but, privately, they voiced concerns that luxury brands, with their imprimatur of status, would be a hard sell in this new, suddenly austere climate. "But I am trying to remain optimistic," says an analyst at Merrill Lynch, who is unwilling to be named for fear of sounding pessimistic. "Because if I sound like doom and gloom, then it may be a self-fulfilling prophecy. If you say no one is shopping, then no one will shop. And I do think that if any brand will endure, it will be Gucci. They have created brand loyalty, and Tom Ford is a brilliant designer."
De Sole is trying to remain optimistic too. "The situation in the United States is difficult," he says, "but we are a global brand, and sales in Europe and Japan are stable. The only question is, what will happen if there are more attacks or further worldwide economic and political deterioration?" 
Remarkably, despite an overall downturn in domestic retail spending, YSL has sold like crazy, posting a 157 percent increase over the same period last year. Gucci was down significantly, but, then, they didn't have YSL's secret weapon, the shirt of the season: the YSL gypsy peasant blouse, with puffy sleeves in purple silk for $2,500. The shirt is a classic illustration of why Ford has been so successful. The blouse is festive and sexy and oddly familiar, since it is a reworked version of the rich hippie look that Yves Saint Laurent made popular in the 70's. On Sept. 11, the YSL store on Madison Avenue received more than 40 calls asking when it was opening and if the shirt would be available. 
"I'm very aware of the need to create a piece that will sell," explains Ford, displaying the businesslike manner that separates him from other designers. "I was happy when I realized that that shirt was fabulous and it looked good on almost everybody and it probably was going to be the right price. I have always believed that fashion has a purpose. It's created to be used, to be worn, to be sold."
After the Sept. 11 attacks, all the remaining shows of Fashion Week were canceled. American designers invited small groups of buyers and editors into their studios, and there was speculation that the shows in Milan and Paris would be similarly streamlined. "I didn't think of not having those shows," Ford said, a week after the attacks. "But it was hard to think about the show, because after Sept. 11, who cares? That was my mood in New York, but I felt very differently when I landed in London five days later. In Europe, they're upset, but they lived through World War II. They've had their share of horrific acts. And then I thought, This is not the moment to go into a dark, minimalist fog.
"I did, however, revamp the Gucci show. I had been working on girls coming down from poles and lap-dancing the audience. Obviously, I had to dilute that concept. And I had these little worker jackets, and if you looked at them the wrong way they could have been seen as Afghan jackets, but we put one on a girl that looked like the 60's model Verushka and called it the Verushka jacket, so that took the emphasis away from Afghanistan."
Ford pauses. "I've thought about this a lot," he continues, "and going dark is not the answer. Fashion is more than just clothes -- if you include the growing of crops to make fabric, the manufacturing and all the stores, it's the biggest business in the world. And luxury brands set the standard. More than ever, I think this is a time for beauty."
Even if this is a rationalization, it paints the right picture. Which is important. Christmas is on the way, traditionally the biggest shopping time of the year. If this holiday season is a disaster, Gucci will be hurt. Since Sept. 11, stores like Barneys New York and Bergdorf Goodman have been virtually deserted, and the marking down of merchandise began early, in the first weeks of November. While retail sales rallied in October, that was mostly good news for only the discount stores like Wal-Mart. LVMH sales dropped 5 percent in October. 
On Sept. 16, Domenico De Sole flew to Italy, where Gucci has its headquarters, to address the factory workers outside Florence. "I bring everyone to the cafeteria," explains De Sole, over breakfast at the Ritz Hotel in Paris in mid-October. "I do this every quarter to explain our company's financial results. These workers have been with Gucci forever -- 30 years or more -- and they remember when the company was broke in 1994. But even then they were not as worried as they are now."
De Sole is calm, direct, seemingly unflappable. This morning, he is, as always, elegantly dressed in a dark blue suit, and he has the eagle-eyed manner of an interested host who has both the guest at the door and the meal in the oven on his mind. Throughout his career, De Sole has been consistently underestimated, and this misperception has served him well. When, in 1999, Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH, whose empire includes Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior and Givenchy, thought it would be simple to capture Gucci by buying up it stock (which is publicly traded), De Sole surprised him by allying with Francois Pinault, whose assets include Christie's auction house, Converse sneakers and Samsonite luggage.
The LVMH-Gucci power struggle was particularly nasty, even by fashion-world standards. "The fight went on and on and on," Ford says. "It was very distracting. But the LVMH battle reaffirmed how important the company was to me and Domenico."
On Sept. 10, after two years of steady fighting, Gucci Group and LVMH reached a final agreement at a court in the Netherlands. It was an arranged stock deal, with Pinault's company, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, paying $94 a share for 40 percent of LVMH's stake in Gucci. LVMH made more than $200 million on the transaction; De Sole protected his minority shareholders, many of whom are factory workers who have been given options over the years, and he flew to America for the YSL store opening, relieved that the deal was finally signed.
"I went, 'Ahhh, it's done,' " De Sole recalls, taking a bite of pink grapefruit. "Things will be easy now." He sighs. "But nothing with this company is ever easy." 
Founded in 1921, Gucci has withstood internecine battles among family members, the 1995 murder of Maurizio Gucci arranged by his ex-wife, the megalicensing of the name and cheapening of the brand to raise money (remember Gucci toilet paper?) and the sale of the company to Investcorp, an international investment bank. De Sole, who was born in Italy and received his law degree at Harvard, had been Maurizio Gucci's lawyer, and in 1995, Investcorp named him C.E.O., assigning him the seemingly insurmountable job of fattening up Gucci so they could sell it. 
"That is when Tom" -- Ford was a junior designer at Gucci at the time -- and I forged our bond," De Sole explains. "Maurizio wanted me to fire Tom. Instead, I gave him Gucci to design. I saw that Tom, like me, is a maniac. We're totally determined. But, I must admit, on Sept. 10, when the LVMH deal was finished, I thought, I'm going to have so much time on my hands because the war is over. And then, it's Sept. 11, and a new war begins." He pauses. "But what are you going to do about it? Cry? That doesn't work. That's not my job. I'm responsible for 10,000 people, and I can't be crying."
Following the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, a rumor began circulating in financial circles that the deal between LVMH, P.P.R. and Gucci was not going to go through as scheduled. During the week of Sept. 17, while the world was in a state of shock and mourning, money managers, counting on disasters, were shorting Gucci stock. They assumed that Sept. 11 would invalidate the LVMH agreement. By Sept. 20, the Gucci stock price had fallen from $82 to $62, the lowest it has been in five years.
On Sept. 25, when Gucci Group released its second-quarter financial results, there was more bad news: the yearly revenue projections, because of the events of Sept. 11, were lowered from $2.45 billion to less than $2.4 billion. But even with the adjustment, there were analysts who thought Gucci's projections were just best guesses, and perhaps a bit rosy. "No one knows what's going to happen next in the world," Paola Durante of Merrill Lynch told Women's Wear Daily. "This is a difficult situation for all luxury-goods companies that rely on tourists for at least some of their income."
On Sept. 26, The Financial Times hinted that the LVMH-P.P.R.-Gucci agreement would not be enforceable, and De Sole erupted. "It's very simple," he told the paper. "If those guys don't pay, I'll cut their expletive off and sue the hell out of them for specific performance." By the end of the week, with the deal signed, Gucci's stock price rebounded to $85, where it has pretty much stayed.
The fashion business is particularly ill equipped to adjust to abrupt shifts in the cultural mood. A collection is designed nearly eight months before it hits the stores. Although Ford studies sales patterns and is highly aware of shopping trends, no one could have anticipated something as cataclysmic as Sept. 11.
"The last months have been very difficult," De Sole told me. "But you must have a long-term view. I believe there will also be opportunities now. The price of real estate is going down. A lot of brands are not going to be advertising, and each page in a magazine will now become more visible." He pauses and takes a sip of coffee. "My view is that, in the end, people don't change. They still want beautiful things. They may buy less, but, long-term, consumers will consume."
It's a Thursday afternoon in late September, and Tom Ford is doing the final edit on the coming spring Gucci show, which will be held in Milan in 10 days. He is in his office in London, which is decorated in 70's-style minimalist boy tech -- brown leather sofa, a dark brown fur carpet, a white desk with a white chair and silver bits accessorizing here and there. It is the prototype for a half-dozen other Tom Ford offices scattered around the globe. It is also remarkably similar to the decor of the Gucci stores and Ford's own homes. They even smell the same. Figuier, a Diptyque candle that fills the room with the aroma of figs, follows Ford around the planet.
This studied, controlled universality is emblematic of Ford's design and business philosophy. "Tom has a global vision," says Carine Roitfeld, the editor of French Vogue and a stylist for Gucci from1995 until last year. "Tom is artistic, but he has such a strong business side, and that is very rare. For most designers, it's the cut of a jacket. With Tom, it's the cut of the jacket and all the accouterments. He thinks about the car the woman drives, the kind of place she likes to live, how she likes to have sex. Tom considers all these things when he thinks about Gucci or YSL or any of the new companies he has acquired." 
Ford and Gucci Group have been canny in their acquisitions, especially with the designers, who are all promotable personalities, with strong identities and talent. Stella McCartney has, perhaps, one of the 10 most famous fathers in the world and knows how to design skinny pants and pearl-encrusted bustiers for the Gwyneth Paltrow set. Alexander McQueen combines a gift for flamboyant presentation, expert tailoring and a skinhead bad-boy reputation that has made him notorious in his native London. And Nicolas Ghesquiere is the most gifted new designer to emerge in years. His ability to reawaken Balenciaga, a great but moribund fashion house, is reminiscent of Ford's success at Gucci. Ghesquiere has everything: beauty, commercial sense and an ability to create clothes that are unexpected and, yet, absolutely of this moment.
Just as Ford prides himself on having high-end mass taste, being able to pick the shoe or purse that will be a best seller, he is careful in Gucci Group's investment choices. The designers have to be stars or, at least, have star potential. While Gucci Group quietly gave money to Hussein Chalayan, a reclusive fashion designer whose brilliant shows are really performance-art events, Ford ultimately decided that he did not want to take on a designer who creates tables that turn into dresses. Ford may think Chalayan is a thrilling conceptualist, but he is also aware of his unmarketability -- he refuses to be photographed, for one thing -- and chose not to bankroll his company. 
Ghesquiere is that rare breed of designer who is able to create the handbag every fashion insider craves (last fall's slouchy leather satchel with lariats and buckles) and win every award, while never appearing in a gossip column. Meanwhile, McCartney designed Madonna's wedding dress last year and the whole world got the news.
"At some point," Ford explains, "we had to have more than one brand. It's the natural evolution of this company. The process was accelerated when LVMH tried to buy us, but at a certain point, the Gucci brand will reach its maximum growth potential."
Even though they sensed a change in shopping habits pre-World Trade Center, Ford and De Sole have consistently believed that big, bigger, biggest is the only strategy for Gucci Group. "Big is better because you can save enormous costs," Ford maintains. "Globalization may be a dirty word right now, but it is inevitable. You can't hold back a gigantic movement. And big is better because you have synergies that can work. Alexander McQueen can have a beautiful new store in Milan that he could not have had on his own. Nicolas Ghesquiere can now manufacture the shoes he couldn't get produced last season. Stella McCartney will have a perfume in the stores much faster than she would have before. At Gucci Group, we can almost control production because we give the factories so much business that they will work for us first. Department stores will give us more floor space, and we can buy advertising in bulk. The bigger you are, the more power you can wield." Ford pauses. "Unless," he continues, "everyone stops shopping." 
Historically, war has been good for fashion. During World War II, embargoes on foreign goods and travel created the American designer fashion business. Before that, Americans just knocked off European designs, but beginning in 1942, designers like Pauline Trigere, Norman Norell and Claire McCardell rose to prominence in New York. Until then (and, frankly, after then), high style was seen as the province of the French, with a few Italians mixed in for variety. Many believed that World War II officially ended when Christian Dior showed his "New Look" dresses in Paris in 1947. His opulent, full skirts took yards and yards of fabric and were considered a return to the luxuries that had been rationed during the war.
During the 60's, while she should have worn American, Jackie Kennedy dreamed of dressing like Audrey Hepburn, who wore Hubert de Givenchy. When she was scolded for buying foreign, she had her dressmakers copy the lines of his gowns. The Vietnam conflict had no effect on consumerism in America, and in the 70's, Yves Saint Laurent became the designer to wear, or to copy. It wasn't until the 80's, when Ralph Lauren created his haute-WASP universe and Calvin Klein emblazoned his name on underwear, that American designers became as famous in their own country as their foreign counterparts. Their names, however, did not export well -- despite their huge domestic success, Lauren and Klein have never had global success. Their sensibility did not translate overseas.
"The truth is, Americans are afraid of style," Ford says. "We are descended from Puritans, and it is still in our culture. You can put an American woman and a French woman in the same clothes, and the French woman will just look different. The French woman's hair will, perhaps, not be as clean. She'll tie her scarf in a different way. She'll stand differently. But she'll look chic. The American woman will be too clean. That's the Puritanical strain. And too clean is not sexy."
This is, perhaps, why Ford has been so successful. He has married two worlds, grafting a Euro sensibility on a solid American base. He's then taken that image and sent it out globally. With Gucci and, now, with YSL, it is a subtle meshing of worlds that sells Ford's brands. In Japan, they buy Gucci because it seems American. In America, they buy Gucci because it seems exotic, but not too exotic. In his advertising, Ford knows how to sell sex that is provocative enough to seem European and yet polished enough to appeal to Americans. "That was the whole idea behind a global vision," explains Ford. "But now, and even before Sept. 11, the positive spin is off globalization. I still feel it is inevitable. I'm not saying I like globalization or I don't like globalization, but I think the generation under me -- people in their 20's -- know nothing else. To them, the world is the Net. They are exposed to exactly the same things at the same time, and that creates a new culture in which, all over the world, people want the same things in their lives at the same time. At Gucci, we capitalized on that."
Ford pauses. "I think, perhaps, we now need to reinterpret globalization. It can also mean that everyone wants to look different at exactly the same moment. Now, I'm exploring how we could come out with limited-edition stores and merchandise. For instance, our handbags at Gucci have increased 22 percent this year, but we don't have an icon handbag, one handbag that is our signature. We have 10 top-selling bags and then we have 20 right below it that also sell strongly. What this tells us is that the Gucci customer doesn't want the same bag as her friend. So if the company can figure out how to personalize everything, that may be the key to our business in the future."
This is a smart strategy, smarter still for the fact that Ford said, more or less, the same thing before the World Trade Center collapsed. Now that he has created this jet-set world, he's going to turn down the volume and let the Gucci customer define herself a little. It will still be Gucci, but it won't scream Gucci. This is how a brand evolves: it starts out loud and then gets quieter. Of course, Ford can always make it loud again.
The problem is that a limited-edition handbag is still an unnecessary purchase, and, post-Sept. 11, the luxury customer in America may be afraid to buy anything that seems decadent, even if it is personalized decadence. Ford is aware that terrorist activity can be viewed as an outgrowth of globalization, a wish to rid the world of materialistic Western impulses and imagery. "I don't want to sound callous," Ford says, "but if you don't want to let the terrorists defeat us, have that extra piece of cake and third drink." Ford smiles. "All of us feel a sense of transformation, but into what, I'm not sure. Would you buy a big car right now? I doubt it. But it's hard to judge how far and how long this mood will linger. People want to be soothed. And when words fail, I think beauty can fill the void. Anything with edge feels wrong right now, but I doubt that will last. The fashion world thrives on irony and bitchiness and meanness. This attack is making people sincere. I'm not sure that will be good for fashion." Ford laughs, but he is not really joking.
Tom Ford, as he will tell you again and again, is a Virgo. He defines himself through his astrological sign, beginning sentences with "As a Virgo . . . " or ending them with: "What can I say? I'm a Virgo." Virgos are, according to Ford, determined, organized, compulsive, creative and unable to sleep. Ford, like many in the fashion world, assumes that everyone is consistent with their signs of the zodiac. "We're both Virgos," Stella McCartney says of Ford. "As long as we don't work with each other, it's fine." Carine Roitfeld says: "Oh, yes. Tom and I are both Virgos. That can be very good, or very bad."
Ford says: "As a Virgo, I am focused, but I always have an exit plan. In a hotel room. Here. Everywhere. That's why I don't sleep." It's mid-July, before the world went crazy, and Ford is standing in an upstairs studio on the Rue Boissiere in Paris, surrounded by 20 nearly naked male and female dancers. It is a moment from the recent past, the pre-Sept. 11 universe of lavish perfume launch parties and galas celebrating a designer's celebrity friends who are, of course, photographed in the designer's clothes. Pre-Sept. 11, the fashion world thrived on this sort of publicity -- it fed the jet-set image of the brand.
Scents are particularly important to the success of a house and, pre-Sept. 11 -- he wouldn't do this now -- Ford needed a way to promote YSL's new perfume, called Nu, which means nude in French, so he decided to stage a kind of stylized orgy as the centerpiece of the YSL perfume launch party. The ad for Nu is a tangle of male and female body parts and, as always, Ford is thematic in his approach. Right now, he's trying to decide whether the dancers should wear underwear of some sort to cover their genitals when they writhe around on top of one another. "Body grooming will be done," says Kevin Krier, who is coordinating the production. Ford nods. "People look best naked," he says, tilting his head and staring hard at the dancers. "But if some of the guys get excited. . . . "
It is decided that YSL will provide specially designed flesh-colored thongs, even though Ford really wants the dancers to be completely bare in the spirit of his scent. He looks exhausted, but this launch is important. YSL has a worldwide sales goal for Nu of 100 million, and the scent could introduce YSL to a mass audience. Ford is wearing his usual uniform of jeans and a half-unbuttoned white shirt, but he looks as if he'd like to take a nap, if he could only fall asleep. It has been a particularly hectic week. Last Sunday, he showed his YSL men's collection. Before Gucci Group purchased YSL, the men's division was overseen by Hedi Slimane, a gifted designer who became known for his narrow-cut suits. After only two seasons, Slimane was heralded as the first important new men's-wear designer, and his suits, which were too skinny and stylized for most men (although the ever-fashion-forward Brad Pitt was married in a custom Slimane suit), often sold to chic women, like the fashion bellwether Madonna.
When Gucci Group bought YSL for $1 billion, there was an outcry in Paris. "The French love Mr. Saint Laurent," says Roitfeld, the editor of French Vogue. "And the French were, and continue to be, very mean to Tom. Saint Laurent is a part of French history. Even now, when his collection is not as good, he's a symbol for the whole country. As an American -- it was very risky for Tom to take over Saint Laurent."
Slimane did not want to work under Ford and accepted a deal from LVMH to design the Christian Dior men's collection. Pierre Berge, Yves Saint Laurent's longtime partner, decided to embrace Slimane and LVMH as a way of announcing his anti-Gucci Group stance. "They were awful to Tom," McCartney says. "Paris is the city of fashion. They take their fashion very seriously, and the Parisians hate this Gucci power mogul for ousting their king."
In a rare public appearance, Saint Laurent -- the master himself -- showed up at Slimane's first show last year. Saint Laurent embraced Slimane after the show, as if they were old friends. "I think that was the first moment they met," Ford sniffs. 
But it worked for LVMH and Berge: the kiss made every newspaper, and Ford was seen as the avatar of anticultural globalism out to destroy nothing less than a master of French couture.
Ford was upset by the blah reviews of his men's wear for spring -- and the raves for Slimane. "You put your personality out there and then they slam it," he says now, still studying the dancers as they intertwine to some slow electronic music. "I don't wear my heart on my sleeve, and people feel that I don't agonize, that I make it look easy. But making things look easy is one of the hardest things in the whole world." Ford pauses, noticing that one dancer does not seem to be moving with the rest. "I don't believe in being one of the those people who, when you ask them how they are, says, 'Terrible,' " Ford continues. "You should always say, 'I'm great.' But, then, I'm a Virgo. And I have so much to do. I can't let these things impact me for more than a day."
Monday, the day after his show, Ford flew to Florence to edit the early spring collection for Gucci. On Tuesday evening, he left for London, where he had design meetings for two days. He came back to Paris for a series of YSL meetings, specifically focusing on Nu and the cosmetics line. "The first thing I did when I arrived at Yves Saint Laurent in May of 2000 was the Opium ad," Ford explains. "I wanted to reintroduce that perfume and immediately set the idea for my YSL woman, even before I'd designed any clothes."
That first ad was classic Tom Ford: a voluptuous woman, very pale, lies naked, seemingly drunk on some heady combination of sex, alcohol and, of course, opium (the perfume, naturally). "The YSL woman is about excess," Ford says, as the dancers illustrate his point. "She eats too much, she drinks too much, she smokes, she has sex. She's lush. The Gucci woman -- you know what she wants, you know what she's after. The Saint Laurent woman -- she's going to torture you a little bit. You might have sex, but she will drip a little hot wax on you first. This," he continues, waving his hand at the dancers, "is a more decadent world. It's refined, but very rough."
And, if that strategy fails, there's always YSL blue, which is not exactly blue really, but a bluish shade of violet. Ford appears to be branding this label by color. Violet is the hue he favored in the last collection and the shade of the Nu perfume bottle. These dancers will be in a 30-foot glass container, and they will be bathed in blue light. The invitations for the party are the same shade, and the ads for YSL are predominantly filtered with blue tones. "I like the pinky, sexy flesh in the middle of all that cobalt," Ford says.
That is also the palette for the Nu ads, which would not be altered after Sept. 11. The ads are sexy, but not overtly decadent. They hint at an orgy, which, Ford believes, is always an attractive notion. "I think we should make the pillows blue," says Ford, as he prepares to leave the dance studio for another appointment. Kevin Krier makes a note. "Blue pillows," he repeats, "but is anyone really going to see anything other than gorgeous naked bodies?" Ford smiles. "People always take in more than you think," he says.
Three months later, after the world Trade Center disaster, Ford has not changed his view of the YSL woman. "There's a vocabulary for every brand," he says. "And the vocabulary for YSL -- sexy, mysterious, strong- still works after a terrorist attack." Ford even sounds confident about Nu reaching its projected financial goal. "That's going to be tough," he acknowledges. "I had a fragrance meeting yesterday, and there are real concerns with regards to the duty-free shops. Travel retailing has been greatly affected by Sept. 11, but we have to keep designing products. And, even more than before, the clothes or the bag or the scent has to be potent. A dull plain shirt doesn't mean anything right now. In an economy like this, people buy clothes like they're accessories. A jacket needs to do this and do that and be completely potent. If I'm in a design meeting and I'm bored, the customer's going to be bored. There's so much stuff in the world, I have to find a way to attract people." Ford laughs. "Now all I have to do is translate that mentality into key pieces. That's what I'm concentrating on for the YSL spring show next week. I'm a Virgo -- I'm happiest when I have a plan."
Richard Buckley, the editor of Vogue Hommes International and Ford's romantic partner for the past 15 years, says: "Tom has always been steady and determined. On our first date, when Tom was just a design assistant for Cathy Hardwick's" -- a midprice American sportswear company -- I asked him what he wanted to do. Tom said: 'Well, in 10 years, I'm going to be a millionaire, and I'll be showing in Paris because it's the center of global fashion. And I'll change the business like Ralph Lauren did, but not in the States.' I thought, Poor naive kid, but Tom accomplished all that, and more, in nine years."
When I bring this up with Ford, he says: "It sounds very cocky and egotistical, but, yes, absolutely, as a child, I knew I would be successful at whatever I did. Virgos are very focused. All my life, whatever is in front of me gets my undivided attention. And Virgos are very confident. That blind confidence propelled me as a child."
Growing up in Santa Fe, N.M., Ford was restless. His parents were partners in a real-estate-development business, but Ford was more ambitious than his father. "I remember when I graduated from high school, I was very depressed, and my father said: 'Who cares? You won't even remember this day,' " Ford says. "He is the opposite of me. As a child, I always wanted more. I wanted this, I wanted that. I was probably awful."
In 1979, when he was 17, Ford moved to New York to attend N.Y.U. and pursue an acting career. At one time, he had 12 national advertisements running simultaneously, but when the hairstylist on a Prell commercial told him that he would lose his hair, Ford quit acting. He switched to Parsons School of Design and studied interior design and fashion. In 1990, after jobs with Hardwick and Perry Ellis, he was hired by Dawn Mello, then the creative director of Gucci. "I knew he could do anything," Mello says. "Tom is just one of those people who grabs you."
The rest is the stuff of fashion history. From his second show in 1995, Ford turned Gucci into the brand of the decade. "I was skeptical," recalls Roitfeld, who was key to the Gucci look in advertising. "In 1994, Tom came to ask if I would work on his first campaign. I thought Gucci was a bit old for me. The loafers and all. But Tom was so beautiful, so charismatic, so sexy, that I thought, I must work with him."
The fashion-conscious agreed. Over the years, Ford has given the world velvet hip-huggers, fringed and beaded jeans, rhinestone encrusted jackets and any number of slinky gowns. He dressed Helen Hunt in Jackiesque pale blue satin when she won her Academy Award and befriended Hollywood wives like Rita Wilson (married to Tom Hanks) and celebrities by the dozen. They loved that he looked like a movie star and made them look like movie stars.
But by 1998, Ford wanted to dream a new dream. After 8 years at Gucci, he had played out his 10-year plan. "I had the life I wished for as a child," he says. "I had hit it. And then I thought: Is this really it? Should I quit?" He talked to Stella McCartney about taking over Gucci, but her unwillingness to design fur or leather goods made hiring her an impossibility. He thought about abandoning fashion altogether and directing a movie, which he views as "the ultimate design project."
"I started planning my exit," Ford recalls. "I'm a Virgo. I bought a house in L.A. I started spending more time there. I read scripts. But, then, LVMH happened, and we bought YSL, and the business got interesting again."
Ford pauses. "But I think you do have to be realistic about age," he continues. "We are all a product of our times, and there's a window for us to do certain things. Right now, I'm 40, which is the age of our customer. My generation is the world now. But our window is sliding, and you can't hang on when what you do is no longer valid. As a designer, it's a struggle, a constant struggle, to stay current. I grew up watching 'I Dream of Jeannie' and they didn't. Things that seem hollow and shallow to me seem normal to them. I can't do this forever. At some point, I'll be picking the shoe that only the people over 50 will pick."
Ford stops a second. "And there's Sept. 11. . . . " His voice trails off for a moment. "Actually, there's a little bit of challenge in that for me. It makes everything more difficult, and difficulties are exhausting, but they can force you to think harder." Ford laughs. "As if I needed another thing to keep me up at night."
It's 5 p.m. on Oct. 10, three days after the United States began bombing in Afghanistan, and a shrunken version of the international fashion world -- press, photographers and very few buyers -- are gathered on the steps of the Cite Internationale Universitaire de Paris waiting for the showing of the Yves Saint Laurent spring collection for 2002. Anna Wintour, the editor of American Vogue, has flown back to America, and only Barneys, Bloomingdale's and Henri Bendel have sent representatives to shop. The Japanese, an important market for YSL, are not traveling, and, in three days, the elaborate black custom-built YSL pavilion, which is the size of a small opera house, is being put on a boat and traveling to Tokyo. On Nov. 28, Ford will show the entire spring collection again, with the same models, the same makeup, music, the works, for the Japanese. "It's very, very important," says Mark Lee, president of YSL, who has just greeted Jonathan Newhouse, the head of Conde Nast International, in front of the YSL house. "Tom has to go to Japan and explain the position of the brand. That's critical for YSL. We have to secure that business."
Today, the mood among the remaining fashion flock is a mix of nervousness and somberness. Normally, the editors and writers are like high-school seniors -- cliquish and superior and deeply concerned with who is wearing what and what could they be thinking. And if this is high school, then the designers are the cute boys. The fashion flock angles to get an audience with Tom, Stella or Nicola (which is the insider nickname of Ghesquiere). They dress to dazzle the designers, who are the ruling bodies of this galaxy.
Today, in their post-Sept. 11 mood, the fashion press appears becalmed. With some startling and welcome exceptions (Isabella Blow, a fashion muse to a number of designers, in a sequined sheath, Hamish Bowles of Vogue in a lavender shirt), they seem to be dressed for a stylish funeral. Heels are sensible, makeup is pale and the talk is not of handbags but of which Parisian doctor is willing to write Cipro prescriptions.
Francois Pinault and his wife, who is carrying a large brown Hermes alligator Kelly bag (a small scandal since it is not a brand her husband owns) arrive and, like the rest of the audience, make their way through security. There have been X-ray machines and metal detectors at other shows, but YSL has only three armed, but stylishly dressed, men inspecting purses and asking for photo ID.
Backstage, past the racks of clothes and the girls having their hair blown straight, Ford, dressed in his usual jeans and shirt, is scrutinizing a model. She is wearing a sheer leopard-print blouse with a beautiful hand-laced leather skirt that sits low, on the top of her hipbone. The skirt is tan and has an artisany feel, as if a hippie craftsman sold it in his shop in San Francisco in 1975, except this particular hippie used a fine glove leather and had a refined sense of tailoring. "I think women want something that feels touched by human hands," Ford says. This will become his mantra for the spring "African" collection: "Clothing needs a sense of authenticity in this climate. It's my job as a designer to strip away the artifice and give women something that feels touched by human hands."
It's fashionspeak and, like all fashionspeak, it works for only those willing to believe. And yet, it is somehow comforting to hear Ford talk about style as if the world were not turning into a battlefield. "I'm really disappointed that Anna Wintour left Paris," Ford said, taking a short break in a small curtained-off, backstage area that, yes, looks exactly like a miniversion of one of his offices. "And the buyers should have come. The stores said they didn't want their people to get stranded. Well, then, we have to take the collection to New York. I guess it is O.K. for us to get stranded." 
Ford smiles tightly. "I should shut up," he says. He looks even more exhausted than usual. He returned from Milan 10 days ago. "I changed the Gucci collection," he says. "I took away some things that were inspired by New Mexico, that had naked girls taken from velvet paintings and from the sides of vans. And I changed the presentation. I lowered the runway and I put pink flowers in the lobby. I changed the music to Peter Frampton's remix of 'Baby, I Love Your Way,' which is one of my favorite songs ever. And I think it really worked."
Gucci received positive reviews, and Ford is already planning the new advertising campaign, which will not be as overtly sexual as this season's, which featured an out-all-night party girl with her hand in the crotch of her zippered pants. This spring's Gucci girl will be a strong warrior type. "A survivor," Ford explains. "I think that's right for now. Even for six months from now."
Stephano Pilati, Ford's chief YSL assistant, interrupts with a question about an animal-print caftan that will be shown tonight. They decide that it should be worn with a certain bag. "I love this collection," Ford says. "And it didn't change after Sept. 11." He takes a sip of water. "The point of a fashion show is to convince the world that your way is the only way," he says. "When the audience leaves that room, they should think that there is only one way to dress, only one way to look, and that's the way I want to be. Sept. 11 hasn't changed my mind about fashion. I am still egotistical. I still want to say, 'The world should look like this.' "
Ford laughs. His show is going to start in 20 minutes, and he has to work. "But I also know that timing is everything. You have to know the right moment. And, tonight, at this moment, it's a time for beauty. I think people who say fashion is trivial are wrong. I was reading somewhere that World War II was the end of frivolity, not the end of gaiety. Beauty has its own power. And I think this collection is so beautiful." Ford gets up to go. "I love this collection," he repeats, "and I hope I'm not wrong."
Outside, the audience is waiting, wrapped in YSL blue light beaming from above. The room has been sprayed with Nu, and De Sole is standing to get a better view of the collection, which he has not seen. The music begins -- I Put a Spell on You," sung by Bryan Ferry -- and a succession of leopard-print chiffons and hand-stitched leathers make their way down the runway. The show is what Ford does best, an amalgamation of different styles -- some vintage YSL (the animal prints), some counterculture 70's (the crisscross hand-stitching on leather) and some zeitgeist (a military feel which adds strength to the shapes). The show has strong individual pieces -- a leather skirt with metal rings going up the side and a brown saddlebag that loops across the body, gaucho style, seem instantly desirable. There is something very Tom Ford about mass-producing garments that are supposed to look handcrafted. It's a clever way to assuage the guilt of consumerism -- something hand-stitched feels earthy and wholesome, rather than slick and designy.
After the show, there is applause, and an enthusiastic line forms backstage to congratulate Ford, who has changed into a black YSL suit. When he spies De Sole, they hug and disappear into the inner mini office. "I thought it was amazing," De Sole exclaims, leaving to go to dinner. Ford has to stay. He has interviews to do, the message of human hands to get across. "Now," he repeats to the 10th television reporter, "more than ever, there is a need for beauty in the world. Later Ford says: "I hope they believe me. I think we should all cry for beauty. That may be the only way to get through this."
