HEADLINE: The Public's Stake in a Cultural Crossroads 

BYLINE:  By EVAN and FREDA EISENBERG; Evan Eisenberg is the author of the book "The Ecology of Eden." Freda Eisenberg is a principal of Sector Planning Ltd.

 BODY:
FOR a place whose stones are stained with the tomato traces of so many critics -- critics of architecture, urbanism, acoustics -- Lincoln Center has inspired a good deal of affection. Take this husband and wife (please): growing up in the suburbs, one of us made the pilgrimage with high school friends to receive the dual sacrament of high culture: Mozart on one side of Broadway, asparagus crepes on the other. One soft spring night years later, we had our first kiss by the Henry Moore reflecting pool. Our 5-year-old daughter has grown up at Lincoln Center, careering around the fountain by day (the white paving is dry land; the black, water -- don't fall in!), dancing to swing and merengue on the plaza by night and sleeping through third acts in many of its hallowed halls.
 Despite early opponents like Jane Jacobs, Lewis Mumford and Christopher Alexander, who inveighed against putting the city's cultural eggs in a single basket -- Alexander asking whether anyone would visit concert hall and opera house "gluttonously, in a single evening" -- Lincoln Center is indeed greater than the sum of its parts. Public space is the reason, more than six open urban acres: a largess emulated, in the last half-century, by arts centers all over the world. 
 Of the $1.2 billion budget of the redevelopment plan for Lincoln Center that will soon be made public, only 15 percent is devoted to public space. It is, however, a crucial 15 percent. For in one respect the critics are right: the center's public spaces are miserably flawed. To make them perform on the same level as the artists who tread its stages is one of the plan's stated goals.
A project of the utmost importance for the future of the Upper West Side, of New York City and, indeed, of the arts in America; a project with the potential to take a great place and make it a great good place, a welcoming place, a place without peer in all the cities of the world -- such a project should by now have generated tremendous public excitement.
It has not. Indeed, unless some production of "Aida" used a prop pinched from a pharaoh's tomb, one is hard put to explain the curse that seems to have fallen on Lincoln Center and its redevelopment project.
It all began well enough. Buoyed by the city's flush economy, Lincoln Center and its constituent organizations put together a list of their needs and wants, ranging from plumbing repairs to a new house for the New York City Opera.
Last summer, a constellation of designers and planners was assembled, among them the architect Frank Gehry and the landscape architect Laurie Olin. In charge was Rebecca Robertson, the celebrated stage mother of the New Times Square. The chairman of the project was Marshall Rose, a developer best known for his role in the transformation of Bryant Park in midtown. On Jan. 1, Lincoln Center itself acquired a new president in Gordon Davis, a real estate lawyer and former parks commissioner who had just found Jazz at Lincoln Center a ritzy new home with a Central Park view.
Three weeks later, things began to fall apart.
The Metropolitan Opera walked out. No sooner was it coaxed back on board than the project began leaking like a French man-of-war that had just run afoul of Jack Aubrey. News, or supposed news, was leaked of unseemly squabbles among the constituents, and of such unlikely notions as plowing up Damrosch Park for a new opera house and turning the main plaza into an enclosed suburban mall.
Though Lincoln Center could hardly be so self-absorbed as to count Sept. 11 as its own private misfortune, the blows that leveled the towers seemed to smash the center's hopes along with countless others. In rapid succession, both Mr. Davis and Mr. Rose resigned. The New York Times described a project board meeting that seemed to have ended an inch short of fisticuffs. Shortly afterward, the paper administered an editorial rap on the knuckles, advising the dysfunctional family to stop its bickering and content itself with such basic repairs as the present economy might permit. Not to be outdone, a writer in The Times Magazine suggested bulldozing the center and starting from scratch.
While the blame for some of these misfortunes might be laid at the door of a cave in Afghanistan, others had a local origin: the board's decision to shroud its work in secrecy. If we had been given even an inkling of the problems the planners hoped to solve -- not just of crumbling travertine, bad acoustics and backstage cramping but of intermittently splendid yet mostly sterile, wasted public space -- and of the marvelous transformations that a bit of inspired tweaking might achieve, there could have been a bubbling up of ideas, a ferment of debate.
Instead, there was a battle of leaks. Ignorant of what they might gain, New Yorkers could only fret about what they might lose.
The plan, or what is left of it, will soon be out in the open. Rushed into hard copy to meet the deadline for the first installment of a promised $240 million in city funds, the "Blueprint for the Future" has gaping holes. The big question of where to put a new home for the City Opera has been sidestepped, and the big idea of Mr. Gehry's undulating glass canopies -- not very mall-like after all -- has been scrapped. (Insiders charge both failures to the opposition of Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Met.) Whether Avery Fisher Hall will be razed or merely gutted; where the new dormitory for the Juilliard School will go: these and other questions remain open. But the inspired tweakings are there, a myriad of details that add up to a livelier home for the lively arts.
Some of Lincoln Center's faults -- the acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall and of the New York State Theater in its makeshift role of opera house -- are well known. Others, less often discussed, may be more critical: not to critics, maybe, but to real people, even if their awareness of them has never risen above the level of the solar plexus.
Built as a fortress closed on three sides, Lincoln Center is hard to approach even on the fourth. Crossing 13 lanes of traffic on Broadway and Columbus Avenue can feel like fording a moat. Once inside, the newcomer is quickly lost among blank walls of travertine. Only 4 of the center's 13 constituents are in the great fountain's near orbit; the rest are in outer darkness, somewhere beyond the meteorite belt. Of the living, creative community that Lincoln Center actually is -- a place where 10,000 people study and create music, theater and dance -- one finds as much evidence as one would find on the moon.
No one disputes the magic of the center's main plaza just before 8 p.m. The place is luminous, filled with the wonderfully paradoxical movements of people hurrying toward their leisure. But most of the time it is deserted -- though not as thoroughly as Damrosch Park, which without an event is a two-and-a-half-acre manicured wasteland. Even the North Plaza, with its Henry Moore reflecting pool, often feels serene to the point of desolation. Attempts to enliven it with programming must contend with the awkward distribution of seats among the grid of trees in planter boxes -- just as, in the main plaza, the central fountain forces off-kilter, jerry-built stages for Midsummer Night Swing and Lincoln Center Out of Doors. In all the center's open spaces, a pounding sun can drive away all but those desperate for free culture at any price.
Mindful of these problems and a litany of others, the planning team has proposed a package of concepts intended to wake Lincoln Center's public spaces from a 40-year sleep. The big proposals have been shot down. Mr. Gehry's floating canopy over the plaza -- "the dome," to its detractors -- didn't last the summer. But a "galleria" flanking the west sides of the State Theater and Avery Fisher Hall held out until just before the final vote. (The project board has refused to release illustrations of the canopies, partly because they were rejected and partly because their Gehryesque form was only one of many possible incarnations: the project is still in the planning phase, with design work yet to be done. It should be noted, too, that the plan leaves the idea of a covering open for further exploration.)
Practically, the galleria would have provided climate-moderated space for a cafe, a restaurant and special events. Conceptually, it would have emphasized Lincoln Center's north-south axis: the broad crayon stroke from 65th Street to Damrosch Park that connects the constituents' scattered dots.
Happily, the planning team has proposed other, subtler means of making that connection. To begin with, 65th Street will be converted from autobahn underpass to living, breathing thoroughfare. (We use the future tense because it is convenient and evocative, but bear in mind that it describes one possible world: the improbable one in which the plan is adopted, financed and executed just as it stands.)
The overbuilt, underused Milstein Bridge will give way to a slender footbridge; its stone buttressing will fall, opening the North Plaza to the sidewalk in a broad series of steps, which the plan intends as a major entrance, rivaling the one on Columbus Avenue. But instead of the pomp of the plaza, this entrance will offer the intimacy of a campus quad or village green, a place where Ms. Robertson imagines "a girl reading a book while doing a plie." Students from Juilliard and the School of American Ballet, stagehands, bassoonists on breaks from rehearsals, lounging playwrights and lunching accountants will mingle; picture Washington Square, but greener and less louche. At the east end will be a bistro doing business from lunch time to late evening.
One of 65th Street's five lanes will be shaved away, leaving room for on-street, marquis-topped entrances to the theaters and for rehearsal spaces annexed to the theaters and to Avery Fisher Hall. In a delightful conceit that seems inspired partly by Javanese shadow puppets and partly by the MTV studio overlooking Times Square, the outer walls of these rehearsal spaces will be translucent, giving passersby dreamlike, abstract glimpses of work in progress. (Similar spaces may be tacked on to the east side of the State Theater.)
Following the axis southward, one will come upon a transformed Damrosch Park, its open spaces grassy, its plantings rich and strange. Two new entrances will open the park to Amsterdam Avenue. The old bandshell will have washed away, its place taken by a pacific grove of trees that will muffle outdoor music before it reaches touchy neighbors. As needed, a temporary bandshell will appear alongside the State Theater. (At least one of the plans for a new opera house in the park would have produced a similar outcome; by closing 62nd Street, it would actually have increased the usable area of the park by 2,300 square feet.)
The approach from Broadway will be transformed, too. Snagging visitors from the north, an aggrandized lobby for Alice Tully Hall will house a performing-arts bookstore to rival the nearby Tower Records and Barnes & Noble. Pedestrians approaching from the south will instead be drawn to a visitors' center sprouting from the east wall of the State Theater, its underground reaches housing two multifunction rooms and possibly a 300-seat theater.
In between, the grand approach to the main plaza will be made grander by dropping the service lane to street level, so that visitors may step dogelike into the majesty of the plaza without having to dodge taxis. Though the constituents felt that this majesty would be tainted by cafes or retail, caprice will have its place: a spiral staircase -- possibly a musical one, each step triggering a note or theme -- will lead down to the subway. Another at the far end of the plaza will descend to the parking-level concourse, which will somehow be made elegant and unbunkerlike.
To tame the tangle of traffic at the junction of Broadway and Columbus, two plans are being explored. One would pare away some asphalt and shorten the crossing by 40 feet. A second, more radical plan would extend the one-way segment of Broadway from 59th Street to 66th Street, creating an 80-foot-wide pedestrian promenade. Such a green strip would link Lincoln Center to Central Park -- the city's center of culture to its center of nature -- as the Lincoln Center Mall (an east-west greenway from the park to the center, proposed and disposed of in the 1950's) would have done, but in a way far more natural to New York. It would also link Lincoln Center to itself: that is, to the new home of Jazz at Lincoln Center in the AOL Time Warner complex now rising in Columbus Circle.
We have merely sketched some highlights of the "blueprint," a big, complex plan that deals with many things besides public space. As noted, the plan has some holes in it. Inevitably, it has some flaws as well.
Though its westward thrust is laudable, it doesn't thrust hard enough. The western wall of the acropolis remains blank and uninviting. Nothing has been proposed to enliven or increase foot traffic on 62nd Street, and even 65th Street's remaking relies on elements that are unlikely to be effective around the clock and throughout the year.
What is necessary, in our view, is to seed this institutional Sonora with retail and food services. To hazard an offhand example: a two-tiered cafe appended to the main Juilliard building could bring people into 65th Street at nearly all hours, offer a convenient mingling place for students and their future public, and make the pueblo cliff-face entrances to Juilliard and the Walter Reade Theater less forbidding. And this is a place where one of Mr. Gehry's dreaded curlicues (those not-yet-designs that sprout like fiddleheads all over the planning models) would be a form well suited to the function at hand.
IF Damrosch Park is now perceived as unsafe, putting deep dark woods at the Amsterdam Avenue end may only make matters worse. By contrast, a cafe opening onto Damrosch Park and Amsterdam would enliven both -- and would make more sense than the planned cafe at the east end of the park, which would get in the way of outdoor performances.
In case one feels that cafes are for young lovers, the westward edge of the park might also harbor a playground, something the neighborhood badly needs. Picture a place where children from Amsterdam Houses could roughhouse with polichinelles from the School of American Ballet, preteenagers needing to let off steam after a Young People's Concert and toddlers waiting for their siblings to emerge in a cloud of rosin dust from lessons at the Lucy Moses School. And why not make it a musical playground -- an aural wonderland where swings, seesaws and all manner of other contraptions are rigged to produce astonishing sounds -- at moderate volume, of course?
On the Broadway side, the planners might give some thought to controlling high-rise development. Like traffic flow, this is a municipal matter, but one on which Lincoln Center's prestige, financial clout and creativity could have a big impact. When Glenwood Properties' 29-story tower goes up at 1926 Broadway -- the site of the Saloon -- the last patch of sky visible as one looks east from the plaza will have vanished. Arguably, the present building should have been given landmark status; failing that, a determined effort by Lincoln Center and the city might have found a role for the center in the new building -- and curtailed its height. But the center's leaders seem hobbled by ambivalence. On one hand, they feel that the sky opposite the plaza has already been torn to shreds by existing towers. On the other hand, they are proud of the 50 high-rises that have gone up in the area since Lincoln Center's inception: as Mr. Davis, the former president, put it, "These buildings are our success."
The plan before us, though incomplete, is a fine one, worthy of lively debate and further inspired tweaking, which ought to ensue as city agencies and community groups get their licks in.
Far from being rendered trivial by the events of Sept. 11, the project is now more urgent than ever. It should be cheered and urged onward by everyone who cares about the future of the West Side, of New York City and of the arts in America, and who shares the ideals of freedom and diversity that everyone has been yammering about for the last three months.
In the architects' models in Ms. Robertson's office, the main plaza's current fountain is replaced by a golden egg. "Is this a joke?" she asked Mr. Gehry. His answer is unrecorded; but Lincoln Center is indeed a goose that lays golden eggs, valued at more than $1 billion a year, for New York's economy. In recent years, many of the world's major performing-arts centers have been renovated and updated. If Lincoln Center falls behind in its technical, artistic and social capacities -- if the goose is allowed to languish -- the present economic slump could become a helpless downward spiral. Conversely, a Lincoln Center that becomes, in Peter Martins's words, "one of the wonders of the world" -- a place whose energy attracts Danish tourists, strolling teenagers, black-clad downtowners and children from Amsterdam Houses -- will help ensure the vitality of New York for decades to come.
The prospects are not as bleak as one might think. Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor-elect, is a member of Lincoln Center's board (recruited by his friend Beverly Sills, the chairwoman of the board, whose strength of will, worthy of a Donizetti queen, will no doubt color the coming drama). Mr. Davis is a member of the mayoral transition team, and his predecessor as the center's president, Nathan Leventhal, is its chairman.
In any case, so important are the open-space elements of the plan for developing new audiences, and for winning the hearts and minds of the community, that they should, in our view, be given precedence over everything but the most critical repairs.
In an age when city life is under attack from every quarter -- and now murderously, without quarter -- both the lively arts and lively public spaces are more precious and more necessary than ever. Let Lincoln Center be a place where people come to enjoy the pageant of their differences, as if this itself were art -- which, of course, it is.

City Opera Could Look Beyond Lincoln Center
SPAULDING: Tell me, Mr. Chandler, where are you planning on putting your new opera house?
CHANDLER: Oh, I thought I should like to put it somewhere near Central Park.
SPAULDING: I see. Why don't you put it right in Central Park?
CHANDLER: Could we do that?
SPAULDING: Sure, do it at night when no one is looking. Why don't you put it in the reservoir and get the whole thing over with? Of course, that might interfere with the water supply. But after all we must remember that art is art. Still, on the other hand, water is water, isn't it, and east is east and west is west, and if you take cranberries and stew them like applesauce, they taste much more like prunes than rhubarb does. Now, uh -- now you tell me what you know.
From the Marx Brothers
film "Animal Crackers"
In the chess game of urban revitalization, cultural institutions are high-value pieces. Sometimes there is strength in massing: on the Upper West Side, the phalanx of Lincoln Center has done good service. But the time may be ripe for a broader deployment.
Already, Jazz at Lincoln Center turns out to be a bishop, zipping down Broadway to Columbus Circle. The New York City Opera could be next to make a bold move.
Imagine: In the corner of Central Park abutting Columbus Circle, a glimmer of glass amid the foliage. An opera house married to nature, rife with greenery inside and out.
Impinge on Central Park? Well, the Metropolitan Museum did it, and no one is complaining. A new house for the City Opera is as worthy a cause and would need far less acreage. Indeed, offices for the City Opera, as well as storage and rehearsal space, could be found in 2 Columbus Circle, a building now vacant that the city has no idea what to do with.
Maybe this notion belongs only in a Marx Brothers farce. But Central Park is not the only park in town. Would a new opera house in Damrosch Park be less threatening to the Met if it were almost invisible? Half submerged in earth, with verdant ramparts leading to a verdant roof, such a house would, in any case, be less threatening to the public's sense of public space (even underused public space) than a more conventional building would be.
If a linear park is created in what is now the northbound side of Broadway between Columbus Circle and Lincoln Center, some sites that are now too small for an opera house -- like the Saloon site, now marked for an overbearing tower -- might accommodate a structure that extends into the promenade.
Perhaps, though, one's main objective in the urban chess game should be to open Lincoln Center to the west. In that case, rather than follow the jazz bishop down Broadway, the City Opera could take the role of knight. With a jogging leap to the west it could gallantly open the region bordering Hell's Kitchen to the influences of culture and commerce.
Alas, the one nearby and available site on Amsterdam Avenue, the one now occupied by the American Red Cross, is too small to cram a modern opera house into. But three or four jumps would take our knight to the Hudson River. Here, perhaps on a pier over the water, an opera house might rise to rival Sydney's. To make this workable, shuttle buses would have to link the new house to Lincoln Center and its subway stop. For those preferring to hoof it, a safe and appealing route would have to be found or created.
 EVAN and FREDA EISENBERG

HEADLINE: ART; 
Surveying New York's Art World

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
THE Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art performs an important service with "Best of the Season: Selected Highlights from the 2000-01 Manhattan Exhibition Season," its annual display of work from the New York art world. The offerings of that world can be daunting; this exhibition helps make them more approachable.
 This year the curators have chosen work that seems more traditional than that picked in recent years. There is only one video piece, for example. 
 In that work, Christian Marclay focuses his camera relentlessly on an amplified electric guitar being dragged along a Texas highway. In this context, the guitar recalls a sleek race car, but it also summons up an era in which destroying instruments was part of some bands' acts. Mr. Marclay works with great economy; the experience is the same whether a viewer sees 10 seconds of the video or 10 minutes.
The show has some surprises. Conventional wisdom has it that abstract painting is dead, unless the abstraction incorporates some kind of narrative, but the work of a couple of pure abstractionists has been chosen.
Terry Haggerty makes paintings consisting only of stripes that recall minimal painting of the 1960's and 1970's. The effect, though, is very fresh. Paul Brown builds up layers of pigment, and small breaks in the surface reveal the layers underneath. This falls in the category of Process Art, in which the process of making the painting is revealed and is the work's only subject.
The most compelling piece in the exhibition is "Targets," by Joyce Kozloff. 
The work is in the form of a huge globe that viewers can enter. Ms. Kozloff was associated with Pattern Painting, an art movement of the late 1970's and early 1980's that was built on the premise that decorative motifs could be high art. There is patterning on the inside of the globe, but it is purposeful: maps of sites all over the world that the United States has bombed since World War II. It is chilling to see, because some of these places are in the headlines these days. Moreover, being inside the globe, a world turned inside out, creates a feeling of vulnerability.
Andres Serrano's large photographs are meant to carry an emotional charge. He can push his point to an extreme, as in pictures featuring African-American men. One is dressed in a Santa Claus suit; the other wears Ku Klux Klan robes.
The exhibition has its share of figurative art. Verne Dawson's people are usually somewhat Neanderthal but there are moments of elegance, like his depiction of men doing acrobatics on the backs of bulls.
In two panoramic paintings, Mr. Dawson imagines a prehistoric, pastoral and idyllic world. In each painting, a large form, a combination of nature and architecture dominates. The tower of Babel might come to mind.
The exhibition works mostly because the curators found a lot of modest, intimately scaled pieces. These include Jane Harris's drawings of pleasing yet mysterious shapes formed by a heavy application of graphite.
Yun-Fei Ji displays a lighter touch with evocations of traditional Chinese landscapes with their grey-green background. Yet the content of these pictures is strong; they include modern, industrial objects as well as familiar landscape elements and mythological creatures. The result is a bold combination of myth and modern life.
Tim Gardner's watercolors are so crisp and luminous that a viewer inevitably thinks they are color photographs. His "Home at Christmas" is as cozy as it sounds. The snow outside the suburban house festooned with lights has a palpable crust. 
Some works that embody a simple domesticity also underscore the inherent modesty of the show. Swatch by swatch, Polly Apfelbaum has built a floor piece that evokes a circular hooked rug, but a luxurious one. The pieces are made of dyed velvet. Roy McMakin's two untitled chests of drawers each have something wrong with them. One has no knobs and the other oversized drawers. A similar frustrating sense of daily life discord was mined decades ago by Richard Artschwager.
In an installation separate from "Best of the Season," Jordan Tinker, a Ridgefield native, has doctored the photographs in his 1986 high school yearbook, making them vague and ghostly. Despite an elaborate presentation, nostalgia for high school is too flat-footed a notion to resonate as art.
"Best of the Season: Selected Highlights from the 2000-01 Manhattan Exhibition Season," remains at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, 258 Main Street, Ridgefield, (203) 438-4519, through Dec. 30.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joyce Kozloff's "Targets," at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, is in the form of a globe that viewers can enter. (DC Moore Gallery)

HEADLINE: POLITICS; 
9/11 as Tax Hike Rationale

BYLINE:  By DEBRA WEST 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
FACING a dire state economic forecast and increased security costs related to the threat of terrorism, Westchester County Executive Andrew J. Spano has proposed a budget for 2002 that would increase the property tax levy by 9.5 percent, the largest county tax increase in 12 years.
 If approved by the County Legislature in December, it would be the first property tax levy increase of Mr. Spano's tenure. During the previous three years, Mr. Spano, a Democrat, has reduced the property tax levy by 7.8 percent. 
 "This is directly related to Sept. 11," Mr. Spano said. "It affected our economy, which affected our sales tax and our hotel taxes. We're getting less money from the state, not that I'm blaming them, they have got their own problems, but it's money we are not getting."
Mr. Spano's proposed $1.3 billion budget for 2002 includes an $89.4 million increase in spending. Under the proposal, the amount of money raised by county property taxes would be $370.5 million, compared with $338 million for 2001 and $357 for 2000. 
Katherine S. Carsky, a Republican legislator, said the expansion of county government personnel and programs in the last three years had contributed to the need to raise taxes. 
"It is obviously a budget that a lot of people want to shave," Ms. Carsky said. "The increase is above what has been cut over the last three years. It would have been nice if government had the foresight to reserve revenues and not grow government during the good times, but the time-honored tradition is to expand in good years and then you have to restrict." 
Westchester set aside a surplus in the boom years, Mr. Spano said, and $70.8 million of that will be used in the 2002 budget to keep the tax increase from being more than double what is proposed.
The largest part of the budget increase, $55.4 million, Mr. Spano said, can be attributed to an increase in the cost of state and federally mandated programs like special services for preschool children with disabilities, Medicaid and retirement expenses. While the costs are increasing, the state subsidy to Westchester was scheduled to be cut by $5.2 million even before Sept. 11. 
The proposed budget also includes an increase of $13.4 million in spending for public health and safety related to the Sept. 11 attacks. The costs include salaries and expenses for 55 new police officers to be stationed at the Westchester County Airport, in 10 round-the-clock positions, so that the airport can meet the Federal Aviation Administration's standard of high alert, and 23 other new police officers to be stationed in sensitive locations throughout the county like government buildings in White Plains. The county is also creating 28 new positions in public health, criminal justice and scientific laboratories that test for anthrax and other health threats. 
The county's debt service costs increased by $4.9 million, largely because of maintenance projects, acquisition of parkland and a $500,000 increase in insurance costs directly related to the Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. Spano said.
A series of public hearings was held last month to give residents a chance to comment on the budget. Legislators are scheduled to vote on the budget Dec. 10, but Richard G. Wishnie, the chairman of the Budget and Appropriations Committee, said there was so much work to be done on the budget that the vote might be postponed.
"I think we will meet every day to try and soften the impact of 9.5 percent," Mr. Wishnie, a Democrat, said. "This is not about politics. This is about democracy. The people we work for, our constituents, recognize that these are highly unusual times."
As part of the budget, Mr. Spano announced he would save money in the following ways: by closing the Playland Ice Casino at the end of the spring hockey season, instead of keeping it open year round to save $793,000; freezing the salaries of all nonunion employees; continuing a hiring freeze that was begun in October; cutting employees' travel, meals and educational expense budgets by 10 percent; using staff employees who earn an average of $67,000 instead of outside contractors, who earn between $105,000 and $144,000, for the Department of Information and Technology.
While they may not welcome a tax increase, Mr. Spano predicted that Westchester residents would understand the need for one.
"Most people I talk to realize that we are in better shape than most places," he said. "We're not Suffolk or Nassau. We still have our triple-A bond rating which I'm very proud of."

HEADLINE: Island's Airports Win a Partial Reprieve 

BYLINE:  By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: EAST FARMINGDALE 

 BODY:
FRANK HANAN, who was polishing his blue-and-white single-engine Hawk parked near the Republic Airport terminal here, had not heard the news.
 A day earlier, on Thanksgiving Day, the Federal Aviation Administration issued an air traffic waiver for Republic and three other New York-area airports, Caldwell, Morristown and Lincoln Park in New Jersey, all of which lie within a 20-mile ring of Kennedy International Airport. The waiver lifted a restriction that had kept pilots who were not instrument-rated from flying in and out of the four airports. 
 "This news is 9 on the scale of 10," said Mr. Hanan, a manufacturer of frozen deserts who flies for both business and pleasure. "Free gas would make it a 10." 
Lifting the restriction meant that all of the small airplanes based at Republic could fly again. Normally, they number 520, but about 100 were relocated during two brief escape periods granted by the F.A.A. in September and early October. The rest, unless flown by instrument-rated pilots, had to stay put. 
With over 200,000 annual takeoffs and landings, Republic is one of the busiest airports in New York State, but activity had decreased 60 percent under the F.A.A. restriction, Hugh D. Jones, the airport director, said. Most of the pilots who used Republic are weekend recreational flyers who are not instrument-rated, he explained.
The precipitous drop in air traffic hit hard at Republic's businesses like fuel suppliers and maintenance shops. Mr. Jones said that many elected officials and regional F.A.A officials, recognizing the economic impact of the reduced activity, had worked hard on Republic's behalf to win the waiver. 
The F.A.A. has gradually been easing restrictions it imposed on the national airspace following the terrorist attacks. Normal operations, including flight instruction, had resumed at all other Long Island airports on Sept. 21. At Republic, the Island's only airport within the 20-mile ring around Kennedy, limited operations under instrument flight rules as well as flight instruction were able to resume Oct. 6. 
Instrument flight rules require that a flight plan has to be filed at least an hour before takeoff and that the plane operates under the scrutiny of air traffic controllers at all times. Visual flight rules do not require a flight plan and give pilots more freedom to steer their own courses. 
Although he is instrument-rated, Mr. Hanan reveled in his new freedom. "Now I don't have to fly a very specific route," he said. "I can just go flying." 
The good news for many was not good news for all. All private planes continue to be barred from the 20-mile zone around Kennedy except on a case-by-case basis. The same restriction on private planes is in place around Boston and Washington.
Because of the 20-mile restriction at Kennedy, all of New York City is off limits to private aircraft. Bob Filonuk is worried about his job as the pilot for a Wall Street investor who used to commute from Republic to the East River by seaplane.
"I've been flying into the East River for 20 years," Mr. Filonuk said. "The tower knows me, everyone knows me, and all at once we are a threat?"
Before Sept. 11, private planes could enter the controlled space around Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark Airports with the permission of air-traffic control, keeping to certain altitudes that did not conflict with commercial airliners. 
Now that private planes are locked out, flying westward from Long Island presents problems. Pilots must head 20 miles south over water -- particularly risky for single-engine planes -- or north over Danbury, Conn.
But the restoration of normalcy at Republic is a big step forward, and it came in the nick of time for many -- but not all -- of the businesses, Mr. Jones, the airport director, said. 
"I've been asked how many have gone out of business, and I haven't heard of any giving up, but I've heard them say another week or another month," Mr. Jones said.
The 50 businesses on airport property have a total work force of about 1,000 people. The companies include flight schools and rental operations, fuel suppliers and maintenance shops, and even a museum with fly-by demonstrations by World War II aircraft. Some have been helped by the recent F.A.A action, but others are still in trouble.
One of them is Skytypers, which has been in business for 32 years, delivering commercial messages written in smoke, mostly in the skies over and near Manhattan.
"We primarily do our work in New York during the playoffs, the World Series, the marathon and football games at Giants Stadium," said Mort Arken, who owns the business with his son, Larry, an American Airlines captain. Skytypers employs 15 pilots part time, most of them retired veterans. "Now none of them are working for me," Mort Arken said. "We lost the entire fall season, and I pray to God that by spring the airspace over New York is open. We are hurting bad."
Also still affected is Island Aerial Ads based at Brookhaven Calabro Airport in Shirley. Island Aerial tows advertising banners along the Island's beaches during the summer season and operates two traffic planes year round. Now because of Kennedy's no-fly zone, the two traffic planes can report only on eastern Long Island, said Paul F. Calabro, the owner of the 18-year-old company. And his principal business, towing banners, is in jeopardy. His season starts on Memorial Day. If the restriction around Kennedy continue next spring, Mr. Calabro said, "it will put us out of business."
For other businesses, the lifting of the Republic restriction signaled another step toward normalcy. 
"This is beautiful weather, and if it stays like this we can probably rejuvenate and recover some of our losses," said Norbert Koenig, a co-owner of Nassau Flyers in East Farmingdale, a flight school and rental operation with 27 airplanes.
At the neighboring American Airpower Museum, attendance had dropped by as much as 30 percent because its planes couldn't go up on demonstration flights. "This is the best news we've had since Sept. 11," a museum spokesman said.
The day before Thanksgiving, Edward Libassi, the owner of A&P Aircraft Maintenance at MacArthur, a business he started 30 years ago, had only one week's worth of work waiting, compared with the normal six weeks' worth. He had moved from Brookhaven Calabro to MacArthur in May 2000, and "it was phenomenal for me until Sept. 11," he said.
Then after the terrorist attacks, customers trapped at Republic had not been able to get their aircraft to his shop for maintenance or annual inspections, he explained. 
Now with the restriction at Republic lifted, "it should bring some normality back for people who fly for enjoyment and just want to punch holes in the sky on a Saturday morning," he said. "It's going to help everything all the way around."
Bob E. Gordon, the president of the 1,000-member Republic Airport Pilots Association, said he hoped that general aviation on Long Island would be back to normal soon.
"I understand their concerns, but general aviation was not involved in the Sept. 11 attacks, and a typical private plane weighs less than a car, so does it really pose much of a threat?" he said.
But few people expect that all the freedom given to private aircraft before Sept. 11 will be entirely restored. "From a personal standpoint, it's sad," said Gene Portela, the general manager of Eastway Aircraft Services, a maintenance and parts company at MacArthur. "You used to be able to get into a plane and fly up the Hudson River past the Statue of Liberty. It was terrific. But those days are gone forever."
A lot of the fun has gone out of flying, said Jim Zambik, the owner of Zambik Aviation, a flight school at Spadaro Airport in East Moriches. "But national security comes before personal freedoms, so I don't see any easy answers," he said.
Bob Schaefer, a recreational pilot who is not instrument-rated, echoed that sentiment. He flies his single-engine Cessna up from Tryon, N.C, to Republic at least twice a year to visit his mother in Brooklyn and his sister in Dix Hills, he said. This Thanksgiving, he arrived before the restriction was lifted at Republic, so he flew into Trenton and rented a car.
"It's pretty selfish to complain," he said. "We may have lost a little bit of our 100 percent freedom, but driving an extra 20 miles for the sake of national security is a small thing when you remember Sept. 11 and how many people lost their lives."

HEADLINE: SENIORITY; 
Still ShowingOlder Workers the Door

BYLINE:  By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LESS than two years ago -- in the midst of one of the tightest labor markets ever -- companies were warned that they faced dire consequences if they discriminated against older workers. The reason? As vast numbers of baby boomers begin to retire in a decade or so, there will not be enough younger workers to replace them.
 In her book "Age Works: What Corporate America Must Do to Survive the Graying of the Workforce" (Free Press, 2000, $25), Beverly Goldberg contended that even if the economy turned sour, the labor shortage would ease only temporarily. 
 Well, here we are in a sour economy. Has corporate America heeded the warnings of Ms. Goldberg and others about ageism? Apparently not. 
Two years hence, when displaced-worker reports on the current downturn are in, they are likely to show that older workers bore the brunt of layoffs. At least that's the expectation of Marjorie Honig, who along with Michele Siegel and Charlotte Muller prepared a recent report -- "The Incidence of Job Loss: The Shift From Younger to Older Workers, 1981-1996" -- for the International Longevity Center-USA, a research organization affiliated with the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan.
The report concludes that older workers have cause to worry, based on what happened in the last two recessions, in 1981-82 and in the early 1990's. In the earlier recession, the job-loss rates for men 45 to 59 years old were 40 percent lower than those for men 25 to 39. In the recession of the early 1990's, however, the job-loss rates of older workers were just as high as those of younger workers. (Interestingly, and for unclear reasons, such a change was not found among women in the work force: in both recessions, layoff rates were higher among younger women.)
"The data aren't available on what's happening now, but it's my gut feeling that what we see from the previous two recessions is a trend," said Dr. Honig, chairwoman of the economics department at Hunter College and co-director of research for the longevity center.
"Many employers are using the current downturn as an excuse to get rid of older workers," she added. Under the guise of restructuring, she said, they are usually able to get around age-discrimination laws. 
Dr. Honig echoed Ms. Goldberg's point that the downturn was temporary but that the looming labor shortage was not. "Companies are going to need those older workers," Dr. Honig said. "They're going to need that experience."
Why are companies so shortsighted when it comes to older workers?
"In part, it's probably because many companies take a short-term view generally, looking from quarter to quarter in terms of shareholders and profits," she said. "If you cut a bunch of workers, especially higher-paid older workers, your profits look better. But there will be trouble in the long term."
Another factor, Dr. Honig said, is that companies have broken an implied long-term contract they used to have with workers. A worker would stay with one company for an entire career because of the understanding that workers would accept lower wages when they were young in exchange for higher wages when they were older, even though they might be performing at a less robust rate.
"This was good for the company," she said, "because that lure of higher wages later kept workers' job performance high."
"Now that's all gone out the window," Dr. Honig added. "But as a result, younger workers are ruthless in demanding higher wages. And they're right, because they don't expect to be with one company more than 5 or 10 years. So now a company has to pay through the nose to attract younger workers, because there's no expectation the company will keep them, as was the case under the old implicit contract."
Theodore Roszak, the author of "Longevity Revolution: As Boomers Become Elders" (Berkeley Hills Books, 2001, $15), also sees the current situation as temporary.
He says that as the population grows older, age discrimination will be addressed more seriously and the nation will develop firm rules that will allow older workers to keep their jobs.
"Often, age discrimination is the result of fashion, style, appearance and false assumptions about who should be working and holding jobs," Mr. Roszak said. "But these make no demographic sense and must be overcome as we become an older society."
Dr. Robert N. Butler, president of the International Longevity Center, noted that under current law, the age at which workers can retire and collect full Social Security benefits was being raised to 67 from 65. In addition, there are proposals to raise it further, even to 70.
"So here we are, facing a delay in Social Security benefits because of age, and at the same time facing age discrimination at work," he said. "That's a problem."
Dr. Butler said that in this age of longevity, one of the most important tasks was to keep extra "human capital" working.
"In the 20th century, we gained an additional 30 years of life," he added. "It took the preceding 50 centuries to do that. That's extraordinary."

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
High School on a College Campus

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: HARTSDALE 

 BODY:
HAZEL PARNELL is hoping that her 14-year-old daughter will be one of the lucky ones. A select group of ninth graders from Irvington, Harrison and Woodlands High Schools will be taking their classes on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase starting Jan. 28. 
 As members of the first class of the Westchester Magnet Academy, these 60 students -- 30 from Greenburgh Central 7's district, home to Woodlands, and the rest from Irvington and Harrison -- will participate in a program that combines academic curriculum with hands-on activities, a component that is modeled on aspects of the Outward Bound program, community service and arts classes taught by SUNY Purchase faculty. 
 Under the terms of a $2 million, three-year federal grant, these ninth-grade students will be the first graduating class in what will become a four-year high school. By last week, about 30 students -- all from the Greenburgh district -- had applied, and parents and students were invited to presentations about the magnet program. 
"This reflects a hands-on integrated approach to learning that would appeal to some students," said Joseph DeGennaro, assistant principal at Irvington High School. "It's really offered for students who want to branch out and try a different style of learning." 
The grant is part of the Magnet Schools Assistance Program, which is financed by the United States Department of Education. It is meant to promote equity and achievement for all students. Part of the grant's purpose here is to bring together students from diverse backgrounds to learn in a challenging setting. While the grant expires after three years, program administrators said they expected to be able to renew it as long as the school is successful. The academy may also have access to financing from New York State's magnet program and from the students' home districts.
The Westchester Magnet Academy is an unusual innovation for a county where loyalty to home school districts tends toward the extreme. In the recent past, efforts to consolidate smaller high schools into a larger entity, or even to develop a selective county-wide high school that would bring together the top students from districts like Chappaqua, Scarsdale, Byram Hills and Bronxville, along with White Plains, Yonkers and Katonah-Lewisboro, have not made much progress. Some local districts have feared that such programs, which would siphon off the top academic performers, would harm their competitive status for the most selective college admissions.
"It's neither an alternative for higher end kids or kids who can't cope with normal high school," said Dr. Donald A. Howard, superintendent of the Harrison public schools. "This is for any kid who is ready and willing to experience something radically different, that involves kids very personally in their own destiny. I had been looking for an alternative path for kids to get their high school diploma. There are a lot of kids who march to a different drummer, and this could be a better experience for them." 
For Mrs. Parnell, whose daughter is interested, the appeal is obvious. "I think it's an excellent program that's good for the community," she said. "The magnet school has a lot to offer. My daughter loves art and music and drama. I'm hoping she gets in." 
One unusual feature of this magnet program is that it links an ethnically and economically diverse district like Greenburgh Central 7 with more affluent districts like Irvington and Harrison.
As Jennifer Dolan-Waldman, assistant superintendent of Irvington said: "We want to provide a strong, viable academically strong high school alternative. When you have a small district, it's hard for students to find a wide range of options. This had very different goals than having a Westchester Stuyvesant. People move to Westchester for the good schools. This is not just a school for an elite bunch of children. It's more for the students not to be in such isolation." 
Not every parent is enthusiastic about the idea. "If it were for the academically elite, I'd consider it," said one Irvington parent, who spoke only if she were not identified. "When I looked at this, and saw that it wasn't screening on academics, I was baffled."
The current ninth grade classes number about 250 students in Harrison, 125 in Irvington and 140 at Woodlands. Even though the program will be run at SUNY Purchase, where the students will be able to benefit directly from its strong arts program, those who run the magnet program point out that the high school students will still be taking required Regents exams and meeting all New York State standards. The magnet academy's four teachers will be responsible for instruction in social studies, science, mathematics and English; SUNY professors will provide classes in the arts.
Josephine Moffett, superintendent of the Greenburgh Central 7 district who, as superintendent in Freeport on Long Island supervised the development of four magnet schools, said: "We want to be giving parents choices. And when I spoke with the students from the student government team, they talked about wanting instruction to be innovative and challenging." 
That would mean, for example, that students studying earth science or biology could map a stream, analyze the mineral content of its silt and sand, as well as the types of rocks and rock formations found along the stream bed, and report the findings using mathematics and scientific techniques. Students working on a social studies and language arts project might adopt an older person, conduct an oral history and produce a biographical report incorporating historical and cultural perspectives, as well as the individual's personal experiences.
For now, and under terms of the grant, the slots in the academy are restricted to students from the three participating districts. Students will receive transportation from their homes to the SUNY Purchase campus and be able to participate in extracurricular activities at their home district high schools.
Students will be selected for the magnet program solely on interest and motivation, based on applications that will be screened starting Dec. 10. Each student will be assigned a laptop computer as part of the focus on using technology in daily learning. The college's science and computer laboratories, as well as performance studios, will be available for the students. They will receive high school diplomas from their schools, in addition to a certificate of completion from the magnet academy.
"I do think it's interesting to have three districts collaborate among themselves, and to collaborate with a college," said Janet Walker, executive director of the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association. "This opportunity may spark an excitement in learning. It'll be interesting to see what develops."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Miriam Bernabei, director of arts, music and special projects in the Greenburgh Central 7 district, spoke to parents about the magnet academy that will begin in January. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: And the Winner Is: Patchogue! 

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN

DATELINE: PATCHOGUE 

 BODY:
SWANLIKE young women in glittering gowns floated onto the stage. A man in a tuxedo belted out "Fly Me to the Moon." An audience of hundreds gazed at the spectacle, beaming. 
 Hollywood? Vegas? Atlantic City? 
 Try Patchogue. This Suffolk County village, which has for years been grappling with the question of how to revitalize its sadly quiet downtown, last week hosted its most glittering event: the Miss New York USA and Miss New York Teen USA pageants. 
"I think we all deep down inside want to be Miss America, or better yet, Miss Universe," said Karen V. Gole, a real estate broker from Patchogue, grinning broadly last Sunday as she waited for the coronation ceremony to begin. "Finally we get to see the girls in person." 
Ms. Gole's 35 years have included countless hours in front of the television watching beauty pageants. On Sunday, she slipped on a sparkly red shirt and rhinestone-encrusted boots and arrived at the Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts on East Main Street with her 12-year-old niece, Marlana King, in tow.
They settled into their plush seats for what the two agreed was the greatest thing to happen to Patchogue since the Christmas parade, which had been the highlight of the local calendar.
"Nothing happens here," Marlana sniffed. 
That is precisely the point, say those who hope that events like the Miss New York USA pageant, which in recent years had been held in Albany, will breathe life into Patchogue, a once-bustling downtown that now has too many empty storefronts and too few customers. 
"An event like this just gets more people thinking about coming to Patchogue, to go shopping or to get a sandwich," said Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau and Sports Commission. "The name Patchogue gets on the map. People start to know that Patchogue exists."
The Miss New York USA pageant and its undercard, the Miss New York Teen USA contest, are contracted to take place here for the next two years, and Mr. Hollander and others are trying to bring the Miss USA pageant, the next level of the competition, to Long Island as well. (It's scheduled for next March in lovely Gary, Ind.) The pinnacle is the Miss Universe contest. On Long Island someday? Who knows?
"You want to get branded as being a positive place," Mr. Hollander said. "And something like this brands you." 
No doubt. But the important news, of course, is that the new Miss New York USA, beating out 30 other contestants, is Karla Cavalli, and she's from Mineola. 
Contestants in beauty pageants fall into two groups: those who are pageant people, and those who are not. The pageant people have previously found themselves wearing a bikini and heels in front of a crowd of strangers, and are likely to be in such a position in the future.
Miss Cavalli, a sweet-faced 25-year-old blonde with the major advantage of having a boyfriend who is a hairstylist at an upscale Manhattan salon, is a pageant person.
"She's just a natural," said her mother, Vicki Cavalli, who stood by as her daughter competed in pageant after pageant, winning Miss Long Island in the Miss America pageant circuit a couple of years ago. Her latest title is part of the rival Miss USA constellation.
"She doesn't need much coaching," said Mrs. Cavalli, who is from England. "If you notice, she has an elegance about her, a grace. It's the English part of her." 
Miss Cavalli's father, Ernesto, an Italian by birth and the manager of Due, a restaurant on the Upper East Side, had a different perspective. "Great gal, great heart," he said, whispering, "It's the Italian in her."
When not attending beauty contests, Miss Cavalli is a professional dancer for the New Jersey Nets basketball team.
"This is huge for me and huge for my career," she said, packing up her Russian Red lipstick and tanning spray in the theater dressing room. "I'm really, really excited." 
And what about Patchogue? 
"A big event in a small town like this is good, because it's giving back to the community," she said. "It's more all-American, supporting the small-business man type of thing." 
The other winner last weekend -- Marley DelDuchetto, 16, of Syracuse, the new Miss New York Teen -- is definitely not a pageant person, according to her father, Ernest, who was beaming Sunday evening in spite of himself.
"She's not going to be in any more pageants," declared Mr. DelDuchetto, who allowed his daughter to compete for Miss New York Teen USA only after she convinced him it would help her get into Yale. "I don't believe in pageants."
Miss DelDuchetto's mother, Debra, said the new family pageant moratorium did not apply to the Miss Teen USA pageant in August, and insisted that her husband was warming up to the notion of the pageant.
"Once he saw it in action, he really felt positive and knows that she's going to have a great year," Mrs. DelDuchetto said. 
It might have helped that Miss DelDuchetto told her father, a lawyer, about Carolyn M. Wright, a Yale junior who competed for Miss New York. 
Miss Wright, a theater studies major from upstate Guilderland, acknowledged that some of her classmates were a bit taken aback when she first mentioned the pageant. But they came around.
"They're very performance-oriented, so they considered this another form of performance," Miss Wright said. Plus, she figured the experience could be considered research for her playwrighting seminar. 
"Maybe somebody will end up in a story sometime," she shrugged. 
There is no talent component to the Miss New York contest. Which served some of the contestants well, by their own admission. Instead, there were swimsuit competitions, evening gown competitions and brief personal interviews by a panel of judges.
The judges, among them the Brookhaven town supervisor, John Jay LaValle; K. T. Mills, a radio program host on WALK-FM; and a Westchester County chiropractor, fired a motley collection of questions intended to ensure that the winner will be able to carry on a conversation with politicians and fourth-graders alike.
"What is your greatest fear?"
"If you were on the television show 'Survivor,' what luxury item would you bring?"
When Nicole Vought of Rockaway was asked, "What would you do if we held a celebrity charity auction, and a total loser shelled out $5,000 for the honor of dining with you?" she responded: "I might like him, I might not think he's a loser."
It seemed like a good answer, but Miss Vought did not place.
As the contestants waited to be interviewed at the Wyndham Wind Watch Hotel in Hauppauge, where they stayed for the weekend, some of them sought advice from a true pageant mom. 
"It's good to have a coach, and I'll tell you why: they have experience," said Gladys Colon, 41, whose daughter, Gloria Sophia Almonte, 18, of the Bronx, relinquished her Miss New York Teen crown Sunday evening. "It's a tough job. Everybody sees the glamour."
Ms. Colon had a litany of complaints: the pageant was disorganized, the judges' panel lacked racial diversity and Miss DelDuchetto was allowed to sing the national anthem at the start of Sunday's ceremony. 
"All the girls on the stage had their mouths open when that young lady got up to sing," Ms. Colon said. "Judges are human." 
The pageant director, Lauren M. Malis, said the judges might have all been white, but they are "well-rounded individuals who deal with all walks of life and all kinds of people every day." And it was the pageant's producer and choreographer, Miss Malis said, who asked if any of the contestants could sing upon learning moments before the ceremony that the professional singer hired for the job had been in a car accident. 
"I was just as surprised as everyone else," Miss Malis said, adding that she did not believe the judges took Miss DelDuchetto's vocal skills into account.
"That doesn't bear any judgment, whether a girl can sing or not," she said. "We don't have talent in this pageant." 
The event was Miss Malis's debut as director of the New York pageants. Miss Malis, 33, a former Miss Connecticut who has directed the Miss Connecticut USA pageant for two and a half years, said she strove to transform the New York pageant from an Albany-based event where the contestants ("delegates," they are called) performed in a hotel ballroom.
"I was looking to change the venue, change the type of production that had been in the past and give it a face lift," said Miss Malis, who runs a public relations agency in Manhattan. "I love Long Island." 
Through her former job with the Empire State Development Corporation, Miss Malis got to know the Long Island Grucci family, of fireworks fame. She asked Donna Grucci Butler, president of Fireworks by Grucci, to help judge the Miss Connecticut USA pageant, and talked to her about moving the New York pageant to Long Island.
"Donna said, 'You have to see this theater,' " said Miss Malis, who toured several Long Island venues but quickly settled on the Patchogue theater. "I was like, 'This is magnificent.' And this town, it's postcard perfect. If you had to pick this little American town, Patchogue would be it."
The Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts is easily the jewel of village, and many local leaders and residents have seen it as the village's saving grace, the Main Street magnet with the potential to bring the crowds back downtown. With this in mind, the village has recently spent some $6 million renovating the theater, which opened in 1923 as a vaudeville house and changed with the times, becoming a single-screen movie theater and, later, a multiplex that eventually failed. 
In the past couple of years, there have been plays, concerts and dance recitals. After a dispute with the Gateway Playhouse, a Bellport production company that wanted to manage the theater, the village has now taken the job into its own hands.
Anthony D. Sala, 24, owns Salabella's Pizzeria and Cafe across the street from the theater. He renovated the restaurant, adding marble-dusted tables, optimistic that the theater will work its magic. Anything that brings the outsiders in and the residents down will be good for business, he said. 
"People come, they see the town, it's a nice little village," Mr. Sala said, preparing a meatball sub for a police officer. "Patchogue's starting to die out. We need to bring it back to life."
Vincent J. Grucci, president of the Patchogue Chamber of Commerce and a nephew of Donna Grucci Butler, was ecstatic. "The history books this past weekend were written," he crowed. "And the line is that when the pageant decided to change its location, forever in the books will be that the Incorporated Village of Patchogue was chosen as its new home."
But a lack of local hotel rooms sent most of the economic ripples elsewhere, mainly to the Wyndham. Though 800 spectators showed up for the final judging on Sunday, there was a measure of disappointment in the pizzeria that more people did not stop in for a slice or an espresso, and that the glitz was largely confined to the theater itself. 
"I was expecting limos and busloads of girls hopping out in bikinis," said Krystal L. Schweimler, 17, who works at Salabella's. "We just see big officials and people walking around in suits." 
Nonetheless, Miss Schweimler, a senior at nearby Patchogue-Medford High School, had jumped at the chance to serve as an usher.
"I think it's exciting," she said. "We don't have stuff like this." 
Mr. Sala had urged her to enter, but Miss Schweimler had demurred. Maybe next year, she said.

HEADLINE: Where More Is Less in Political Representation 

BYLINE:  By DONNA KUTT NAHAS 

DATELINE: BALDWIN 

 BODY:
AS Albany legislators armed with the latest census figures take up the once-a-decade task of reconfiguring legislative districts, some civic groups are pursuing campaigns to unify communities split among multiple representatives and divided by district lines.
 Nowhere is the problem felt more acutely than in Baldwin, a South Shore hamlet that is a jigsaw puzzle of legislative districts. 
 Baldwin's representation in the House of Representatives is split between Peter T. King and Carolyn McCarthy; in the state Senate between Dean G. Skelos and Charles J. Fuschillo Jr.; in the state Assembly among Earlene Hill, Kathleen Murray and Robert Barra; and in the Nassau County Legislature among Patrick Williams, Joseph Scannell and Michael Zapson. Aside from the United States Senate, the only legislative body in which Baldwin is not split between districts is the Hempstead Town Board, where Anthony Santino is the hamlet's only councilman.
With multiple lawmakers at almost all levels of government, residents say they are insufficiently represented by people whose focus is Baldwin and its interests. Adapting arguments made in the lawsuit that turned Hempstead's at-large town council arrangement into a district system last year, they say the system amounts to a dilution of the voting power of Baldwin's 32,000 residents. 
"If the community is dissatisfied with its representation, voters are free to exercise the power of the ballot box to either reward or punish that representative," said Doris R. Duffy, a member of the Baldwin Community Association and chairwoman of a committee on legislative redistricting. "But Baldwin cannot reward or punish because we are so carved up. Our votes do not mean as much as an entire village or area that is completely represented by one legislator."
Baldwin's problem was exemplified prior to a renovation of the hamlet's Long Island Rail Road station in 1999. Late in the planning, community groups learned that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority proposed to overhaul the station in a style clashing with plans for Baldwin's downtown revitalization project, featuring antique-styled lighting and benches. The M.T.A.'s plans were brought in line with the community's only after residents contacted the town's two state senators and three assembly members.
Like 31 other places in the Town of Hempstead alone, Baldwin is an unincorporated hamlet without a local government. And that creates a hardship for residents, they say, since no one has governmental authority except Councilman Santino, whose district also includes a portion of Hewlett, East Rockaway, Oceanside, Lynbrook, Rockville Centre and Island Park.
"The advantage of having one representative at the town level," Mr. Santino said, "is that you have one representative for the community and everyone knows who to go to." 
Mr. Scannell, who lives in Baldwin but represents only part of the hamlet in the county Legislature, suggested that all of Baldwin be included in his district. "It's easier to advocate for a town, easier to go to bat when one person knows all the issues," Mr. Scannell said.
Incorporation is an option, but the Nassau County charter bars newly incorporated villages from controlling their own zoning, a major function of most village governments. Ms. Duffy said redistricting is a more expedient and immediate way to effect change at all levels of government.
The Baldwin Community Association has petitioned the state Legislative Task Force on Demographic Research and Reapportionment, a six-member bipartisan panel charged with redrawing congressional, senate and assembly districts, to to reduce the number of lawmakers representing Baldwin at each legislative level. The panel is scheduled to issue its plan this month, but the decision ultimately rests with state lawmakers. Once a plan receives clearance from the federal Justice Department, it must then be approved by the governor.
Nassau and Suffolk will also redraw their legislative districts next year.
Baldwin is not the only community on the Island balking about being divided by district lines. A coalition of groups representing African-Americans in New Cassel, East Garden City, Hempstead, Uniondale, Roosevelt, Freeport, Lakeview and Elmont, along with Wyandanch and North Amityville in Suffolk, say split senatorial districts have weakened blacks' voting power.
Dorothy L. Goosby, a plaintiff in the suit that abolished at-large districts in the Town of Hempstead and now a member of the town board, contends that for three decades, state lawmakers have repeatedly gerrymandered minority communities to thin the percentages of blacks in many state Senate districts.
After the 1990 census, she said, legislators split minority communities such as Freeport, Roosevelt, Hempstead, Uniondale, West Hempstead, South Hempstead and North Baldwin between the Sixth and Eighth state Senate districts and Westbury, New Cassel, Elmont, South Floral Park and North Valley Stream between the Seventh and the Ninth Senate districts. She suggested that minority communities in the Sixth through Ninth Senate districts, which are geographically compact and contiguous, could constitute a majority in a redrawn district.
"Our people have been disenfranchised too long," Ms. Goosby said. "We have enough people in those areas to have that type of influence and to insure that the lines are not drawn in a manner that allows our votes to be lost."
Eugene Burnett, chairman of the Suffolk County Black Caucus, a civil rights group, said that in the redistricting in 1984 and 1992, North Amityville, which is 80 percent black, was placed in a senate district separate from neighboring Wyandanch, which also has a high proportion of African-Americans.
"When you dissipate the strength of our vote, our leaders become impotent and we are ignored by elected officials," Mr. Burnett said. "The closer you bring government to people, the better it functions in their interest because they have input. When you remove input, our issues are taken off the table."
Among those issues is education. The New York Civil Liberties Union has filed a lawsuit against the state asserting that students in Hempstead, Uniondale, Roosevelt, Wyandanch, Amityville and 16 other districts upstate receive far fewer educational services than those in predominantly white schools. A second suit alleges that the state failed to provide students in Hempstead, Roosevelt, Wyandanch and Westbury, among others, with a "sound and basic education" by depriving them of adequate educational resources and services.
"If there are no representatives directly representing Wyandanch, Brentwood and other communities that are overwhelmingly minority in composition, then the argument goes that those communities cannot have the political influence that white communities have," said Don Shaffer, cooperating attorney at the New York Civil Liberties Union and the legal director of its Nassau chapter. "The school issue is particularly evident because school aid is one of the prominent characteristics that elected representatives always point to as, 'I brought home the bacon.' "
Long Island Hispanics say they too are being shortchanged in the political arena. Patrick Young, program director of the Central American Refugee Center in Hempstead, asserted that the political system fails the Hispanic population because "no state senator views Latinos as a primary constituency," and said it was no coincidence that none of the Senate districts in Nassau is more than 13 percent Hispanic.
Similar complaints are heard in Suffolk. Diana Dominguez Weir, an East Hampton town councilwoman who is also the former chairwoman of the Suffolk County Hispanic Advisory Board, said that Brentwood, where more than 50 percent of the population is Latino, is in three assembly and two senate districts.
Since May, the legislative task force, led by Senator Skelos, a Rockville Centre Republican, has sponsored hearings throughout the state to define what constitutes a "community of interest" for the purposes of drawing legislative districts. 
"Do the folks in Brentwood and Wyandanch feel more in common as an ethnic community or less in common because of other factors like school districts, employment patterns, etc.?" asked Assemblyman Chris Ortloff of Plattsburgh, who is a member of the task force. "Ethnicity is not the be-all and end-all, but if that is what defines a community then that's the way the legislative districts should be drawn."

HEADLINE: Suffolk Cuts $400,000 From Marine Project 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
AMID the tax increases and spending cuts of a hard budget year for Suffolk County, a reduction of nearly $400,000 for a highly regarded marine program operated by the Cornell Cooperative Extension hardly stood out.
 But as the dust began to settle last week after the deliberations that produced what some Suffolk officials are calling a wartime budget for next year, the Cornell program was being recognized as a major casualty. 
 Its fate signals the difficult road ahead for groups and agencies that depend on county money at a time when slumping sales-tax revenues, a slowing economy and uncertainties after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are taking their toll. 
The Cornell program, an educational and research effort that began 13 years ago, operates a marine center at Cedar Beach in Southold, an education center in Riverhead and a recently opened branch at the Vanderbilt Museum in Centerport. Thousands of volunteers and schoolchildren, as well as local governments, marine businesses and baymen, take part in its projects to preserve and restore shorelines and coastal waters. 
Those projects range from seeding bays with scallops to growing eelgrass in a nursery for eventual planting and creating local fishing jobs. 
Under the new budget, the county cut its contribution to the marine program to zero. The county's contribution had accounted for about a third of the program's annual funding. 
The program's staff members, some of whom have worked in local waters for more than 20 years, secure government grants and private financing for projects that currently employ about 40 people. Program administrators estimate that the projects bring in $3 million a year in revenues.
Now, the marine program must find new financing or close its doors. "We took a huge hit," said Christopher Smith, a marine scientist who is the program's director. "We are scrambling for survival, for sure."
The Suffolk cooperative extension, a nonprofit educational and research agency in Riverhead with close ties to Cornell University, depended on the county for about 43 percent of its annual budget last year, or about $3 million of $7.2 million.
The county also cut $278,000 for another extension program, one for diabetes education that the extension runs under contract with the Suffolk Health Department. The program offers diabetes management and weight-control counseling at county health centers. Judi Veeck, an extension spokeswoman, said that the program was within a year of gaining formal recognition from the American Diabetes Association, which would make it eligible for federal reimbursements.
The cooperative extension cuts, which total nearly $678,000, were the largest for any agency holding county contracts, officials said. 
The extension's board of directors said in a statement that it "realizes the difficult situation faced by our county and appreciates the effort that went into preparing this budget." "What is being proprosed as a savings to taxpayers will ultimately cost us all far more," they added.
The directors and other extension officials said they did not know why the county cuts fell so heavily on their programs. "I still haven't figured that one out yet," Mr. Smith said.
Some county legislators said that the cuts might have reflected disagreements between Michael J. Caracciolo, a Republican from Wading River in whose district the extension headquarters is situated, and other legislators on the special committee that negotiated the final 2002 county budget. The committee, created by Paul Tonna, the County Legislature's presiding officer, a Republican from Huntington, agreed with Robert J. Gaffney, the county executive, on a 13 percent rise in property taxes and $10 million in new fees. 
The adopted budget had to make up for a potential $37.7 million shortfall after legislators rejected Mr. Gaffney's tobacco settlement securitization proposal and declined to eliminate the sales tax exemption on clothing and shoes costing less than $110.
It also increased from 1 percent to 2.5 percent a tax on home heating oil, natural gas and residential electric bills. The increase on electric bills will bring in an estimated $8.4 million, but the Long Island Power Authority is protesting the tax increase and has asked for a rollback.
The marine and diabetes program cuts were among about $21 million in program and service reductions the legislators ordered. 
Under an informal arrangement, legislators who agreed to vote for the final budget were each allowed $200,000 to restore programs or services in their districts. Mr. Caracciolo and three other legislators who voted against the budget were excluded and got nothing.
Mr. Caracciolo said last week that the cuts in the extension programs were in line with other budget reductions and were not a punishment for his opposition. But, he added, "I would be dishonest to say the thought didn't cross my mind."
Maxine Postal, a Democrat from Amityville who sat on the special budget committee, defended the $200,000 awards. "We had to make some very tough decisions, and we decided that each of the legislators willing to vote for the budget would be able to restore some programs to the tune of $200,000," Ms. Postal said. "If you are not willing to vote for the budget, should you have the ability to spend money?"
It was not clear whether Mr. Caracciolo would have been able to restore financing for the extension programs even if he had supported the budget.
Mr. Caracciolo said he opposed the budget because it relied too heavily on raising fees, taxes and revenues rather than on what he called reasonable spending cuts. He called the electric tax "a sneak attack" that should have been discussed publicly before being included in the budget. 
Other officials said the budget deliberations were remarkable for the high level of cooperation among officials confronting suddenly changing economic conditions.
"In my 25 years in government, this was by far and away the most difficult budget to deal with," said Paul Sabatino, the counsel to the County Legislature. "I called it a war budget. There were no easy choices."
Mr. Sabatino said cuts in the Cornell marine and diabetes programs were "a question of prioritization" and no reflection on programs' quality. "We were cutting or partially cutting and raising fees, and every decision was really a horrible choice," he added.
Mr. Smith, the marine program's director, said that operations would probably cease within three to four months unless financing was found elsewhere or restored by the county.
"I have got to believe that once people understand how deeply we are woven into the fabric of Suffolk County, they will at least stop and reconsider the magnitude of these cuts," he said.
