HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Perth Amboy; 
A Waterfront City Planning a Comeback

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
THE new waterfront walkway along Sadowski Parkway in Perth Amboy reflects both the city's ambitious revitalization efforts and the challenges left by its industrial past. The esplanade, which has an immaculate red brick sidewalk, acorn-shaped Victorian lights and decorative iron and wood benches, overlooks a breathtaking view of Raritan Bay and Staten Island. In sharp contrast, however, it also overlooks Perth Amboy's battered and badly eroded shoreline to the east and its a sprawl of weathered brick and cinder-block industrial buildings -- some vacant with trash-strewn lots and broken windows -- to the north. 
 Financed with federal, state and Middlesex County grants, the esplanade cost nearly $15 million and is part of a metamorphosis that Mayor Joseph Vas predicts will revitalize the city through the injection of $1 billion in private investment into the 4.4-square-mile city over the next eight years. 
 His monumental redevelopment plan, called Focus 2000, involves 700 old industrial sites and nearly one-third of the city's land, mostly along the waterfront. It calls for the restoration of the shoreline, the development of beaches, the cleanup of brownfields left by industry and the construction of housing, a community center, an open-air market, new retail stores, a hotel, restaurants, a sports arena and a new industrial park. The largest portion of the plan is the $600 million Landings at Harborside, which is just getting under way with the demolition of old industrial buildings north of Sadowski Parkway to make way for 2,000 housing units, the hotel and stores.
"We are reclaiming more than 1,000 acres left behind from the postindustrial period," Mr. Vas said in an interview. 
The impending redevelopment follows a decade in which the once-proud manufacturing city has been clawing its way back from urban decay that set in with the flight of industry and the middle class from East Coast cities in the 1960's and 1970's.
Among the conditions that set the stage for redevelopment is a 40 percent reduction in crime in the last six years, after 14 years of rising rates. Largely because of the demolition of blighted apartment houses and community policing, the number of reported crimes in the city last year stood at 1,688, compared with 2,826 in 1995.
Other factors stimulating development are the city's spectacular location on the Raritan Bay at the confluence of the Arthur Kill and the Raritan River and its abundant transportation options. The Garden State Parkway, the New Jersey Turnpike, Interstate 287 and Routes 1 and 9 are all within 10 miles; the city is on the New Jersey Transit rail line to Manhattan; and next summer, ferry service to Manhattan is to begin.
The city's renaissance is manifesting itself in the housing market, according to James J. Elek, owner of the J. J. Elek Realty Company in neighboring Woodbridge. "Houses that sold a year ago at $115,000 on Hall Avenue," which is around the corner from one of the demolished high-rises, he said, "are now going for $185,000." 
"The largest jump is in the two- and four-family market, which is steaming hot." A two-family that sold five years ago for $120,000 can go for $220,000 today. Two-bedroom units in those houses command rents of $950 to $1,200.
Fernando Gonzalez, manager of Weichert Realtors in nearby Edison, attributes the increases to anticipation created by the city's redevelopment plans. "People who would otherwise sell their houses are waiting for price rises," he said. "Also anticipating increased prices, more people are trying to buy. It's a matter of low supply and high demand."
In mid-November, 56 houses were on the market, ranging in price from $56,000 for an 80-year-old two-bedroom colonial being sold as-is on Oak Street in the southern section of town up to $600,000 for a five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath colonial on Water Street, overlooking the waterfront. Housing styles vary widely, from old colonials with no hot water to large Victorians and brand new town houses.
The largest rental development is Green Village, a 318-unit garden apartment complex off Harned Street in the northern section. The complex has mostly one-bedroom apartments and a few two-bedroom units. There is now a waiting list for one-bedroom apartments that will become available at $680 monthly in March, and no two-bedroom units are forecast to become available in the near future. 
The largest new housing development in progress is Harbortown Crossing along the Arthur Kill, off Buckingham Avenue, where about 1,500 condominium town houses and rental housing units are being built. Although designed to be sold, most of the 479 units in the completed first phase are now rented, many to low-income families receiving federal and county housing assistance. However, those who purchased in Harbortown have been rewarded with significant appreciation in the past three years, according to Robert Alex, one of the first buyers.
Mr. Alex says a four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath town house that is almost identical to the one for which he and his wife, Edna, paid $147,900 in 1998 sold recently for $242,000. This year, according to Perth Amboy tax records, 15 condominiums in Harbortown had sold by Aug. 31, ranging in price from $158,900 to $218,900.
MR. ALEX is a self-employed business consultant, and Mrs. Alex recently retired from her job as a social work supervisor for Middlesex County. She is about to start a new job as director of a day-care center for old people in Perth Amboy. They moved from a large single-family home on one acre in East Brunswick, 12 miles away.
"We knew we would be pioneers and welcomed the challenge and the excitement of being part of the rebirth of a city," Mr. Alex explained. Since moving to Perth Amboy, Mr. Alex has been drafted by the mayor to serve as a commissioner on the Perth Amboy Redevelopment Agency, a volunteer group overseeing the renewal of the city. 
The "City by the Bay," as Perth Amboy calls itself, has a proud history. Founded in 1683, it was the first city in New Jersey to be chartered by the Crown, in 1718. Its seal, presented by King George I, contains the Latin phrase "Portus Optimus," meaning "the best port." Indeed, Perth Amboy's port has served whale boats, oyster sloops and naval vessels, and it still receives large oil tankers and freighters.
The name Perth Amboy comes from the Earl of Perth, one of the proprietors of New Jersey under the royal grant, and the Leni Lenape Indian word "ompage," meaning "level ground." The town served as the first British capital of East Jersey and was home to William Franklin, the last royal governor of New Jersey and illegitimate son of Benjamin Franklin. His palace -- Proprietary House on Kearny Avenue -- is the last remaining British royal palace in the United States. The building, now used for a local museum and private offices, is listed in the National Register of Historic Places, along with the city's restored Historic Ferry Slip, which operated from the end of Smith Street from the late 17th century until it closed in 1963 for lack of passengers. The slip will remain a tourist attraction and will not be used for the new ferry service.
Mayor Vas says he hopes the new town houses along the shore and the easy commute to Manhattan will lure young middle-class families and singles back to Perth Amboy. Currently, the town is 70 percent Hispanic and has one of the lowest median household incomes in Middlesex County: $39,323, according to a 1997 estimate.
A key component in Mr. Vas's plan is the 9,200-student public school system, which faces enormous challenges because of overcrowding and its high proportion of low-income immigrant families. The number of students in the district has grown by more than 50 percent since 1992. Despite the construction of three new schools and the renovation of three others over the past decade, class sizes -- 19 on average at Perth Amboy High School and 24 at the elementary school level -- remain about 15 percent larger than state averages.
According to the superintendent of schools, Dr. Pablo Clausell, the district has purchased property and received a state commitment to provide $112 million for the construction of a second high school, two new elementary schools and an early childhood center. The start of construction is not yet scheduled. 
SINCE the first language of more than 70 percent of the students is Spanish, 1,500 students are currently enrolled in the English-as-a-second-language program. Because of the low income of the residents, 85 percent of the students receive federally funded breakfasts and lunches.
Dr. Clausell says the district offers a six-hour prekindergarten education daily to all 4-year-olds, with an optional three-hour after-school program. Computers are introduced in kindergarten and keyboarding in first grade. Every classroom above prekindergarten has Internet access, with one computer for every three students, compared with one for every six pupils statewide. Besides its programs for children, the district also runs a 3,000-student adult-education program.
Perth Amboy High offers 13 advanced placement courses in English, the sciences, history, government, mathematics, computers, Spanish and art. On last year's College Board tests, Perth Amboy High students' combined verbal and math scores averaged 863, compared with a state average of 1012. Of last year's 315 graduating seniors, 27 percent went on to two- and four-year colleges.
Like most other sections of Perth Amboy, the central business district on Smith Street throbs with activity from 9 a.m. until 9 p.m. There are few vacancies among the 400 stores, mainly because of Perth Amboy's designation in 1994 as a state Urban Enterprise Zone. Rather than collecting the full 6 percent state sales tax, enterprise zones collect 3 percent and invest the proceeds in redeveloping their business districts.
Among items financed with the $8 million in zone funds received since 1994 are new Victorian-style street lights and sidewalks along Smith Street and State Street, another commercial street. The money has also helped to pay for widespread road resurfacing throughout the city.

HEADLINE: Scarce Jobs and Dashed Hopes For the Class of 2001 

BYLINE:  By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

 BODY:
BILLY TILSON remembers the good times. The days when looking for a job meant sorting through competing offers. When companies sought to sell themselves to him during interviews, rather than the other way around.
 "All the companies were fighting over me," Mr. Tilson said. "Everyone was hiring and the companies were bending over backwards for you. It was a lot of fun." 
 It's not so much fun anymore. Mr. Tilson is only 23, and it hasn't been that long since his career seemed flush with possibility. But prospects have changed dramatically for Mr. Tilson, an Edgemont native who graduated from the University of Virginia with the class of 2000. His story is representative of many in his generation: those who began college during a robust economy and four years later have entered a job market that is contracting by the month. 
Last week, a group of economists that tracks business cycles made it official: the country is in a recession for the first time in 10 years. The National Bureau of Economic Research said that the largest economic expansion on record gave way to a recession in March, months before the terrorist attacks or the sharp rise in unemployment that began last summer.
Like many of his classmates, Mr. Tilson started out strong. He began a new job right after graduation. He went to work for PricewaterhouseCoopers in Manhattan, first spending three months in an intensive training program and then being assigned to work as a consultant in the area of Internet development. Eight months after he was hired, he was laid off.
While he had seen it coming -- his was the company's second round of layoffs, and projects in his division had become scarce -- Mr. Tilson was shocked when he re-entered the job market. He found it transformed.
"I was completely unprepared for dealing with tough times," Mr. Tilson said. "All the career help I'd had before was basically how to choose between all the job offers you get and how to handle interviews. Now it was pretty dramatic if I could just talk to someone and get an interview. I had a great start-up job and good experience and it didn't seem to matter."
For five months he sent out his resume, wrote cover letters, made phone calls and grew increasingly discouraged. He said that he worked harder finding a job than he ever had actually having one. Some mornings, he said, it was hard to get out of bed.
Currently Mr. Tilson is working as a contract consultant at TrafficMac, a company that specializes in managing the performance of on-line advertising campaigns. He works full time but gets paid by the hour and receives no benefits. That worries him, especially since he plays rugby. He shares an apartment in the East Village in Manhattan with three roommates. Still, he hopes to stay where he is, at least until the job market improves.
"I'm very happy working here and I'd like to keep it," Mr. Tilson said. "I'm sick of searching. It's just full of frustration because no matter what I do, nothing seems to be working."
His frustration -- and that of other job seekers in the metropolitan area -- is not likely to let up. The latest figures from the New York State Department of Labor show that from October 2000 to October 2001, New York City lost 59,400 private sector jobs. And 44,200 of those jobs were lost between September and October of this year.
The huge drop over the month represents the relocations and layoffs associated with the World Trade Center attacks, said James P. Brown, a labor market analyst with the state Department of Labor. But the economy was already in a decline before then. 
Two broad forces are at work in the metropolitan area, Mr. Brown said. First, the economy in and around New York City is heavily dependent on selling services to other companies. As national corporate profits began falling in the middle of last year, so did the demand for services in businesses like advertising, consulting and finance. And as Wall Street took a sharp downturn, the financial community was further damaged.
"This was all pre-Sept. 11," Mr. Brown said. "You already had an economy that was significantly weakening, particularly in high-wage areas that attract college graduates. The events of Sept. 11 tended to hit many of the organizations that were having problems already -- the advertising market, the travel market and Wall Street -- and it also slowed the national economy, which meant corporate customers were cutting back yet more."
Regional figures -- which include New York City, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Nassau and Suffolk -- are a little less discouraging. From October 2000 to October 2001, there was a drop of 52,000 jobs. From September to October 2001, 26,300 private sector jobs were lost.
As each recent college class has progressed, it has faced an increasingly tight job market.
"Anyone being hired from the class of '99 graduated into a very strong market," Mr. Brown said. "By spring of 2000 some weaknesses began to show up with the dot-com collapse. By the class of 2001, it was obvious that we had a national recession developing and substantial regional weakness."
Mr. Brown said that many companies did their hiring well in advance and recruited people from college campuses last fall to begin work this September. As it turned out, "they don't need all the people they thought they did," he said.
That's not something you need to tell Richard Tyre. Mr. Tyre, 23, grew up in Chappaqua and graduated from Lafayette College in May 2001 with a degree in international economics and commerce. He had several interviews with investment consulting and technology firms. In January, he was packing his suitcase for an interview in Rhode Island with American Power Conversion. he night before the trip, he received a phone call telling him not to bother flying to headquarters. The company was no longer able to make him a job offer.
Meanwhile, he had been pursuing other leads. Mr. Tyre had interviewed with Accenture, formerly Andersen Consulting. In April it offered him a position, but the job was not available until March 2002. He accepted, though the offer was later pushed off another month. Mr. Tyre was offered a sum of money to wait for the job, and he accepted. He hopes to start at Accenture in April 2002. In the interim, he did some temp work, which he disliked, and is now substitute teaching in his old school district. Last month he moved from his parents' home in Chappaqua into Manhattan, where he is sharing an apartment with two friends.
"I do have it rough, but it's not as bad as the upcoming graduating class," Mr. Tyre said. "At least I have an offer and I can see the light at the end of the tunnel. From what I've heard, Accenture is not going to recruit this year. They'll use my class to replace the class of 2002."
That class -- the current crop of college seniors -- is already getting bad news. They, too, began college is a strong market. Many of them took steps they thought would guarantee them a place in the corporate world. Now they find the rules have changed.
Take Kiamesha Colom, 20, a senior at Manhattanville College in Purchase. She worked for two summers at MasterCard International Inc. and is currently interning there. She has worked in corporate services, business performance solutions and competitive intelligence at the company. In years past, MasterCard has viewed senior class interns as employee prospects. But because Ms. Colom currently works there, she has seen the in-house e-mails announcing a hiring freeze.
"Most likely there won't be an offer, even though you were basically promised one at the beginning," Ms. Colom said. "You think you're doing the right thing for three years and suddenly you get stopped short."
Ms. Colom, who is president of the student government at Manhattanville, had been planning to work for a year and then begin graduate studies. Now she is thinking of going directly to graduate school, with the hope that the job market will improve.
"Financially, I didn't want to be any more in debt," said Ms. Colom, who lives on campus. "I wanted that year of work. Just graduating from college in general is scary, and then having to hear every single day when you wake up that they are dropping the interest rates one more point, it's very scary."
Munish Thairani, a classmate of Ms. Colom's at Manhattanville, also went the internship route. He has worked with Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, as well as at a consulting firm in Connecticut. Mr. Thairani, 21, who also held part-time jobs on campus, maintained a grade point average of over 3.8 and has recommendation letters from every firm for which he has worked. He has sent out dozens of resumes but gets the same response: hiring is frozen.
"When I came to college in '98, the financial industry was booming," he said. "The opportunities were endless. My idea was that if I kept on doing my best in school and making sure I had the training at the same time, I would be selected as a candidate. But because the market is so bad now, it does not matter how impressive you are."
Mr. Thairani has enough credits to graduate next month. But he has decided to stay in school for another five months, with the hope that things will improve in the spring.
For college career counselors, it is a difficult time. Karen Ganz, associate dean of career service at Manhattanville, has watched the experiences of Ms. Colom and Mr. Thairani with frustration.
"To have been promised jobs because you've interned for two years, and you love them and they loved you, and to have that vanish, that's a great disappointment," Ms. Ganz said. "Especially for people who have done all the right things."
At Pace University, with campuses in Pleasantville and White Plains, this fall's career fair also reflected the downturn. Last September, 120 employers went to the school's job fair. This year 70 signed up, and many who came were not hiring anyway.
"The word out there seems to be freeze," said Jody Queen-Hubert, director of co-op education and career services for the Westchester campuses of Pace University. "I'm hearing from students that they are grateful for any offers. They recognize the market is bad. Instead of waiting for any other offers, they are saying, hey, let me go with this one, and not wait out an anxious situation."
Even internships are not what they once were. Local colleges report that some internship programs are being suspended. And for remaining internships that were once paid positions, the companies are now asking students to work for free.
To be sure, not every field is in trouble, Ms. Queen-Hubert said. Pace held a very successful career fair for nurses last spring, and the market is still strong for education, nursing and human services.
At Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, graduates historically have not been drawn to corporate jobs, said Mary Raymond, director of career counseling. Instead, students tend to look for work in education and with nonprofits, with a significant number applying to AmeriCares and the Peace Corps. This year, she said, seniors are showing more interest in graduate school. And she acknowledged that even noncorporate jobs are affected by a poor economy.
"At this point, if the money continues to dry up, with all those corporate people funding these great not-for-profits, we're in trouble," Ms. Raymond said.
COLLEGE career counselors are trying to reach out to alumni to help new graduates find jobs, but are finding that more and more alumni are themselves seeking career services.
"In the past we've seen alums who wanted to change careers, but now we're seeing alums who are unemployed, and these people have worked here in this area for major corporations -- 13 years at Readers Digest, 14 years at Texaco," Ms. Queen-Hubert said.
Schools also anticipate a change in the popularity of majors. In the last five to seven years, there has been a large increase in enrollment in computer and finance majors. But with the shake-out in those industries, colleges expect students to start to return to fields like accounting.
"Whether you're making money or losing money, you still need accountants to generate that data," said Joseph M. Pastore Jr., a professor at the Lubin School of Business at Pace University. 
Career counselors say that part of their role now is to educate students on how to have realistic expectations of the job market. Gone are the days of signing bonuses, let alone having a company foot the bill for a fledgling employee's M.B.A. degree. But they don't really need to tell students that.
"It's very discouraging," said Noah Schwarz, 21, who grew up in Chappaqua and will graduate from Colgate University in May 2002. "You're having these interviews, you're preparing for them, you do all your reading on the company, you get in your suit, you go through all the stress and at the end they say thank you, but we're not hiring. It's really tough."

A Degree, a Good Resume, Iffy Prospects
IT'S not exactly life imitating art. But since this is a story that features MTV, a line from an Alanis Morissette hit song, "Isn't it ironic?," does come to mind. Here is Josh Kleiman, recent graduate of Sarah Lawrence College, clearly a go-getter, with significant experience to his credit. Not only hasn't Mr. Kleiman found a full-time job, but in his position as an unpaid intern at MTV, he just finished working on a segment for the station's news program on a topic all too familiar to him: how tough it is for young adults to find work.
The segment, which was shown last month, included an interview with the director of career counseling at New York University and also covered a career fair at Yale. Mr. Kleiman, 22, worked on it as a research assistant, helping out in whatever way he was asked.
"The story that I'm trying to get across to students is that they should keep working toward a job for when the economy starts up again, and not use this time to sort of do nothing and go live at home and wait," Mr. Kleiman said.
He is taking his own advice, as best as he can. Throughout college, Mr. Kleiman worked and interned in entertainment and production jobs. One summer he worked for a subsidiary of Universal Pictures. The fall semester of his senior year, he secured "the best internship I've ever done" with "The Howard Stern Show." (He got that by waking up to the radio program and hearing that it was looking for interns. He said he was dialing the number to apply before his eyes were fully open.)
Throughout college he worked for Buena Vista Pictures Distribution, a position for which "they pay you to go to the movies," he said. Specifically, Mr. Kleiman would count how many people were in the theater and what trailers were being shown. He also interned in Washington with Senator Barbara Mikulski of Maryland.
When he graduated from Sarah Lawrence last May, Mr. Kleiman could not find a job he wanted. He said he could have gotten a job as a store manager or a waiter, but that it wouldn't have led to the career he desires. So now he is back in another internship, in the field he wants, but without the salary he needs.
To make ends meet and pay the rent on the apartment in Manhattan he shares with a roommate, Mr. Kleiman until recently had a job designing Web sites, which he did on the weekends and in his spare time. But he is currently looking for a permanent night job. On top of that he is working on a novel. And here's one more thing keeping Mr. Kleiman busy these days. He is studying for the LSAT. 
"An executive-level producing job is much easier to attain with a law degree in your pocket," he said. 
Mr. Kleiman said that most of his friends are in the same situation as he is.
"My best friend has been trying to find a job for months and has gone on more than 20 interviews," he said. "Obviously if you have a college degree and it's a necessity to have a job, you're going to get a job -- in the service industry or hostessing or in a clothing store. Getting a job is not on hold for most young people, but pursuing a career is." Kate Stone Lombardi

HEADLINE: A Booming Business in Selling Money 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago when Carl and Debbie Kaufman began looking for a house in Connecticut for themselves and their three children, who back then ranged in age from 13 to 6, they found a four-bedroom 1920 colonial in Milford, Conn. But because of what Mr. Kaufman described as "some credit problems in the past," the banks to which they applied for a mortgage turned them down.
 Eventually, however, the Kaufmans obtained a $74,900, 30-year loan through a mortgage broker, $65,000 of it for the mortgage, several thousand dollars for closing costs and the remainder for some of the many repairs needed to upgrade the half-century-old house. Because of the Kaufmans' earlier credit problems, they had to pay far more than the going interest rate. At a time in 1996 when the average mortgage rate was 8.03 percent for a single family residence, their rate was a whopping 11.5 percent. 
 But Mr. Kaufman, a photographer for Yale University's department of media services, had no complaints then about his dealings with Shoreline Mortgage in Milford and has none now. "What else could we do?" he asked. "I needed a house for my family, and with my credit history no bank would touch me, but Shoreline did." What is more, he and his wife recently refinanced their mortgage with Shoreline, this time obtaining a 30-year $200,000 loan at 8.1 percent, still higher than typical rates these days because of his past credit history, but a rate that will drop a percentage point if they make all of their payments on time for 24 months.
It should not be very surprising that a broker found both the original loan for the Kaufmans and their refinancing loan, for mortgage brokers have originated a majority of residential mortgages in six of the last seven years, according to Wholesale Access Mortgage Research and Consulting Inc. in Columbia, Md.
The only year the mortgage brokering industry slid in that period was 1999, when its market share dropped to 47 percent when rising interest rates caused refinancing, in which brokers tend to specialize, to all but dry up. This year, according to David Olson, the managing director of Wholesale Access, brokers are likely to account for 65 percent of residential mortgages. If so, that will be their second highest market share since Wholesale Access began keeping track in 1987, behind only a 69 percent share in 1998, when refinancing was also strong.
Back in 1987, brokers had a market share of just 20 percent and there were only 7,000 mortgage brokerage firms nationwide. This year, Mr. Olson said, there are probably 33,000 to 35,000 such companies.
Despite the specialty's robust growth in recent years, many potential and actual borrowers have only a sketchy idea of what mortgage brokers do, often confusing them with bankers and other lenders. In fact, brokers are the mortgage industry's equivalent of matchmakers, bringing together borrowers and lenders instead of brides and grooms. 
As the role and numbers of mortgage brokers have grown in recent years, the practices of some of those matchmakers have brought scrutiny that is now resulting in proposed regulatory changes that would affect the entire industry. Complaints of predatory lending practices, in which borrowers are charged high fees or talked into loans they cannot afford by brokers who work on commission, have brought federal action to force greater disclosure by all mortgage brokers.
Many brokers, Mr. Olson said, were formerly salaried employees at banks or savings and loan associations and a significant number struck out on their own when the S.&L.'s ran into regulatory and liquidity problems. Before long, Mr. Olson said, banks and other lending institutions not only overcame their suspicions of their mortgage broker competitors but also realized that outsourcing much of the loan process to brokers obviated having to employ more loan officers and clerical help. 
Thus, in return for brokers arranging loans for borrowers, completing the necessary paperwork and making sure that the loans meet the guidelines that will enable them to be sold to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac (which will bundle them and sell to investors), lenders were more than willing to pay the brokers a commission. That commission usually averages between 1 to 3 percent of the loan, depending on its size, complexity and the relationship between lender and broker.
Interviews by Wholesale Access of more than 3,000 mortgage brokers, picked at random from a database of 28,000 firms, found that last year the typical brokerage had one office, originated 125 loans, employed five people and was generally profitable. Many such brokerages consist of one or more family members, although Mr. Olson said that a few brokerages have about 100 brokers.
"It's a service business -- we're selling money, said Richard A. Sales, who has been in the business almost 40 years and who owns RTN Mortgage brokerage in Fairfield, N.J., where his son Todd and daughter, Michele Ligorelli, also work. "It's an easy business when interest rates are going down," Mr. Sales added, "but when rates are going up, you don't have many friends." 
What most brokers also do not have many of are wealthy customers, Mr. Sales said. People with upward of $1 million usually have relationships with banks, he explained, and they tend to care more about that relationship, which often includes financial advisers, than they do about having a broker shop around for the lowest cost loan.
"Our market is basically people who want the lowest rate and who are uncomfortable in banks," he added, "and they would rather drop by or phone us to get that rate without having to put up with the hassle you often get in a bank."
To which Mr. Kaufman, who bought and refinanced his house through brokers, would probably add "Amen." He said he preferred dealing with brokers because they usually seem able to deliver a lower rate and because "they go out of their way to find you a loan, even if your credit history hasn't always been perfect."
BANKERS, of course, paint the picture differently. "Bankers offer a relationship that extends beyond the mortgage loan sought and beyond such other bank products as home equity loans and lines of credit, car loans, education loans and more," said Julie Malveaux, a spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association. Because brokers rely on others to finance the loan, she added, "borrowers should choose a mortgage from a lender they trust and are comfortable doing business with."
When they shop for loans for their clients, mortgage brokers spread a wide net and may well land a lender that the borrower is unfamiliar with.
The Kaufmans' loan when they refinanced, for example, originated through a broker, Shoreline Mortgage, but the lender was First Union, a conventional banking company headquartered in Charlotte, N.C. Susan Harris, the owner of Shoreline, said she had correspondent relationships with about 40 banks, including some in California, Florida and Iowa. She chose a Connecticut branch of First Union because it offers a Fannie Mae loan that automatically reduces the interest rate by up to 1 percentage point if the borrower makes 24 consecutive monthly payments on time.
"People think that rates are the same at every bank," said Joseph L. Falk, president of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers, "but there is a wide diversity of loans and prices, because lenders all look at things differently." 
"What's good for one lender might not be right for the next one," he added. "We have 41 state associations, and each one has an annual trade show where hundreds of lenders from all over show up" to display their wares.
These wares consist not only of various blends of loan rates and durations, but also loans for such niche markets as senior citizens, military veterans, minority communities, immigrants, self-employed borrowers who lack income verification and people with spotty credit.
Not only that but "rates often change every hour, depending on what's been happening with the Taliban, consumer confidence, unemployment, the stock market or the Federal Reserve," said Peter L. Spalthoff, executive director of the Connecticut Association of Mortgage Brokers. Using an example from Shoreline Mortgage, the brokerage owned by Ms. Harris, who is his wife, Mr. Spalthoff said that about a month ago she could have gotten customers a 15-year fixed-rate loan at 5.75 percent if they were willing to pay a fee of two points. (Each point represents 1 percent of the loan.) "But that rate," he added, "was available only the last four hours of the day." 
This example, brokers say, is indicative of the hundreds of short-term offers available almost daily, for those who know where to look within the vast mortgage marketplace. And knowing where to look for the best rates and niche markets is why brokers forge correspondent relationships with banks and other lenders across the nation.
The average mortgage broker deals with up to about 15 lenders, but Dan Levitan, managing director of the Manhattan-based Home Mortgage Acceptance Corporation, which originates loans for customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, said his firm has about 80 lenders.
Why? "Because there is no one mortgage market -- there are many -- and each bank is going for one segment of the market," he said. "And we know the players in those markets."
These days, most players are forced to wait several weeks to have loans processed and the mortgage check in their hands, instead of the wait of a week to 10 days that was usual until recently. The reason is that refinancing this year -- which the Mortgage Bankers Association of America has projected will total $970 billion, which is $220 billion more than the record $750 billion in 1998 -- is now clogging the mortgage pipeline. Loans and loan applications are backed up, while lenders are swamped, along with appraisers, real estate lawyers, title companies and just about everyone else involved in the mortgage loan process.
With 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rates rising to 7.21 percent through last Wednesday from 6.59 as of Nov. 9, things have cooled slightly, but the pipeline remains clogged. That is one reason some mortgage brokers, and a number of banks, either do not solicit refinances or limit their number. 
"We and most companies our size never want to do more than a third of our business in refinancing," said Tom Weisman, account executive for the Newburgh, N.Y., branch of CTX Mortgage, a big Dallas-based company. "We get most of our business from referrals from lawyers, realtors and accountants, so if you stay in the office all day and concentrate on refinancing, the next time they want to refer somebody they'll phone Tom, Dick or Harry." Besides, he added, "When refinancing dries up, so does a good part of your business."
Penn Johnson, the owner of Stamford Mortgage Company in Stamford, Conn., said his brokerage accepts refinance customers but does not solicit them. "We prefer purchases, because refinances come and go and we have to stay in business," he added. "I can't service purchase customers if we're swamped with refinances." 
But most brokers do not limit the number of refinancings, because the demand for first mortgages is also dependent on the economy, if not to the extent that refinancing is. So, brokers tend to accept the longer hours and frenzied pace that come with the periodic refinancing cycles, knowing that they will also have to endure down times, much as owners of summer businesses at the seashore and owners of ski lodges and ski slopes resign themselves to the doldrums that accompany their off-seasons. 
Furthermore, many people finance two or more times with the same broker, as Carl and Debbie Kaufman did with their Connecticut company, and brokers say that customers who refinance also occasionally buy a bigger or more expensive house later, and many times they recommend the broker to family members, friends or acquaintances who are looking to buy a house.
A handful of online lenders, including E-Loan and Countrywide, have elaborate and comprehensive Web sites, but Mr. Olson of Wholesale Access said that online mortgages account for a very small proportion of the total.
Still, even some traditional lenders and brokers are finding that going online is a good way to increase business.
A. J. Romano Mortgage in Stratford, Conn., was unsure whether to use the Internet, because it did not know what to expect. "But we went online in September 1996, and our first loan closed in January 1997," said Joseph L. Romano Jr., the company's president. "Now about 30 percent of our business comes via the Internet, including from people in other states." Moreover, whereas the company's typical loan had averaged about $185,000, he said, the loans generated on the Internet average about $205,000. 
Romano Mortgage does not actually make loans or commitments over the Internet, because for the company to do credit checks the borrowers would have to provide their Social Security numbers online. Mr. Romano said he would not provide his own Social Security number online, in case it should fall into the wrong hands, and so his company obtains that information by telephone.
Companies that make extensive use of online applications, however, stress that they employ encryption and other techniques to prevent unauthorized parties from viewing any personal information transmitted to or from the company. 
Almost every state has laws regulating mortgage brokers, said Robert S. Lotstein, the general counsel for the National Association of Mortgage Brokers and the managing partner of the law firm of Lotstein Buckman in Washington, usually requiring that they be licensed or registered. 
New York, for example, requires that mortgage brokers register with the New York State Department of Banking, and they must have two years of experience in credit analysis or underwriting, although business experience or education may be used to satisfy that requirement. And registrants who originate loans through HUD's Federal Housing Administration must post $25,000 bonds.
Connecticut requires mortgage brokers to post $40,000 bonds. 
To obtain a license in New Jersey, mortgage brokers must post a $50,000 bond and maintain a net worth of $50,000. And unlike New York and Connecticut, neither of which requires mortgage brokers to maintain offices in the states, New Jersey licenses mortgage brokers only if they have offices in the state. 
While the overwhelming number of mortgage brokers are reputable, according to Mel Martinez, the secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, for several years there has been pressure in state legislatures and in Congress to rein in what Mr. Martinez also criticized last April as the "dishonorable practices" of "a small number in the lending industry who choose to prey on the most vulnerable in our society." The vulnerable include the elderly, minorities, the least educated and people with little money. Among the practices that Mr. Martinez condemned are those that burden the unwary with bigger loans and higher interest rates than they can afford and that he said "may often lead to foreclosure."
He also criticized those who inflate the price of appraisals, legal fees, title registration and other closing costs -- fees that consumer organizations and other critics say are little more than disguised kickbacks, financial rewards for foisting the bigger loans on the unwary.
Mr. Martinez has also been critical of the illegitimate use of "yield-spread premiums," the higher commissions that banks pay brokers for bringing them loans with higher interest rates, but which the unscrupulous among them use to fleece the unwary by talking them into loans with unnecessarily high interest rates. TYPICALLY, such higher-than-market-rate loans are part of a package in which all or part of the closing costs and other fees -- sometimes including the fee that some mortgage brokers charge for preparing the loan applications -- are included in the loan itself, which then carries higher payments, making it more attractive to the lender and far costlier for the unwary borrower.
And in a policy statement released on Oct. 15, Mr. Martinez reiterated that "it has always been HUD's position that yield-spread premiums serve an important purpose in the housing market," in that when used properly they give lower-income home buyers the option of paying all or part of their closing costs over the term of the loan in return for paying a higher interest rate.
But the policy statement went on to say that HUD is drafting regulations that, if enacted after a six-month public comment period, would require brokers to provide borrowers with a more precise estimate of the yield-spread premium and the fees that will be required at closing, rather than giving borrowers rough estimates and possibly springing inflated costs on them at the closing. He also suggested that lenders and brokers adopt those policies now instead of waiting for them to become law.
Mr. Lotstein said that no one would be more pleased to get rid of unscrupulous brokers than the large majority of honest brokers who are sometimes tarred with the same brush. "There are predatory loans," he added, "and the system is clearly not working when the borrower is paying more than is appropriate." The association's hope, he said, is to join with HUD to get rid of unscrupulous mortgage brokers without doing damage to a system that has been a win-win situation for most brokers and borrowers.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED; 
Giving Is Taking Its Toll

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
THE middle of September is usually a hectic time at the regional offices of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, with thousands of volunteers trying to raise $1.5 million for research.
 This year was different. 
 "The phones weren't ringing," said Elizabeth Preston, executive director of the organization's mid-Jersey office in Hudson County. "There was no mail. A pin could have dropped in here and you could have heard it. We wanted to just go home and close the door."
Instead, they came to the office every day after Sept. 11, even though Ms. Preston lost seven family friends and acquaintances in the attack on World Trade Center, and tried to figure out how best to seek donations in the aftermath of such an enormous tragedy. 
Four walks were scheduled for the last two weekends in September. Three days after Sept. 11, the office cancelled the walk in which about 5,000 people would have started at Liberty State Park -- projected to raise $710,000. So far -- even without that one walk -- $290,000 has been donated. Three other walks raised $650,000, about $150,000 short of projections.
Nationally, the goal was to raise $78 million, but a little more than $61.5 million was taken in. Overall, money raised from walks in the Northeast was down 35 percent, as against 17 percent in other regions, said Julie Kimbrough, a spokeswoman for the organization.
"It was important that we had those walks because people needed to be together," Ms. Preston said. "We're going to reduce our expenses by 20 percent, and we're redoubling our efforts in our fund-raising programs.' 
The diabetes foundation is among the many charitable organizations in New Jersey that have found contributions down since Sept. 11.
Americans are a generous lot -- having donated $203 billion to nonprofit organizations last year -- said Adam Meyerson, president of the Philanthropy Round Table, a group up of 650 donors. More than $1.2 billion has been raised for victims of the World Trade Center attacks, which is what is given every two days on the average to charitable groups, Mr. Meyerson said. But he and others who monitor fund-raising expect the economic downturn and the events of Sept. 11 to make it more difficult to raise funds this year. 
"Giving will be strong and the economy will come back, but there are certain charities that are going to have tough times in our state," said George C. Ruotolo Jr., president and chief executive of Ruotolo Associates Inc., a fund-raising consulting firm in Cresskill. "Organizations that have cultivated relationships over time will do better. Churches aren't going to suffer and schools will be okay. Animal rights groups and arts organizations may have some tough times, but they will come back. I'm more concerned about start-up organizations.' 
For instance, the annual fall Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Walk, which last year raised $9 million, brought in $8.5 million this year.
Volunteers and staff at the Monmouth County Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in Eatontown are currently making their annual holiday appeal, and the hope is that contributions will make up for what has been lost the past 10 weeks. Donations are down about one-third, said Ursula Goetz, the society's executive director, and the shelter -- already filled with almost 300 animals -- is beginning to get more from people being called up by the military. 
"With all the human needs, people are forgetting animals now," Ms. Goetz said. "We are very concerned as we enter 2002 on how we are going to make it. We are not seeing the 25, 50 and 100 dollar checks."
Area food banks are also finding a drop in donations -- in both money and goods. And in some cases, agencies are seeing the demand increasing at the same time that donations are slipping.
"We have had such a tremendous increase since Sept. 11 in the number of people requesting assistance, and the donations can't keep up," said Thelma Fedele, director of community and government relations for the Center for Food Action in New Jersey.
The organization, which has five locations, is serving 200 more families than it was before Sept. 11. Ms. Fedele said that among those seeking aid were hotel and restaurant workers, limousine drivers and office staff members who were laid off after the collapse of the twin towers.
The Mercy Center in Asbury Park, which supplies about 7,000 families a year with food, clothing and shelter is also finding the demand heavier than usual but donations lagging, said Sister Carol Ann Henry. Although they do not have figures, Sister Carol Ann said parishes in North Jersey were attending to the needs of people in their congregations.
At the Food Bank of South Jersey in Pennsauken, donations increased in recent weeks after organizers put out a plea. Last year, the group took in about $40,000 in unsolicited contributions, said Bedzaida Mendez, executive director of the food bank. This year, it has raised about $32,000 so far.
"Most people scrounged what they had for 9/11 which is a great humanitarian thing to do," Ms. Mendez said. "We've been through hard times before and we know how to survive. We still have to make sure that no one goes to bed hungry."
Both Mr. Meyerson and Mr. Ruotolo agreed that charitable organizations needed to remind loyal donors that their causes still existed and needed money and when possible, groups should address the issue of 9/11.
"How do you use your resources to stop terrorism in the first place?" said Mr. Meyerson.
The Newark Museum, which saw the city decrease its financing this year because of lower revenues at the airport, is trying to make up for it through donations from visitors. In addition, it recently received a $75,000 grant from the Dodge Foundation, said Lorraine McConnell, a spokeswoman at the museum.
The plan, Ms. MccOnell said, was for the grant to go toward the recreation of a garden of solace and contemplation, similar to those in Spain in the 9th through 12th centuries that were shared by Jews, Muslims and Christians. 
Then there is PuttinOn the Ritz Theater, a 470-seat theater in Oaklyn, where attendance has dropped somewhat since Sept. 11. At this time last year, performances had attracted 11,998 patrons. For the same period this year, attendance was at 10,692 people, said Bruce A. Curless, the theater's producing artistic director.
Mr. Curless said he struggled with whether to have shows the weekend after Sept. 11. In the end, he said, the show went on -- and before each performance he read a quote by George Cook, who during World War I said: "The social justification which we feel to be valid now for makers and players of plays is that they shall help keep alive in the world the light of imagination. Without it, the wreck of the world that was, cannot be cleared away and the new world shaped."
While fund-raising experts say it will be difficult to find new patrons, Mr. Curless insists that arts organizations must always look for new viewers to keep going.
"Because we are grassroots we aren't looking at a lot of large individual donors," he said. "Because we're the arts, we're looking for people to pull into the arts. We're always reaching out to different people."
For now, fund-raisers can take heart in statistics included in a report prepared by the Trust for Philanthropy Giving USA report, which show that with the exception of 1987, a year of financial panic, charitable giving has gone up every year in the United States for the past 40 years.
In two acts of terrorism that the group examined -- the bombing of the World Trade Center and the bombing of a federal building in Oklahoma City -- the rate of growth in giving increased in the year of the event over the previous year. 
Workers at the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation hope to make up some of the fund-raising shortages with golf tournaments and galas next spring. This year's walks in South Jersey and Philadelphia missed their goal by $40,000, but Valerie Minuti, executive director of the Greater Delaware Valley chapter, expects the organization to do well in the end.
"We have had tried-and-true donors," she said. "We will be standing strong."

HEADLINE: COPING; 
A Pantry Offers Soup and Solace, But There's Never Enough of Either

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
THE big trucks packed with cans of food and bags of grain arrive on Tuesdays at the West Side Campaign Against Hunger food pantry, a warren of basement rooms beneath the soaring white stones of the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, at West End Avenue and 86th Street. Inside, last Tuesday, a dozen volunteers and employees scurried about counting and stocking, knowing that when the shelves were full the next day the lines would wind around the block in the affluent Upper West Side neighborhood. 
 Sometimes, on busy days, just two hours after opening at 8 a.m., people are told to come back in the afternoon. On an average day a year ago, people from 100 households would come by to load up their shopping carts. That figure today is 168 households. As in so many other New York neighborhoods, there are more hungry people than there is food. 
 Johana Solana and Eduardo Rodriguez, counselors at the pantry, were stocking food on Tuesday and bracing themselves. On Wednesday, with a waiting room full of people, mostly women and children, they would interview clients and collect the documents verifying their need. Recently, a fight broke out in front of the church because the food had run out. Every day, they said, they grapple with sadness and helplessness. Ms. Solana has nightmares. Mr. Rodriguez has started smoking again.
"When I started this job, I expected to see homeless people or people with drug or alcohol problems," Ms. Solana said. "But I'm talking about your average American not able to make that dream. People who have lost jobs in factories, or sales, baggage check, construction, you name it. They are ashamed to come here."
Mr. Rodriguez said: "For me, the undocumented immigrants are the saddest. Because they have no documents, I can't really help them, and they show up with all their kids and you know they are hungry and need help. They say: 'My husband left, and I have three kids. I want to work.' "
Emergency food programs are the other ground zero in New York these days. But with a record loss of 80,000 jobs in October alone, the 32,800 families facing the five-year welfare limit today and a softening economy, New York faces a hunger crisis.
Just as many New Yorkers began to look at police officers and firefighters with renewed respect after Sept. 11, attention must be paid to people like Ms. Solana and Mr. Rodriguez, on the front lines of a different catastrophe. Their stories need to be heard. This city's heightened sense of community and sympathy offers a chance to rethink everything from the minimum wage to subsidized day care. 
Food for Survival, one of the city's most important food-pantry groups, recently issued a report estimating that more than one million people, one out of eight New Yorkers, rely on the city's 1,200 soup kitchens and food pantries to avoid going hungry. The preliminary results of a continuing study by Food for Survival found that since Sept. 11, two-thirds of the people receiving emergency food for the first time were single mothers. About 40 percent of them had lost jobs. They wanted information about job placement and day care.
"I have sat down with people and done the math," Mr. Rodriguez said. "It's paying the rent or buying the groceries. It's using that $6-an-hour job for child care or staying home with the kids yourself and getting welfare."
Ms. Solana, 27, a single mother of a 1-year-old daughter who lives with her mother, her cousin and her cousin's two children in Washington Heights, was once an unhappy statistic.
After years of working, she found that her bachelor's degree in social work was useless when it came to finding a job after moving here from Florida. She ended up at the food pantry in June. Doreen Wohl, the Campaign Against Hunger's executive director, overheard Ms. Solana tell a counselor her educational background and, admiring her warm, forthright manner, hired her. 
"The danger is that in donating to food programs people think they're doing their bit," Ms. Wohl said, showing a visitor an empty storage room on the day before the food deliveries. "This is not the solution. The solution is that people have adequate incomes to walk in and make purchases like dignified human beings."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
Brother, Can You Spare a Billion?

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN attacking our country, terrorists inadvertently demolished more than the World Trade Center, part of the Pentagon and our collective sense of well-being. They also took out some major barriers to corporate welfare.
 How else to explain the sudden proliferation of government handouts to big companies? Some years ago, welfare for people was recognized as something to be restricted as much as possible for everyone's good, yet the venerable practice of handing out money to corporations has survived the rhetoric of the Clinton years and has flourished anew in the aftermath of Sept. 11. 
Like anyone who gets something for nothing, businesses love this stuff, even though it's bad for them -- and even more so for the companies that pay taxes and get no direct handouts. The total bill, after all, is enormous; Stephen Slivinski, a fiscal policy analyst at the Cato Institute, a research center in Washington, estimates that corporate welfare -- direct subsidies to business -- from the federal government amounted to $87 billion in fiscal 2001. 
That's a lot of money, but the cost to the overall economy is many times greater. For some reason, public officials who grasp instantly the case against welfare for people do not understand that the same arguments apply to companies. Welfare saps corporate initiative, for instance. It's an insult to low-wage workers struggling to get by, especially when the chief executive makes millions. And just as conventional welfare hurts the economy by removing some people's talents and energy from the marketplace, corporate welfare makes the economy less efficient by misallocating capital, propping up businesses that should be left to die and imposing a drag on successful ones.
How has corporate welfare blossomed of late? Let us count the ways. First, under cover of terrorism, the government has approved a $15 billion airline bailout. Although $10 billion of that would come as loan guarantees for which the government could at least demand warrants or some other reward for its risk, $5 billion is an outright gift to companies thoughtful enough to fly people around for profit. The airlines, of course, have been hurt by fear of terror and a general economic malaise, but so have cab drivers, hotel operators and tourist traps everywhere, none of whom can see any government help on the horizon. (That is not necessarily for want of trying; so far, travel agents and bus companies have both found advocates in Congress.)
Then there is the section of the House-approved economic stimulus plan that would abolish the corporate alternative minimum tax and refund 15 years' worth of payments to corporations. The nonpartisan Congressional Research Service figures that this gift would amount to a jaw-dropping $25 billion giveback to corporations including Ford Motor, General Motors and I.B.M.
Many other companies and industries are lining up for giveaways, too. In October, the House found time amid the din of terror and war to approve the Farm Security Act of 2001. The price of this appalling and irrational collection of agricultural subsidies is $170 billion over 10 years, and if you think this money will bail out the Joads on some dusty family farm, guess again. The main beneficiary of federal farm programs is agribusiness.
Industrialists are getting help, too. In early November, the United States International Trade Commission ruled that foreign steelmakers were hurting American producers by selling us hot-rolled steel too cheaply. That opens the way for the government to impose tariffs, in effect forcing the foreigners to charge us more -- and handing American steelmakers unearned profit. A group of American steelmakers has filed yet another anti-dumping petition with the Commerce Department, including among its targets some of our NATO allies and other countries whose help we might like in the war on terrorism.
The rush to provide welfare for business -- usually big business, at that -- may help a few companies and industries, but it will leave everyone worse off by reducing overall economic growth. Instead of fighting to get their share, enlightened companies should be fighting to get rid of such handouts. But corporate greed and compliant politicians are a tough combination. For too many companies, it is easier to make some campaign donations and then go on the dole.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
A Diversification Path Leads Abroad

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

 BODY:
INVESTORS who who have limited themselves to American stocks may want to consider shares of foreign companies that, by some measures, are among the strongest in the world.
 Many global blue chips that have outperformed the American market recently remain moderately priced, analysts say. Some of the stocks have the added virtue of convenience, with United States listings that make them as easy to trade as American shares. 
 "Valuations are reasonable, and the remarkable strength of the dollar makes this a good time to allocate overseas," said Shawn Johnson, research director at State Street Global Advisors in Boston. "To me, the strength of the dollar is more of a reason to put assets overseas now than the terrorism threat or the U.S. recession." 
Companies like Honda Motor, the ANZ Banking Group and Telefonos de Mexico rank among the strongest in the world on a composite measure of value and growth known as the prospective earnings growth, or P.E.G., ratio, according to FactSet Research Systems of Greenwich, Conn. 
The ratio, the price-to-earnings multiple of a company divided by a consensus estimate of expected earnings growth, is an important number for many investors. A low ratio suggests that each dollar of earnings is priced relatively cheaply -- and should become even cheaper because earnings are growing rapidly.
"Investing in stocks with a low P.E.G. ratio and strong price momentum can produce a positive return," Mr. Johnson said. But such measures are "not the be-all and end-all" in selecting stocks, he said, even if they are useful as starting points. 
A low ratio in itself is not always a sign of a strong company. Some stocks have low ratios because their share prices have plunged, a sign of trouble. That is why close attention to a company's recent performance and its competitive and financial position are essential companions of such an analysis, many financial professionals say.
Honda is a popular choice among analysts and fund managers who admire its management for its ability to thrive in in a sluggish economy. "We like Honda because it's the best in its sector," said Steve Tyson, head of global equities at the London office of AXA Investment Managers. Despite problems facing the global auto industry, like overcapacity, he said, "the company can grow market share, particularly in the States."
The United States accounts for the majority of Honda's sales and profits, but with only 7 percent of the American car market, Honda has room to grow. Its strategy has been to create a scarcity premium, Mr. Tyson said. "The philosophy of the company is that size doesn't matter," he said. "It has controlled capacity and brand image. The emphasis is on high-quality production. There are few fears of Honda having overcapacity."
Shahreza Yusof, a fund manager in Singapore for Aberdeen Asset Management, also likes Honda's strategy in the United States. "Waiting lists for the Acura MDX run to a few months, which is impressive in today's market environment," Mr. Yusof said, "and that leads to the industry's lowest costs regarding dealer incentives." He added that Honda had made "successful sharp cuts to production costs with each new model year." The strategy has been so successful that Honda, recession or not, is expected to pay off its debt this year. 
Almost all the large, attractively priced foreign companies traded in the United States are in developed markets, FactSet said. An exception is Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, the primary Mexican telephone company. The stock is a favorite of Scott Lewis, co-manager of the Credit Suisse Warburg Pincus Global Telecommunications fund. Emerging-markets phone companies like Telmex, Mr. Lewis said, "generally face less competition than their developed-market peers and are cheaper." 
Telmex benefits from a regulated operating environment but still has great earnings potential, he said. 
Telecommunications analysts at Merrill Lynch, who recommend buying the stock, point to the company's debt load, the lowest among similar companies in emerging markets, and its profit margins, the highest in the sector.
Safety is one of the stock's attractions for analysts at UBS Warburg. They like Telmex's strong cash-flow generation and its decision to reduce capital expenditures, which they estimate will save the company $300 million next year. 
Warburg also recommends buying ANZ, one of several Australian banks it favors, because the bank appears "conspicuously inexpensive against bond yields, fair value against the Australian market and fair value relative to global banks."
The bank focuses mainly on profitable activities like financial and investment services for retail clients, while limiting involvement in riskier ventures like securities underwriting, the analysts say. ANZ is doing a good job of cutting costs, improving efficiency and expanding its business overseas, according to Warburg.
Several pharmaceutical companies with strong growth prospects offer attractive values. Mark Pignatelli, a manager of Continental European equity portfolios at Schroder Investment Management in London, said he particularly liked Novo Nordisk of Denmark.
"Pharmaceuticals is the defensive area that we would sell last," Mr. Pignatelli said. 
Novo Nordisk's strength, he said, lies in its large share of the insulin market and in its NovoSeven anticlotting agent. Noting the drug's $70,000 yearly retail cost for a patient, he said, "to put it mildly, it's a high-margin product."
Simon Melluish, who is based in Conshohocken, Pa., and is responsible for North American equities at Gartmore Investment Management of London, said his funds owned shares of the Royal Bank of Canada. That bank "has been more adept at controlling costs and not paying top dollar" for brokerage assets compared with banks elsewhere, he said.
CANADIAN companies occupy a conspicuous share of the list of low-P.E.G., high-return stocks. Others include Manulife Financial, a life insurance company, and BCE, the holding company for the Bell Canada telephone business. 
"Valuations in Canada tend to be more muted than on Wall Street," Mr. Melluish said. "Manulife is one of three or four life companies that went public in the last two years. They came at good valuations, and operating results have been very good." 
Mr. Melluish described BCE as a north-of-the-border Baby Bell that benefits from its dominance of the tightly regulated market in local phone service while still being able to enter other, more open segments of the industry. BCE also disposed of its large stake in the equipment maker Nortel Networks before Nortel's stock plummeted with the piercing of the technology bubble.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN; 
Refurbishing a Courthouse, If Not Its Reputation

BYLINE:  By KELLY CROW

 BODY:
For nearly three years, the New York County Courthouse, better known as the Tweed Courthouse, had been shrouded in scaffolding as the city worked on an $85 million restoration.
 Three weeks ago, the metal wrapping came down, revealing a creamy, marble facade and a new granite staircase rippling down to Chambers Street. 
 Arl Danirov, the bagel cart vendor across the street, called the new view startling. 
"I have only been in New York a year, so I have never seen this before," Mr. Danirov said. "But you see now? It is so beautiful."
Wayne Taylor, a messenger who walks past the courthouse several times a day making deliveries in the City Hall area, stopped for a moment on Friday to admire the new beds of seaweed grass. He remembers what the building looked like before renovations began in May 1999 -- "old and dirty." Now he wonders what kind of work is being done inside.
"Hope it looks as good," he said.
Once again, the Tweed Courthouse is inspiring the curiosity of passers-by, though perhaps not as much as that surrounding its notorious construction from 1862 to 1878. William M. Tweed, or Boss Tweed, ringleader of the Democratic political machine known as Tammany Hall, is perhaps best remembered for having sunk more than $13 million of city money into the project and then funneling most of the money to himself and his cronies.
The courthouse's association with Tweed has stamped it with an air of corruption. Coincidentally, the city has acknowledged that current renovation costs more than doubled, growing from $37 million to $85 million, as the scope of the work expanded. But the work is expected to be completed by February, when the building is to be turned over to its incoming tenant, the Museum of the City of New York, and city officials say all that is needed are the finishing touches.
Last week, about 75 workers were installing bronze doorknobs and ornate, globe-shaped glass lamps in the courthouse's 28-foot-high rooms.
Architects had to refer to old photographs in replicating the fixtures; the originals were destroyed or carted away when the building was converted to a city courthouse in 1929 and to city offices later, said Michael Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which is overseeing the work.
The 52-foot-wide octagonal skylight above the rotunda has been redecorated with colored glass images of frogs and birds and flowers. All the indoor scaffolding is gone, as the recarving of the columns with pilaster capitals was finished last month. The cast-iron staircases still need to be grinded and repainted, and the floors have yet to be polished.
Outside, the staircase leading to the portico has regained 17 steps lost when the city expanded Chambers Street in 1942.
For Mr. Carey, it is this staircase that best symbolizes the courthouse's return to what he called "its historical integrity."
And what of its Tweed-tainted past?
"Now that we've so rehabilitated this building, maybe it's a good time to give it a good name," he said. "I don't have any ideas, but now the place is spectacular." KELLY CROW

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Tweed Courthouse again revealed in all its glory. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times) Chart: "MULTI-MILLION-DOLLAR BABY: The Palace on Chambers Street"The notorious history of the Tweed Courthouse can be told in numbers. Here is the short list:Amount the city appropriated for the new courthouse between 1862 and 1878: $13 million. Amount spent on thermometers for the building: $7,500. Amount spent on safes: $400,000. Amount paid to Andrew Garvey, the Tweed Ring's so-called Prince of Plasterers, for two days' work: $133,187. Amount paid to one carpenter for a month's work: $360,751. Amount estimated in May 1999 for the latest renovations: $37 million. Amount spent on renovations so far: $87 million.(Source: The Encyclopedia of New York City)
