HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Shaken Consumers Are Looking to Life Insurance

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
FOR years, life insurance was a hard sell. Even some companies that sold it began dropping "life insurance" from their names and calling themselves financial services companies. They recognized that Americans had become less interested in buying protection for their families than in making investments intended to make themselves comfortable in retirement.
 But the terrorist attacks turned life insurance into a hot commodity. 
 "Sept. 11 brought people's mortality back into focus," said Mickey Mann, a life insurance agent in Norman, Okla. "You can kiss your family goodbye and leave home and that's the last time you see them." 
Unlike some other kinds of insurance, life insurance has not increased in cost since the attacks. The companies are not charging more for customers who work in office towers, now regarded as potential terrorist targets. People in the riskiest jobs, like coal miners, have always paid more for life insurance, and they still do. And there have been no changes so far in the costs of coverage for mail handlers or airline crews, even with the threat of terrorism and anthrax infection. 
Life insurance rates are based on life expectancy of the entire American population; over all, rates are not affected by the relatively few people in dangerous jobs or locations. Still, the cost can vary by hundreds of dollars -- the only difference being the choice of companies. 
Across the country, sales of life insurance, which had been declining for years, jumped about 9 percent in October from the same month a year earlier, according to the MIB Group in Westwood, Mass., which compiles data for the industry. 
The average size of a life insurance policy has jumped, too. Byron Udell, the chief executive of the online insurer AccuQuote.com, said the average policy his firm had sold since the attacks was for $443,000, up from $383,000 in the months before Sept. 11. Other agents report that customers have been coming back to increase their coverage. Mr. Mann said one client, a hospital administrator in eastern Oklahoma, had quadrupled his coverage, to $2 million, while a businessman in central Texas had doubled his, to $500,000.
The whole pace of the business has quickened. "We used to get two or three calls a week on life insurance," said Mr. Mann, whose sales have jumped 30 percent since the attacks. "Now we're getting two or three a day. We used to get a lot of Looky-Lous, people just looking, trying to get prices. Now they're serious."
Shannon Curley, an insurance analyst at Banc of America Capital Management, said that estate planning had picked up again and that the sale of larger policies, intended to offset estate taxes, had accelerated. "The attacks reminded people they needed an estate plan," he said. "And the downturn in the economy and the cost of all the antiterrorism things makes it less likely that the estate tax will actually go away." 
Term insurance is the most popular type of policy. It is the least expensive and works well for people who want coverage only until their children are grown. It is sold for a specific term, in contrast to whole life insurance, which is intended to remain in force over a lifetime. Term life often costs less than 10 percent of what whole life costs, but it lacks whole life's savings feature, which accumulates money that can be borrowed against or spent.
A few weeks ago, Todd Munday, 30, who owns a mortgage brokerage firm in Norman, Okla., bought $250,000 of term life coverage for 20 years, at $41 a month. "Things seem to be happening all around us now," said Mr. Munday, who is married and has a 2-year-old son. "If something happened to me and my wife wasn't covered, well, I don't know. I've got a house payment, two car payments and I'm self-employed."
Manila Whitehorse, 38, the owner of a hair salon in Norman, decided that she needed more coverage. She already had $125,000 in whole life insurance and bought a $150,000 term life policy that runs for 30 years and costs her $29 a month. Her husband, John Clour, 51, plans to buy at least a $250,000 term policy after he graduates from law school in December. They have a 19-year-old son, Ryan, in college. "You realize how short life really is," Ms. Whitehorse said.
Both Mr. Munday and Ms. Whitehorse bought policies from the Fidelity & Guaranty Life Insurance Company that cost 20 to 30 percent more than the least expensive term policies, though the difference can be three times greater. But under the provisions of their policies, they will get all their money back if they pay premiums until the end of their coverage terms. (There is a danger: many people drop these "return of premium" policies after a few years and end up paying more than they would for standard ones.)
How much life insurance should anyone buy? Originally, life insurance was intended to cover burial expenses. As the idea expanded, many people began to regard the insurance as a financial bridge for survivors until they could find other income. For a long time now, it has been billed as a replacement for lost income so that survivors can go on without a change in lifestyle. Of course, independently wealthy people with few or no dependents may not need life insurance.
But for those who do, most experts say the right amount is now 10 times a policyholder's annual income. For someone earning $100,000 a year, that would be $1 million. Jackson National Life Insurance offers that coverage in a term policy for a 40-year-old man in excellent health for $740 a year; it is available for $745 from the Empire General Life Assurance Corporation and for $765 from General American Life Insurance, Mr. Udell said. Some companies, however, provide the same coverage for about $1,500, and one company, Employers Modern Life, charges $2,310.
Over all, prices for term life insurance have been dropping because of competition and because people have been living longer. That means companies can collect premiums longer and pay fewer death benefits. 
Five years ago, for example, a $500,000 policy for a 40-year-old man in excellent health cost as little as $830. Now, Mr. Udell said, three companies -- Banner Life Insurance, General American Life Insurance and West Coast Life Insurance -- offer the same coverage for $420. That is $60 less than in early 2000, when prices jumped briefly after state regulators required insurers to add to their expenses by increasing their reserves. But some companies are selling the same coverage for about $800 and one company, Employers Modern Life, offers the coverage at $1,170, Mr. Udell said.
COMPARISON shopping is important. Not long ago, there were two ways to do so: by contacting several companies or by calling a broker who represents a handful of them. But the Internet has simplified the process in many ways. You can click to AccuQuote.com or Quotesmith.com, for example, answer a few questions and, in a few minutes, have some price quotations.
But price is not the only consideration. Experts suggest sticking with companies with financial strength ratings of A or better from rating agencies. For term policies, they also recommend a feature called convertibility. It permits a policyholder to shift automatically into a whole life policy when a term policy expires, without submitting to a medical examination. Without that feature, a person whose health is deteriorating as the term insurance runs out could face a staggering price for another policy or be denied coverage.
In buying coverage over the Internet, however, some prospective buyers provide overly rosy assessments of their health. That can result in a low price, but one that an insurer will not honor if a medical examination turns up conflicting information. In that case, experts say, it is often better to start the search again rather than to accept an adjusted price. An insurer who offers great prices for people who are in excellent health may not be competitive on coverage for people who are not. 
Other complications can arise. Companies can be idiosyncratic in assessing risk -- some may be happy to insure scuba divers and pilots of small planes at their best rates while others charge extra. Smokers may find different rates at different companies. Insurers also have varying definitions of dangerously high cholesterol levels or different standards for height and weight ratios, used to measure obesity.
All this makes it difficult to buy insurance on the Internet without the help of an agent. One tactic is to use the Internet to get an idea of prices, then to go to an agent. AccuQuote combines both approaches. It provides some comparative price quotations but also has an agent contact a prospective customer.
Most companies using the Internet have yet to offer discounts for bypassing a commissioned agent.
Cathy Riddle, 34, who is pregnant with her first child, and her husband, Paul, 31, computer programmers who live in Elkridge, Md., did not turn to the Internet for life insurance. They checked with their employer and with an agent referred by a friend. The agent's price was better: two policies of $1.25 million each for 20 years from Transamerica Life Insurance, at $900 a year in premiums for her, $1,300 for him.
They wrapped up the deal in two phone calls. "We were pretty sold that we needed life insurance," Mrs. Riddle said. "Now, anytime you travel, you never know what's going to happen."

Pricing a Policy
Here are a few Web sites that can provide information on life insurance rates.

HEADLINE: By Any Name, It's the Mercedes of Cargo Vans 

BYLINE:  By NORMAN S. MAYERSOHN 

 BODY:
ARE American tradesmen and delivery people ready for the Sprinter commercial van by Mercedes-Benz? My plumber would appear to be; he motored up in a vintage 560 SL roadster to give an estimate for a new bathroom. Given the size of that estimate, he may be able to afford several Sprinters.
 Alas, if he should decide to haul his drain snakes and pipe wrenches in one, he will have to make do without a three-pointed star on the grille. The new work van will carry the name of Freightliner, the American truck subsidiary of DaimlerChrysler, along with badges that say, "Powered by Mercedes-Benz." 
 DaimlerChrysler officials say they chose to market the Sprinter this way because Freightliner is their recognized channel for commercial vehicles. But they were also mindful of the impression that might arise if a carpenter arrived in a vehicle that Americans associate with luxury.
But even without the gleaming wood trim and leather-wrapped thrones of Mercedes luxury sedans, the Sprinter may attract a devoted following. Since its introduction in Western Europe in 1995, it has become the best-selling commercial delivery van. In this country, FedEx has agreed to buy 1,900 of the distinctive slope-nosed Sprinters.
The Sprinter's agility, compared with heavy-duty versions of the Ford Econoline or Chevy Express vans, may be a big attraction in crowded cities. "The vehicle was originally designed for small and tight European streets, so the turning circle is amazingly short," said Tim Reuss, president and chief executive of DaimlerChrysler Vans in Huntersville, N.C.
The Sprinter gets its power from an advanced five-cylinder diesel engine, the same one installed in the Mercedes E270 sedan in Europe -- but not emissions-certified for use in passenger cars in the United States. The 2.7-liter power plant is rated at 156 horsepower and is paired with the five-speed automatic transmission from the S-Class luxury sedan.
Because the engine uses energy-efficient technologies like direct fuel injection -- a design in which the fuel is delivered straight to the engine's cylinders for combustion -- the Sprinter can achieve 22 m.p.g., according to Mercedes-Benz, about 20 percent better than competitors.
Safety features include four-wheel antilock disc brakes, a stability control and dual air bags on trucks with passenger seats.
Both cargo and passenger models come in three wheelbase configurations, two weight-capacity ratings and two roof heights. Cargo models are assembled in Gaffney, S.C., from component kits prepared in Germany, at a plant where Freightliner builds medium-duty trucks.
Don't worry about a flood of Sprinters filling the spaces outside your next P.T.A. meeting. Although individuals can buy and register the vans, these plus-size carriers -- with up to three times the cargo space of a Honda Odyssey -- are unlikely to lure many soccer moms from their Caravans and Expeditions.
The first of the cargo models went on sale this fall starting at $27,075; passenger vans, destined for duty as airport shuttles, range from $28,525 to $35,325. DaimlerChrysler hopes sales will reach 7,000 a year, through a network of 50 Freightliner dealers.
The decision to bring the Sprinter to North America was driven by a perception that e-commerce would fuel huge demand for home deliveries. While the dot-com decline altered that view, Mr. Reuss still sees great potential for his maxi-van.
"The market opportunity now is very interesting," he said. "And Sprinter is the only cargo van specifically designed for the purpose. It's not a derivation."

HEADLINE: School Budget Cuts 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Economy Puts Schools in Tough Position" (news article, Nov. 26) did not put into context the spending reductions proposed by Gov. Gray Davis of California. 
Even with the proposed $843 million cut, Mr. Davis will still have provided education with a year-over-year increase of well over $1 billion, in a year when state revenues will be down as much as $14 billion. The amount of increased state spending on education over the last three years is 10 times greater than the amount of the proposed cuts. 
 The vast majority of the proposed spending reductions are targeted at new programs that have not been put into effect, programs that have left unspent money provided to them by the state or programs that will simply be delayed. The proposed cuts spare essential classroom programs as well as after-school programs serving 1.2 million students.

KERRY MAZZONI
Secretary for Education
State of California
Sacramento, Nov. 26, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS; 
Flying to Santo Domingo, Rum in Hand, for Holidays

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
New York's Dominicans may soon have another carrier to ferry them on the immensely popular air route to their homeland. The move will challenge American Airlines, which is now the only commercial airline that flies from Kennedy International Airport to Santo Domingo. 
 "Perfect, magnificent," said Olga Corniel, a home attendant from Washington Heights. "If it's new, that's what we need." 
 The rival airline is Peru's Aero Continente. It plans to begin daily flights from Kennedy to Santo Domingo on Dec. 10. The announcement comes with airlines still suffering the economic and psychological aftereffects of Sept. 11. It also comes just weeks after American Airlines Flight 587 to Santo Domingo crashed over Belle Harbor, Queens, although the move was planned long before the accident. 
Pending expected approval from the United States Department of Transportation, Aero Continente will begin daily departures at 12:30 p.m. from Kennedy to Santo Domingo and on to Lima in time for the heavy travel of the Christmas season. 
American operates four flights a day to Santo Domingo during the holiday season. With most of those flights fully booked between now and Christmas, many Dominicans welcome more planes on the route. Aero Continente will have 290 seats on its new daily flight.
Many Dominicans also welcome the competition. Although Continental Airlines operates some flights from Newark, many Dominicans say American has a virtual monopoly, with tickets often topping $600. Ms. Corniel said she avoided flying home at Christmas because of the "super high" prices.
Aero Continente says it will offer a peak-season rate of $399 for a round trip.
"It's a shame that the Dominican Republic does not have a national airline that can cover the New York route," said Anthony Duran, the new general manager for Aero Continente's New York operations, adding, "American is taking advantage."
Marty Heires, a spokesman for American Airlines, said, "We welcome the competition." He added, "We feel we have a loyal customer base in Santo Domingo and we're going to continue to do the best job we can." He would not comment on pricing strategy.
Aero Continente is planning to make its service culturally appropriate.
"We will be the Latino option for our customers," said Jose Ares, the airline's general manager in Santo Domingo. Thirty Latin American flight attendants are now training in the Dominican Republic for the flights from Kennedy. Free Dominican rum will be served on board, and a typical meal might consist of rice, beans and beef, said Mr. Duran, a meal often referred to as "the Dominican flag." American has stopped serving meals on some of its flights.
But not everything will be Latin. Because Aero Continente does not currently have enough employees to work the flights, it has hired an outside company to provide the plane and cockpit crew, a common practice. The aircraft and pilot flying Dominican immigrants home this holiday season will be Icelandic. SETH KUGEL

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Peruvian airline will give Dominicans another option. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/John J. McCabeAnd Mark F. Trautman; 
M.S.B. Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
FORECASTING what consumers, businesses and investors will do during normal times is as difficult as trying to put a pair of pants on an elephant, says John J. McCabe co-manager of the $58 million M.S.B. Fund. 
 Trying to do so after the events of Sept. 11 is utterly futile, he said, yet he and his co-manager, Mark F. Trautman, still make such forecasts, believing that it is sensible to buy stocks as long as they keep a truly long-term view in mind. "We will make some mistakes, but we do our homework, and time, patience and history are on our side," Mr. McCabe said from his office in Midtown Manhattan. "We plan to keep our companies for a long, long time." 
 In 2000, the fund's turnover rate was a tiny 15 percent, versus more than 100 percent for the average domestic diversified stock fund, according to Morningstar Inc. 
The fund returned 2.9 percent a year, on average, in the three years ended Thursday, versus a 0.1 percent loss for all large blend funds and a 0.2 percent decline for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, Morningstar said. It lost 4.2 percent in the last 12 months, versus a 14.9 percent loss for its group and a 13.9 percent loss for the S.& P.
Mr. McCabe, 58, is senior vice president of Shay Assets Management, the fund's investment adviser, which is based in Chicago and manages about $3 billion for seven mutual funds and for institutions. Mr. Trautman, 36, is vice president of Shay. Though the fund is open to all investors, it was originally intended as an investment portfolio for employees of New York State mutual savings banks, hence the name M.S.B.
The managers describe themselves as Graham-and-Dodd investors. In 1934, Benjamin Graham and David L. Dodd wrote "Security Analysis," the classic text for value investors. Perhaps their most famous disciple is Warren Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, M.S.B.'s biggest holding, at about 6 percent of assets.
Berkshire Hathaway owns General Re, one of the largest global reinsurers. "Their rates have gone up quite a bit," Mr. McCabe said, "which should more than offset the payments that they will be required to make on account of Sept. 11, which won't occur for a number of years because it will take time to evaluate and pay off the claims."
The managers pick the 25 to 30 stocks in the fund from among United States companies with market capitalization of at least $5 billion. They look for companies that are dominant in their businesses, with consistent growth in long-term cash flow in established industries. They also want solid management and significant free cash flow -- what is left after capital expenses.
Because they look for sustainable competitive advantages, the managers typically avoid technology companies. Two exceptions are Intel and Microsoft, which dominate their markets, Mr. Trautman said.
The managers prefer companies with ratios of debt to market capitalization below 50 percent, depending on the industry, as a cushion during periods of economic weakness. They also want returns on capital of at least 15 percent over five years or more.
To value a company, they calculate an internal rate of return by forecasting the share price 10 years ahead, based on probable cash flow. Generally, they want that rate to average at least 12 to 15 percent a year. 
On Sept. 21, the fund bought shares of the State Street Corporation of Boston, a provider of investment services and management, at an average of $39.57. The price exceeded $50 in the summer but fell during the general market decline after Sept. 11 and is now at $52.34. State Street's business has grown consistently, Mr. Trautman said, and he expects the company to generate an internal rate of return of 11 or 12 percent a year in the next 10 years.
The managers bought shares of Procter & Gamble in July at an average of $69.62; they now trade at $77.46. The company's growth slowed early last year, Mr. McCabe said, as name-brand products in the paper products area, including Bounty paper towels and Charmin toilet tissue, were hurt by higher raw-material costs and increased competition. The stock had traded at more than $100 in early 2000.
"We don't mind buying a low-growth company if it is reflected in the stock price," he said. He expects a long-term internal rate of return averaging 11 percent.
The slowdown in consumer spending also pushed down the stock of Sherwin-Williams, the paint company in Cleveland. The fund bought shares in January at an average of $24.66; they had traded as high as $26 in the spring of 2000.
"People are pricing the company as if it will have low same-store sales growth or none at all," Mr. Trautman said. "When the economy rebounds, people will buy more paint." 
He expects an 11 percent internal rate of return in the next 5 to 10 years.
The stock closed on Friday at $27.99.

HEADLINE: Small, Stunned 

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ

 BODY:
VINCENT AU'S mother says that God messes with her son. Twice he has faced death. Twice he has lived. He has given both those lives to his work.
 Mr. Au, a 31-year-old stockbroker, founded a small brokerage firm called Avalon Partners in 1998. The next year, he and two employees moved into a modest office on the 18th floor of 2 World Trade Center. On Aug. 13, 2001, the company relocated to a spacious new office on the 84th floor of the north tower. 
 All that is gone now.
Large corporate tenants of the twin towers -- Cantor Fitzgerald, Marsh & McLennan -- have naturally loomed large in reports of the tragedy. But thousands of small businesses, like Avalon, were also directly affected by the Sept. 11 attack. 
According to the CoStar Group, a real estate information service, nearly two-thirds of the tenants of the trade center occupied less than 10,000 square feet, modest digs in the corporate world.
Some of these small ventures have vanished. Others, like Avalon Partners, are beginning their struggles through the afterlife. For many, like Mr. Au, the scramble to rebuild is a sad if strenuous re-enactment of their efforts to create the ventures in the first place.
Economically, the revival of these small businesses is crucial. According to J. P. Morgan Chase, before the attacks there were nearly 7,800 businesses with annual revenues of less than $10 million at ground zero, and about 34,800 of them south of 14th Street.
Modest enterprises like Avalon Partners have been a major engine of growth for the city. But unlike larger firms, many of these companies have no backup systems, little infrastructure, small staffs and limited access to credit. And anyway, achieving the outward signs of recovery -- finding a new office, buying new computers -- does not alone reinflate the client list, restore morale or revive other intangibles. Replacing the tools does not mean the old world will return.
"Every time you think you have a leg up on it," Mr. Au said of his climb toward recovery, "another thing happens."
On Sept. 11, Vincent Au escaped with his life. Now comes the hard part.
Mr. Au, whose parents emigrated from Hong Kong when he was 2 months old, drives a silver Porsche Boxster and has his suits tailored at Peppino's on the Upper East Side. But he was lured into the financial services industry by the promise of free food.
Growing up in Chinatown and New Springville, Staten Island, Mr. Au (pronounced ow) attended Pace University, where he majored in finance and later got an M.B.A. As a freshman, he found a job making "cold calls" for a brokerage firm. The position offered $5 an hour and pizza or McDonald's three nights a week, a big jump over his summer job as a cook at the Roy Rogers across from the World Trade Center.
"I was giddy," said Mr. Au, a single man with an open face and an easy demeanor. "I really liked the job, and quite frankly, I'm not too good at too many other things."
While still a teenager, Mr. Au became a licensed broker. "I could sell stock, but I couldn't legally drink alcohol," he said. He spent the next decade tearing through a series of small brokerage firms. Soon, the money came pouring in. In 1994, he moved into a one-bedroom apartment in Battery Park City, paying just under $2,000 a month. The next year, he bought a black BMW for $55,000.
Through it all, Mr. Au had some collisions with the securities establishment. According to his record at the National Association of Securities Dealers, he was "discharged" from two jobs and "permitted to resign" from another. In one instance, the association suspended his license for 10 days, fined him $5,000 and required him to retake an industry exam.
"Like everybody else, I made a mistake," Mr. Au said about his record. "It's done."
But Mr. Au also has his own gripes with the industry. He particularly chafes at what he sees as the pressures that Wall Street firms place on their brokers.
"Everybody has a list of stocks they want their brokers to promote," he said. "Half of them are based on the fact that they have a banking relationship with them."
One reason he founded Avalon, Mr. Au said, was to challenge that system. The firm, which he started with Peter Bull, an English client, would dispense investment advice without engaging in underwriting, which might endanger its objectivity.
"If we have a firm motto, it's that we want to give everybody a fair shake," said Mr. Au, who is not unfamiliar with the persuasive arts. "That's all the investment public can really ask for."
Mr. Bull provided the bulk of the $350,000 start-up money. "I had no reason to trust him, but I did," Mr. Bull said. "It turned out to be a good move."
Mr. Au had a list of 500 clients from his years in the business, but that was about his only asset. Even Office Depot wouldn't give him a line of credit. "How do you want me to get credit if you don't extend credit?" Mr. Au asked.
He did not have a name for his fledgling company, either. "I spent two weekends in a row at the Barnes & Noble looking for a Latin phrase or a Greek name that would really serve me well," he said. "All the good names were taken." Eventually, he found his inspiration at Park Avalon, a restaurant on Park Avenue South South he visited regularly to see a bartender friend.
In bringing Avalon to life, Mr. Au ran up $30,000 in debt on his credit cards, beyond the money from Mr. Bull. "Sometimes I was afraid to go home," he said. "I thought Visa might have a hit man waiting for me." 
His parents were anxious, too. "We were very upset by his experiments in finance," said his father, George Au, an assistant manager in accounting at Citigroup, at which he has worked for more than 30 years. "We didn't know if he could afford to run the business."
"My parents are very button-down conservative," said Mr. Au, calling his father "a loyal company man."
"They would have loved to see me become a doctor, an accountant, something that's more stable than riding the peaks and troughs of Wall Street."
But Mr. Au sought something different. "I wanted to work for myself," he said. He dreamed of building a boutique brokerage firm with offices in Europe, Asia and the United States.
It is the vision of a driven man. "In high school he was all about tennis," said his younger brother, Terry. But in college, Mr. Au's competitiveness found a new outlet in finance. 
One clue to his singlemindedness is that Vincent Au can recite more than 300 phone numbers from memory. But nearly all the numbers are clients'; Terry's number he has to look up.

A First Brush With Death
On July 5, 1998, just before Avalon Partners was to open, Mr. Au was on his way to dinner in Chinatown when a truck ran a red light, causing him to crash his BMW into a hair salon. "I almost died," he said. He was hospitalized for more than a month. 
So instead of taking shape in a proper office, Avalon Partners was born in Mr. Au's Battery Park City apartment. (He moved out in spring 2000.) His mother took a two-month leave of absence from her job as a service agent at Verizon and helped him with everything from having phone lines installed to cooking dinner.
"I got on my walker, then my crutches, then my cane," Mr. Au said. "I rolled out of bed, turned on CNBC, and worked at my kitchen table for seven or eight months." 
Then, in April 1999, he hired a broker and a secretary and moved into an office for $4,000 a month on the 18th floor of the south tower.
"It was such a great leap forward," he said. "It was a validation of the work I had put in. It wasn't much -- 1,100 square feet, two offices, and a little open area -- but it was mine and it was great."
It was also good for business.
"Being a small firm, when you're talking to a client overseas and you tell them your office is in the World Trade Center, your respectability goes up a huge amount," he said. "They knew, O.K., I'm not calling you from a Chinese restaurant. I'm a legitimate company."
He "fired" his mother.
"I never paid my mom," he said. "She doesn't want money. She wants me to get married and give her half a dozen grandchildren." 
Avalon's clients, Mr. Au said, include homemakers, chief executives, football players and physicians, with from $10,000 to $10 million in assets.
The firm has no money for a research staff, so Mr. Au researches investment opportunities himself. Sometimes friends at large brokerage houses give him research reports. Avalon brokers also come up with their own ideas.
Mr. Au himself prefers stocks that have plummeted in value, an investment strategy that requires fearless optimism. "We don't dance on anybody's grave," he said. "But we do like companies that are distressed and out of favor."
One favorite is Ericsson, the Swedish telecom giant. Its stock traded above $26 in March 2000 and closed Friday at $5.46 on Nasdaq. Mr. Au said it could "easily double" in the next 6 to 12 months. 
One of Mr. Au's first clients, Harper LeBel, who was a tight end for the Baltimore Ravens and other pro football teams, said: "He told me, 'I buy stocks like your wife shops for clothes. I look for a discount.' "
Mr. LeBel also said Mr. Au doesn't sit on stocks for long. "Vincent is not a buy-and-hold guy," the investor said. "Sometimes I tease him. I said if you've got this stock after lunch I'd be surprised."
As the years passed, the firm grew. In late 1999, Avalon Partners opened an office in Frankfurt, to be run by some former colleagues of Mr. Au. Last year, Mr. Au said, the firm's revenues were $1.5 million, up from $150,000 in 1998.
"In the three or four months before Sept. 11, things were really picking up," Mr. Bull said. The firm had 2,500 clients and was managing more than $50 million in assets. The New York office had 11 employees and the Frankfurt office 15.
Mr. Au and Mr. Bull were also gambling on a big expansion of their headquarters. On Aug. 13, Avalon moved up to an office on the 84th floor of the north tower that was five times the size and cost of the old one, 5,300 square feet at just under $20,000 a month. Within a year, they hoped to have 35 employees and revenues of $4 million. On the drawing board were plans for offices on the West Coast and in London and Hong Kong.
"Even though he wasn't born here, it's the American dream," Mr. Au's father said.
The new furniture came. So did an airplane.

Pursued by a Dust Cloud
On Sept. 11, Mr. Au arrived at work at 7:30 a.m., as usual. Victor Wald and Gary Lam, both brokers, were the only other employees there. Mr. Au was drinking tea and reading the newspaper when a plane crashed into Tower 1, about 12 floors above his office. He thought it was a bomb.
He gathered his employees and followed some Japanese bankers to an intact exit. The men were soon separated in the crowded stairway. 
"Victor was right with me," Mr. Au said. "Then he became right behind me, and then. . . ."
It took him nearly an hour to get out of the building. Outside, debris was falling. He headed for his father's office on Wall Street.
"When I got to the Federal Reserve building, I heard people screaming," Mr. Au said. "I looked back and all I saw was this thousand-foot-high dust cloud coming at me."
He ran. "People were falling, I just hopped over them, one bad leg and all," he said. Then, exhausted, he sat down and said to the onrushing cloud, "Hey, you got me. If I die, you got me here." 
The dust came, but Mr. Au made it to his father's office, where they waited for the second tower, Mr. Au's tower, to fall.
It did. Down came the new cherry-wood chairs, the tax files, the client records, the 20 new Dell computers, the 20 new Hewlett-Packard printers and the $21,000 phone system. Down came the Derek Jeter baseball and the "Jerry Maguire" poster autographed by Tom Cruise. Down came the list of leads and the five-year plan.
Mr. Lam had survived, but Mr. Wald was missing. He was last seen sitting on a staircase in the tower, unable to move.

New Office, Few Supplies
"This whole thing hurt me more because my work is my shelter," Mr. Au said of the Sept. 11 attack.
Some of the pain could be measured. The company lost $85,000 worth of new furniture and equipment. By Oct. 5, Mr. Au had poured a third of the company's cash reserves into rebuilding. For weeks, revenues hovered around 15 percent of normal. Only part of the losses were insured. "We just got a thank-you note from Workbench because we bought all that furniture," Mr. Au said. "It's kind of funny. Not funny."
The Workbench delivery, which arrived at the end of August, was supposed to take six to eight weeks. "I befriended the manager at the store," Mr. Au said. "We got it in three weeks."
Some things could not be measured. "I cannot sleep at night," he said. "Things spook you a lot more. When a truck hits a pothole, that bang. . . ." 
On Oct. 8, Avalon Partners opened for business at its new office on the 34th floor of 60 Broad Street. Mr. Au signed a 10-year lease for the space, which is one block from the New York Stock Exchange. "I don't want anybody chasing me out," he said, explaining the location and the long lease. "It's our home. If we leave, they win."
The office overlooks ground zero. From their desks, the employees can see too much of the river. The spot where the twin towers used to be is filled with the glorious blue of the Hudson.
Four brokers and one trader showed up for work Oct. 8. They didn't have business cards, stationery, a copier, a fax machine or printers. They could not make international phone calls. The secretary did not show up. Some cabinet keys were missing. They had no permanent phone number to give clients.
Tom Maiden, one broker, stared at his dark computer screen. How do you work without a computer? "You don't," he said.
Branden Gillespie, 24, had got his first job as a broker at Avalon Partners last July. He made cold calls and $250 a week. "This guy Osama bin Laden robbed me," Mr. Gillespie said that day. "I was just taking off financially." With his list of prospective clients lying amid the rubble, he said, "That phone weighs about 400 pounds right now. I don't want to pick it up."
In the next several weeks, there was progress, but it was fitful. Dell Computer gave Mr. Au 30 percent off on 10 new computers. But then the phones stopped working, and everyone stayed home for three days. Mr. Au's loan from the Small Business Administration has yet to be approved, and he has made little progress on reconstructing lost client records.
Still, by last week, most of the logistics were in place. Mr. Au was able to think about growth, not just recovery. He hired a new broker and expects four more to arrive soon. Today, he estimated, revenues are about 50 percent of normal. "We're a lot more focused on the work," he said. 
But time and energy have not healed all. Last week, the office was still heavy with quiet. No jokes flew across the room.
"Monetarily it was bad, but it wasn't a death sentence," Mr. Au said. "What hurt us more than anything else was the morale."
The firm had been at a high point before Sept. 11. Employees were excited about the new space, the new recruits, the expansion. After Sept. 11, the team began to fall apart. 
Some brokers were upset by the way the rebuilding was handled by Mr. Au, who defends his acts as the best possible in trying times. Mr. Lam, seeing "no future at Avalon," resigned in late October. Since early November Mr. Gillespie has been on a leave of absence, trying to get a handle on his post-Sept. 11 world.
"It's a rough patch right now," said Mr. Au, who hopes that as business improves morale will, too. "It's like something that's in the air. You can't put your finger on it. Even though everything else in your body tells you to move on, to get over it, it's like a lingering cold that won't go away."
But while Avalon sits under the spell of a strange sickness, the clock is ticking. The markets move. Money is made.
"We have a phrase in Chinese from when I was a kid," Mr. Au said. "In English translation it goes, 'Which is more valuable: An ounce of gold or an ounce of time?' Of course being a capitalist, an ounce of gold. I didn't figure it out. You can't buy time back."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
The Stock Market Must Rise in 2002? Think Again

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
STATISTICIANS refer to it as the gamblers' fallacy: betting that the odds of an event's occurrence depend on previous events that in fact have no relationship to it.
 If the ball in a roulette wheel lands on red four times in a row, for example, many gamblers believe that on the fifth spin there is a much higher-than-average chance that the ball will land on black. Of course, the odds of landing on black are static: they do not change, regardless of the sequence of reds and blacks that have come before. 
 The gamblers' fallacy is much in evidence among investment advisers these days. Many of the advisory newsletters that I monitor have contended in recent weeks that equities must rise in 2002, a view based on the claim that the United States stock market has never declined for three years in a row. (They are making the seemingly safe assumption that 2001 will go down in the record books as a second consecutive year of losses, since the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down almost 14 percent with just a month remaining.) 
The argument is based on both bad history and sloppy statistical reasoning. 
Consider the most striking counterexample, from the Depression years of the early 1930's. After declining in both 1930 and 1931, stocks should have risen in 1932, according to their theory. Instead, the market was further rocked, declining by 42.9 percent, as measured by the Standard & Poor's Composite Index, the precursor to the S.& P. 500.
What about 1933, the year after that? Stocks lost an additional 8.6 percent, for a fourth consecutive year of decline.
Some newsletter editors concede that there is no certainty that stocks will rise after two down years, but they still believe that the odds of their doing so are much higher than average. To find the right way to respond to their argument, I analyzed the stock market's yearly gyrations back to 1872. Over those 129 years, there were eight occasions in which the stock market, as measured by the S.& P. Composite Index or the S.& P. 500, declined for two years in a row. In the calendar years immediately after those eight occasions, the stock market rose in six of them -- or 75 percent of the time.
Such odds may strike you as good enough to justify placing an outsized bet that stocks will climb in 2002. But you would be wrong, since the stock market rises in most years anyway. The 75 percent average is, in fact, statistically indistinguishable from the percentage of years in which the stock market rises in general. Over the last 129 years, stocks have climbed in 95 of them, or 74 percent of the time. 
The inescapable conclusion is that the stock market's yearly gyrations are independent of one another. If the future is like the past, there is about a three-in-four chance that the stock market will rise next year. Those are not bad odds, but they have nothing to do with the fact that 2000 was a down year and that 2001 is likely to be, too.
IT does not follow from this conclusion, however, that all movements of the stock market are random. Instead, investors should conclude that the patterns that exist in the stock market do not manifest themselves in neat and tidy calendar-year intervals.
Researchers in recent years have discovered a number of exploitable patterns. Stocks that trade at very low price-to-book ratios, for example, tend to have above-average performance. So do stocks of companies where insiders are buying, rather than selling, shares, and where stock repurchasing programs are in place.
Investors, then, should focus on these
patterns, not on the sequencing of the
stock market's calendar-year gains and losses.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Metal Stocks Gain Ground Amid Cuts In Production

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO 

 BODY:
WITH profits tumbling and mines closing, producers of base metals would appear to be enduring the worst of times.
 Yet companies like Alcoa and Alcan in aluminum, Inco and Falconbridge in nickel and Phelps Dodge in copper have been popular with investors in recent weeks, outpacing the broader market. 
 Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, announced on Nov. 19 that it was eliminating 6,500 jobs and would take an after-tax charge of $200 million to $250 million in the fourth quarter. But its stock has climbed 36 percent, to $38.60, since it fell to $28.30 on Sept. 21. 
Other metals stocks have fared well since their lows in the aftermath of Sept. 11. Phelps Dodge, based in Phoenix, is up 39percent since Sept. 26, closing on Friday at $35.83. Inco, based here, has climbed almost 46 percent, to $16.10, since Sept. 26. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, by comparison, is up 21 percent since its low on Sept. 21.
The jump in these stocks reflects a rise in commodity prices. The price of copper, the most widely used industrial metal, is often regarded as an early indicator of manufacturing activity. It jumped to over 75 cents a pound last week, from 63 cents in mid-October, its lowest level in almost a decade. Aluminum was up to 65 cents a pound last week, from 59 cents in early November. 
The spurts have occurred despite economic data that continues to paint a bleak picture of the world economy. The Commerce Department reported last week that industrial output in the United States fell for the 13th month in a row in October. 
Nevertheless, investors have taken heart from two developments. One is a rise in long-term interest rates, inspiring predictions that the worst of the downturn may be over. The other is the move by producers of copper, nickel, aluminum and zinc to cut output, to bring supply in line with demand.
Indeed, the impetus for the market rally was the announcement by Phelps Dodge on Oct. 23 that it was curtailing copper production by 220,000 metric tons a year. Since then, BHP Billiton of Australia has cut 170,000 tons annually from operations in Chile and Peru. Several other companies have followed suit.
"We've had a pretty good portfolio of cutbacks," said Terence S. Ortslan, whose research company in Montreal tracks base metals. "We needn't worry about demand or inventories now. That will come later".
Investors also appear to be banking on merger and takeover moves to help base metal stocks. WMC, an Australian producer of alumina, nickel and copper, said on Nov. 21 that it was rejecting a takeover bid by Alcoa and splitting into two businesses, partly to encourage competitive bids for its constituent parts. Its stock fell after the announcement but then rallied somewhat.
Some companies are more sensitive than others to price changes in the underlying commodities. Phelps Dodge is among the most responsive in that way. The company says its pretax earnings rise or fall about $20 million, or 25 a cents a share, for each one-cent move in the price of a pound of copper. Inco says its earnings move about 15 cents a year for every 10-cent-a-pound change in nickel prices. 
Aluminum producers, on the other hand, rely more on manufactured products, especially for the automotive and packaging industries. In the process, analysts say, their earnings are becoming less volatile. Anthony B. Rizzuto Jr., an analyst at Bear Stearns in New York, has set a price target of $45 for Alcoa within the next 12 months.
Michael F. Gambardella, mining analyst at J. P. Morgan in New York, says the "enormous" balance sheet and borrowing capacity of Alcoa put it at the top his list of favorites.
But not everyone is convinced that the fire under metal and mining stocks will burn as strongly as it has in recent weeks. Lawrence Smith, an analyst at TD Newcrest in Toronto, said he was "leery" of the sector. "You need to have an improving trend in industrial production globally, and I think that's still some way off," Mr. Smith said.
The recent surge in Inco's share price led John Redstone, an analyst at Scotia Capital in Montreal, to downgrade the stock to "buy" from "strong buy" last week. In a report, Mr. Redstone predicted that nickel consumption in Western countries would fall 2.9 percent this year but would grow 4 percent in 2002 as stainless-steel production picked up.
Moody's Investors Service said it was reviewing the credit rating of Noranda, a copper and aluminum producer based in Toronto, for a possible downgrade. According to Moody's, "conditions in the metal industry are expected to remain challenging well into 2002." 
The challenge for investors may be to decide whether the recent action in commodity markets heralds an upturn in the overall economy. If so, base metal stocks could be strong performers in the coming months. If not, the stocks could founder.
Mr. Gambardella of J. P. Morgan, for one, has concluded that "the easy money has been made already" in the sector.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
PatriotBond Sales To Begin This Month

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer 

 BODY:
The Treasury will begin selling Patriot Bonds this month, but unlike the war bonds of the 1940's, these savings bonds will not generate revenue designated for a particular national purpose.
 The money will go into the Treasury's general coffers and, like all other revenue, "will contribute to the federal government's overall effort to fight the war on global terrorism," the department said. 
The House and the Senate had separately approved bills calling for "war bonds" but have not enacted legislation. The Treasury, which originally was not enthusiastic about the proposal, has moved ahead on its own, inscribing a variation on the standard Series EE savings bonds as Patriot Bonds. 
The bonds will be available at the middle of the month in denominations of $50 to $10,000, the Treasury said, and will be sold at banks and through a Treasury Web site, www.savingsbonds.com. Like other EE bonds, they will be sold at half their face value. Until April 2002, they offer a yield of 4.07 percent.
By comparison, the Treasury's inflation-adjusted bonds, or I bonds, also offered in denominations beginning at $50, now offer a yield of 4.40 percent, which includes a guaranteed inflation adjustment. The I bonds do not carry the Patriot inscription.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
Gains for Social Screening

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer 

 BODY:
 Assets in so-called socially responsible investment portfolios grew 36 percent, to $2.03 trillion, from 1999 to 2001, according to the Social Investment Forum, a nonprofit organization that includes mutual funds, community development organizations and portfolio managers. 
 The group defined socially responsible investing as involving at least one of these three strategies: shareholder advocacy, community investing and avoiding stocks that shareholders find objectionable. It said 230 mutual funds now incorporated social screening, compared with 168 in 1999. Screens to eliminate tobacco stocks are the most widely used, the group said. Other screens eliminate companies involved in weapons, alcohol and gambling or look for companies that promote human rights, equality in employment or a healthy environment.

HEADLINE: Nationalists Are Routed in Taiwan Legislative Election 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Dec. 1 

 BODY:
Taiwan's Nationalist Party was routed today in legislative elections on the island, completing a political fall from grace that began when it lost the presidency last year.
 The Nationalists, who governed Taiwan for a half-century after fleeing there from China after a civil war in 1949, lost 42 seats, and their majority, in the 225-seat Legislature. The Democratic Progressive Party of President Chen Shui-bian gained 21 seats and supplanted the Nationalists as the biggest party. 
 It was a resounding victory for Mr. Chen, who made history last year by leading the opposition party into the presidency. But it was an even more resounding defeat for the Nationalists. Although the party had been expected to lose its majority, the results were worse than expected. 
The vote underscored the antipathy that many people in Taiwan still feel toward the Nationalists, who built an enormously wealthy, and increasingly corrupt, political machine during their 55 years in power.
"It shows that it takes time to heal the wounds," said Shaw Yu-ming, the chairman of the party's newspaper, The Central Daily News.
Mr. Shaw said the Nationalists could still cobble together a formidable bloc in the Legislature by allying with a third party that split off from the Nationalists in 1999. He noted that while Mr. Chen's party had strengthened its hand, it, too, had fallen short of a majority.
Political analysts expect several weeks of intense horse-trading as Mr. Chen and the Nationalists maneuver to put together coalitions with smaller parties to give them control over the Legislature.
"The end of the elections is the beginning of cooperation," Mr. Chen said in a statement after the results were announced. 
Most analysts foresee more contention than cooperation. But the victory has put Mr. Chen, an earnest lawyer and native Taiwanese, in a markedly stronger position. After he humiliated the Nationalists in the presidential election in March 2000, they exacted vengeance by tying up his government in the Legislature.
Politics in Taiwan has been paralyzed for the last 19 months, with Mr. Chen and the Nationalists blaming each other for the impasse. The sense of drift has been amplified by Taiwan's economy, which is heavily dependent on exports to the United States and has fallen into a deep recession. Now, though, Mr. Chen's party said it hoped to form a government that would be able to gets things done. 
"We did extremely well," said Wilson Tien, the party's director of international affairs. "We will have more momentum to work on developing alliances, and it will be very hard for the K.M.T. to oppose us," he added, using the initials for the Nationalist Party's Chinese name, the Kuomintang.
Analysts warned against writing off the Nationalists. The party performed better in county and municipal elections that were also held today. In one closely watched race, Jason Hu, a former party spokesman and foreign minister, was elected mayor of Taichung, the island's third-largest city.
The Nationalists, these experts predicted, will choose a new generation of leaders from its grass roots. "The local chiefs are going to be much more outspoken in the future," Mr. Tien said.
The election was marred by harsh campaigning and a fixation on small-bore issues. Partly this is a function of the complex way Taiwan elects its Legislature. Each voter casts a single ballot, but each district sends as many as 16 lawmakers to Taipei, so a candidate need only place among the top vote-getters in his district to win.
Since the parties want to win as many seats as possible in each district, they strategize endlessly about how to allocate their supporters' votes to the various candidates. Often, a voter will pick his third choice rather than his first, if his first choice seems likely to win. 
The election rules, which have come under criticism in Taiwan, work against the development of broad campaign themes. Instead, the battles between candidates are tactical, personal, and brutally partisan. 
Beyond the rules, some commentators said the depth of the problems facing Taiwan deprived the candidates of easy solutions. The island's economy has been depleted by the migration of its computer industry to mainland China, where labor is cheaper. With China and Taiwan both joining the World Trade Organization, economists say that exodus is likely to accelerate. 
With no experience in governing, Mr. Chen's administration was ill-equipped to deal with the economic collapse. And its feuding with the Nationalists doomed any chance of a coordinated economic policy. 
Mr. Chen did relax restrictions on investments by Taiwanese companies in mainland China last month. Analysts said the government would probably also open direct trade and transportation links with the mainland if the political atmosphere between the two sides improved. 
Relations between Taiwan and China have been in suspended animation since Mr. Chen came into office, however. China refuses to deal with him because his party formally advocates an independent Taiwan. While Mr. Chen has pledged not to push for independence, he has steadfastly rebuffed the Chinese government's demand that he recognize a single China, governed by Beijing. 
China did not try to intimidate Taiwanese voters, as it has in previous years, by threatening military action if the island edged toward independence. Previous efforts to do that have backfired, emboldening Taiwan to elect Mr. Chen and his independence-minded predecessor, Lee Teng-hui. 
China also mentioned President Chen by name for the first time late last month, in an article in the official People's Daily. Before that, his name never appeared in China's official news media. 
Some analysts said this was a sign that Beijing is learning to live with the Taiwan leader. Others noted, however, that the reference to Mr. Chen was in an opinion piece that lambasted him for not recognizing the one-China policy. 
"If Chen Shui-bian can prove himself to be a person with staying power in Taiwanese politics, Beijing will have to deal with him," said Chu Yuan-han, a professor of politics at National Taiwan University.

HEADLINE: Boom Over, Las Vegas Goes Back to the Basics 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 30 

 BODY:
As the self-described "happiest mayor in America," Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas leaves no superlative unspoken in his quest to revitalize downtown, the seedy underbelly that lies a few miles from the fantasy world of the Strip. 
 A vacant 61-acre parcel at an old rail yard is "the best piece of urban real estate in the country," says Mayor Goodman. Another stretch of downtown is the perfect spot for a giant "incubator" for high technology companies. Roaming past blighted pockets that include an impressive collection of pawnshops and bail-bond operations (many with "God Bless America" decals in the windows), the mayor describes another dream project of his. 
 "We're going to make this whole block here into an agora, like a marketplace where Aristotle and Plato would gather," he says, beaming. "It's going to be very, very special." 
When Mr. Goodman talked like this a year ago, anything was possible in still-booming Las Vegas. But as the economy soured, some of these big plans have been scaled back or delayed and others, like the high-tech complex, seem to have fizzled altogether. And the mayor has seemed to go back to basics in his pursuit of almost any investment on behalf of rebuilding downtown.
First, Mr. Goodman, a nationally famous organized crime lawyer before he became mayor, announced that he was negotiating with Beefeater gin to become a pitchman. The mayor said he would donate all proceeds to Las Vegas, including money to help what the city calls the "chronically inebriated." 
Then Mr. Goodman was spotted meeting in his office this month with Marion Knight, who is known as Suge, the recently paroled music mogul and co-founder of Death Row Records, a label that made millions off gangsta rap hits but was nearly done in by Mr. Knight's many clashes with the law and his reputation for gangster-style intimidation of rival artists and producers. 
The Las Vegas Review-Journal reported that Mr. Knight, paroled after four years in prison for violating probation in an assault case, had come to City Hall "at the mayor's request to discuss downtown redevelopment" and quoted Mr. Goodman as saying he hoped Mr. Knight would choose Las Vegas as the site for a music and production studio for his new record company, Tha Row.
Mr. Goodman said the report was a wildly overblown account of the meeting, which he described as only a "very, very casual" discussion that was actually initiated by his friend and longtime law partner, David Chesnoff, who represents Mr. Knight. The city is not actively recruiting Mr. Knight to set up his studio here, Mr. Goodman says. 
However the meeting got started and whatever was said, some here feared that a city once fueled by gangster money might now seek an economic charge from gangsta rap -- and perhaps another from alcohol, if their mayor's face ever appeared on the label of a gin bottle. 
"We're kind of falling back on our heritage," said Professor Robert E. Parker, who teaches a course on the sociology of Las Vegas at the University of Nevada here. 
The mayor concedes that he took a lot of criticism for his meeting with Mr. Knight, who a former chief of the Las Vegas homicide squad described as one of the most uncooperative witnesses he had ever dealt with. In 1996, the rap star Tupac Shakur was shot to death in Las Vegas in a car driven by Mr. Knight. A few hours before Mr. Shakur's shooting, Mr. Knight assaulted someone suspected of being a rival gang member at a casino here, a violation of his earlier probation for his 1992 assault of two rap artists at a Hollywood recording studio. That led to a new prison sentence, which ended with his release this past summer.
While nearly all the calls to the mayor's office were from people who said Las Vegas needed Mr. Knight's studio like it needed a hole in the head, Mr. Goodman seemed angry at the criticism, saying Mr. Knight deserved a fresh chance. The rap mogul was a "genius in his field," he said, suggesting that some complaints stemmed from racial bias.
"It amazes me, it appeared to me there were an awful lot of people who had a lot of bias and prejudice," the mayor said in an interview. "I don't know whether it was against people who got out of prison or against a rapper or a black rapper or a black guy who got out of prison, but my phone was deluged with phone calls saying, don't let this guy come here." 
It is unclear what Mr. Knight's plans are. Mr. Chesnoff said neither he nor Mr. Knight would comment. 
The mayor says he simply listens to anyone with any plans to bring in business downtown. 
What Mayor Goodman was far more interested in talking about was all the things that are already happening downtown, including the recent opening of the first big office building in 25 years and the opening next spring of Neonopolis, a retail, theater and dining complex. 
Tourists, who are returning to Las Vegas after the fall's sharp decline, are attending the Fremont Street Experience, an hourly light and sound show that plays across a giant canopy each evening. Planning is under way for the 61-acre lot, which the mayor hopes will include housing, an arts complex and a medical center affiliated with a university. 
There has been an influx of artists to the area, with a large lithography studio opening. "These buildings, which are inherently ugly, when you put them into an art context, they become funky," Mayor Goodman said. "They become cool places rather than old rundown places when you call it the arts district."
The very same was true, he said, of the giant cockroach model that adorns a pest control business in the area. "I hated the cockroach until this became the arts district," he said. "So the cockroach I couldn't stand becomes the cockroach I love. Everything is relative."

HEADLINE: A New Count of the Dead, But Little Sense of Relief 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
The number tumbles. First 6,700, then 5,000. Down, down, down, 4,500, 4,000, now 3,300.
 The death toll in the World Trade Center attack keeps falling as officials refine their count. When they are finished, the toll will be much smaller than anyone anticipated, probably about 3,000, less than half the number that made headlines in the weeks following the attack. 
 That is a fact. In historical terms it means that Sept. 11 can no longer be called the bloodiest day in American history. (That was Sept. 17, 1862, when at least 3,650 Confederate and Union soldiers died at the Battle of Antietam, and thousands of others were wounded.) In contemporary ones it means that the evacuation and rescue efforts were even more spectacularly successful than anyone imagined. The 400 rescuers who died helped save more people than anyone might have dreamed possible. 
Mere numbers, of course, do little to diminish the nation's sense of horror.
And yet as the number has fallen, and been publicly recorded, people have reacted in a variety of ways, not all of them simple relief: one sister of a victim watched the number shrink and felt all the lonelier, briefly fearful that people might think the wholesale devastation that took her brother was somehow less epic; the mayor of New York excoriated reporters for chronicling the declining totals, describing it as a "macabre" exercise; military and political leaders have said the total does not for a second change their sense of outrage. 
Historians and psychologists say that such a mix of relief and confusion, anger and insistence is not unusual, and maybe even to be expected. Over history, the early, dreaded estimates of death totals in cataclysmic events have had a way of taking stubborn hold. People invest in them, however broken their hearts. People come to defend them in certain ways, in part because they think worrying about definitively counting the deaths amounts to a conscious effort to diminish the event's awfulness.
No one is wrong in all this, and no one, however conflicted their emotions, feels that Sept. 11 was anything less than a cursed day. Much of it just has to do with how people process loss, how humans protect that which they cherish, how slowly some truths nudge powerful myths from the historical stage.
Lori Barzvi, whose brother, Guy, 29, worked at Cantor Fitzgerald and died in the attack, said she watched the numbers of dead and missing decline and felt something might be at risk. "I was afraid that it might be looked at as being less of a tragedy or it would be easier to forget because less people died," Ms. Barzvi said. "It is not that I wish that there were more people. It just made me feel a little bit more alone."
Joel Best, chairman of the department of sociology and criminal justice at the University of Delaware and author of the book "Damned Lies and Statistics" says that sometimes people's feelings can go beyond the strangely disconcerting sensation experienced by Ms. Barzvi. People can almost actively cling to high numbers of dead or hurt despite the fact that those numbers have been proven erroneous.
"People develop an emotional stake in defending a number," Mr. Best said. "They feel they have to defend it."
The phenomenon, while understandable, can also blunt what is objectively a good development. "If there are 3,000 dead instead of 6,000 dead that does not make the tragedy half as bad," Mr. Best said. "What people ought to see is the astonishing good fortune that we had in evacuating these buildings."
And yet the ability to feel anything like comfort can prove difficult. Some people ask, not without sound reasoning, how anyone can feel any better knowing that "only" about 3,000 people died. Even engaging in a discussion about the declining count has brought some people criticism.
"It appears to many people to be callous," said John Allen Paulos, a professor of mathematics at Temple University and author of the book "Innumeracy: Mathematical Illiteracy and Its Consequences." 
"I have had conversations with people and I sense it a bit -- that concerns with the numbers is somehow unseemly."
Certainly, the United States diplomats, military leaders and members of Congress who have repeatedly cited the thousands killed in explaining why the country has gone to war do not think the lower total affects their rationale or the country's cause. For weeks, they cited 5,000 and 6,000 dead when it was public knowledge that the figure was substantially lower, although they probably were erring unintentionally. 
Spokesmen for the Pentagon and the State Department, where Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell have each referred to much higher death tolls in explaining the United States engagement, said the lower numbers changed nothing.
"Our country was attacked, thousands of innocent Americans and citizens from other countries were killed and the terrorists have threatened to kill more," said Philip Reeker, a deputy spokesman at the State Department. "We are waging a campaign in self-defense."
Along those lines, psychologists and other experts suspect that the change in the death toll will mean little in how this disaster affects the American psyche. That enduring, collective sense of horror, these experts say, results in part from the fact that so many people around the country experienced the intense trauma of watching the towers collapse on television, and perhaps felt almost as if they were there. And the towers, the signature of the downtown skyline, were such recognizable icons that many people had almost a personal relationship with the buildings themselves.
Perhaps most importantly, psychologists say, is that the scale of the disaster on Sept. 11 was so incomprehensibly great, that even when the number of people who died was cut in half, the loss remained just as incomprehensibly great.
"If you hear about a car accident in which one person died versus one in which four people died, that is experienced much differently psychologically," said Jennifer S. Lerner, an assistant professor of decision science and psychology at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, who is studying how Sept. 11 influenced risk perception and economic behavior. "But if there is a train wreck and 100 people died versus 104 people died, you are not going to pay that much attention to whether it is 100 or 104, because it is already beyond the threshold where you count individuals."
In any disaster of such proportions, these experts say, we tend to form memories and an outlook on life that will be unaltered by a lowering of official death counts.
"Our grief is not proportionate to the number of people who died," said Shelley E. Taylor, a professor of psychology at the University of California at Los Angeles, whose research focuses on how humans deal with stress and trauma. "Our grief depends first on the personal impact, if we knew someone, and second to the sense of loss that pervades everyone psychologically because of the loss of innocence and the realization of our vulnerability, and none of those things are affected by the reduction in the number of casualties." 
Historians, too, are wrestling with what to make of the smaller death toll. Even in the course of a single conversation, several seemed to revise their thoughts about what, if anything, the smaller death toll will mean in the way history records Sept. 11, 2001.
Robert Jay Lifton, a psychiatrist and historian who published a book in 1999 about the Japanese cult that released poison gas in the Tokyo subways, said the lower number may mean that as time passes, "there can be a gradual sense in people's minds that the disaster was not as vast as they had thought." But, he added, given that this attack was on civilians and not on soldiers on a battlefield, the lower numbers may not have an effect on how people perceive the vastness of the calamity.
"This was a unique attack and its standing as an historical experience has to do with it being a terrorist attack, as opposed to an event in war time, for which we have different standards," he said.
Ultimately, historians said, the historical importance of Sept. 11 is still being defined on a day-by-day basis, from the fate of the war in Afghanistan to the effort to rebuild Lower Manhattan to any realignment of relations among world powers, like the United States and Russia.
David M. Kennedy, a Stanford University professor of history, said that to him it was clear that the drop in the Sept. 11th death toll would have no effect on its standing in history. "The whole experience is what has made an impact on us and will remain in our memory, and the absolute number is irrelevant," he said.
He noted, for example, that few Americans know how many people died during Pearl Harbor (2,400), and yet it does not change the significance of the event.
"None but a few specialists and historians will know the exact number," Mr. Kennedy said of the Sept. 11 attacks, which as of the latest official count, left 3,533 dead, including 189 at the Pentagon and 44 at the crash site in Pennsylvania. "But the magnitude of the event is well established and will be remembered." And that truth is felt most powerfully by the families whose loved ones died. "It just doesn't mean anything," said Warren B. Nelson of St. Louis, whose son, David W. Nelson, 50, a senior vice president at Carr Futures, died in the attack. "A whole lot of people got killed, whether it is 3,000 or 6,000."
Elizabeth Crawford, David Nelson's wife, said that when she finds herself in a room of say 50 or 60 other widows or family members of victims, she is already overwhelmed by grief. But she said that perhaps in some way, solace can be taken from the decline. "Any family that does not have to go through what my family is going through, is a wonderful thing," said Mrs. Crawford, who lives in Brooklyn with two children, ages 8 and 4. "I do say, 'Thank God it is less than we had thought.' I wish David would have been one of those who got out. But it was out of my control."
