HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
Sheffield With Mets Is Unlikely Scenario

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Mets have been through this dance before, and the repetition has become tiresome. If they do not trade for Gary Sheffield this time, they should be banned from ever uttering his name again, let alone trying to get him.
 Actually, their latest attempt to put Sheffield in their outfield has most likely ended before it really got started. The Los Angeles Dodgers apparently want more for Sheffield than the Mets want to -- or can -- give, and Sheffield would want more money in a monstrous new contract than the Mets, who are on his no-trade list, would want to give. 
 The Mets tried to get Sheffield last spring, when he asked the Dodgers to trade him because they would not give him the lifetime contract he wanted. The Mets did not get Sheffield because they did not want to give the Dodgers Mike Piazza or Edgardo Alfonzo, or a package of players including Armando Benitez and Jay Payton. 
The Mets tried to get Sheffield the first time when he played for the Florida Marlins. It was less than a month after the Marlins won the 1997 World Series, and their owner, H. Wayne Huizenga, directed the front office to shed the high-priced players. 
At that time the Mets seemed to wrestle with Sheffield's history and reputation as a problem player, and when General Manager Steve Phillips finished his internal monologue, he ceased pursuit of a trade.
Sheffield remained with the Marlins until the following May, then went to the Dodgers for Piazza and Todd Zeile, who subsequently wound up as teammates on the Mets.
If he is still talking to the Dodgers about Sheffield, Phillips is not talking to the news media about Sheffield.
"I can't talk about a player on another club," he said. But speaking generally about evaluating the possibility of a trade for any player, he said: "Generally we take all issues into account on any player we pursue. Look at what they can do on the field, the talent evaluation, the clubhouse evaluation, impact on the chemistry of the team. Obviously the cost, meaning the dollars and impact on a payroll and talent it would take to acquire the player. Those are the factors we consider in acquiring a player."
The factors have never added up to a trade for Sheffield and presumably never will, leaving the Mets to look elsewhere for a big hitter to go with Piazza. Maybe they will sign Barry Bonds. He is a free agent with a fresh home run record. His agent, Scott Boras, said he had spoken with the Mets, and their talks reflected interest.
But is not Bonds the player whose teammates have said goes his own way, creating a 24-and-1 environment? Wasn't that the problem Phillips cited a year ago when he abandoned the quest for Alex Rodriguez, another Boras client?
The Mets believed Rodriguez wanted to play for them. They believed he was so eager to play for them that they would not have any real competition for him. Then they discovered that he was considering four or five other teams. Their interested disappeared -- quickly. 
A couple of days later, Phillips announced the end of the Mets' pursuit before it really started. Phillips ticked off a whole litany of perks that he said Boras said were necessary to make Rodriguez a happy player. Boras denied making such demands. Rodriguez was insulted, not to mention embarrassed that anyone should think he was a selfish player.
A friend of Rodriguez recently expressed the view that the real reason the Mets bowed out was that Fred Wilpon, the team's co-owner, did not want to become involved in a bidding contest for Rodriguez and instructed Phillips to find a way out of the race without making the Mets look bad. 
Last week Wilpon and Phillips denied that explanation.
"That's fiction, not fact," Wilpon said. "The fact was there were very few people in that quest for the guy. I'm not sure there was more than one other team. It never got that far. It happened exactly as Steve reported. Steve decided he wasn't going in that direction and I agreed with him. Those are the facts."
Phillips said he did not want to "relive the whole A-Rod situation; that's come and gone." "But," he added, "that's not accurate, no. The explanation was the explanation."
Boras said he did not want to bring up the matter either a year later.
But just think what might have been had the Mets had Rodriguez. He batted .318, hit 52 home runs, drove in 135 runs, scored 133, amassed 201 hits and had a .622 slugging percentage. He could have given the Mets a respectable offense instead of the worst one in the league.
And they would not have to look for a big hitter now, certainly not Bonds, who is 11 years older than Rodriguez.

Preparing for Giambi
It seems to be a foregone conclusion that the Yankees will sign Jason Giambi, and they are expected to do it by the end of this week. 
Other teams will grumble that there they go again, spending tons of money, and George Steinbrenner will respond that the Yankees are not the ones who set new salary milestones. Giambi, he will point out, will not make as much as his new teammate Derek Jeter, which means his salary is even further behind the $25.2 million that Alex Rodriguez averages annually.
Giambi led the American League in slugging percentage and on-base percentage, combining them for a total of 1.137. How remarkable a year did Barry Bonds have? He led the National League in slugging and on-base percentages, and he totaled 1.378.

Andruw Jones Pact Defended
Final word on the Andruw Jones contract with the Atlanta Braves:
Stan Kasten, the Braves' president, took strong exception to the impression that the Braves took advantage of Jones because his father and not his agent, Scott Boras, negotiated his six-year, $75 million contract.
Kasten was particularly irate over an issue being made out of the absence of a no-trade provision in the contract. The thought was that Jones took less money to stay with the Braves than he could have gained as a free agent next year, and the club, with a no-trade clause, could have protected Jones, a center fielder, from being sent elsewhere.
"They asked for a no-trade, and we told them no," Kasten said. "For the record, the Braves have never given a player a no-trade clause, even those with agents."
The Braves apparently need to get a break on some contracts because as remarkable a streak as they have had with 10 consecutive division championships, figures in last year's report of baseball's blue-ribbon panel say the Braves lost $6.88 million in 1995-99. 
On the other hand, people familiar with the Braves' operation scoff at the idea that they lose money, given, among other revenue sources, the national scope of their cablecasts on TBS and their own boast of having the most comprehensive sports broadcasting in baseball.

Contraction Hearing Ahead
It could become a collectors' item, the Minnesota Twins' 2001 postseason guide, a compact 200-page publication reviewing the team's outstanding season and the contributions its individual players made to the surprising second-place finish.
But with each passing day, the chances of the Twins having at least one more postseason guide grow. The court case in Minnesota alone guarantees that Commissioner Bud Selig cannot execute his contraction plan until January, if then. In addition, baseball's arbitrator, Shyam Das, could rule that the clubs have to bargain contraction with the union.
Lost in the morass of contraction is the bargaining the clubs and the players are supposed to have for a new labor agreement to ensure a peaceful 2002 season. That agreement will be far more difficult to achieve than consent on contraction and its effects. 
If Selig eliminates two teams and the Pittsburgh Pirates select Vladimir Guerrero in the dispersal draft, it will not matter if they do not have a season to play next year.
But if contraction represents the first round of the labor fight, Selig's appearance before the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday and his disclosure of clubs' financial data (profits and losses, mostly losses) will be the second round. 
The union is certain to dispute many of the figures, and it will have the support of skeptical economists, who will question how 25 of 30 teams can lose money in an industry whose revenue has risen in the last five years from $1.5 billion to $3.6 billion.

HEADLINE: Nov. 25-Dec.1; 
Economic Woes Grow

BYLINE:  By Richard W. Stevenson

 BODY:
 It was a bad week on the economic front. The official arbiters of such things proclaimed that the longest business expansion on record ended in March, ushering in the first recession in a decade, and that the federal budget surplus has likely given way to persistent deficits. 
 With that gloomy backdrop, Democratic and Republican leaders sat down with White House officials to begin negotiating a plan to revive the economy. But they couldn't even agree on how to run the talks, much less on the proper mix of new tax cuts and additional government spending. Richard W. Stevenson

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FAMILIES; 
GIFTS TO RESCUERS DIVIDE SURVIVORS

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARSTOW and DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
One firehouse has collected $2 million in donations. Another received $225,000 out of the blue from a small company in Texas. In a single day, members of a family in Park Slope, Brooklyn, collected so much for their local rescue squad that they stowed garbage bags of cash in their shower stall for temporary safekeeping.
 Since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, breathtaking sums of money have poured in for the families of about 400 police officers, firefighters and other uniformed personnel who died trying to lead thousands to safety. Charities set up exclusively for the rescuers' families -- there are more than 50 such groups -- have raised at least $353 million so far, according to a survey by The New York Times. That works out to more than $880,000 for each rescuer's family, and with donations still flowing in, many families could collect $1 million or more from these charities alone. 
 For the widows of firefighters and police officers, the money has provided financial security, a sense of being embraced by a nation. But for the families of civilian victims -- and even some of those raising money for the rescuers' survivors -- the flood of charity to the families of the uniformed dead has obliterated the hope that America's donations will be distributed in an even-handed way to all the survivors. 
Soon after Sept. 11, when the magnitude of the nation's charitable response had become clear, several government and charity officials stressed the importance of distributing aid in an equitable manner. Those experienced in disasters, like the Oklahoma City bombing, warned that disparities could produce division among the survivors.
And those divisions are starting to emerge as more than $1.3 billion in charity is spreading across the landscape of need. Legally, the rescuers' funds cannot simply redirect their money, and much of the remaining $1 billion in charity has been pledged to small businesses, the unemployed and the traumatized, not specifically to the families of the civilian dead. Now, even officials for the uniformed-service funds are worrying about the growing perception that there is an aristocracy of grief.
At a recent support meeting in New Jersey, for example, a screaming match broke out when a widow of a Port Authority police officer argued that her family deserved more charity than other families because her husband had died saving others.
"How can you say that?" a widow of a financial executive retorted, insisting that every person killed on Sept. 11 was a casualty of the same war and deserved equal treatment.
The estrangement between the families of uniformed victims and civilian victims is not simply about money. Some families of civilian victims complain that they have been made to feel like second-class victims who have less access to the site of the collapse and less influence at City Hall. They are also convinced that families of firefighters, the police and emergency service personnel are getting most of the free concert tickets, vacations and even seats for the lighting of the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center.
"We're not just angry, we're heartbroken about the inequities -- that people could value the lives of those men more than they would value the lives of our men," said Mary Ellen Salamone, of North Caldwell, N.J., whose husband, John Salamone, worked for Cantor Fitzgerald.
"Nobody got up to the floors where my husband was," she said, her voice trembling. "They died alone. And you have no idea who was helping whom. Don't tell me there weren't people up there trying to do heroic things. They had to be their own heroes and help each other."
In dozens of interviews, those raising money for the families of rescue workers said they were stunned by the millions that have flowed in, often with little effort on their part. But while they are grateful, some of these officials are troubled by the stark, evolving disparities.
"You don't want to see anybody walk away here a millionaire; that is not the intent," said Frank Ferreyra, president of the New York State Fraternal Order of Police Foundation, which has raised $3 million in its WTC Police Disaster Fund.
Some are calling on the large, general-purpose charities like the United Way's September 11th Fund to help narrow the gap by making special payments to civilian families.
"We have been taken care of," said Tom LaMacchia, treasurer of the Uniformed Firefighters Association in New York City, which has received $29 million for its Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund since Sept. 11. "As a citizen," Mr. LaMacchia said, "I hope that these other funds that have not distributed their money yet are distributing their money to the civilians."
To be sure, it is far from clear how everyone will ultimately be compensated in the months and years to come. The families of all who were injured or killed, including the rescuers, are eligible to collect substantial awards from a new multibillion-dollar federal victims' compensation fund, and the awards may eliminate some of the inequities.
But for now, families have only charity to count on, and with more than 200 charities raising money for trade center victims, the danger that some families would receive far more money than others has been evident from the start. In Oklahoma City, the problem was resolved with the creation of a central database of the 168 victims that kept track of how much aid each family received. Officials met every week to monitor the distribution.
Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York attorney general, has been working for months to replicate that system, but progress has been slowed by disagreements among the charities.
"By the end of this process, there will be equity that people are very comfortable with," he vowed.
Clearly, though, he and other players in the charitable relief effort face a problem born chiefly of the country's desire to reward the indisputable heroism of rescuers who marched into two burning towers.
"What I was moved by -- as most Americans were -- were the unselfish acts of the firefighters," said Michael H. Feuer, chief executive of OfficeMax, which has pledged $1 million for scholarships for the rescuers' families. "In retrospect, given the obvious abundance of charity going to the rescuers, it was a decision made with the heart and the gut, and not the mind."
And he does not regret it one bit. 
States have long recognized a special obligation to the families of police officers and firefighters killed in the line of duty. New York provides spouses with pensions equal to the lost salaries and children with full scholarships to state universities. Additionally, the federal government provides $250,000 to families of police officers and firefighters killed on duty.
Those raising money for families of firefighters and police officers benefited from the fact that their unions, some with national reach, had existing charity funds and an established structure.
They also found a powerful fund-raiser in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose Twin Towers Fund alone has raised at least $113 million for uniformed victims.
The families of civilian victims -- sprawled over several states, employed by dozens of companies -- have been slower to organize. Some employers and unions have established funds, but they pale in comparison to the major funds for uniformed victims.
"We just want to be recognized as needing, as well," said Liz McLaughlin, of Pelham, N.Y., the widow of a Cantor Fitzgerald executive, Robert C. McLaughlin Jr., and one of the founders of a nonprofit group called Families of September 11th Inc., whose 11-member board has people from six states, none of them representatives of uniformed victims.
Even among the rescuers, there are significant differences in what their families are receiving in charity. As things stand now, for example, the families of the 37 Port Authority police officers will collect roughly one-third less money in charitable assistance than the families of 343 New York firefighters. The reason is simple: charities dedicated solely to firefighters are taking in far more money than those dedicated solely to the Port Authority police officers. 
"The firefighters are getting so much publicity," said John McAusland, counsel for the Port Authority police union, which has raised $1.4 million in its Survivors' Fund. Mr. McAusland said that early on he struggled to get major Web sites and television networks to give equal attention to the Port Authority fund. "We couldn't get ours on the screen," he said.
And disparities are even emerging among firefighters' families, largely because of luck and geography.
"It is safe to assume that every single fire company that lost somebody has a fund of some sort," said Ann Berger Lesk, a lawyer with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson in Manhattan. "The size will depend on how many people were lost, how large the company is, how connected they were to their community -- and how affluent that community is."
The amounts are not trivial. The Ladder 12 Firefighters Fund in the Chelsea section of Manhattan has raised $250,000 for five families, with donations from as far away as Ireland. Another downtown firehouse, with more than a dozen casualties, has received gifts estimated at $400,000.
So sensitive is the subject of money that many of the firehouse funds are refusing to disclose what they have collected, although they ultimately will have to do so under federal charity laws.
Sean Delaney, the executive director of an organization that provides legal advice to nonprofit groups, is helping four firehouses obtain tax-exempt status and said that his clients refused to let him provide any information about the funds because they have become so wary of criticism. "They see where this is going," Mr. Delaney said, "and they don't think it's helpful to them."

HEADLINE: How Islam and Politics Mixed 

BYLINE:  By Saad Mehio; Saad Mehio is a regular contributor to The Daily Star in Lebanon and Al Khaleej in the United Arab Emirates.

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon 

 BODY:
So what comes after the Taliban and Osama bin Laden are finished? Probably more Talibans and new Osama bin Ladens. This is the sad and shocking reality that we must confront. It will happen apart from all the fanfare surrounding America's military triumph in Afghanistan and all the other achievements of this so-called war on terror. Why? Because the Taliban and Mr. bin Laden are not isolated cases but manifestations of a complex, and potentially durable, sociopolitical phenomenon.
Basically, this phenomenon involves the immoral, unscrupulous and irreligious exploitation of Islam as a political weapon -- by everyone. The West, the United States, Arab and other Muslim tyrannies have all used the weapon of Islam. And all are paying their different prices for it.
 During the cold war it was easy, and easily justified on pragmatic grounds, to enlist the help of political Islam in the fight against Communism. Yet this enlistment of Islam, which helped hammer the final nails in the coffin of Communism by defeating the Red Army in Afghanistan, led to catastrophe -- first for the Middle East and later for America, as was so shockingly brought home by the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. 
 The policy of using political Islam as an anti-Communist tool was a crucial reason why so much of the Muslim world came to be dominated by stagnant, undemocratic but stable (so it seemed) and adequately pro-Western governments, on one hand, and the traditional forces of political Islam, reconfigured for the latter half of the 20th century, on the other. The crowning achievement of such a policy was the defeat of the modernizing alternative: those movements that hoped to avoid aligning with either the Soviet Union or the United States; to develop their societies along secular lines by, ideally, ever more democratic means; and to substitute nationalism for colonial humility and Islamic traditionalism. Such movements were sometimes called Nasserite, after President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt. He struggled against the Muslim Brotherhood for most of his political life.
The Nasserite space has been shrinking over the three decades since his death. The alliance between Western democracies and local despots, whether Saudi royals or Saddam Hussein in his early years, had two results: the destruction of democratic openness in the Arab world and the obliteration of any chance for a liberal Arab nationalist movement that could act as a bridge to the modern world. State power may have been, in most cases, secular, but political hope and political mobility were left in the hands of God's representatives.
After the cold war ended in 1989, and while the rest of the world was gearing up to join the march of globalization and making great strides toward democracy, liberty and human rights, the Middle East looked like a bombed-out city. More political oppression, more intellectual and cultural stagnation, more economic and social despair -- and an ideological void that only the fundamentalists were able or were permitted to fill, under the demagogic banner of protecting identity and character.
Political exploitation of Islam continued, but the enemy became simply Muslim peoples themselves. This was exemplified in the financing (with petrodollars) of some 7,500 religious schools in Pakistan, India and the Arab world, schools that taught only isolationism, backwardness and hostility. Arab and other Muslim tyrannies sought, by leaving the educational and cultural fields to Islamism, to acquire legitimacy at the cheapest and most opportunistic price: by keeping the masses ignorant and preventing them from improving their lot, politically and economically. Better to direct their hopes toward the hereafter.
Where was America then? Where was the West? Cavorting with tyrants on the sunny beaches of the Mediterranean. So long as the oil flowed at a good price, petrodollars were recycled in the West's arms factories and Israel was in no real danger, there was no reason to interfere in what America's moderate or even immoderate allies were doing to their own peoples.
Sept. 11 changed all that. The United States lost its sovereignty. Suddenly security in the streets of Washington, New York, Boston and Los Angeles was inextricably linked to the curriculums of schools in Peshawar, Mazar-i-Sharif, Cairo, Algiers and Deoband.
And just as suddenly, the regional system that Washington had nurtured during the cold war, then left to its own devices after 1989, was seen to have turned into a hatchery for human missiles and suicidal rage directed against the United States itself.
Now we have a world war on terror. This war is already yielding results: the prehistoric Taliban regime is all but finished, the financial lifelines to fundamentalist extremist networks have been severed, Mr. bin Laden is on the run.
Winning a war, however, does not mean winning the peace. This war can, in truth, be won only by winning hearts and minds. This can be achieved only by correcting the historical mistakes made by the West, including the United States, in undercutting the modernizing forces of pan-Arabism -- and by correcting the spectacularly misguided choices made by Arab elites in their use of power and of politicized Islam as a way to keep it.
Benjamin Barber, author of "Jihad vs. McWorld," wrote recently, "In the long run, war cannot defeat terror alone because violence cannot defeat fear: only democracy can do that." Secretary of State Colin Powell seems to view matters in a similar light. In his speech of Nov. 19, which received careful attention in Muslim countries, Secretary Powell articulated his vision of a Middle East in which "all people have jobs that let them put bread on their tables and a roof over their head and offer a decent education to their children."
"We have a vision of a region where all people worship god in a spirit of tolerance and understanding," Secretary Powell continued. "And we have a vision where respect for the sanctity of the individual, the rule of law and the politics of participation grow stronger and stronger."
For now these are just promises. It is extremely hard not to question the likelihood of their fulfillment. For much of the 20th century, excessive American pragmatism tended to stress short-term interests, which often were served by tyrants like Saddam Hussein at the expense of the future of Arabs.
Nevertheless, Secretary Powell's promises alone may widen the chasm between the United States and its regional allies, and that is to the good. Americans seem to be realizing that having undemocratic allies -- ones who manipulate political Islam for their narrow purposes -- has been a pennywise policy, at best. The stress Colin Powell put on respect, dignity and the rejection of humiliation widens this chasm still further, for personal dignity is about the last thing Arab rulers have allowed to Arab citizens. Secretary Powell's emphasis makes the issues clear; it shows that the solutions adopted in ignorance by all sides, including America, have not worked. The Arab and Muslim worlds may yet sign on to modernity and globalization -- because they and the West may come to realize there is no other choice.
Through this window of hope, it may be possible to see that the self-inflicted injuries in the Arab and Muslim soul can indeed heal. But until these promises and visions reach fulfillment, the passions, fears and hatreds of the Taliban and Osama bin Laden will remain alive among us.

HEADLINE: With Enron's Fall, Many Dominoes Tremble 

BYLINE:  By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
THE Enron Corporation, despite its origins as a gas pipeline business, was no mere energy company. Its ambition, its passion for innovation and its boundless appetite for risk gave it a far greater reach than that of competitors, even those that control many more power plants or far larger reserves of natural gas.
 In the last decade, it became not only the world's largest trader of electricity and natural gas, but also a telecommunications company, an investment firm, a paper and lumber producer and an insurer. It was, with more than $100 billion in revenue last year, the nation's seventh-largest company. 
 Its collapse last week reverberated through not just the nation's energy industry, but also through retailing, real estate, insurance, banking, Internet services, newspaper publishing, even the manufacturing of plastics and glass. 
Most other energy companies were content to provide electricity or natural gas. Enron signed contracts with 28,500 customers worldwide, including J. C. Penney and Owens-Illinois, to manage all their energy needs, usually promising that it would absorb the risks of volatile prices and fluctuating supplies itself. Now those customers fear that the risks are once again all their own. 
Houston, where Enron keeps as high a profile as its 50-story downtown headquarters, is bearing the greatest burden. There, the Trammell Crow Company immediately cited Enron's collapse in halting the planned groundbreaking last month on a 34-story office, apartment and shopping complex next to Enron Field, the new home of the Houston Astros. 
At the end of last week, those who did business with Enron, or depended on it in other ways, were still trying to puzzle through all the consequences of its ruin. No easy task, this, considering that Enron's own finances, more convoluted than anything even a Max Bialystock could imagine, proved beyond the grasp of its chief executive, Kenneth L. Lay. 
Here, though, is an initial look at how Enron's fate has affected industries across the nation (not to even mention the 40 or so though, is an initial look at how Enron's fate has affected industries across the nation (not to even mention the 40 or so other countries where Enron operates).
 ALLEN R. MYERSON

HEADLINE: Community; 
A Crown JewelBecomes a Liability

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN BALLEZA 

 BODY:
In a Houston economy where corporate stars like Continental Airlines and Compaq Computer were suffering, Enron had become the premier business. Its executives reveled in the role, naming the Houston Astros stadium for their company, building a new office tower and writing checks for every civic cause. Through Enron, above all, Houston, long the capital of the world's oil industry, was extending its claim to natural gas and electricity. 
 Suddenly, any tie to Enron has become a liability. In April 1999, Enron signed a 30-year, $100 million contract for the naming rights to the new baseball stadium. Today the Astros, are wondering what the future holds. "It's really a sad day for Enron and for Houston," said Pam Gardner, the Astros' president for business operations. Though Enron is current on its payments, she said, "It is all up in the air." 
 Though construction on Enron's new building continues, developers of other projects are thinking twice. Work on Trammell Crow's Ballpark Place, a shopping, office and apartment project downtown, had been set to start at the end of last month. 
While the terrorist attacks and the recession had already raised doubts, Matt Khourie, Trammell Crow senior managing director, said that he will now delay, until at least the first half of next year. "Recent events with Enron, where no one is quite certain what the final resolution would be," he said, "really is the factor we had to consider when deciding whether to start this month or not." 
Jim Kollaer, president of the Greater Houston Partnership, a leading civic group, said that Enron's donations to the United Way and a host of other causes were at risk, as were its dealings with a broad range of businesses. "Their vendors range from the people who are designing the interior spaces of their new office tower to the people who run the Starbucks coffee bar in the lobby, to the attorneys, to the bankers, to the traders, to the clients," Mr. Kollaer said. 
Many among Enron's 7,000 Houston employees are bitterly protesting the loss of retirement savings invested in its stock they recently were forbidden from selling. For them, the immediate future will be tough, whatever the outcome. "Six months ago, nine months ago, people were calling me to hire me away," said one employee who asked to be identified only as Jorge. "No one's called this week. So I think my market value has gone down, along with Enron's." 
 MAUREEN BALLEZA

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AN OVERVIEW: DEC. 1, 2001; 
Report of Raid Gone Awry, Music in Kabul and the Looming Economy

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
Although things could still go wrong for American forces and their allies in Afghanistan, the end of the Taliban was in sight. American B-52's relentlessly bombed Taliban troops holding out in Kandahar, their last bastion, with the unmistakable message being that surrender was their only way out.
 CLOSING IN ON TALIBAN -- At the Pentagon, a senior official said that anti-Taliban Afghan groups controlled the roads north and south of Kandahar, and United States marines reinforced a defensive perimeter around the city. Taliban forces seemed to be pinned down, with "no sign of movement whatsoever," the official said. 
 But no one underestimated the bitter-end determination of some in the Taliban, notably the Pakistanis, Arabs and other foreigners among them who have fought hard. An example of their ferocity was the surrender of a surprisingly large number of these fighters at the Qala Jangi fortress, where hundreds of people had died, including an American intelligence official, during a revolt by Taliban prisoners.
It had been thought that only a few holdouts remained. Instead, more than 80 finally emerged from their bunker and surrendered to forces of the Northern Alliance. They were a wretched sight -- starving, barefoot, soaking wet and filthy. They gave up only because "there was nothing left," one man said. "We had no ammunition, no weapons, no food."
VILLAGES ARE HIT -- On things perhaps going wrong, there was an American air raid over Tora Bora, the cave complex in eastern Afghanistan where Osama bin Laden may be hiding. Although military officials vigorously denied missing their target, residents of nearby villages said that bombs fell on them, killing scores of civilians -- at least 70 some said, and maybe many more.
As the fighting continued, so did talks in Germany on the shape of a post-Taliban government. Negotiators worked into the night trying not to let a possible deal slip through their fingers.
CHANGES IN KABUL -- There can be little doubt that Kabul, the Afghan capital, is changed now that the Taliban are gone, and with them their iron-fisted brand of Islam. For the first time in five years, young women enrolled at an Afghan university. That is a far cry from the Taliban days, when girls over 8 could not go to school.
In recent days, a surgeon who is a woman operated on a patient for the first time in years. A businessman took forbidden paintings out of storage. A singer and his friends made music. Yes, there is change. But perhaps only up to a point. Most women, for example, still shroud themselves in head-to-toe burkas, even though the virtue-and-vice police have disappeared. They are afraid, one woman said, and "it is going to take time."
IT'S THE ECONOMY -- Americans of the Vietnam War generation will remember Senator George Aiken, the Vermont Republican who urged the United States to declare victory in Southeast Asia and get out. A rough equivalent has been suggested to President Bush by advisers who want him to claim victory as soon as possible in the war on terror, and then focus on the economy.
The debate is over how to calibrate the president's priorities. He has told Americans to brace themselves for sustained battle against terrorists and can hardly seem to be sounding a premature retreat. But he also knows well the fate of his father, who was enormously popular after the Persian Gulf War in 1991, only to lose the 1992 election. The lesson, some advisers are telling Mr. Bush, is that the economy trumps war, and the country may not cut him much slack.
PRICE OF SORROW -- The pain caused by the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center keeps taking new forms, one being the price of sorrow. Extraordinary sums, at least $353 million, have been raised by charities distributing money solely to 400 or so families of firefighters, police officers and other uniformed rescuers. That comes to about $880,000 per family -- apart from insurance payments, pensions, scholarships and other money that can be expected.
But what about the families of the civilians who died at the trade center? Many feel neglected by a nation far more eager to embrace firefighters' widows. Their loved ones were victims, too, they say, yet that fact is not reflected in the aid distribution. Emerging divisions among survivors worry people in the charity field. Even some who have raised money for the uniformed workers are uncomfortable with a perception that grief has a caste system. CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: Rural Irish Post Offices to Double as Banks 

BYLINE:  By BRIAN LAVERY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Dec. 1 

 BODY:
In a deal that may set a pattern for sustaining rural financial services elsewhere in Europe, the Irish postal system agreed this week to begin handling some banking transactions for customers of Allied Irish Banks at 1,000 of its 1,800 post offices. 
 As decades of emigration and urbanization have drained rural Ireland of much of its population, it has become harder to justify the cost of maintaining small-town bank branches and post offices. 
 But small communities depend on them as an economic and social nexus and a lifeline -- especially the post offices, which commonly follow a model rarely seen in the United States outside the most remote towns. They are generally attached to a family-run small business, like a convenience store or pub, and are run as a part-time sideline by the proprietor, who does it for the social standing as much as for the small paycheck, and often dispenses local gossip along with stamps. 
The national postal system, known by its Gaelic name, An Post, has been trying to keep these rural post offices viable by adding services, like accepting utility bill payments and dispensing welfare benefits -- though the welfare function has been challenged by the European Union as anticompetitive.
On a parallel track, the country's big banks have been looking for relief from the costs of serving rural areas. Allied Irish Banks's principal competitor, the Bank of Ireland, has provoked protests from customers and labor unions for closing branches.
Arranging with An Post to have rural postal workers double as bank tellers has obvious benefits for Allied Irish, but the bank insisted that the deal was not a precursor to widespread branch closings of its own. In fact, it promised to keep all its current branches open for at least two more years.
The service will begin in July and will be exclusive for two years; after that, An Post could make similar deals with other banks.

HEADLINE: THE CLOSE READER; 
Martha Stewart Brings Us All Together

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz 

 BODY:
MARTHA STEWART'S dazzling brand has been slightly dimmed over the years by critics aghast at her transmogrification of the most routine household chores into acts of domestic theater. Let it never be said, however, that in this she misconstrues the spirit of Christmas. Her Christmas publications, like the 1997 "Christmas With Martha Stewart Living" and the "Martha by Mail" 2001 holiday catalog, are as overstuffed as stockings with recipes and instructions for making geometric chocolates, professional-looking ornaments, fir-draped fireplaces and glistening banquets of prime rib and Yorkshire pudding served on the best silver. The very over-the-top-ness of Martha's productions testifies to her deep understanding of the holiday. Christmas has always been a time for extremes. That the extreme in her case should be a labor-intensive effort to summon up the ghost of Christmases past supposedly enjoyed by British gentlefolk in homes run by invisible servants amid cheery fires and well-heeled visitors proves mainly that she is a woman with an uncanny ability to capitalize on American dreams. 
 What does Martha know? That the essence of Christmas is its appeal to nostalgia, whatever languid fantasy the nostalgia may happen to express. Even the earliest Christmases celebrated a yesteryear that existed only in the imagination. The church invented the holiday four centuries after the birth and death of Jesus Christ largely to steal thunder from Roman winter festivities, which tended toward drunkenness, overconsumption and fertility rites. No one, not even the church fathers, knew when and where and under what circumstances Christ had been born. The Gospel accounts don't provide much in the way of historical detail, and Jesus' immediate followers would probably have considered it idolatrous to celebrate his birthday, since that was sort of thing done for earthly kings. Just because the feast of the Nativity came along relatively late, though, doesn't mean it lacks a lasting power: there are good literary reasons we can't conceive of the mystery of the Incarnation -- the divine embodiment of the son of God -- without summoning up the images of an infant, a mother, a stable, worshipful animals and solemn magi. 
 Slightly more than a millennium later, the Puritans turned against Christmas for its lack of a textual basis, to say nothing of its well-preserved pagan rituals. These had evolved into elaborate displays of wealth by the rich and public cross-dressing, aggressive begging and scenes of near anarchy by everyone else. During the first two centuries of American history, good Christians ignored Christmas, working through the day, at least in the Northern American states, though it often occasioned parties on Southern plantations. In the early 19th century a group of wealthy New Yorkers, including the writer Washington Irving and the author of " 'Twas the Night Before Christmas," rebelled against the Puritan ban on the holiday. What we now think of as the standard American Christmas was in part their creation.
The historian Eric Hobsbawm has called what these 19th-century citizens did "the invention of tradition"; a common academic term for made-up customs is "fakelore." A less sneering way to think of this is that we experienced an extraordinary outburst of national creativity. Cultural historians have recently begun to focus on these homegrown Christmas rituals; indeed, in the past decade there has arisen something of a cottage industry in American Christmas studies, and our "fakelore" has been extensively chronicled. Among the elements that scholars have identified as essential ingredients in the Americanized Christmas are Santa Claus, the Christmas tree and the giving of gifts. Santa Claus was a clever Yankee repackaging of St. Nicholas, the patron saint of children, whose feast day was Dec. 6. ("'Twas the Night Before Christmas" helped make him a national hero.) Christmas trees came from Germany by way of German immigrants: the idea of bringing nature indoors charmed our burgeoning Romantic sensibility, and the lustrous adornment of the home appealed to the nesting instincts of the emerging American bourgeoisie. 
The best thing to happen to the American Christmas, though, was gift exchange. In some places and families this is now so extensive it amounts to what anthropologists call "potlatch," huge feasts held by tribal heads who compete for prestige by doling out gifts of bankrupting proportions. Up through the mid-19th century, gift giving took place on New Year's Day, but the custom migrated to Christmas once that holiday captured the American imagination. Our end-of-the-year potlatch, accompanied by the high artistry of marketing strategists and cultural impresarios and department store window dressers, has become an indispensable part of our economy, spurring consumption and production and serving as a general boost to our well-being.
In less than a century and a half, we have turned the American Christmas into an adoration less of a divine Christ than of the quasi-divine in us -- our homes, children, families and communities. Religiously, Christmas is, as it has always been, a mad syncretic mishmash of pagan and Protestant and Catholic and New Age doctrine and ritual. Why do we feel compelled to wrinkle our noses at this populist amalgam, with its delirium of buying and wrapping and consuming and visiting? Aren't these sociable pleasures just what we want as afternoons disappear into night and the cold sets in? If there is such a thing as an authentic Christmas tradition, it would have to be overdoing it -- spending and drinking and eating too much and hanging out at length with friends, a habit that goes back to the Romans, if not before, and that Christianity has only intermittently managed to stamp out. 
But we also use the holiday as a chance to dwell in the shadow of a wondrous made-up past, which seems as fine a way as any to pass a dark season. Some nostalgia takes the form of fretting about whether there's any Christ left in Christmas, as if he and not the frenzy of carnival ever really dominated the day. Some people obey the orders given in the Martha Stewart books and give over their Decembers to the making of shopping lists and clever little items, as well as the pursuit of epicurean festivities, secure in the belief that this will bring them closer to the ideal of gentrified country living -- and who's to say that it doesn't? Others, like me, observe Hanukkah, a minor Jewish holiday blown wildly out of proportion to offer an alternative to our nation's irresistible winter solstice festival. But if dreaming of invented traditions is what we're doing, at least we're doing it together, and that strikes me as the point.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Robert Grossman)

HEADLINE: STYLE; 
The Last Word

 BODY:
Carrie Donovan introduced The Times Magazine's readers to Donna Karan for the first time in May 1986, and this is how Donovan captured her: "The designer strides forth, a freshly filled coffee mug in her hand, a big bag over her shoulder, dark glasses hiding some of her usually unmade-up face, which is framed by brunet hair casually tossed here and there. At 37, Donna Karan is a noticeable person, not beautiful, but handsome, with an infectious smile and a commanding voice accented unmistakably with the vowels of New York." That description is affectionate and blunt, insightful and superficial, typical for Donovan, who loved to play up the dichotomies of her own character. A few months before that cover article ran, a home videotape captured Karan accepting congratulations backstage after her first show. At the celebration, Donovan sat knee to knee with the triumphant, glowing designer and gazed gleefully into the camera: "My daughter Donna," Donovan beamed. "I'm so proud of her." Karan turned her attention away from Donovan only for a moment to look with ardor at her husband, Stephan Weiss, who gave her a short kiss, then a longer one. 
 This year, Karan lost both her husband and her surrogate fashion mother. Donovan, who left behind only her industry children, the designers she discovered, died Nov. 12. As part of a series for the magazine she was working on, called "Conversations With Carrie," she revisited Donna Karan at a landmark moment in the designer's career. The interview was to come out when Karan's store opened in September. Then, when Donovan became increasingly ill, it was rescheduled to coincide with the acquisition of Donna Karan International by LVMH Group last month. Ever a pro, Donovan was determined to write the introduction and edit the transcript of the interview herself. It may have been the first deadline she ever missed. 
 Over Labor Day weekend, Karan dropped in at Donovan's house in the Hamptons to have their chat, the last interview Donovan would do in a long career. "I hadn't seen Carrie in a long time," Karan says. "But when someone is with you, they're with you forever, regardless of the time that passes. We had that kind of connection. She was like my mother, but she was my mentor, an inspiration, and my teacher. I wanted to perform for her, to please her. I can't tell you how emotional it was, the highs and the lows of it. Of course, I wanted to reminisce. She wanted to go forward."

You want to talk to somebody. There will be a tea bar in there. We'll also have soup and tea and --.
C.D.: How are the salespeople?
D.K.: Oh, the best. But more important than anything, if I have to train them personally myself, I will. I'll probably be more in the store than I will be in the designing room now. Because I want to do couture. I want to do made-to-measure there. I want to make custom-made suits.
C.D.: Black suits.
D.K.: You know, my whole life history in fashion has been so dramatic. Everything has been dramatic. It's a drug. It's the thing that keeps us going. It never stays still. That's why I'm not into the return of the style of the 70's or the 80's. I've lived it. You know? I don't want to go back.
C.D.: We were there. We were there.
D.K.: I lived it too much. It's too close to me. You know? I'm more interested in the places I didn't live. I'm more interested in the turn of the century. I'm more interested in past cultures. And now I'm starting to get really fascinated in technology on a different level.
C.D.: The technical thing must be riveting.
D.K.: Although the mouse gives me hives. We're visceral people. Visceral means we're feely, touchy, you know, speaky. It's all about, you know, our energies. Now, there is this flat, impersonal energy.
C.D.: But we need that energy.
D.K.: So we're definitely going to be moving forward. I think the world in general is coming together as one. I don't think fashion is any different than the rest of the world. Fashion is a reflection of the world.
C.D.: As it always has been.
D.K.: A mess. (laughs)
C.D.: As it always has been.
D.K.: And yet, everyone is looking for something to give them pleasure. Something that's going to make a difference. Something that's going to say, "I'm new." I remember when I started my company, we were in a recession.
C.D.: Yes, we were. In 1987.
D.K.: But how wonderful to restart my company in a recession again. I'm very positive about that.
You know, Bernard Arnault chairman and C.E.O. of LVMH --.
C.D.: I was just going to ask you, have you met him? Have you dealt with him?
D.K.: Not very much. But I have met intensely with Yves Carcelle president of LVMH Fashion Group .
C.D.: My impression always of Arnault was that he loosened up considerably after his second marriage. But I used to see him always at the shows in Europe. And he was always so cold, you know? He seemed so still, and his hair was even stiffer.
D.K.: (laughs) Very like me.
C.D.: Then when he married a second time, his hair got looser and more attractive. But I think that he's probably a top-notch businessman.
D.K.: Yeah
C.D.: I like that you're just taking this attitude about the store -- when it opens, it opens.
D.K.: My house isn't finished, my store is not finished, my apartment. . . . I don't have a place that I'm living. Because everything in my life is like this.
C.D.: Ever since I've known you, you know, you've always been. . . . 
D.K.: Building. 
C.D.: . . . reinventing, building, doing something. But I like your description of everything as sort of . . . how would we say that in words? 
D.K.: Everything's under construction. (laughs)
C.D.: Everything in your life is. . . . 
D.K.: Being built. Nothing is the way it was.

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-02-01: ON LANGUAGE; 
Clintonyms

BYLINE:  By William Safire 

 BODY:
'Bill Clinton is a relic of another age," the essayist Lance Morrow wrote in Time magazine, "like the 20's party boy F. Scott Fitzgerald stranded in the landscape of the Great Depression." 
 I rise today to our immediate past president's linguistic defense. Let me tell you about the very articulate. They are different from you and me. The Lexicographic Irregulars, asked in this space to choose the phrases that Bill Clinton would be remembered by, responded with words that evoke an era of intense controversy and vituperation. Respondents included his critics and his speechwriters, those nostalgic for the time of prosperity and peace as well as for the days of whine and nosiness. 
 The most memorable Clintonym (a coinage of F. Gwynplaine MacIntyre) chosen by a plurality of entries was a sentence that thrilled every semanticist, grammarian and syntactician in the nation: "It depends on what the meaning of the word 'is' is."
The words that raised parsing to a fine art were spoken under oath to a grand jury. They were about a statement made by the president's lawyer during a deposition about the relationship with a White House intern, in which the lawyer asserted, "There is absolutely no sex of any kind." Clinton pointed out that because his attorney had been speaking only in the present tense, the statement was true: "It depends on what the meaning of the word 'is' is," he explained, adding, "Actually, in the present tense, that is a true statement." That is indisputable: during the deposition, no sex of any kind was taking place between them. 
What made the sentence so memorable? Part was the exquisite nature of the literal reading, taken by Clinton critics to be an infuriating example of legalistic slipperiness. Another part was the unique juxtaposition of the quoted is with the unquoted is. The sentence would not have had the same puissance -- indeed, it might not be destined for the next edition of Bartlett's Familiar Quotations -- had it concluded with "the meaning of 'is' was."
I feel your pain, an expression of compassion often associated with psychiatric jargon, was the runner-up in this sample (which has an accuracy estimated at plus or minus 60 points). The remark was ad-libbed at a March 26, 1992, campaign rally as part of a riposte to an AIDS activist who angrily accused the candidate of avoiding the issue. The candidate, who later became a champion of gay rights, came back with: "I feel your pain, I feel your pain, but if you want to attack me personally . . . go support somebody else for president." He ameliorated that with, "I know you're hurting, but you won't stop hurting by trying to hurt other people." 
Tied for second place, thanks to its repetition thousands of times on television, is his statement of Jan. 26, 1998: "I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Miss Lewinsky." What made it memorable was not only its unequivocal tone but also its accompaniment by a wagging finger. More than the words, the stern digit fixes it firmly in the national memory. 
A charge leveled by Hillary Rodham Clinton at her husband's nattering, battering cottage industry of vilifiers makes it into the political lexicon. On Jan. 27, 1998, during the month that the most memorable Clinton locutions were launched, the first lady told a television interviewer, Matt Lauer of the "Today Show," that she and her husband were targets of "a vast, right-wing conspiracy." (That is most frequently written without a comma between the adjective vast and the compound adjective right-wing; such an error is not attributable to Mrs. Clinton but to the vast right wing.) 
"I didn't inhale," which was widely quoted in derision early in the Clinton era, seems to be on the decline in quoted recollection. Regarding the use of drugs, Governor Clinton of Arkansas said in 1992 that "when I was in England I experimented with marijuana a time or two, and I didn't like it. I didn't inhale it and never tried it again." (The phrasal verb experimented with became the operative term in such admissions, giving the action an almost scientific connotation, rather than "smoked" or "used.") It was the careful plea of guilty with an explanation -- of smoking but not inhaling -- that struck many as ludicrously clever, but the phrase was overtaken by "is' is."
Clinton enthusiasts are proud of "The era of big government is over," spoken in his 1996 State of the Union address, a stunning statement from a Democrat, somewhat tempered by "but we cannot go back to the time when our citizens were left to fend for themselves." This was described by his public-opinion aide, Richard Morris, as triangulation, the positioning of a politician above two contending ideologies, a geometric updating of "stealing the opposition's clothes." 
Another Clintonism that those who remember his administration fondly like to recall is the campaign semislogan, "It's the economy, stupid." This was a sign posted by his campaign manager, James Carville, and not a statement by the candidate. Clinton did say in his stump speeches, "My responsibility is to grow this economy," which was effective though it drew the ire of grammatical purists who objected to the use of the intransitive verb to grow in a transitive form. 
Students of regional dialect recall with fondness Clinton's use of Ozark expressions. The most memorable of these was spoken at a Feb. 15, 1992, rally where the Arkansas governor said that he hoped people would see him "working hard, reaching out to them and fighting until the last dog dies." (As 'til the last dog is hung, this has been traced to a 1902 novel set in Michigan.) Clinton also contributed this proverb to the political lexicon: "Even a blind hog can find an acorn."
Perhaps the most poignant of the memorable Clintonyms was recalled by Uzi Amit-Kohn of Jerusalem. In a farewell to Yitzhak Rabin on Nov. 5, 1995, after the Israeli leader's assassination, Clinton said, "Shalom, chaver," which translates from the Hebrew as "Goodbye, friend" or "Peace, friend." 
These statements are hardly the relics of a forgotten age. But as F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in his notebook, "There are no second acts in American lives." And "show me a hero, and I will write you a tragedy." And in "The Great Gatsby," his unforgettable, "So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."

HEADLINE: THE CITIES; 
In Paterson, an Unusual Alliance

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: PATERSON 

 BODY:
THE Great Falls of the Passaic have always signified Paterson's history, the place where Alexander Hamilton envisioned the country's first planned industrial city.
 Later the falls symbolized, at least to some, less glorious chapters of the city's past. Today, there are those who see them as the very key to Paterson's future. 
 Until recently, Thomas C. Rooney, a 74-year-old veteran councilman and former mayor, was known more for his stands against taxes than for vision.
Yet over the summer it was Mr. Rooney who led a campaign to halt construction of 57 two-family townhouses on a historic tract in the Great Falls Historic District -- oddly enough, a plan he once voted for. In its place he proposed an unusual theme park. 
Surprisingly, he sought and won help for his efforts from a political foe from the 1960's and 70's, former Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer.
With the death of the townhouse plan and after other failed proposals over 25 years, preservationists see this as the last chance to build something historically significant and economically beneficial on the deteriorating seven-acre site, where, among other things, the Colt revolver and the nation's first skein of sewing silk were born. 
"The thing we need to embrace is the concept that we're going to develop this place as a heritage tourism destination -- tourism based on the history of the area," said David Soo of Paterson Friends of the Great Falls, a nonprofit preservation group that took the townhouse plan to court.
Mr. Rooney is the first to have made a detailed proposal: a self-sustaining theme park, including preserved factory buildings, an Indian village, boat excursions, and construction of a foot bridge over the Passaic River and a catwalk below and across from the falls. 
"Tourists will bring us revenue and help provide jobs for our people who will work here," Mr. Rooney told the council last summer. "They will leave and spread the word of how grand a trip they had."
Mr. Rooney's enthusiasm was matched only by the disinterest of Mayor Marty Barnes, who favored townhouses at the site and said he did not need another park to maintain.
"Now were talking about creating Disneyland," Mr. Barnes complained.
But even those who have reservations see Mr. Rooney's plan as a catalyst for further discussion.
"Apparently what turned things around was when Tom Rooney came out with his idea," said Flavia Alaya, a former president of the Paterson Historic Preservation Commission. "Even if it never gets into place, where there was nothing before and where people didn't have imagination, there is something now to consider."
The site's future is likely to be a campaign issue when Mayor Barnes seeks re-election in May. The outcome is also of interest because Congress has approved a study of whether to designate the Great Falls Historic District as a national park.
Passaic County Vision 2020, a nonprofit planning group, endorsed the Rooney plan after Mr. Rooney and Mr. Kramer appeared before the group.
"We were really thrilled by it," said Pat Di Ianni, president of the organization. "We're not saying that particular plan as a whole is the way it's going to be, but it's such a wonderful concept, and he's really thought this thing out."
Mayor Barnes is not buying.
"We're trying to look for a development, whether it's a hotel or some housing," he said. "The bottom line is it needs to generate dollars."
For his part, Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., who was mayor here when the townhouses were proposed in the mid-1990's, said elements of Mr. Rooney's plan could be folded into any development, though he still favored residential housing on the site.
"The falls has its own special place in American history," Mr. Pascrell said. "The district does, too, in terms of manufacturing, but it also has a special place for all immigrants who came in one wave after another. I don't want to put up a purple rope around the district."
The site in question -- where the Allied Textile Printing Corp. operated until the early 1970's -- is a fenced-in wasteland of overgrown vegetation, stacks of old clothes, piles of empty beer cans and hulks of dozens of brick factories destroyed by fire. The Colt Gun Mill, built in 1836, is a brownstone shell. 
Mayor Barnes said Paterson had received a $250,000 federal grant to study developing the Passaic River waterfront, and the city would seek proposals to develop it.
The Rooney plan, "Walk Back In Time 10,000 Years!", would begin with a clean-up of the buildings. Those worth saving would be shaped up and given historical markers.
Paying visitors would enter a welcoming center with a small restaurant and follow paths among the buildings and archeological digs to a Leni-Lenape village with wigwams, long houses and sculptures of people going about daily life.
A dock would be built from which boats would travel to the falls or down the Passaic. A foot bridge built over the Passaic would lead to a path and then a tunnel -- drilled though a rock wall leading to a platform and catwalk -- from which people could look up at the 77-foot waterfall.
Mr. Rooney is an unlikely champion. As head of the Paterson Taxpayers Association in the late 1960's, mayor in the early 1970's and a councilman since 1980, he has been seen as a nuts-and-bolts type to whom you could give your wallet and not have to count the money later.
Even he would admit to a lack of imagination when it came to the value of saving old mills, unlike Mr. Kramer, 69, and his late wife, Mary Ellen, who fought to divert a Route 80 ramp from destroying the factory area and got it designated a national historic district. 
"I just didn't get it," Mr. Rooney said.
What changed him, he said, was a tour of the site several years ago with Friends of the Great Falls. 
"I literally felt I wasn't in the current Paterson at all," Mr. Rooney recalled. "You can't hear trucks or cars or any of the noise of the city. It's almost spooky."
He went on: "It had an impact on me like nothing else has in a long time. And that's when I realized it was outrageous to fill this in and lose all of this." 
Mr. Kramer, who is now executive vice president of V. Paulius & Associates, a design consulting company in Allendale, was surprised to get a call from Mr. Rooney, whom he had beaten in four mayoral elections, last July. 
The two mayors, now both white-haired grandfathers, met at The Bonfire, a restaurant where political maneuvering has been as much a part of the atmosphere as the food.
"He had had an epiphany," Mr. Kramer said, recalling that Mr. Rooney was almost teary-eyed. "He said, 'I feel terrible about things. I never understood Mary Ellen's and your commitment to the historic district. If it isnt too late, I want you to help me.' "
Mr. Kramer, who does not agree with every aspect of the Rooney plan -- the tunnel for one -- said he would. He talked to Mayor Barnes about getting out of the townhouse deal and appeared before the council to ask it to remove the developer and support the Rooney plan. In September, the council rescinded the contract with Regan Development Corporation of Yonkers, which it had approved in 1995. 
At the end of his report, which Mr. Rooney read to the council, he wrote: "Other men and women in past years worked hard to elevate our historic district and the falls into a major drawing card for our city. Most notable were former Mayor Lawrence Pat Kramer and his wife, Mary Ellen. This proposal should build on their work."
To which Mr. Kramer said: "You've got to take your hat off to Tom. This is not a politician speaking here. I was moved by the fact he was big enough to say, 'I didn't see this. You were right.' A lot of guys talk a big game, but he put it in writing."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A Sashay To the Right, Some Smiles From the Left

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT was a wish list for corporate lobbyists and conservative ideologues alike. As such, the tax bill pushed through the House this fall by Representative Bill Thomas of California, the Republican chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, was clearly an opening gambit in what was sure to be an intense partisan battle over how to revive the economy. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill even dismissed it as "show business."
 It went well beyond what President Bush had been seeking, particularly in granting some of the nation's biggest companies the right to claim, immediately, billions of dollars in tax credits built up over 15 years under the corporate alternative minimum tax. But the administration, Mr. O'Neill's comments notwithstanding, did little to distance itself from the Thomas bill, which has come to embody the Republican position on economic stimulus. 
 In one sense, the bill has had its intended effect. It ensured that bipartisan negotiations over a stimulus package would start so far to the right that Democrats could hope for little more than to drag them back to the center. For that, Mr. Bush is no doubt grateful.
But in another way, Mr. Thomas's strategy has backfired. His bill's focus on business tax cuts -- 70 percent of its benefits in the first year would go to companies -- has proved a political windfall for Democrats. The legislation casts Republicans as champions of corporate interests and the rich at a time when the country is arguably looking for selflessness.
For that reason alone, some Democrats have not been unhappy that negotiations on the stimulus package have bogged down. Every day that people read about a bill that would grant I.B.M. a $1.4 billion tax rebate while turning aside Democratic calls for more assistance to laid-off workers is another chance to convince voters that Republicans in general and Mr. Bush in particular are no friends of the little guy.
Moreover, the stimulus bill fits a broader pattern of economic policy decisions in which the administration has been criticized for rushing to deal with distressed industries -- first airlines and now insurers -- while dawdling over help for individuals.
Democracy Corps, a liberal advocacy group headed by James Carville, Stanley B. Greenberg and Robert M. Shrum, three of the most experienced Democratic strategists, surveyed voters recently about post-Sept. 11 economic policy. In focus groups, they reported, people could almost not believe that some of the Republican proposals were for real, especially the repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax and the provision allowing immediate refunds to big companies.
"After they accepted the proposition that this was actually happening, they were furious," said Jim Gerstein, the executive director of Democracy Corps. "Items in the package like the A.M.T. repeal are completely at odds with the mood of the country following the attacks. If this is the defining element of the stimulus debate and the overall economic debate, it is very advantageous for Democrats."
It is not that the public is against tax cuts. A recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll found 50 percent support for the basic Republican approach to reviving the economy -- tax cuts, with a special emphasis on tax breaks that encourage businesses to invest and create jobs.
Even the Democracy Corps poll found very high levels of support for many Republican ideas, including accelerating the planned reduction in income tax rates for middle- and upper-income people.
THE notion that Republicans want to cut business taxes because they are beholden to corporate lobbyists and campaign contributors may have some truth to it, but it obscures a more important point: Republicans don't cut taxes because they are told to. They cut taxes because it is in their political DNA to do so. Cutting taxes, more than any other issue, is what defines the party.
It helps that there are also legitimate economic arguments in favor of the Republican approach, which is based on the reasonable notion that helping companies -- or employers, as Republicans are now careful to call them -- will create jobs by supporting renewed investment in plant and equipment.
Moreover, with his job-approval ratings at record levels and the nation much more consumed for now with the war against terrorism than with the lurching of the economy, Mr. Bush has not yet felt much of the political pressure to back away from the Republican orthodoxy. Besides, he managed to push the biggest tax cut in 20 years through Congress this year even though public opinion was lukewarm at best.
In the end, Mr. Thomas's bill may help Mr. Bush get much of what he wants in the stimulus plan. Whether that proves to be a political victory will have to wait on whether the economy bounces back quickly and strongly.
Because once the shooting war in Afghanistan starts winding down, public attention will shift to the recession and what the president is doing to help. And as the current president's father learned a decade ago, the political glow from a well-prosecuted war fades faster than you can say "rising unemployment."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
A House Divided. Senate, Too.

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE post-Sept. 11 Congress has now almost fully abandoned its briefly adopted pose of high-minded bipartisanship, when it put aside political advantage and even submerged principled differences to unite the nation. 
 Democrats probably started it. Senator Barbara Boxer of California said that a Republican tax cut plan "to reward their biggest contributors is nothing less than unpatriotic." Representative Sherrod Brown of Ohio said, "This kind of political profiteering by House Republicans is downright shameful." 
 But Republicans joined in gleefully. Representative Sue Myrick of North Carolina said that any effort to vote more funds for New York City or homeland defense "is a vote to delay support for our men and women in Afghanistan." Representative Tom DeLay, the Republican whip from Texas, accused Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, who proposed the homeland spending, of being "the last guy we want to trust on national security" because he voted against last year's defense bill.
At times it seems that the only change the Capitol since Sept.11 is that new subjects are exposing traditional differences. 
President Bush has stayed above this fray, thus far safe from personal attack and in no need of the self-pity of some beleaguered wartime presidents (remember Lyndon Johnson's "I'm the only President you've got"?).
Lawmakers may be using the war on terrorism as another reason to try to do what they would be trying to do anyway, but is there anything really wrong when politicians remember their differences and find new areas of disagreement? 
No, says the public. A mid-November CBS News Poll showed that majorities, even of Republicans, find nothing offensive in criticizing the president, be it over economic policy or the conduct of the war. Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster, said even in wartime "honest disagreements over real issues are viewed as completely fair game."
No, say the historians. "We're used to argument," said Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the historian, who served in World War II. Joel Silbey, a Cornell historian, said, "It's happened in every war I know of." Michael Kazin, a Georgetown historian, said, "It's one of the great glories of democracy, it doesn't take a break for wartime." 
In some past wars, conflicts have come from the president's party and focused on the conduct of the war, or even the war itself. Lincoln was bedeviled by his own Republicans, who thought he wasn't opposing slavery adequately or that his generals were too cautious. Democrats were Lyndon Johnson's severest critics on Vietnam. 
Wartime fights have often been institutional, with Congress fearing that popular presidents were assuming too much power. It thought Woodrow Wilson's plan to arm merchant ships was provocative. Mr. Johnson and Richard Nixon were both challenged on their authority to make war in Vietnam. Democrats took the lead, but important Republicans joined them. 
To date, the only areas where the Bush administration faces Congressional scrutiny are civil liberties and military tribunals. Democratic leaders are keeping their distance from Senator Patrick J. Leahy and the Judiciary Committee, while Republican support is token. This dismays John Morton Blum, a retired Yale historian, who said, "There has been lots to oppose and just about dead silence from the Democrats."
Most partisan, as opposed to institutional, exploitation of war situations has come on domestic issues. In the Civil War, Mr. Blum said, "The Republicans used the war to get through legislation they had been supporting right along -- a protective tariff, a National Bank act, land legislation." It was easy, of course, because the bulk of the Congressional Democrats had departed as secessionist southerners. 
IN World War II, there was little Congressional criticism of military decisions. But tough going on the battlefields, unhappiness over rationing and wage and price controls, and the fact that hardly any soldiers voted produced major Republican gains in the 1942 elections. 
As David M. Kennedy, a Stanford historian, wrote in "Freedom From Fear," the new "Congress moved swiftly to lay the New Deal finally in its grave, and then to drive a stake through its heart." It eliminated or deeply cut agencies from the Civilian Conservation Corps to the Rural Electrification Administration.
Today, no solid majorities exist in either house, but long before Sept. 11, "compromise" had become an epithet in a polarized capital. The fact that this war occurs during a recession (and is worsening it) makes compromising even more difficult, because party principles differ most profoundly on economic policy. Republicans think tax cuts help the economy grow; Democrats want to help workers directly. 
INDEED, the economy is the only area where a leading Democrat has taken the plunge and criticized Mr. Bush, however blandly. Last week Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, said: "The president is managing the war well. He is mismanaging the economy with the help of his colleagues in the Senate and the House." 
Even Mr. Blum concedes, "The stimulus package is about the only thing that is getting the usual partisan flak." 
That should be no surprise. As Mr. Kazin observed, "You might say there is a heightened intensity to these economic arguments during wartime.
"If you look at some of the debates in World War II, they are quite vicious," he said. In the 1944 election, along with attacks over who was responsible for unsanctioned strikes, "Republicans basically accused the main labor supporter of Franklin Roosevelt, Sidney Hillman, of being a Communist."
Partisanship in wartime may be inevitable. While a parliamentary government like Great Britain's could postpone elections during World War II, in the United States they happen every two years. As David Herbert Donald, the retired Harvard expert on Lincoln, said, "I think Lincoln would have liked to have a kind of bipartisan government." He tried occasionally, but "the old bonds of party were too strong." 
Today, Democrats are using legislative battles to gear up to run the 2002 elections. Republicans will surely invoke the war and the popular Mr. Bush, but they are not counting on their coattails. 
They may have one relatively new political weapon. For all that the public is willing to see parties argue their principles, the very word "partisan" (like "compromise") has become a dirty word. While the Democrats position themselves as defenders of workers, count on the Republicans to accuse their foes of being partisan.
