HEADLINE: The Nation: Ledger Allegiance; 
My Bottom Line, Right or Wrong . . .

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
THE attacks of Sept. 11 were aimed at the symbolic heart of capitalism, but that does not mean the titans of industry feel obligated to join the fight on terrorism. 
 On numerous occasions since the attack, businesses have found themselves facing a choice between patriotic action or their bottom line. Politicians have suggested that investment houses would be caving to terrorism if they did not rebuild in New York, for example, and asked domestic wheat growers for understanding as they purchased Asian wheat for rapid food shipments to Afghanistan. They have encouraged American apparel manufacturers to continue to buy goods from Pakistan even in the face of rising insurance costs and local unrest. 
 Corporations are designed to make money -- not to meet patriotic or moral obligations. In times of peace, their focus on profit maximization usually dovetails with the goal of national prosperity. But in times of crisis, corporate and national interests can suddenly, uncomfortably diverge. 
In 1940 and 1941, for example, when it was becoming clear that America would soon be drawn into the war raging in Europe, many American corporations tried to duck government military contracts. One main reason: they feared they would end up paying for wartime production facilities that were useless in peacetime -- just as they had in World War I. 
The auto industry was particularly reluctant, because the civilian market was so lucrative. Until 1941, it fought restrictions on total auto output that would have freed resources for the defense effort.
In the end, the government essentially bought corporate cooperation, said Hugh Rockoff, an economic historian at Rutgers University specializing in World War II. 
"Government assumed most of the financial risk," he said, by allowing "firms to keep final title to the facilities they were building after writing the cost of construction off, against taxes, over five years." Later in the war, he said, the government simply built plants for companies and gave them to them. 
Such a risk-free guarantee for doing warwork is not necessarily ill-advised, according to economists. "The basis of business is the belief in the invisible hand" -- Adam Smith's shorthand for the way competitive forces themselves tend to regulate markets -- according to David Colander, the Kelley professor of distinguished teaching at Princeton. "Besides if firms were doing something strictly for a patriotic interest, they could be sued by shareholders." 
Even privately held companies have to be wary of doing things that are not strictly in their business interests. Malden Mills, the makers of Polartec fleece, kept its employees on the payroll while it rebuilt after a devastating fire six years ago -- and ended up filing for bankruptcy protection last week. 
There are historical instances of corporate sacrifice for civic good, but they are rare. 
The industrialist Andrew Carnegie was as cynical an operator as anyone. "One of the purest fallacies is that trade follows the flag," he once lectured. "Trade follows the lowest price current. If a dealer in any colony wished to buy the British Jack, he would order them from Britain's worst enemy if he could save a sixpence." 
But it was Mr. Carnegie who rounded up fellow industrialists to spend their own money to buttress a stock market in free-fall in 1929.Other financiers and financial institutions have also found themselves in the role of rescuers of capitalism. A recent example was in 1998, with the decision of a consortium of private lenders to keep the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management from dissolving all at once. (In both cases, of course, the financiers also managed to protect their own interests by keeping markets from collapsing.) 
There have been corporate sacrifices to help win wars, too. The Axis powers controlled the majority of natural rubber plantations during World War II. Standard Oil farmed out its patented method for making synthetic rubber to its American competitors -- albeit with encouragement (okay, arm twisting) from Congress. 
AFTER Sept. 11, airline, insurance and other industries looked to government for help. Government has started looking back.
When the government first suggested that to speed wheat to starving Afghans, it would buy it from Asia, some domestic wheat growers protested. Congress quickly convinced them to take the patriotic long view.
Backing down made good business sense in the end. As of mid-November, America had bought 15,000 metric tons of Kazakh wheat and 300,000 metric tons of American grain. 
Partly because Afghanistan has long been kept out of international markets by war and its aftermath, there are few immediate arenas where American national and business interests could collide. 
Next door, however, is another story. Pakistan's textile and apparel firms employ an astonishing 60 percent of the industrial work force, and American firms are the country's largest buyers. Or they used to be. Since Sept. 11, American orders have plummeted by two-thirds, according to Pakistani trade groups, and unemployment is soaring. 
That's bad news for the government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, which is already under fire for helping the United States from Pakistan's powerful radical Muslim minority. 
Among the United States firms that reduced their orders from Pakistan are American Eagle Outfitters and Tommy Hilfiger, two firms that have made a steady stream of profits on patriotic imagery here at home. 
"I agree it is likely detrimental to Pakistan to cancel orders," said Laura Wile, chief financial officer of American Eagle Outfitters. "But I think every company has to assess the risk/reward relationship for themselves."
But Ms. Lee would not listen to her mother because she loved her job as an administrative assistant at Aon Consulting, even though she traveled each day from Eltingville, Staten Island. And it was also true that Ms. Lee had quit smoking for eight months before the terrorist attack, and did not need to make all those trips to the plaza anymore. "She loved the people there," Mrs. Greene said. "She loved her boss. And she loved the view."

BRENDA E. CONWAY
Half of a Lifelong Team
Brenda E. Conway was hard to miss. First, because of her unique style -- an avid shopper, she preferred bright colors and patterns, and made funny socks her signature -- and second, because you usually saw two of her. Mrs. Conway was rarely without her twin, Linda McGee. Though they were fraternal, the sisters still looked and sounded enough alike to draw attention.
"They were always together," said their mother, Edith Watford, pastor of the Second Chance Christian Center in the Bronx.
Mrs. Conway was a native of the Bronx, and lived there with her husband, Russell, and children Danielle Alexander, 19, and Mandell Conway, 13. A systems analyst at Marsh & McLennan, on the 97th floor of the World Trade Center, she would have been 40, and she often said that she did not need to have a lot of friends, because she had a twin.
Her sister said, "People ask me, am I dealing with it, and sometimes I say, no, I'm not dealing with it. Everything reminds me of her, because we did everything together."
The weekend before Sept. 11, the twins took a "ladies' day out" shopping trip with their daughters. Mrs. Conway bought almost a whole new wardrobe, now untouched. "She left behind so many new things," her mother said.

YAPHET J. ARYEE
Taxes and Taxis
Yaphet J. Aryee was the person everyone went to for advice. "He was born in Ghana so he was the expert on that," said Ely Yulman, who worked with Mr. Aryee as an auditor with the State Division of Taxation and Finance, on the 86th floor of 2 World Trade Center. "He made his furniture when he got married, so people asked him how to fix the stairs in their house, or how to fix the engine in their car. But first of all, he was the smartest corporate tax auditor in the department. Millions and millions he brought in."
Like many other new immigrants, Mr. Aryee, 49, drove a cab when he first arrived in New York as a young man; hacking paid for bachelor's and master's degrees in business administration from Adelphi University. He and his wife, Maria, moved to Rockland County to raise their four children.
But Mr. Aryee never forgot his taxi, and in August he bought his own cab so he could begin driving again. "Only on weekends," Mr. Yulman said. "It was his hobby."

MICHAEL A. ULIANO
Pleasures of Shore and Stage
Michael A. Uliano, a broker for Cantor Fitzgerald, never changed much from the grinning 10-year-old boy who was profiled in 1969 by his Canton, Mass., paper for snagging a 20-pound bass off Cape Cod. That he had just recovered from a broken wrist only added to his reputation for athleticism.
For the next 32 years, relatives recall, Mr. Uliano returned often to the Cape to dig clams and test out fishing lures he fashioned from chenille and Krazy Glue. He rode the dunes in a 1973 Jeep whose grille he painted to look like a shark's mouth.
Work eventually brought Mr. Uliano to New York, and though he enjoyed being a broker for Cantor Fitzgerald, he really wanted to act. So much, said his sister, Martha King, that he even endured teasing as a student at Ithaca College when he took ballet lessons as a way to improve his football game and prepare for a possible theatrical career.
When he met Linda Buffa in Bay Ridge in 1993, she took note of his Boston accent. He ribbed her about her Noo Yawk habit of talking while chewing gum. They were married in 1996 in Las Vegas, with an Elvis impersonator giving away the bride.
Life had darker moments, too. In March, Ms. Buffa learned she had breast cancer. "Thank God, he was here for that," she said. Daily radiation treatments kept her from attending a ceremony in his honor in which the Canton high school retired the Number 10, which he wore as its quarterback.

ERIC THORPE
Ball Carrier on Wall Street
The booming voice, competitiveness and self-assurance that helped Eric Thorpe become the star quarterback of his undefeated high school football team in Wilbraham, Mass., served him well on Wall Street. Mr. Thorpe, 35, known as Rick, was one of the top salesmen at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.
But Mr. Thorpe kept business success in perspective. He helped run a soup kitchen during college, served as a Big Brother and participated in Hands Together, an anti-poverty program in Haiti. Having grown up in a close family -- he referred to his father, Raymond, as his best friend and called him nearly every day -- Mr. Thorpe was thrilled when his wife, Linda, gave birth to their daughter, Alexis, last year.
Through it all coursed a nonstop sense of humor. Not even Mr. Thorpe's parents escaped his fondness for nicknames, and he enjoyed initiating phone calls with a disguised voice. "He teased everyone, including me," said Thomas Michaud, Mr. Thorpe's boss.

WEIBIN WANG
Living the American Dream
Weibin Wang and Wen Shi met as students in Beijing, and married three years later. A few months after the wedding in 1986, Mr. Wang left for the United States to study geophysics, at Yale and then at Columbia. Ms. Shi followed a year later.
"We were very happy," she recalled. "We were finally able to be together. We were working hard, trying to realize our American dream."
And they did. He did research at Columbia's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory in Palisades, N.Y., and then shifted into computer systems to provide better for his wife and three children, working the last two years for Cantor Fitzgerald at 1 World Trade Center. The family moved to a house in Orangeburg in Rockland Country, where every weekend he cooked dumplings, noodles, even lasagna. On Saturdays he took his children to piano lessons, art school and karate; on Sundays he took them to a school in Fort Lee, N.J., where they studied Chinese reading, writing and culture. The family visited China when they were able.
"We want to instill a lot of learning and a lot of Chinese traditions," Ms. Shi said.
But Mr. Wang, 41, was also committed to his new country. In March, he became an American citizen.

An article last Sunday about the relationship between corporate interests and national priorities at times of crisis referred incorrectly to the industrialist Andrew Carnegie. He did not use his own resources to mute the stock market crash in 1929; he died 10 years earlier.

It marked the end of an eight-day peace march from Washington to New York.

HEADLINE: Oedipal Loop de Loop 

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
So will the president focus more on Wall Street's lipstick index or Teddy Roosevelt's big-stick index?
 The lipstick index is a way to judge a recession. When the economy goes down, lipstick sales go up. Women indulge in smaller luxuries and skip bigger ones. 
 The big-stick index is a way conservatives judge the president. Will W. whack Saddam with the stick, or will he fold, the way his dad did?
Mr. Bush spent his first year using his father's failures as a reverse playbook. Trying to dodge 41's mistakes, 43 catered to Congressional right-wingers and muscled through a mammoth tax cut.
When the economy slumped, he took great pains to tell Americans he understood their pain -- so he would not seem oblivious and wrapped up in foreign affairs like his father.
Then Sept. 11 hit and he had to get wrapped up in foreign affairs.
If the president uses the reverse playbook now, and continues to coddle the conservatives his father neglected, he has to go topple the wacky Iraqi, completing Poppy's unfinished business.
But if he does that, he turns his attention away from the recession, repeating Poppy's mistake after his war, when he never used his celestial approval ratings to fix the economy.
It's a surreal Oedipal loop de loop, made all the loopier by the spectacle of history repeating itself and putting the son at the same juncture where his father made two of the most critical and criticized decisions of his presidency.
Because 41 detached from Baghdad and detached from economic angst at home, 43 is under extra pressure to attack Iraq while attacking the recession.
The man who started out as the most disengaged president in modern history is now being pestered by his aides and his conservative base to engage, engage, engage.
His political and military advisers are competing for his attention, as he decides how hotly to pursue the war at a time when the economy is foundering and deficits are back.
It is a measure of how nervous the White House is, given Republican losses in the recent gubernatorial elections, that it dumped Gov. James Gilmore of Virginia as party chief last week.
Should the president rout Osama and the Taliban and then "focus like a laser beam on this economy," as Bill Clinton said when he beat Bush senior? Or should he go on to Phase Two, as the Get Saddam crowd calls it, now that the U.S. is "on a roll," as State Department official Richard Armitage puts it?
At the moment, Mr. Bush is juggling furiously.
In his Saturday radio address, the president concentrated on the recession and expressed concern about soaring unemployment. "It's a time to reach out to Americans who are hurting," he said, "to help them put food on the table and to keep a roof over their heads."
And, if Mr. Bush has not yet decided whether to crack Saddam with the big stick, he has been talking more loudly anyway. He said if Iraq did not allow U.N. inspectors into the country to check for weapons of mass destruction, it would "find out" the consequences.
It's hard to say if the swagger was meant to co-opt the string of Perles -- Richard Perle and others who are in full cry to crush Saddam -- or to lay a real groundwork for at least bombing Iraq.
It is curious that the president tolerates such open provocation from people in his administration and connected to it, given that the clamor sets him up to look soft on Saddam if he doesn't go after Iraq.
Paul Wolfowitz, the No. 2 Pentagon official, has been the spark plug of the Get Saddam club. Other drum-beaters are Mr. Perle, on a Pentagon advisory board, and fellow board member James Woolsey, who went on a government plane with a team from Justice and Defense to investigate whether Iraq was involved in the 9-11 attacks.
"If we cannot drive this tyrant from office," Mr. Perle said on CNN, "then we can't do anything."
In an interview with Bob Novak and Al Hunt on CNN Saturday, Donald Rumsfeld was asked about Mr. Perle's agitations.
"Look, Richard Perle is Richard Perle," he replied, praising Mr. Perle but adding: "He does not speak for the president. He does not speak for me."
So many voices, so little time. It's enough to send a president burrowing back into his feather pillow.

HEADLINE: Race Is in South Dakota But Interest Is National 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Nov. 30 

 BODY:
On the surface, next year's race in South Dakota for the United States Senate appears clear-cut enough -- the incumbent, Tim Johnson, a mainline Democrat, faces a strong challenge from the state's sole House member, John Thune, a solidly conservative Republican.
 But the contest is much more than that. 
 Underneath it is a battle royal -- a proxy fight, really -- between President Bush, who has pledged strong backing for Mr. Thune, and South Dakota's senior senator, Tom Daschle, who has pledged strong backing for Mr. Johnson and can deliver it, because he also happens to be the Senate majority leader. 
Such a standoff ensures that plenty of national political attention will be focused on South Dakota next year. But there are other reasons to watch the state, too, because besides the Senate race, there will be a House race and a governor's race.
In short, next year is shaping up as one of the most important election years ever in South Dakota, with a good possibility that the votes cast here in the Senate and House contests will be especially important in the overall national struggle for control of Congress.
Mr. Bush recruited Mr. Thune to take on Mr. Johnson and be one of several point men in next year's all-out Republican push to regain control of the Senate by picking off two Democratic seats. The president promised Mr. Thune White House and national party help, including money and staff, and over the next few weeks several top national Republican figures are scheduled to campaign here with Mr. Thune.
Mr. Daschle has made Mr. Johnson's re-election (and by extension perhaps his own survival as majority leader) what he calls "the most important political effort for me" in 2002. Mr. Johnson has also been promised help from Washington.
Independent pollsters have not taken a look at the contest. But polls taken by both candidates show a race too close to call.
Independent analysts agree. 
Charles E. Cook Jr., editor of The Cook Political Report, calls the race a "nail biter" that could end up being "one of the nation's most competitive contests."
Stuart Rothenberg of The Rothenberg Political Report says the closeness of the Thune-Johnson contest, along with the House and governor's races, both also expected to be close, could make South Dakota "the single most interesting state in the 2002 elections." 
Mr. Johnson narrowly won election to the Senate six years ago, beating the veteran Republican incumbent, Larry Pressler, by two percentage points. Given that slim edge, Republicans say it is not politically unrealistic to believe Mr. Thune can take Mr. Johnson. They note that South Dakota, Mr. Johnson's 1996 victory notwithstanding, has a history, year in and year out, of voting Republican more often than Democratic -- witness Mr. Bush's 22-point victory margin here last year.
Mr. Thune also has something else going for him. Though he is a member of the House, he is as well known in the state as Senator Johnson.
With about 750,000 people, South Dakota is so lightly populated that it has only one Congressional district. That means Congressional candidates always run statewide, the same as candidates for senator and governor, and Mr. Thune has run three times.
Almost certainly, the Johnson-Thune race, like most other Congressional races in 2002, will turn in good part on how much progress is made in the war on terror and how much the national economy recovers. In particular, the success of the proxy efforts by President Bush and Senator Daschle will be heavily governed by economic and national security issues. Beyond that, health care will surely be a major issue in the race, as it will be in other states. Because South Dakota is a big farm and ranching state, agriculture will be a major issue, too.
For the moment, however, Mr. Thune's main campaign pitch emphasizes something else. Those who ask why they should vote for him and thereby vote to break up the Daschle-Johnson team are told what Mr. Thune said when he announced his candidacy: "Consider this: Tom Daschle leading the Democrats in the Senate and John Thune working with him and the Republican leadership in Congress and with President Bush. South Dakota would be better positioned than ever before at the federal level."
Steve Hildebrand, Mr. Johnson's campaign manager and a veteran of many Democratic election battles, contends that his man will make political mincemeat of that argument and win re-election going away. But first things first, Mr. Hildebrand says, insisting that Mr. Johnson "really hasn't been able to focus seriously on running yet because he's spending just about all of his time in Washington working on legislation for national security and the war on terror."
"It's kind of got things on a hold," Mr. Hildebrand said. "But that's where the focus should be anyway."
The South Dakota House and governor's contests are not as fully developed as the Senate contest.
In the House race -- the seat opened up when Representative Thune decided to run for Senate -- Mr. Pressler has declared himself a candidate for the Republican nomination, a move that former senators usually view as a political step down. Several other Republicans have also jumped in, but Mr. Pressler is given the edge over all of them.
Gov. William J. Janklow, who under state law is not permitted to run for another term, is said to be thinking about joining the field too, a political move that would also be relatively rare for a former governor. If he does, with his popularity he would immediately become the leading Republican candidate. In the judgment of most political experts in the state, he would also be the favorite to win the general election in the fall, no matter which of half a dozen or so Democratic hopefuls is nominated.
The race to succeed Governor Janklow is even more wide open.
Of several Republicans thinking about running, Attorney General Mark Barnett is most often given the best chance of winning the nomination. But he has yet to formally announce that he is running.
Among Democrats, Jim Abbott, the president of the University of South Dakota, has expressed an interest in running and is given a good shot at winning the nomination. But he, too, has not yet made his move.
Mr. Abbott was unsuccessful in three earlier tries for elective office.

HEADLINE: A Husband Lost, and a Daughter Out of Reach 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Every time she telephones her 8-year-old daughter in the Ivory Coast, Hadidjatou Karamoko Traore says, the girl cries that she wants to come to New York to see her mother.
 "I wish she could come because her father is no longer alive," said Mrs. Traore, whose husband, a banquet cook at Windows on the World, died on Sept. 11. "She cries so much that she wants to see me." 
 But her daughter's hopes to see her mother, an illegal immigrant, have been blocked by the State Department's refusal to grant a visa.
State Department officials call it an open-and-shut case, saying that if the girl, Djenebou, were granted a temporary visa, she would undoubtedly do as her mother had done: remain in the country illegally after her visa expired.
Mrs. Traore, 31, has enlisted her husband's labor union and Senator Charles E. Schumer to fight for a visa, but they have butted up against the State Department's stance that it would be improper to grant a visa to someone, even a child, who is certain to remain in the country illegally.
Senator Schumer has implored the government to show some flexibility. "There ought to be some way that in very rare and unique cases an exception can be made," he said. "It's unfortunate that they could not find one here."
Mrs. Traore does not want to move back to Africa to rejoin the girl because life is much harder there, and because she is raising a 1-year-old and a 3-year-old, who, until their father's death, were thriving in New York.
"I don't think it's very nice not to give her a visa," she said in French. "How can they refuse?"
Her husband, Abdoul Karim Traore, moved to New York in 1993, after the grains-and-beans shop he ran in the Ivory Coast went under. Convinced that it was the only way to lift their family out of poverty, Mrs. Traore supported his moving without her, even though she was pregnant at the time with Djenebou.
In 1997, Mrs. Traore followed him to New York on a three-month tourist visa, without taking Djenebou. She knew she would not have gotten the visa if she had tried to bring her daughter. She recognized, she said, that State Department officials granted her the visa only because they were confident that, with a daughter still in the Ivory Coast, she would go back.
Mrs. Traore said she had intended to return to Africa, but her husband persuaded her to stay with him in the Bronx, hoping they could bring Djenebou over soon. Mrs. Traore gave birth to two more children in New York, while Mr. Traore's parents raised Djenebou in Abidjan.
Mr. Traore, an illegal immigrant, followed the path of many African immigrants seeking to climb into the middle class. He took a job as a supermarket deliveryman and then became a dishwasher.
Five years ago he became a cook at Windows on the World, a job he hoped to keep forever, his wife said. "He loved the job, he loved the people," she said. 
He worked on the 106th floor of 1 World Trade Center from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m. each day, but that was not his only job. From 4 to 6 each morning, he also delivered newspapers.
"He was a fine, upstanding, affable, very intelligent guy," said Michael Lomonaco, executive chef at Windows on the World. "He was one of my best banquet cooks. I thought highly of him as a cook and as a man."
Since the terror attack, Mrs. Traore has spent much of the last two months trudging around Manhattan, seeking financial assistance to keep her family afloat. For now, she is getting by with help from relatives, her mosque and her husband's union, as well as the Red Cross, Catholic Charities and other relief agencies.
One big worry is whether she will lose the three-family house her husband bought in the Bronx last summer after making an $11,000 down payment. It carries a monthly mortgage payment of $1,715. She earns a little money braiding hair, but not enough to cover the mortgage.
Amanda Ream, an official with the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union who is assisting Mrs. Traore, noted that in a similar case in September the American Embassy in Ecuador granted visas to three children of a deceased Windows of the World worker from Ecuador. That worker and his wife were also illegal immigrants.
"His widow went from being completely consumed by her grief before her children came to having a full life with her children," Ms. Ream said. "I'd love to see that happen with Hadidjatou."
But Christopher Lamora, a spokesman for the State Department's bureau of consular affairs, offered little hope. "The embassy in Abidjan," he said, "determined that Djenebou Traore was not eligible for a visa based on a belief that she had no intention of returning to Cote d'Ivoire after a temporary stay in the United States." 
Djenebou's only chance, Mr. Lamora said, is for her family to persuade the Immigration and Naturalization Service to grant a rare humanitarian exception, permitting her into the United States.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE STRATEGY; 
As Guns Still Blaze, Bush Aides Debate Shifting Focus to Butter

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE and THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 

 BODY:
Even as President Bush asks Americans to prepare for a sustained war on global terrorism, tensions are escalating between his domestic political team and his military policy advisers over whether the administration should turn more of its attention to pressing economic concerns.
 At the Pentagon, policy advisers make the case that the Defense Department should not back down from the commitment to eradicating terror, particularly since public support of the president remains strong. 
 But inside and outside the White House, many advisers to Mr. Bush have urged him to use that political capital to declare victory sooner rather than later and to emphasize efforts to fix the economy. The party could suffer in the midterm elections next year, they argue, if there is too much emphasis on the war at the expense of the economy. 
These advisers are mindful that Mr. Bush's father enjoyed astronomical approval ratings after the Persian Gulf war in 1991, only to lose his job 18 months later because the public believed he had not responded effectively to an economic slowdown.
But other advisers and some Pentagon officials expressed the fear that Mr. Bush would abandon the war effort prematurely to demonstrate that he cared equally about jobs and incomes.
President Bush, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and other members of the war council speak in one voice about their long-term commitment to the war, even if the next phase remains unclear. Mr. Bush in recent days spoke in his strongest terms yet on the threat posed by Iraq and seemed to expand his definition of the war on terrorism. And Mr. Rumsfeld expresses confidence that the Bush administration has earned the continued support of the American people for prosecuting the war.
Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief political adviser, insisted that administration officials were in lock step, and that the president could pursue the war and tend to the economy.
"The president's concern is first that the media, and then the American people, need to be reminded that this is a long, grueling campaign ahead," Mr. Rove said. Insisting that Mr. Bush could balance the war and the economy, he said "they will both be important issues" in the elections next year.
Still, as the war in Afghanistan, the first front in the fight against terror, approaches its third month, many other officials said there was a vigorous debate over how Mr. Bush should calibrate his priorities.
"Bush and Rumsfeld are in sync," said one senior Defense Department official. But the official acknowledged worries among some of Mr. Rumsfeld's advisers that powerful voices in the administration were urging what the Pentagon views as a premature desire to declare victory and retreat to domestic issues.
"There is concern expressed that they won't have the stomach to carry it through to other countries," the Defense Department official said.
One of Mr. Bush's political advisers conceded that the patience for a prolonged military operation might be limited, saying: "In the White House, there is a bias toward developing a broad-based strategy to deal with the lack of economic growth. You maintain strong public support when the economy is robust, and they know that. Political concerns in a Congressional election year would normally be part of anything a White House would legitimately be concerned about."
In his weekly radio address today, Mr. Bush linked the ailing economy directly to the strikes at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, saying that "the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 hit our economy hard."
"They hurt our airlines and hotels and restaurants, and undermined consumer and business confidence," Mr. Bush said. "Now we need to act boldly to protect America's economic security."
Former Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, an influential Republican who is close to the White House, said of the need to focus on the economy: "I don't know that it needs to become outright partisan warfare, but it's going to have to be a little bit higher profile than it has been in the last 90 days. People's votes for Congressional and gubernatorial candidates are still going to focus largely on domestic concerns."
Mr. Weber added, "My reading of history shows that at the end of the day, the domestic economy dominates -- even in wartime."
White House officials said they had been devoting more time to the economy than many people realized. The president does not have to be convinced of the importance of focusing on the economy; aides said he remembered that his father's popularity plummeted after the gulf war.
Recalling the experience of Mr. Bush's father, Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, said: "The country doesn't give you much slack. President Bush won one of the most decisive victories in human history to discover the country impatient with the economy."
Yet the conundrum faced by the current President Bush is underscored by the fact that his father was also accused of declaring victory too soon in the war against Saddam Hussein, who remains a threat and may yet become a target in the new war on terror.
Those advocating a sustained war effort argue that if the fight is halted too soon, or played down publicly -- especially in the instance of another terror attack at home -- Mr. Bush's political fortunes would tumble and he could suffer the same fate as his father: losing a bid for re-election.
Already, Mr. Bush's aides are laying out plans for him to have a higher profile on his stimulus proposal and other economic matters -- just as they were before Sept. 11. The debate is over how to strike the proper balance without appearing to play down the war, the continued terrorist threat or the nation's economy, which this week was officially declared to be in a recession.
The latest survey by Public Opinion Strategies, a prominent Republican polling company, found that for the first time concern about "the slowdown of the economy" eclipsed that about "the threat of terrorism on U.S. soil." And the survey found the public to be far less concerned about the drive to eradicate terrorism overseas.
To some degree, the economy and the war are inextricably linked. It was perhaps inevitable that officials at the Pentagon would be more eager to press the military effort while domestic and political advisers would be more worried about the economy, and that after Sept. 11 the national security team would eclipse the domestic policy group that reigned during the administration's first six months.
Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, chairman of the Republican Governors Association, said that if there was not greater focus on the economy, the public could become restless. "It all depends where we are in terms of the war effort and homeland security,' Mr. Rowland said. "Economic issues are always a front-burner issue to people unless you're at war."
Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist who was an official on the Bush campaign, said the White House had to focus on the economy while not appearing to be giving short shrift to the war. "To say 'Forget all the stuff we said about the war on terrorism' would be a mistake," he said. "At the same time, people are concerned about the economy, and hopefully the war on terrorism will become less than a daily concern."
Advocates of opening new fronts in the war on terrorism fear exactly that -- that the concerns about a next attack are already fading in the public's mind in advance of opening whatever second front may come.
"I think we are closer to Phase 2, in part because the end is in sight for Phase 1, unless there is a serious reversal" in Afghanistan, said Richard Perle, chairman of the Defense Policy Board, an unofficial Pentagon policy review panel.
Speaking at a recent meeting of the Defense Writers' Group, Mr. Perle underscored "the risk that there will be a break in momentum" between Phases 1 and 2. "And so," he said, "it would have been better, I think, to look at this as a single campaign, which is what I think the president had in mind at the outset when he declared a war against terrorism -- not against Al Qaeda simply; not against the Taliban simply."
Prominent Republicans who are close to the White House argue that Mr. Bush has no choice but to begin concentrating on the economy.
"As we bring more certainty to the war, I think there will be a real shift and we'll see increased expression or concern for the workers, concern for the joblessness and concern for the economy," said Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee. "I know from conversations with the administration that the concern is there. Workers have lost their jobs or will lose their jobs and they expect government to address it."
Former Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana, a friend of Mr. Bush's who is being considered as the next Republican Party chairman, said: "I have no question that the economy remains at the top of the list in terms of importance and attention being given by the administration. That's why you see them so engaged with the stimulus package."

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 Battles, Past and Present

CLOSING IN -- With relentless bombing and the checkmate positioning of their military forces around Kandahar, the United States military and sympathetic Afghan forces continued to send the Taliban's besieged defenders the message that surrender is the only way out of an otherwise hopeless plight. Meanwhile, in Bonn, negotiations on a new post-Taliban government for Afghanistan proceeded fitfully, with the Northern Alliance making a proposal that has broken Friday's impasse. A1

ERRANT BOMBING REPORTED -- American bombers over Tora Bora, the cave complex where Osama bin Laden may be hiding, struck three Afghan villages, killing or injuring scores of civilians, witnesses and local officials said. But an American spokesman, Marine Maj. Brad Lowell, denied that American bombs had mistakenly hit a village, saying that the target struck was military. B2

Surrendering, Again

THE HOLDOUTS -- More than 80 foreign fighters, the last survivors of a revolt by Taliban prisoners that left scores dead, finally surrendered, wounded, starving and near collapse, at the fort near Mazar-i-Sharif where they had been held. Their surrender, six days after the bloody uprising, ended the last desperate fight of the Taliban in northern Afghanistan. B1

THE UNWANTED -- The foreign soldiers who fought with the Taliban before surrendering seem less diabolical than deluded, ignorant men on a fool's journey that has landed many of them in cells. No one -- neither their captors nor their native lands -- seems to want them. B3

PRESSING THE ENEMY -- Hundreds of marines have flowed into what was once Taliban-controlled territory in southern Afghanistan, clearing the way for more American and allied forces to arrive. Senior Pentagon officials say the force is meant to increase pressure on the remaining Taliban strongholds. B1

A Changed City

IN KABUL -- Three weeks after the Taliban's exodus, residents are resuming those parts of their lives that had been outlawed by an uncompromising vision of Islamic purity. While joy may be too strong a word, there is no denying that a shared sense of relief has embraced the city. A1

DIPLOMATS RETURN -- Some diplomats have returned to their shuttered embassies, or in some cases ruined ones, in Kabul, united by their desire to ensure that nothing like the Taliban ever again takes power and turns Afghanistan into a haven for terrorists. B5

BACK TO SCHOOL -- When Farida Afzali, 21, walked into Kabul University -- the first woman in five years to register for classes -- she had no idea she was walking into history. B5

Questions of Strategy

AN EXPANDED SEARCH -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation has expanded its investigation of the anthrax attacks to include government and contractor laboratories as a possible source of the deadly powder that has killed five people, scientists and law enforcement officials say. While theories about the culprit have focused mainly on domestic loners and foreign states or terrorists, law enforcement officials are now also examining the possibility that the criminal may be a knowledgeable insider. B1

THE ECONOMY -- Tensions are escalating between President Bush's domestic political team and his military policy advisers over whether the administration should turn more of its attention to pressing economic concerns. Pentagon advisers say the president should not back down from the promised long-term commitment to eradicating terror, but others are urging him to declare victory sooner rather than later and to emphasize efforts to fix the economy. A1

SAUDI ARABIA -- William J. Burns, the assistant secretary for Near East affairs, met in Riyadh with top Saudi officials, including Crown Prince Abdullah, for talks intended in part to seek further Saudi help in cutting off money to suspected terror organizations. The Saudis have complained that the United States has not shared the evidence necessary for them to freeze bank accounts, and American diplomats acknowledge that information provided until now to the Saudis has been insufficient for further action. B5

Differences of Opinion

LEAHY-ASHCROFT DISPUTE -- The issue of civil liberties has created a classic balance-of-power struggle between Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and Attorney General John Ashcroft, a onetime colleague now leading the administration's domestic war on terrorism. B6

U.S.-BRITISH TENSIONS -- After percolating below the surface for weeks, a debate between the United States and Britain over when to use peacekeeping forces in Afghanistan became public Friday when the Pentagon made clear that Washington's military campaign came first. B4

THE TRIBUNALS -- Former military lawyers say they are angered by a public perception, fed most recently by the top White House lawyer, that the military tribunals authorized by President Bush are merely wartime versions of American courts-martial. The lawyers say the proposed tribunals are significantly different from courts-martial, adding that confusion between the two has distorted the debate over the tribunals and unfairly denigrated military justice. B6

THE INVESTIGATION -- Officials in Italy and the United States have been describing the Islamic Cultural Center and mosque in Milan which has played a recurring role in various terror investigations, as Europe's logistical support center for Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terrorist network. Two terror suspects who worked there have been taken into custody, one during a raid on Thursday. Both men, the police said, were Al Qaeda recruiters. But on Friday, hundreds of Muslim men who came to the center to pray, protested that the investigations are trumped up and racist. B4

Raising Money

THE CHARITIES -- Soon after Sept. 11, when the magnitude of the nation's charitable response to the terror attacks had become clear, several government and charity officials warned that disparities in how aid was distributed could produce division among the survivors. Those divisions are starting to emerge as breathtaking sums of money have poured in for the families of about 400 police officers, firefighters and other uniformed personnel who died trying to lead thousands of civilians to safety. A1

REST IN PEACE -- The body of a firefighter who was mistaken for a fellow firefighter and buried last month was buried for a second time after it was disinterred last week. B7

NEW BOOK -- A book of photographs, "Brotherhood," documenting the Fire Department's losses in the trade center attacks, goes on sale this week at $29.95 a copy. Money from sales will go to families of the fallen rescue workers. B7

HEADLINE: The Industry Behind the State's Robust Industry 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER 

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
AT the sleek corporate campuses of the world's largest drug-makers tucked away throughout New Jersey, thousands of scientists and executives are working on new cures that will enhance and extend human life and their companies' financial health.
 But for every one of these giant drug-makers, there are hundreds of other companies around the state that serve pharmaceutical manufacturers with everything from raw cells and animal testing to television ads and salesmen. 
 "There is a whole industry behind the industry," said Joseph Palo, a partner in the pharmaceutical strategy practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers in Florham Park.
In all, there are 217 companies in New Jersey that manufacture pharmaceuticals, according to the state Department of Labor. Moreover, those companies provide a client base for thousands of other businesses in the state, particularly the 200 companies that manufacture laboratory equipment, along with 8,571 computer service firms, 8,886 business and management services and 1,074 research and testing companies. 
Seventeen of the state's largest drug companies, including Merck, Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer employ 60,000 workers. Another 46,000 employees work for smaller drug companies and medical manufacturers, according to a study prepared by PricewaterhouseCoopers for the HealthCare Institute of New Jersey, a statewide industry trade group.
Beyond that, an additional 42,500 jobs are generated in the wider state economy by the entire drug industry, according to an economic analysis by the state Commerce Department.
Because the industry pays so well -- the average annual salary last year was $123,710 -- each pharmaceutical jobs supports nearly two others in the state, the Commerce Department said.
"They have a very important ripple effect through the economy," said George Nagle, an economist for the Commerce Department.
But that cuts both ways.
As investigators struggle to find the source of the anthrax spores mailed to news organizations and government offices in Washington, many are not surprised that they appear to have come from New Jersey.
Richard H. Ebright, a professor of chemistry at Rutgers University who is a lab director at the Waksman Institute of Microbiology in Piscataway, said the state was full of experts and equipment that could reduce material into fine particles for use in medications. This is also how the anthrax spores have become weaponized for easy inhalation.
"I think it's very likely it was done in New Jersey," said Dr. Ebright. "I think it was done, and it is being done in New Jersey."
To emphasize his point, Dr. Ebright pointed to at least three companies in the Trenton area that specialize in the production of fine powders for industry on a contract basis. In addition, he said that used pharmaceutical equipment was sold in the state -- including industrial dryers small enough to make fine powder chemicals in a home.
Yet while New Jersey has the expertise to make this deadly form of anthrax, it also possesses the knowledge to help halt it, he said. 
Vincent Gullo, a research executive at Schering-Plough Corp., the huge drug manufacturer in Kenilworth, said the company hired hundreds of outsiders to supply everything from testing equipment to radioactive chemicals and even chemical compounds that could themselves become the essence of a hit drug.
"I sign purchase orders all day," said Mr. Gullo.
Some of the vendors are large, high-tech operations with hundreds of employees themselves. Many more are run by a lone entrepreneur, often a refugee from one of the big pharmaceutical companies, working out of a spare bedroom on a laptop.
While most pharmaceutical manufacturing is done outside New Jersey -- particularly in Puerto Rico and overseas -- the state remains the corporate center of the industry where top managers guide business strategy, marketing and sales and research.
They are in New Jersey because this is where the business is.
"For us, it's convenient,' said Chris Kuebler, chief executive of Covance Inc. of Princeton, which performs testing and clinical trials for drug companies. "We don't have to get on an airplane in order to be underfoot regularly."
Even in an age of e-mail messages and teleconferencing, proximity matters.
This fall, Andrew Carr, chief executive of Amersham Biosciences in Piscataway, was invited to a weekend barbeque by the parents of his child's friend. Lingering by the smoker, Mr. Carr began talking to a venture capitalist with ties to a company in the Midwest that had developed a compelling new gene technology.
Mr. Carr called him back Monday morning.
"That's a lead I'm very interested in following up on," he said. "That's exactly how it works."
Indeed, Mr. Kuebler emphasized what a a "small world" the drug industry was in New Jersey.
"We're always bumping into each other at the grocery store, or our kids' soccer games," he said. "There's never an airplane out of Newark or Philadelphia that is not filled with people from the industry."
That access can mean everything.
Bovis Lend Lease, a global construction company, opened an office in New Jersey more than a decade ago to be even closer to the drug industry than was its New York City office. 
Bovis, which is based in Britain, builds highly specialized drug manufacturing plants around the world. Though most of the plants are not in New Jersey, the people who decide who will be paid to build them are.
"Seventy-five to 80 percent of the construction-related decisions for the industry are made within a 50-mile radius of this office, even if the facility is in Singapore or Europe," said Steve Steelman, senior vice president of the pharmaceutical business unit in the Americas for Bovis Lend Lease in Princeton. Mr. Steelman's office employs about 260 people, of which about 65 percent work on pharmaceutical construction projects full time.
Beyond winning a bid, proximity can help in a long-term relationship.
Mr. Carr's company, Amersham, produces sophisticated equipment used to help drug-company chemists screen millions of compounds for a potential reaction that could halt disease. For instance, Amersham worked directly with Schering-Plough for several years to develop a testing machine, called a LEADseeker, that simultaneously tests thousands of chemical compounds for a reaction to a cell associated with disease. If a compound creates a reaction, it may become the basis for a new blockbuster drug.
"There is e-mail and teleconferencing and all the rest, but to get all the scientists together, and to do that frequently, is helpful," said Mr. Gullo. "It is very helpful that Amersham is in New Jersey and so are many, many other little companies."
The structure of big pharmaceutical companies, which do everything from basic research to manufacturing to parceling out samples to doctors, makes it naturally prone to use outsourcing.
Not only do drug companies do it all, they do it for many diseases. A cardiovascular drug is different from a cancer drug, not only in the laboratory but all the way through the process of testing, getting approval from government regulators and to distributing it to completely different sets of doctors.
Even with the armies of their own employees, drug companies need help. What's more the industry's constant race against the clock must be factored in. From the time a drug is discovered, it has up to 20 years of patent protection to reap profits. Most of that time is eaten up in development and testing, leaving only about seven years of market life.
"The value of working with outside companies is you buy into their expertise on something they have done many times before and get a very quick start-up time," said Mr. Palo of PricewaterhouseCoopers.
Drug companies run in cycles. Sometimes, when they are lucky, they are busy in the lab developing early-stage drug candidates. Other times, after a dry spell in the lab, the focus may be on beefed-up marketing for mature products. With help from outsiders, the company can grow in the specialties it needs most and shrink back in others.
PDI -- with 5,000 employees nationwide, of which 300 are situated in New Jersey -- was a pioneer in offering a contract sales force to the drug industry in 1990. Companies hire PDI when they need an army of salesmen to launch a new product, or reposition an old one. Smaller companies use PDI instead of building their own sales force.
"The pharmaceutical industry is amazing in its ability to plan ahead," said Steve Cotugno, executive vice president of PDI in Upper Saddle River. "It takes many years to develop a drug and get approvals. They have to make huge investments up front. And they're not afraid to spend money."
According to Mr. Kuebler of Covance Inc., 12 major drug companies stretching from Connecticut to Wilmington, Del., spent more than $30 billion on research alone last year, more than half the industry total of $55 billion.
Quite simply, the drug industry is able to spend huge amounts of money because it makes huge amounts. In the United States, it is among the most profitable businesses. So, too, are its suppliers.
Cambrex Corp., of East Rutherford, dates its history back 100 years to Baker Castrol Oil in Bayonne. By the 1980's it had evolved into a chemical company. When it acquired an agricultural chemical company that also sold medicine for animals, managers were pleasantly surprised by the profit-margins on the drugs. The company then began its transformation into a health-care company, which accounted for more than 70 percent of its $492.5 million in sales last year.
Cambrex makes specialty ingredients for the drug industry including experimental drugs for use in clinical trials. It is also the largest supplier of human cells and adult stem cells to drug researchers in the United States, said James A. Mack, the company's chief executive.
"We see the growth rates in pharmaceuticals and biotechnology as being much higher than in the traditional businesses," said Mr. Mack.
He said that outside consultants and vendors had to tap into the culture of large drug companies -- and that culture is based in science. It is cautious and slow moving because the industry is fearful of making a mistake that might result in repercussions from its regulators or the loss of public trust in its products.
"It's important to have the same level of quality in your systems as Big Pharma," said Mr. Mack. "Big Pharma only talks to each other and they don't trust anybody else unless you have quality standards that look just like them."
Even within the overlay of that culture, drug companies have certain personalities of their own, suppliers said. Some are fiercely independent. Others are more willing to collaborate. Some put more emphasis on science, while others are better marketers.
Mr. Kuebler said it got even more complicated than that. For example, he said Merck's corporate headquarters in Whitehouse Station had its own culture, while its research operation in Rahway had another. So, too, does Merck's operations center in West Point, Pa., near Philadelphia.
"And within West Point there are differences in how you approach the cardiovascular team or the gastrointestinal team," he said. "We always have to be aware of the different idiosyncracies."
The main reason for the concentration of drug companies in New Jersey is the availability of highly trained workers, fed by a network of eastern universities. Companies can easily raid another and employees often do not have to uproot their families to change companies.
"There's a huge talent pool of people we can draw on," said Joe Torre, chief executive of Torre Lazur-McCann healthcare Worldwide, an advertising company in Parsippany that specializes in the drug industry.
But that works both ways, said Mr. Torre whose own company was the second ad agency focusing on the drug industry to move to Parsippany.
"Neither one of us ever had a problem with employee turnover," he said, "but then came the third and the fourth and the fifth and the sixth and they started stealing people from each other."
There is also something of a revolving door between Big Pharma and suppliers.
"When people leave a company and go into the service business, sometimes a company will say, 'It's great to have Joe back.' Other times there are companies that say, 'No, we don't want to have people leaving and then trying to come back and sell us something,' " said Mr. Palo. "I've seen it work both ways."
Dana Guazzo of Bridgewater thought she was walking out the door for good in July 2000 when she quit her job at Johnson & Johnson. After 22 years in the industry, Mrs. Guazzo wanted to spend more time with her two daughters and to volunteer at her church. As she was cleaning out her desk, executives asked if she would continue to work with the company as an outside consultant.
"I really was ready to pull out completely," said Mrs. Guazzo, who is a specialist in drug packaging. A pharmacist by training, she figured she could always go back and work in a drugstore if she needed a job.
"But when they came to me, that motivated me to set up my own business," she said. Now she has her own company, RxPax LLC, and 12 clients. She works 20 to 30 hours a week and is earning more than she did at Johnson & Johnson, though that is without any health and retirement benefits, paid vacation or a guarantee there will be work tomorrow.
Still, Mrs. Guazzo said she did not worry that she would go cold outside the thick of the action at a big drug company. "Being out there as a consultant, I'm more aware of what's going on than when I just worked for one company," she said. "That's what my clients want. They want somebody who knows what's going on at a variety of companies."
But the intensely secretive industry, rooted in proprietary formulations, operates on a code of silence.
"We can never talk about confidential business on an airplane," said Mr. Kuebler.
Every project that is awarded comes with a confidentiality agreement and the implicit understanding that if it is violated the perpetrator will need to consider a new line of work.
Mr. Gullo said that in 25 years in the industry, he had never had a problem with espionage. 
Mr. Mack of Cambrex said his clients trusted him, but still cut the cards. For example, if Cambrex is hired to make a trial batch of a new drug that requires a dozen steps, the drug company might give Cambrex four of the steps and do the rest itself, or parcel it out to one or two other businesses.
The industry's close breeding also requires arrangements to avoid business conflicts.
Mr. Kuebler said companies often want to hire his firm because it has done work on a similar product in the past. Of course, the initial client may have a problem with that since the new drug is likely to be competition.
"We have to work through these conflicts all the time," he said.
Mr. Torre, the advertising executive, solved the problem by forming three separate companies that do programs to inform doctors about clients' new drugs or new uses for old drugs. Each company has a slightly different emphasis and can handle competing products, he said.
"The beauty of three," Mr. Torre said, "is that in our industry conflicts are a big thing. If one is handling Paxil then they cannot handle Prozac."
Mr. Kuebler said the New Jersey state government has taken a pro-growth stance with the industry as a whole with tax abatements and training credits and is competitive with other states in attracting and retaining companies in the industry. He said the state helped Covance erect a new office building in the Carnegie Center in Princeton, where 650 of the company's 7,000 employees are based.
When he loses an employee to a competitor in North Carolina, he said, it is usually for the weather and the golf courses, not the lower cost of living. More often, Mr. Kuebler he said, his competitors came away empty-handed because New Jersey employees did not feel they could adjust to the culture of the South.
His company serves 500 clients, yet half of its business is concentrated with the 12 major drug-makers in New Jersey. Its laboratories do more than a third of the tests for drugs in the clinical trial process. In addition, the company is conducting 143 clinical trials, involving 1,500 Covance employees and 10,000 to 15,000 doctors.
Last year, Mr. Kuebler said, there was a downturn in business of a lack of late-stage products in the industry pipeline. But he said Covance's toxicology labs, which are the initial stage of the drug development, are busy again, indicating more large-scale trials in four to five years.
While they all have their niche, New Jersey's pharmaceutical vendors know their futures are linked, for better or worse, to those of the industry's big players.
Working in its favor, said Mr. Kuebler, "is the aging of the population and new advancements in science coming all the time."
But he also shared the worry of those in the executive suites at the large drug manufacturers. "A negative could be society's willingness to pay for it all."

HEADLINE: French Leader Visits Algiers To Shore Up Terrorism War 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY

DATELINE: ALGIERS, Dec. 1 

 BODY:
President Jacques Chirac of France swept into this port city for an eight-hour visit today, the first time a French president had been to Algeria in more than 12 years.
 With President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, Mr. Chirac briefly toured of an area of the city where hundreds of people died last month when a violent storm caused huge mudslides. 
 Under a blazing sun, the French president broke away from his security guards to kiss babies and hug strangers, many of whom chanted, "Give us visas. Give us visas." 
The hastily arranged trip is one more sign that the Sept. 11 terror attacks in New York have changed the political landscape around the world. The Algerian government, much like the Russian government, has found that by offering to cooperate with America's war on terrorism it is getting a far more sympathetic hearing than it had in the past. 
Western governments, including the French, are showing less inclination to listen to the complaints of international human rights groups and Algerian democracy activists who condemn Algeria for its handling of Islamic militants. Indeed, Mr. Chirac made no mention of such issues in a brief news conference before meeting Mr. Bouteflika for dinner at the presidential palace.
And asked if he had wrongly dismissed Algeria's claims in the past that Europe was being used as a base for Algerian terrorists, Mr. Chirac said, "Yes, yes. We were wrong."
Nevertheless, the visit was not quite a full embrace. Mr. Chirac sandwiched his brief stop here in the middle of visits to two other former North African colonies with close economic ties to France: Tunisia and Morocco.
The trip was not an official state visit, only a "tour." 
Mr. Chirac's entourage placed little emphasis on the visit to Algiers, saying that the trip was a matter of telling the leaders of all three countries that the American-led campaign against terrorism was not a campaign against Islam. 
"We have contact with many officials all the time by telephone," Mr. Chirac said just before taking off for Algeria. "But that is nothing like sitting down over a good cup of coffee, which is what we are doing here." 
There can be little doubt, however, that Mr. Chirac's visit was also a calculated political move designed to make him look good at home in the runup to a re-election campaign next spring. 
There are about five million Muslims leaving in France now, almost 10 percent of the population, and the majority are Algerian. But beyond impressing potential Muslim voters, the trip is keeping Mr. Chirac in the news and looking presidential while his likely rival, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, is at home struggling with such implacable problems as the growing unemployment rate. Mr. Chirac has been taking a lot trips lately, including visiting the United States twice since the terror attacks. 
But visiting Algeria is a tricky proposition. France's violent eight-year effort to suppress an independence movement here is often likened to the United States efforts in Vietnam, having caused violent protests at home and led to the fall of a government before the French withdrew in 1962. The Algerians would like an apology for French conduct during those years, but this is a delicate issue in France and an apology has not been forthcoming.
Moreover, recent history is problematic as well. Mr. Chirac's predecessor, Francois Mitterrand, visited Algeria three times. But visits stopped after what is known as "the coup" of 1992 -- when the military canceled elections the main Islamist party was poised to win. 
That led to a violent struggle between the government security forces and armed Islamic groups that has killed 100,000 people, many of them women and children slaughtered in their villages. 
With the backing of the generals, Mr. Bouteflika became president in 1999, promising to end the violence. He offered an amnesty to some of the militants and more than 5,000 laid down their arms. 
Abroad as well, Mr. Bouteflika has begun a charm offensive. He has visited the United States twice this year, meeting with Mr. Bush both times and pledging his support for the campaign against terrorism. 
But the French are not yet ready to be wholly favorable to Mr. Bouteflika's advances. When he visited France last year -- the first visit by an Algerian leader in 17 years -- the red carpet was rolled out. But the visit nevertheless drew criticism from editorial writers, who criticized the nation for what one called "serious and systematic human rights violations."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Jacques Chirac of France, center, met yesterday with President Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria, left, to promote economic links. (Associated Press)
