HEADLINE: H.M.O.'s Flee Medicare Despite Rise In Payments 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
The federal policy of increasing payments to health maintenance organizations in the hope of persuading them to stay in the Medicare program has largely been a failure, federal investigators said today.
 The investigators, from the General Accounting Office, said that H.M.O.'s had continued to leave Medicare and that very few had returned to the program, despite the higher payments. 
 Some health maintenance organizations said they would stay in Medicare next year, but were planning very large increases in premiums, co-payments and other fees.
About 5.6 million people, or 14 percent of the 40 million Medicare beneficiaries, are in H.M.O.'s. The new head of Medicare, Thomas A. Scully, said in June that he and the Bush administration wanted to have 30 percent of Medicare patients in such health plans by 2005. 
In each of the last two years, Congress increased Medicare payments to H.M.O.'s in an effort to reverse their exodus from the program. But the General Accounting Office told Congress today that the higher payments had had "little effect on the number of beneficiaries with access" to managed-care plans.
For the typical H.M.O, Medicare payments increased an average of $16 a person per month this year, although the increase was much higher for some plans and lower for others. Before then, the minimum monthly government payment was $415.
In a report to Congress, the accounting office said that many health plans had used the money to increase payments to hospitals and other health-care providers, but that relatively few had enhanced benefits for the elderly. 
Congress is again weighing plans to increase payments to health plans, which have been popular with beneficiaries because they cover prescription drugs and other items not in the original Medicare program.
Susan M. Pisano, a spokeswoman for the American Association of Health Plans, the main lobby for H.M.O.'s, said the increase in Medicare payments had not been enough to offset cuts made in 1997. 
"Medical inflation has outstripped the increases in Medicare reimbursement," Ms. Pisano said. "Costs are rising 8 to 12 percent a year. Some hospitals are demanding increases of 30 percent in the payments they receive from health plans. But for many plans, Medicare reimbursement has been rising only 2 or 3 percent a year."
Democrats said they found such arguments unpersuasive. 
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, said: "Congress continues to pour money into the coffers of Medicare H.M.O.'s in hopes of providing better care to America's seniors. But the H.M.O.'s keep stranding hundreds of thousands of beneficiaries annually by either leaving the program or reducing benefits. It is foolish even to consider throwing more money at this failed system."
On Jan. 1, 536,000 elderly people are to be dropped from health maintenance organizations that are curtailing their participation in Medicare. Those actions are being taken after three years in which health plans dropped more than 1.6 million Medicare beneficiaries, 933,600 this year, 327,000 at the start of last year and 407,000 in 1999.
Congress had hoped that H.M.O.'s would use some of the new federal money to provide more generous benefits. But many have cut back benefits, saying Medicare payments were still far too low.
Next month, one plan, run by the UnitedHealth Group, is to introduce a huge new co-payment, charging Medicare beneficiaries in Wisconsin $295 for each day in the hospital, subject to a limit of $4,800 a year on all out-of-pocket costs. At present, the company does not charge any co-payment for such inpatient hospital care. United had originally wanted to charge $350 a day, but in negotiations with the government it agreed to the lower amount.
Representative Gerald D. Kleczka, Democrat of Wisconsin, said, "My constituents and I are outraged at the new co-payment, which is unacceptably high." 
Stephanie Sue Stein, director of the Milwaukee County Department on Aging, said the higher co-payments would cause havoc for 16,000 elderly people who relied on the United health plan in Wisconsin. 
"It looks to us as though the benefit changes for 2002 are designed to discourage enrollment of beneficiaries who have health care needs," Ms. Stein said. 
The president of government programs at United, Richard Jones, said it did not have much choice. "Medical cost inflation has exceeded 20 percent a year over the last few years and has caused mounting financial losses," he said. "We are faced with a Hobson's choice. We can either stay in markets by reducing benefits or exit and lose the chance to serve Medicare beneficiaries."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Fewer Donors and Less Cash for Neediest Cases Fund

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
As the annual 90-day appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reached its 30th day yesterday, accountants reported that the fund had received $774,831 less than it had by the same point last year, a drop of 22 percent. They also reported that 2,069 people have given to the fund this year, 42 percent fewer donors than last year at the 30-day mark.
 While some of the decline may be the result of a change in the timing of this year's appeal, officials at The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund, attribute much of the decline to the difficulties of raising money for causes not related to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. 
 Months before the terrorist attacks, officials who run the fund, in consultation with the seven local charities it supports, decided to begin this year's annual appeal for donations three weeks earlier than the starting date that had been used since 1980 -- the Sunday after Thanksgiving. 
The timing of the appeal was meant to coincide with the good will of the holiday season, but so far, it appears to have had little effect on the pace of giving. 
In fact, the pace has slowed. Officials at the Times Company Foundation, and some officials at the seven charities, said that many people who contributed to funds set up to help victims of the attack, including The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund, may be deciding not to spend more on another charity this year.
"Some of the decrease could be due to the fact that we started earlier, and people do wait until the end of December to give for tax purposes," said Alicia A. Erickson, the financial analyst who accounts for donations to the fund, "but probably a lot of that is because so many people have given to the 9/11 fund."
The charities supported by the Neediest Cases Fund report a similar pattern in their own fund-raising efforts. "There's been so much giving in the aftermath of 9/11 that people feel themselves not in a position to give additionally," said Donna A. Santarsiero, executive director of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of the charities supported by the fund. 
Though the 9/11 fund, which as of yesterday had received $47.1 million and spent $17.7 million, ended its active appeal on Oct. 11, money continues to flow into it at a faster pace than to the Neediest Cases Fund. Last week, the 9/11 fund received $375,460 from 450 donors, while the Neediest Cases Fund received $198,096 from 513 donors.
The appeal for donations to the Neediest Cases Fund lasts for three months, but the fund accepts donations all year. Of the $2,676,659 received by the fund so far, $2,143,774 was given before Sept. 11.
While some agencies supported by the fund reported that giving has decreased, others said that contributions have remained steady. 
"We have found that giving remains strong and that 9/11 has served to underscore the importance of community, and of caring for the those that are most in need," said John Ruskay, chief executive of UJA-Federation of New York. "In some ways, paradoxically, we have found that the horror of 9/11 has led to a reframing for many of their own values and commitments, and has led many to feel that they want to help."
Jack Rosenthal, the president of The Times Company Foundation, said that while money donated to the 9/11 Neediest Fund goes to help people who are suffering because of the destruction of the trade center, money given to the Neediest Cases Fund goes where it does every year, to relieve desperation among the poor people of New York City.
"The money is not fungible," Mr. Rosenthal said. "The generosity to the 9/11 Neediest Fund doesn't reduce by a nickel the need of the poor people of New York. If anything, their need this year increases because of the recession and the welfare cutoff that went into effect Friday."
Mr. Rosenthal said that the foundation will sponsor an art sale at the Luhring Augustine Gallery in Chelsea from Jan. 15 to 19 to benefit the Neediest Cases Fund. "We feel a duty to do everything we can to call public attention to the campaign, and we've won the assistance of a dozen truly world-famous artists who have agreed to participate in a benefit sale of their work." 
Officials at the fund hope that with the additional attention, more people will follow in the steps of those like Susan Ralston of Manhattan. 
Enclosed with her check for $500 given on Nov. 19, Ms. Ralston wrote: "I am increasing my contribution to the Neediest Cases Fund from $100 to $500 to help make up for any falling off of contributions as a result of the outpouring of generosity to the 9/11 charities."
Perhaps a letter from Mollie Torras of the East Village says it best. Along with her $10 gift to the Neediest Cases Fund on Nov. 27, Ms. Toras wrote, "I hope the fund will soon catch up to the '00 level."

HEADLINE: New Plan Announced For Area of Rockaways 

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
Almost four decades after the city razed the last crumbling summer bungalows in the Arverne section of the Rockaways, officials yesterday announced a new plan to develop a large portion of the 300 acres of vacant beachfront property in that Queens neighborhood.
 The latest plan, a $350 million project to construct one- and two-family houses, midrise apartment buildings, a retail center and a school on 100 acres of the Rockaway peninsula, comes after a series of other plans for the 60-square-block area failed to take hold. Among the others were Arverne-by-the-Sea, a 1989 plan to build 7,500 apartments in the neighborhood, and Destination Technodome, a 1997 plan for a $1 billion sports, entertainment and hotel complex, featuring an indoor ski slope, skating rinks and movie theaters. 
 But the earlier visions fell victim to economic troubles or developers who pulled out, leaving one of the largest undeveloped urban oceanfront lots in the nation empty since the 1960's, when Mayor John V. Lindsay ordered the demolition of the remaining summer cottages there. 
Announcing yesterday that a Long Island developer had been selected to build 2,300 residential housing units, 250,000 square feet of retail space, a day care center, a community center with a swimming pool and an 800-seat charter school that would be run by a private company, city officials described the latest plan as a scaled-down version of the 1989 proposal and said they were confident it would move ahead.
They also said that because the latest plan is less ambitious than previous plans and the Rockaways have become more appealing to home buyers, they did not expect the new development to stumble as others have. 
"This has been a long time in coming and we have had some false starts," said Claire Shulman, the Queens borough president, who joined Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other officials for the announcement at City Hall yesterday. "But we now have a very good proposal that we believe will give a shot in the arm to the Rockaways."
Officials have resurrected the name of the 1989 plan, Arverne-by-the-Sea, for the new project, which is being developed by Benjamin-Beechwood L.L.C., a joint venture of the Benjamin Development Company of Garden City, N.Y., and the Beechwood organization, based in Jericho, N.Y. The 100-acre site being developed is bounded by Beach 62nd Street on the east, Beach 74th Street on the west, the Rockaway Freeway on the north and the boardwalk and the ocean on the south. 
Officials said they were still looking into similar plans for the remaining 200 acres of the vacant city-owned land in Arverne, called the Arverne Urban Renewal Area, but had no specific proposals. 
Bruised after losing scores of relatives, neighbors and friends in the World Trade Center attack in September and then watching an airplane crash into the middle of a Rockaway neighborhood last month, Rockaway residents and officials said they were buoyed by yesterday's announcement. 
"After what Rockaway has gone through after the last two months, this certainly is good news for us," said Jonathan L. Gaska, district manager of Community Board 14, which has debated and voted on various plans for Arverne over the years. "This is something that can be done; it's not this grandiose Disney-like vision."
However, some said they had seen so many unrealized plans for Arverne and other parts of the peninsula -- separated from Queens and Brooklyn by toll bridges over the Jamaica Bay and from Manhattan by a 90-minute subway ride -- that they were skeptical.
"We've been shown a lot of pretty pictures in our time," said Liz Sulik, a resident of Belle Harbor, the neighborhood where an American Airlines flight crashed last month, and president of the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways. "This has to be more than just a pretty picture. It has to work."
Officials estimated that construction on the first phase of the project would begin by June 2002.

HEADLINE: Sotheby's Case Ends on Issue of Character 

BYLINE:  By RALPH BLUMENTHAL and CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Summing up their cases in the criminal conspiracy trial of Sotheby's former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, the lead prosecutor portrayed him yesterday as a devious price fixer who cut an illegal deal with Christie's, the archrival auction house, while a defense lawyer called him the innocent dupe of a scheming deputy desperate to avoid prison.
 Deriding what he called "the dumb, hungry Taubman story" -- defense witnesses had testified that the defendant was more interested in what was for lunch than in the company's profits -- the prosecutor, John G. Greene of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said the evidence showed that Mr. Taubman conspired with his Christie's counterpart at 12 secret meetings in the mid-1990's. Mr. Greene asserted that he then directed the auction house's chief executive, now his main accuser at the trial, Diana D. Brooks, to carry out his orders to fix commission rates with her counterpart at Christie's in a scheme that cost customers millions. 
 But a lawyer for Mr. Taubman, Robert B. Fiske Jr., said Ms. Brooks had lied so often to associates and investigators to cover up her own admitted role in the scheme that she was "a walking reasonable doubt." 
He told the jury, "If you don't believe Dede Brooks beyond a reasonable doubt, you must acquit."
Throughout, Mr. Taubman, 76, a multimillionaire shopping center developer and art collector, sat impassively at the defense table, listening to proceedings on a wireless headset, gazing at the jury, sucking on a mint and, now and then, closing his eyes for a catnap.
The final pleas to the jury came on the 14th day of a trial in Manhattan federal court that is the climax of a four-year investigation that unearthed one of the biggest art scandals in recent history and exposed a pattern of cozy, lucrative and often illegal dealings between two houses that had often been portrayed as cutthroat competitors.
The trial involved 5 government witnesses, including Ms. Brooks, and 14 defense witnesses, including a federal appeals court judge. 
Among the government witnesses was the former chief executive of Christie's, Christopher M. Davidge, who broke open the case at the end of 1999 when he surrendered hundreds of pages of internal records documenting a scheme between the two houses to increase lagging profits by eliminating costly incentives to clients and raising rates to sellers. 
Mr. Davidge, who along with Christie's obtained amnesty from prosecution, and Ms. Brooks, who pleaded guilty in hopes of winning leniency, both later testified that they acted at the behest of their bosses, Sir Anthony Tennant, the former chairman of Christie's, and Mr. Taubman. Both chairmen were later indicted, Mr. Taubman pleading not guilty and going to trial, and Sir Anthony thwarting extradition by refusing to leave his home in England.
Even before the trial began, the effects of the scandal had rocked the auction industry. Mr. Taubman stepped down as Sotheby's chairman (he is still the company's controlling shareholder), Sotheby's pleaded guilty to antitrust violations and paid a $45 million criminal fine, and both auction houses together paid aggrieved customers a civil settlement of more than $512 million. 
An argument over a 225-year-old quotation the government sought to place, along with chart, before the jury set the combative tone yesterday. The chart depicted private meetings the government said Mr. Taubman held illegally with his counterpart at Christie's, Sir Anthony Tennant. The quotation was from the economist Adam Smith in 1776: "People in the same trade seldom meet together even for merriment and diversion, but a conversation ends in a conspiracy against the public or in some contrivance to raise prices."
Judge Daniels ruled that since Smith was not a witness in the case, the chart should not include his testimony, but that Mr. Greene was free to cite the remark in his summation, which he did.
Given what has already been admitted by the auction houses, Ms. Brooks and Mr. Davidge, both sides readily agreed there had been a price-fixing conspiracy. "The only question," Mr. Greene said, "is whether Alfred Taubman was engaged in that conspiracy." Reminding jurors of the 12 private meetings that Mr. Taubman's diaries and calendars showed he had with Sir Anthony between 1993 and 1996, the prosecutor asserted that that Mr. Taubman was.
Some of the notations were in coded form, he said. "If these meetings were legitimate," he said, why did Mr. Taubman never mention them to his chief executive at the time, Michael Ainslie, who was Ms. Brooks's predecessor? "But he didn't say a word about them," Mr. Greene went on. "Why was that? Because he was discussing things that were unlawful to discuss."
Mr. Fiske, in his summation, said Mr. Taubman was not trying to hide anything by listing Sir Anthony as "Tony" or "a gentleman" among his appointments. "They were social friends," he said. Others Mr. Taubman met were noted in similar ways, Mr. Fiske said. He said the discussions concerned harmless trade issues.
He even offered the jury a list of meetings Mr. Taubman had at his apartment, with people like the restaurateur Warner LeRoy and Sally Ganz, the famed collector whose estate was eventually sold at Christie's.
Mr. Fiske noted inconsistencies in the document and ridiculed it. "Mr. Taubman and Mr. Tennant are supposed to be up there at 10,000 feet directing things," he said. But the only conspirators were Ms. Brooks and Mr. Davidge, he contended. 
Much of the prosecution's case relied on Ms. Brooks, who testified that Mr. Taubman agreed with Sir Anthony that both companies would raise their rates to auction sellers and make the new, higher charges nonnegotiable, depriving customers of their leverage in bargaining for better rates. She testified that she and Mr. Davidge were to work out the details. 
Mr. Greene argued that in the past she had had to lie to protect the conspiracy, but that once in court, she spoke the truth.
Long before the trial, when lawyers for Sotheby's, prompted by the federal investigation, questioned her about any collusion, of course she denied it, Mr. Greene argued, adding: "She'd be disgraced. She and Taubman would have to resign and face criminal charges." 
Mr. Fiske attacked Ms. Brooks's credibility, calling Mr. Taubman her "get-out-of-jail-free card."
He also recalled that a Sotheby's lawyer, Donaldson Pillsbury, disputed her account of a remark she said Mr. Taubman made to her. At one point in her appearance, Ms. Brooks testified that Mr. Taubman had told her after the conspiracy began to unwind, "you'll look good in stripes." Mr. Pillsbury, who was also at the meeting, testified that Mr. Taubman made the remark self-mockingly about himself: "How'd you think I'd look in stripes?" 
Mr. Fiske said: "When you go back into the jury room and ask yourself if she's to be believed here, remember how she lied. Isn't she trying to con everybody in the jury room the way she conned Sotheby's lawyers?"
But Mr. Greene had the last word, and he said the jury did not need to find Mr. Taubman guilty beyond all doubt, just a reasonable doubt. He said Mr. Taubman kept his diaries because "he never expected they would be subpoenaed."
"He thought he was above the law," he said. He argued that Mr. Taubman could not have been as ignorant of the plotting as his defense contended. "You don't become a millionaire without knowing how to read the bottom line." 
The jury is expected to get the case today.

HEADLINE: China Will Accept Soybeans From U.S. 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
China has agreed to import United States soybeans temporarily while it adopts new rules governing purchases of gene-altered crops, the United States trade representative's office said today. 
 In June, China blocked imports of genetically altered soybeans, jeopardizing a $1-billion-a-year export market for the United States. 
President Bush raised the trade dispute with Chinese leaders at an economic conference in Shanghai in October. Though sales of soybeans from the United States have resumed, China had not officially agreed to any interim resolution until now, the trade office said. 
 China will accept soybeans from the United States if they are accompanied by a government certificate saying they are safe for the environment, safe for humans to eat and safe for livestock feed, the trade office said.
About 68 percent of the soybean crop in the United States is genetically engineered, principally to make the plants resistant to the Roundup herbicide produced by Monsanto. 
China has imported or arranged to buy 2.05 million tons of soybeans from the United States since Sept. 1, the beginning of the current sales season.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S COLLAPSE: THE HOLDINGS; 
Enron Causes 5 Major Japanese Money Market Funds to Plunge

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
Shares of five major money market funds in Japan have fallen below their face value because of extensive Enron holdings, and the stocks of the companies that manage the funds plunged today.
 The funds are managed by some of Japan's largest banks and brokerage firms. Shares of UFJ Holdings, a banking giant, plunged nearly 10 percent, and Nikko Securities, a leading brokerage firm, slid 3.4 percent. Each ran major funds with big positions in Enron bonds. The weakness in financial stocks helped push the Nikkei 225-stock index down 3.1 percent. 
 The stampede left investors with few places to turn for steady returns and low risk. In Japan, bank deposits pay almost no interest, so money market funds have been popular with pension funds and other investors that seek security with a reasonable return. In the United States, each share of a money market fund generally carries a face value of $1 and an implicit guarantee that the price will not fall below that amount, preserving investors' principal; there have been a few exceptions.
The losses by the Japanese money funds on Enron bonds led skittish investors to withdraw cash last week, producing a net outflow for November of some 3 trillion yen ($24.2 billion).
An alternative for investors is Japanese government bonds, but they, too, have given investors a scare in recent weeks. Major rating agencies have lowered Japan's sovereign credit rating and said more cuts may be coming. The country's debt rating is now near the point where banks that hold government bonds will have to reserve capital against the chance of a default.
"This is a big headache for safe-haven investors," said Akio Yoshino, head of investment research and chief economist at SG Yamaichi Asset Management in Tokyo. "Investors are becoming very keen about avoiding credit risk, so brokers who recommended these trusts will continue to see a huge outflow," he said, referring to the funds.
Managers of funds are hoping to shore up the confidence of investors by disclosing their bondholdings and other assets more frequently -- they are now obliged to report on them only twice a year -- and perhaps by restricting themselves to issuers with credit ratings of A or better, analysts said.
If the money market funds stop buying debt of lower-rated companies, it could be a serious blow to Japan's steel makers, retailers and other highly indebted companies.

HEADLINE: Fed Now Says '02 Recovery Will Be Slow 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON with LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
Federal Reserve officials say they expect a modest and gradual recovery in the economy next year rather than the quick turnaround many investors and forecasters are expecting. That suggests the central bankers are open to at least one further interest rate cut and may keep rates lower for longer than financial markets anticipate.
 The officials said the recovery could be tempered by a variety of forces, from high levels of consumer and corporate debt to the reluctance of companies to invest in new factories and equipment at a time of uncertainty in the economy and the fight against terrorism. 
 "I am of the opinion that the recovery will not begin until mid-2002," said Anthony M. Santomero, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. "I think the forecasters are overly optimistic." 
Many private economists are predicting that a rebound will begin no later than the spring, and perhaps much earlier. Ian Shepherdson, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm in Valhalla, N.Y., said he expected slightly positive economic growth in the current quarter, after a return to relatively healthy growth rates next year.
"I'm looking for a reasonably robust recovery that will surprise people with its speed and magnitude," Mr. Shepherdson said.
Chris Varvares, president of Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis, said economic growth should resume in the first quarter of next year. "Our forecast is for what would be called a V-shaped recovery," he said, referring to the prospect that the downturn that began in March will be followed by a strong upturn soon.
Fed officials said they also saw evidence that the recession could be coming to an end relatively soon. But in several interviews, some granted on conditions of anonymity, most stressed their belief that the turnaround was likely to be slow in getting off the ground and that any real recovery might not begin in earnest until summer. They suggested that the economy might end up being more sluggish than recent statistics suggest.
Even the more optimistic among them said there were considerable risks that could hinder the economy through much of next year. Before Sept. 11, many Fed officials were predicting that the economy was on the verge of stabilizing if not recovering.
On the plus side, the officials pointed to shrinking inventories, low energy prices, a rebound in the stock market, relatively strong consumer demand and the effects of the interest rate cuts and tax reductions already in the pipeline. And there was fresh evidence today that the economy might be close to bottoming out. 
Personal spending in October rose by 2.9 percent, a record, in part because consumers took advantage of zero-interest-rate financing offers to buy automobiles, the Commerce Department reported. Construction spending in October increased 1.9 percent, the first monthly rise in six months. And there were signs that the worst might be over for manufacturing, with a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management showing that the dropoff in manufacturing activity was slowing.
But most Fed officials remain worried that any rebound will be weak, at least initially.
In a speech last week, Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, said his view was that "the economy should gradually strengthen over next year."
The main force inhibiting a strong comeback, Fed officials say, is the perception among businesses that the rates of return available to them from investing in new equipment remain too low given the uncertainty about demand for their products, the overall health of the economy and the risks associated with the campaign against terrorism.
In this view, the economy will not begin rolling again until capital investment rebounds. Capital investment was a primary driver of the economic boom of the late 1990's. But it fell off sharply starting last year, both a victim and a cause of a general reassessment of the potential for technology to improve business efficiency and profitability.
To the degree that businesses choose to trim capital spending in the face of economic risk and uncertainty, lower interest rates do not help much. Instead, Fed officials said, the return to more normal levels of capital spending will come about steadily -- but slowly -- as demand picks up and terrorism-inspired fear and risk diminish.
"High-tech equipment investment at elevated rates of return will, most likely, resume once very high uncertainty premiums recede to more normal levels," Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told Congress in October.
Fed officials did not say whether they would cut interest rates for an 11th time this year when they meet next Tuesday, and Mr. Greenspan did not shed any light on his intentions on interest rates in a speech here today about globalization.
Mr. Greenspan also met for lunch today with President Bush to discuss the economy. "The president was interested in listening to the chairman's points of view on the economy," said Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary.
Asked if any specific development in the economy had led to the session, the first since the economy officially was declared in recession last month, Mr. Fleischer said "the president has the economy on his mind despite developments around the world."
Investors are betting that the Fed will reduce its benchmark interest rate once more next week, to 1.75 percent from 2 percent. But investors are also betting that the Fed will reverse course next year and push its federal funds target rate up starting in late winter as the economy gains strength.
But the question of how soon the Fed will start raising rates again turns on how soon the recovery starts and how strong any turnaround will be. Fed officials are more cautious on that score than some other economists, including those inside the Bush administration. Testifying to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress last week, R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers, said the notion that businesses continued to be burdened by an overhang of excess capital "seems unduly pessimistic." 
As a general matter, Mr. Hubbard said, "any capital overhang is likely to have been eliminated by the weak investment performance in 2001."
 --------------------

Remarks by Greenspan
 WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- Terrorism poses a challenge to the gains made by increasingly close global economic ties, Alan Greenspan reiterated today. 
Mr. Greenspan did not touch on the the nation's economic or monetary outlook in his remarks, which were largely a repeat of a speech he delivered on Oct. 24.
"If we allow terrorism to undermine our freedom of action, we could reverse at least part of the palpable gains achieved by postwar globalization," he said. "It is incumbent upon us not to allow that to happen."
Mr. Greenspan also said he hoped a new round of international negotiations aimed at lower trade barriers would "go forward expeditiously."

HEADLINE: GOLF; 
PGA Tour Has Courses For High School Junior

BYLINE:  By CLIFTON BROWN 

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3 

 BODY:
At 17 years old, facing the pressure of one of golf's most dreaded tournaments, Ty Tryon became the youngest player to earn a PGA Tour card, shooting a six-under-par 66 today during the final round of the Tour's qualifying tournament. It was an uncanny performance for someone too young to rent a car, too young to drink alcohol legally, but too confident and too determined to believe his dream would not come true.
 Tryon played his best golf when he needed to, making a final-round charge at Bear Lakes Country Club that lifted him into history. Only the top 36 finishers in the original 167-player field earned Tour cards, and Tryon began the last of the six rounds tied for 50th, a difficult position for a veteran, not to mention Tryon, who missed his 11th-grade classes today and who has an English paper due Friday at Dr. Phillips High School in Orlando. 
 But instead of succumbing to the pressure, Tryon seemed inspired by it. In his best round of the grueling 108-hole event, Tryon had an eagle, four birdies and no bogeys, showing power and accuracy off the tee, control with his approach shots, a steady putting stroke and solid course management. Tryon did not make a double bogey in six days, and when inside the ropes, he seemed almost oblivious to the attention and unfazed by the situation.
Tryon finished 18 under par, tied for 23rd and one stroke ahead of the qualifying cutoff of 17 under. Pat Perez won the tournament at 27 under, and notable players earning Tour cards included Gary Nicklaus (22 under) and Russ Cochran (23 under), who shot a final-round 64, including a 29 on the front nine.
Tryon said he knew he had done something special. In his first attempt to join the Tour, Tryon advanced through three stages of qualifying and earned a place on golf's most prestigious circuit, where he will compete against Tiger Woods, Phil Mickelson, David Duval and scores of players more than twice his age. While it remains to be seen how Tryon will fare, he wanted an opportunity to compete against the best, and he earned it, getting his Tour card at a younger age than Sergio Garcia, who earned his at 19, and Woods, who earned his at 20.
"Hopefully I've won a few people over by doing this," said Tryon, who is aware that several players have questioned his readiness for the Tour. "I went through every stage and I did it the hard way. I knew I'd get some flak for it, but that's the way it goes. I was totally ready.
"I didn't really feel that much pressure. A lot of these guys have families, wives, children, so many expenses, this is their livelihood. I'm with my parents. I don't really pay for much. I don't have any pressure economically. I just had the pressure of wanting to be on Tour next year."
Tour rules forbid players from becoming full-fledged members until their 18th birthday, and Tryon will not be 18 until June. He is eligible to play 12 Tour events before June -- 7 with sponsor exemptions and as many as 5 with top-10 finishes or Monday qualifying.
Tryon turned professional after last summer's United States Amateur, a decision that meant he was forgoing high school and college competition. He has since signed with IMG and picked up endorsements from Callaway Golf and Target Stores that are reportedly worth as much as $1 million a year.
At 5 feet 11 inches, with a wiry but muscular build and size 13 shoes, Tryon is still growing, just as his game is still maturing. He has not decided where he will play his first event next year, but the current plan is for him to fit his golf schedule around his academic schedule. 
Today's performance will only increase the buzz around a teenager who has shown no fear while competing. Tryon made the cut in both Tour events he played this year as an amateur, with a tie for 39th place at the Honda Classic and a tie for 37th place at the B.C. Open, in which he shot an opening-round 65 to share the lead.
That performance at the B.C. Open convinced Tryon he could compete with the best. Several prominent European players have turned professional as teenagers and succeeded, including Seve Ballesteros, Bernhard Langer and Garcia. But in the United States, the longtime norm has been for the best players to attend college for at least a while. Tryon made a daring decision to break that mold. 
Tryon's father, Bill, watched proudly today with his wife, Georgia, and two of their three other children, and he insisted that his son would handle the expectations.
Asked how he expected his son to fare next year on Tour, Bill Tryon said: "I expect less than he'll probably deliver, because that's been his history since he's been a little kid. I plot the future and have these grandiose plans, but at the same time, I'm a realist. I don't want him to feel the pressure to have to produce. He's just a kid still, but more often than not, he rises to the occasion.
"Tiger Woods is by far the best player in the world. Ty needs some physical maturity. He doesn't need any more emotional maturity. He's as emotionally mature as 90 percent of the players out there. He needs more mass, more size. Time will tell how he competes on tougher courses. Right now, he goes at the ball 110 percent. To get to Tiger's level, he's going to have to play a power and accuracy game with an 85 percent swing. That will take some years."
But for the present, Tryon was elated with where he stood, and where he was headed.
"Tonight when I go to sleep, I will know I am on the PGA Tour," Tryon said. "It's just unbelievable."

CHIP SHOTS
BOO WEEKLEY of Milton, Fla., who became a favorite by playing in sneakers and rain-slicker pants, earned his Tour card. When someone mentioned that one of his putts was knocked off track by a spike mark, Weekly smiled and said, "Spikes -- I think they should outlaw them." . . . The most heartbreaking experience belonged to ROLAND THATCHER, who saw his Tour card slip away with a triple bogey on the final hole. That dropped him from 17 under -- the cutoff -- to 14 under.

HEADLINE: A Changed Police Department Awaits Kelly in Second Turn 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN FLYNN 

 BODY:
When he returns for a second stint as commissioner on Jan. 1, Raymond W. Kelly will find a Police Department filled with old friends, a familiar office and a force so in vogue its fans wear N.Y.P.D. caps.
 But Mr. Kelly will also find that the department he inherits, and the city it patrols, face severe pressures and stiff tests that will make the commissioner's job more taxing than usual. 
 The threat of terrorism has so expanded the department's responsibilities that overtime could hit $1.7 billion this fiscal year, an amount equal to the entire police budget for 1993, when Mr. Kelly was last commissioner. 
In addition, an economic downturn threatens to sap the tax revenue that financed the department's recent expansion and to complicate labor negotiations with a police force that believes it is woefully underpaid.
And the department's manpower is dwindling, even as its duties grow. A total of 2,099 officers have retired so far this year, about 5 percent of the force and an 87 percent increase over retirements for the same period a year ago.
Even the department's success at crimefighting, which has gleamed like a polished badge for much of the last decade, is showing tarnish in spots. Crime for the year remains down, but shootings and murders have risen by double-digit percentages over the last month, and homeless people and squeegee men appear to have returned to some city streets and intersections.
It is true that crime for the year remains as low as it has been at any time in the last three decades, but a recent spate of shootings in which innocent bystanders were struck by stray gunfire seemed to date from an earlier era.
"I think there are enormous problems here," said Thomas Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, "and the man who solves these problems is going to be a great figure in American law enforcement."
Much has changed in the department since Mr. Kelly served as its 37th commissioner under Mayor David N. Dinkins. Back then, he commanded a force of 28,500 uniformed officers, not the 40,000-member department of today, which was built through budget initiatives and the merger of the transit and housing police units into the larger city force.
Crime rates were much higher eight years ago, too. Although crime began to decline under Mr. Kelly, the descent accelerated greatly during the Giuliani administration. 
The number of incidents in every major category, from murder to auto theft, has dropped by at least 40 percent over the last eight years.
But for the four-week period ended Sunday, homicides were 20 percent higher than in the same period a year ago, going to 54 from 45. Shootings also increased, by 41 percent. At the same time, some of the quality of life concerns that had helped propel Rudolph W. Giuliani into the mayoralty, like street peddlers and squeegee men, appeared to be returning. Advocates for the homeless say a record number are now living in city shelters or welfare hotels.
Several criminologists said that, even though an economic downturn can foster a rise in crime, they were not convinced that the recent spike in shootings and murder was meaningful. "Four weeks does not a trend make," said James Alan Fox, a professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University.
Police officials also have characterized the upturn as a blip, one they believe may have resulted when officers who had been on street patrol were assigned to terrorism recovery operations or bridge check posts in the weeks after the Sept. 11 attack. In recent days, Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik has begun moving many of those officers back to street enforcement, where they may deter criminals from carrying guns. In the same vein, all detectives assigned to the narcotics division were ordered last week to begin working six-day weeks, possibly until the end of the year.
In remarks last month, Mr. Kelly acknowledged he would have to find a way to muster enough manpower to respond to both crime and the threat of terrorism. "Having lived through the unthinkable," he said, "we have to be ready to live through the unthinkable again."
Mr. Kelly will also have to balance the effectiveness of traffic checkpoints and truck searches against the damage lengthy traffic jams and delivery delays may do to the city business climate. Further slowing of the local economy would not help the police effort, analysts said, because a budget drained of tax revenue may not be able to cover the cost of an ambitious enforcement program, even if the federal government continues to pay a large part of the overtime budget, as expected.
For one thing, police officers are already in arbitration seeking a raise well above that offered to other uniformed employees. If they are refused, the recent surge in police morale that came with the outpouring of respect for their work after the terrorist attack will be short-lived, a police union official said.
On the other hand, criminal justice analysts said an economic slump could help a department with an attrition problem because veteran officers looking to retire would no longer be able to find jobs so easily in the shrinking private sector. Union officials disagree, saying terrorism has increased the demand for people with law enforcement experience.
"You might lose jobs in other sectors, but the security market has exponentially grown," said John Driscoll, president of the Captains Endowment Association, the union that represents many police supervisors.
Mr. Kelly will also find that the chilly relationship between the police and many black and Hispanic citizens has thawed since the days when the shooting of Amadou Diallo led to criticism of the aggressive police tactics used during the Giuliani administration. Jerome Skolnick, an expert on policing at New York University School of Law, said attitudes toward the police shifted noticeably after the events of Sept. 11.
"The role of the police is much more widely accepted across the five boroughs in virtually every neighborhood," Mr. Skolnick said. "He starts off with good feelings toward the police."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE CHILDREN; 
Millions of Afghan Children, and No Ideas About Their Future

BYLINE:  By C. J. CHIVERS 

DATELINE: ALCHIN, Afghanistan, Dec. 2 

 BODY:
His face was dirty and his pants, cinched tight with rope, were several inches too wide in the waist. His rubber boots looked twice the size of his feet. He is 8 years old and has never been to school. He reached into his sweater, pulled out a few pages of Arabic script and began to read. 
 It was not much, merely the alphabet in Dari, but in Afghanistan it is enough to move him well ahead of his peers. He lowered the grubby book and smiled. 
 "The mullah taught me," said the boy, Qundahakha, who lives in this shepherd's village without plumbing, electricity, a health clinic or a school, and where children have virtually no idea what they will do in the future. 
The United Nations estimates that half of the 23 million Afghans are younger than 18, and although demographics are impossible to verify in a land without a census, it is clear that in each mud-walled hamlet or cold city alley the children swarm in bunches and packs. They are a huge mass of people, largely illiterate and mostly unvaccinated -- some skilled in the basics of waging war, others without any moral reference point after being raised under the Taliban's brand of law.
They are savvy to the streets and the steppe, yet without the slightest sense of the world. Here one can meet 10-year-old boys who can clean a carburetor, butcher a sheep, point out a land mine, disassemble a Russian rifle or look after a storekeeper's stall.
Only rarely does one meet a boy like Qundahakha, who is learning to read. It is even worse with the girls, whom the Taliban barred from school.
What will become of this enormous group, and how they will be incorporated into whatever sort of society Afghanistan eventually becomes, is one of the pressing questions for a nation trying remake itself after more than two decades of war.
"This is a problem of the center of the Afghan situation," said Olara A. Otunnu, the United Nations special representative for children and armed conflict. "You are talking about two generations of children and youth who have been exposed to war nonstop."
Mr. Otunnu said the problems exist on two related scales. The issues involving human need are obvious and complex. And on a deeper level, if they are not solved, he said, the children will be the seeds for more violence and terrorism. "Unless the children have viable alternatives, Afghanistan will be an incubator that can be exploited or manipulated by almost anyone," he said. "We have already seen that its problems can spread over borders."
The collapse of standards of living for Afghan youth goes beyond the near absence of organized education. Almost all of the children are living in poverty. Some are psychologically scarred. Most have few role models besides soldiers -- and their parents struggling in a hand-to-mouth economy. A few are visibly sick. 
Dr. Muhammad Nodir, a specialist in internal medicine in the nearby city of Kunduz, said that in the past year he saw two dozen children die of illnesses that in most of the world would be readily curable, including diarrhea or colds that became lung infections that could not be stopped. 
"Most of the children have a cough and other problems, you can just look at them and see it," the doctor said. "We need antibiotics."
There are also unsettling signs in children who have been exposed to so much violence and severity that they have little sense of their meaning. Mirwais, a 12-year-old boy in Kunduz, said that earlier this year he stood in a crowd on the city's main soccer field and watched the Taliban lop a hand and a foot from each of two men accused of theft. 
He saw nothing odd about it. He thought it strange that someone would ask. "They were criminal people," he said. "That is what criminal people get."
At the moment, the efforts to help children are patchwork and informal.
In Kunduz on Sunday, while dozens of children played in the muddy alleys, 11 others crammed into a 12-by-6-foot mud-walled room to practice multiplication tables. Class was in session in an underground school, an illegal education center during the Taliban's four-year reign in the city. It has continued to meet in the past week, even after the Taliban surrendered.
"The Afghan people do not have an economy, but we have good brains," said the teacher, Mahboba. "We are very smart, clever people. All we need is a chance."
Then she amended her thought: "We also need tables, we need blackboards, we need books and chalk and the other things to make schools good again." 
Like the dozens of others interviewed for this story, the children in her class brightened when they talked about the future. Then they faltered. 
They want to have jobs and earn money, but they know so little of a functioning society that they could name only the few professions they have seen first hand: doctor, shepherd, shopkeeper, teacher, mujahedeen.
One said engineer, but only after Mahboba said the word first. Another, in a moment of inspiration, realized she had learned a new line of work.
"Journalist!" she said, and the rest of the class laughed.
In the shadow of one of the city's schools, which was closed and used as a Taliban barracks, even one former senior Taliban commander said the extremist movement had devastated his country. Sitting by a wood stove with his bodyguards, the defector, Gen. Abdullah Gaurd, said he used to command 500 soldiers in the Kunduz region. He knows the extremist movement set Afghanistan, already suffering from Soviet invasion and civil war, even further back.
"It was a big calamity," General Gaurd said. "The children growing up shouldn't be like us. All of the children should be brought up better. They need doctors and school."
Asked if the classrooms and clinics should be open for girls, he said: "Yes. Even girls."
But with schools now tending to only a fraction of the population, for many other children childhood is short. Boys who would be elementary school pupils in the West are already working as apprentices in manual trades.
In the city's bazaar, Mansoor, 10, was cleaning the grease from the starter of a Russian jeep. His hands were blackened with oil and dirt. He washed the parts in gasoline. He said he has been at the job three years. "I am going to go to school next year," he said. "I will learn how to read. Right now my father feeds our family as a mechanic, and it is my job to help him."
In Alchin, children are similarly busy helping their parents tending camels, cows and sheep. Poverty was self-evident: a few of the 60 or so children who clustered around visitors walked barefoot on nearly frozen ground. Another bunch wore sandals without socks. Only four said they could read.
One girl, Zanab, 12, said that she had watched the American bombs explode on the hills nearby, and that now that the province was freed of Taliban she wanted to study. "I would like to go to school and learn how to write, and then go meet the faculty of a college," she said. 
Asked if she knew where the college was, she was quiet for a moment. "Maybe Kabul?" she asked back.
One of the parents nearby interrupted. "I want to send my children to school, but we are poor and there is no school," said the parent, Abdul Aziz. "This is the problem. Only with school can our children improve our situation."
A few hundred yards away, the gate to Qundahakha's home is a piece of metal stripped from the hood of a Russian truck. Light passes through dozens of bullet holes. He is one of the few in the hamlet who is learning to read, having picked up the alphabet from the Taliban mullah who was teaching him the Koran. 
He was 4 years old when the Taliban took over the region, and he knows no other life. He has heard his father say that there was sheep rustling in the Taliban days, and already a few sheep have been taken by hungry Northern Alliance troops. 
He thinks the Taliban mullah has given him a chance, and he looks forward to more study at the mosque. He said he will take teachers where he can find them. "I like the Taliban," he said. "The Taliban is good."

HEADLINE: National Briefing Washington: Economic Stimulus Bill 

BYLINE:  By Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

 BODY:
 Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders agreed on a procedure for negotiating an economic stimulus bill and said they would try to begin working on a compromise today. 
The parties have been deadlocked for weeks over the measure, with Republicans insisting on tax cuts for businesses and individuals and Democrats demanding increased aid to the unemployed and low-income workers. With the economy in recession, Congress is likely to have to consider raising the federal debt limit next year, an indication that plans to reduce the national debt could fall victim to the downturn. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

HEADLINE: 2 Rival Chip Makers Consider Joining Forces 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
Two archrivals in the chip-making business, Hynix Semiconductor and Micron Technology, have begun negotiations on a strategic alliance that the chief executive of Hynix, Park Chong Sup, predicted today would "change the landscape of the chip industry."
 Mr. Park said it was too early to say if the talks would lead to a full-blown merger of the two companies. "We'll know whether it's go or no-go within a month," he said. 
 Responding to rumors of an imminent deal that have circulated here for weeks, Mr. Park and Micron's chairman, Steve Appleton, issued a joint statement today saying their companies were "evaluating a broad array of strategic options."
Industry analysts said the possibilities included an arrangement for Hynix, which is struggling with $8.6 billion in debt, to produce semiconductors for Micron, which leapfrogged over Hynix to move to second place in the world memory chip field, behind Samsung Electronics.
Another option may be joining forces on research and development. Analysts said Hynix, starved for cash, is falling dangerously behind in research and development as its creditors argue over resolving its debt problems.
"We're looking at all alternatives -- anything's possible," said Daniel Behrendt, a manager in investor relations at Hynix. 
In the meantime, Mr. Behrendt said, Micron, based in Boise, Idaho, will stop complaining that Hynix is being kept alive by government subsidies, in the form of rescue plans led by creditor banks that are largely owned and controlled by the government. Under the latest plan, Hynix creditors have agreed to write off $1 billion that Hynix owes them and to accept Hynix stock in payment of $2.5 billion more.
While Micron may also take an equity stake in Hynix, analysts said they doubted that Micron was prepared at this stage to take majority control of Hynix in a deal akin to the one General Motors is completing with Daewoo Motor, the bankrupt automaker.
"General Motors is a financially stronger firm in discussion with a much weaker firm," said Richard Samuelson, managing director of UBS Warburg Securities in Seoul. "Micron only has about $1 billion in cash available at this moment. Hynix is a big chunky thing for them to swallow whole. The relationship would be more like a supplier agreement than a merger."
Still, news of the talks heartened South Korea's finance minister, Jin Nyum, enough to prompt a prediction from him that both Daewoo Motor and Hynix Semiconductor, two of the government's biggest headaches as it tries to pull the country out of its current economic slump, would soon resolve their problems.
The companies were pillars of two of South Korea's largest conglomerates, the Daewoo Group, which collapsed in mid-1999, and the Hyundai Group, which broke up into several smaller groups this year.
Mr. Samuelson said Hynix might cooperate with Micron as it perfected and began mass-producing its latest memory product, a 256-megabyte synchronous dynamic random access memory, or SDRAM, chip that it hopes to market in 2002.
"It's very costly to get economies of scale and bring the error rate down," Mr. Samuelson said. While Micron's profits have suffered in the current slump, he added, "they are not taking huge losses like Hynix."
Mr. Behrendt said Hynix was retooling its plant in Eugene, Ore., to begin making the chips, which could be marketed as a Micron product.
Hynix has had to sell its mainstay 128-MB DRAM and 64-MB DRAM chips at a loss in recent months as prices worldwide have plummeted by 90 percent in a year. 
Investors, buoyed by word of the talks, bid Hynix shares up today by the daily limit of 15 percent on the Korea stock exchange, closing at 2,465 won ($1.95) a share. Micron Technologies stock closed at $28.56, up $1.40.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
As Investors Worry About Mideast and Enron, Shares Fall

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday with selling generated by a sudden leap in Middle East hostilities and concern about the corporate fallout from Enron, the former Wall Street darling that is now the largest bankruptcy case in American history.
 These concerns overshadowed the optimism that made November the best month for the market since April, with a 7.5 percent gain in the broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Stocks have been on a tear after skidding to three-year lows on Sept. 21 in the wake of the attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average declined 87.60 points, or 0.9 percent, to close at 9,763.96, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 25.68 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,904.90. The S.& P. 500 shed 9.55 points, or 0.8 percent, dropping to 1,129.90. 
"We've had quite a bit of a rally since the lows in September and then you've got the Mideast situation and the Enron thing," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners. "Maybe there's a little bit of profit taking here."
Argentina's continuing financial crisis has also contributed to Wall Street's jitters, helping to overshadow a batch of better-than-expected economic data, including a report that United States manufacturing activity fell at a slower pace last month.
Shares of Enron rebounded 14 cents, to 40 cents, but this is still well under a dollar and a far cry from its year high of almost $85. Enron was a drag on the stocks of utilities and some leading Wall Street firms, including Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, on fears they might suffer losses from their dealings with Enron, the once-mighty energy trader.
Enron filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Sunday and sued Dynegy, its rival and onetime suitor, for $10 billion for pulling out of a last-ditch rescue merger. Dynegy followed with a countersuit. Dynegy stock fell $3.18, or 10.5 percent, to $27.17.
Tension grew in the Middle East with a series of Palestinian suicide bombings in Israel and Israel's retaliation. Israel launched missile strikes on Gaza City and buildings near Yasir Arafat's headquarters.
The violence there, along with optimism that Russia will comply with calls from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, sent oil prices soaring.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices rose as heightened tension in the Middle East, Enron's bankruptcy and a slide in stocks bolstered the attractiveness of government debt.
Gains were limited after a manufacturing index rose more than expected in November, bolstering speculation that a quarter-point interest rate cut at the Federal Reserve's Dec. 11 meeting might be its last.
The Treasury market has been "like a yo-yo," said Bob Ried, an economist and partner at Ried Thunberg & Company, a research firm in Westport, Conn. 
The 10-year Treasury note rose 14/32, to a price of 102 12/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.69 percent from 4.76 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 20/32, to 101 30/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.24 percent from 5.29 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Despite Ills, Automakers Report Solid Sales for November 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
Auto sales remained strong for much of November but began to slow after Thanksgiving, when the Big Three automakers started to restrict their interest-free financing offers. Still, the nation's auto industry remains on pace for what should be at least the third- or possibly the second-biggest sales year ever.
 General Motors said yesterday that it would increase first-quarter production by 7 percent to replenish a stock of vehicles diminished by record October sales and a strong November. G.M., the world's largest automaker, also said it would step up production by about 15,000 vehicles this quarter, and it said the increase would have a favorable effect on earnings projections. 
 That does not mean all is well in the Motor City. 
"We do have to realize we are not going to defy gravity and continue to see sales at record levels," said Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director for global market and industry analysis.
"It was pretty clear as the month went along that sales started off at a pace that was not that different from October and then faded as the month went through," he added. 
Financial analysts have been waiting for the payback to materialize from the wave of interest-free financing deals. Although the deals have been great for buyers and have propelled sales, analysts expect they have stolen hundreds of thousands of sales from next year and only delayed much of the economic pain for the Big Three: G.M., Ford Motor and Chrysler. 
October sales set a record seasonally adjusted annual pace of 21.3 million vehicles as the economy was in recession. That pace fell to an annual selling rate of 18 million vehicles in November, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, but was a 9.5 percent increase from November 2000.
Analysts and automakers are projecting the year's final sales rate will be around 17 million vehicles, about the pace in 1999 and behind the record 17.4 million sold last year.
But the slowdown late in November, many believe, tells of a tougher environment to come. 
"The payback for the zero percent financing programs began in November," John Casesa, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said in a research note. "We expect industry demand to decline through 2002, and likely into 2003."
George Pipas, Ford's sales analyst, said, "There was a noticeable falloff in the last week."
"Not dramatic or frightening, just noticeable," he added. "It was coincident with the change in our incentive program that started on Nov. 21. Perhaps that week provided a window into December."
Wall Street reacted negatively to the news yesterday, as shares of all three top automakers declined.
Shares of Ford Motor were battered, falling 6 percent, to $17.80, after a report over the weekend that the company would warn that its fourth-quarter loss would be steeper than expected. Ford's sales rose 4.4 percent for November, less than analysts expected considering the incentive programs that the company had in place. Ford's market share has declined to 23.2 percent so far this year, from 24.2 percent in the first 11 months of last year. 
Officials at Ford have not commented on the report about its fourth-quarter losses. But Ford acknowledged a new round of cost cutting yesterday, including an indefinite suspension of matching salaried workers' 401(k) contributions 60 cents per dollar; increased out-of-pocket health-care costs for workers; the suspension of merit raises for more than 2,000 top managers; and the layoff of 600 hourly workers at a truck plant in Edison, N.J.
The Chrysler Group reported another month of lagging sales in November, with overall sales falling 6 percent. Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, was the only company among 10 automakers to report a drop in United States car and truck sales, according to the AutoData Corporation. Shares of DaimlerChrysler fell 2.4 percent, to $41. 
At G.M., sales rose 13 percent in November. If its results affirmed G.M. as the healthiest of the wounded Big Three domestic manufacturers, they will probably not please environmental groups concerned about oil consumption as the country fights a war in Central Asia. G.M.'s sales have been propelled almost entirely by gas-guzzling pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. Company officials said G.M. was on pace to sell more S.U.V.'s this year than any other company had before in a single year. G.M. also projects it will have its best sales year for pickup trucks in more than two decades. 
Despite its sales gains, shares of G.M. fell 1.3 percent, to $49.03.
G.M. has shown signs of making a move on the beleaguered Ford Motor as Wall Street's pick among the Big Three. In the third quarter, the mutual fund companies Fidelity Investments and Capital Research bought G.M. shares while they sold Ford. But G.M.'s incentive strategy remains a concern for analysts, and most professional investors appear to fear the weakness of all the Big Three automakers, which are faced with stiff and persistent competition from abroad. 
Sales at Toyota, the nation's fourth-largest automaker, were up 10 percent for November. Honda's sales in the United States rose 11.5 percent, while Nissan gained 7 percent. Foreign manufacturers' sales gains have come even as the companies have relied far less on the costly incentives that have been eroding the profitability of the Big Three. Ford is expected to post its first lost since 1992 this year, and the Chrysler Group is also expected to report a loss.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE WARNING; 
White House Issues Alert Of New Terrorism Threat

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
The government warned this afternoon that there could be new terror strikes against the United States in the next several weeks, perhaps tied to the final days of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan or other religious observances.
 The urgent alert by Tom Ridge, the White House director of homeland security, was the third since the attacks of Sept. 11 in which the federal government had put the nation on a state of heightened vigilance without providing any detail about the nature of the threat or possible targets. 
 "Now is not the time to back off," Mr. Ridge said in a late-afternoon appearance in the White House briefing room. 
The Federal Bureau of Investigation issued the advisory to 18,000 state and local law enforcement agencies around the country. And Mr. Ridge notified the nation's governors of the new alert in an afternoon conference call.
Intelligence analysts have reported that threats monitored from multiple sources had become more numerous in recent days and were considered credible enough to issue a warning, Mr. Ridge said. He said President Bush had personally approved the latest announcement.
"The threats we are picking up are very generic," Mr. Ridge said. "They warn of more attacks but are not specific about where or what type. We do know that the next several weeks, which bring the final weeks of Ramadan and important religious observations in other faiths, have been times when terrorists have planned attacks in the past."
Senior government officials said the warning had been based in intercepted communications related to Osama bin Laden's terrorist network, Al Qaeda.
One official said there was precedent for plans by Islamic militants to take action in the last days of Ramadan, which ends in mid-December.
"The sources are more credible and, let me just say, the decibel level is higher as they talk about potential attacks," Mr. Ridge said. He added that the alert would be in effect for several weeks.
The warning followed three Palestinian suicide bombings over the weekend in Israel that brought retaliatory Israeli air strikes today. But Mr. Ridge said there was no sign that the threat had been related to the escalating violence in the Middle East.
The alert also came as fighting in Afghanistan intensified in the last major Taliban stronghold, Kandahar, and as United States warplanes continued to bomb caves and bunkers where Mr. bin Laden and other Al Qaeda leaders were believed to be hiding. 
United States officials now believe that Al Qaeda's leadership in Afghanistan is virtually incapable of communication with its cells around the world. Officials involved in the alert declined to characterize what they were hearing, but the situation in Afghanistan suggests that the intercepted communications were among operatives outside that country.
The Justice Department and F.B.I. earlier issued two other general terrorist alerts, each time drawing criticism that they were creating a sense of panic that ran counter to efforts to get Americans to resume their normal lives. Today's warning came as retailers hoped for a strong Christmas shopping season to help lift the nation out of its economic recession.
Mr. Ridge today acknowledged the questions and criticisms about issuing generalized warnings, but said that judging the intelligence was an art, not a science.
"It would be so much easier, admittedly, if there were a little more specifics we could refer to," he said. "But there are not."
Mr. Ridge said he did not want Americans to cancel holiday plans, but he also did not want them to relax unduly. "The further removed we get from Sept. 11, I think the natural tendency is to let down our guard," he said. "Unfortunately, we cannot do that. We are a nation at war. We are the targets of enemies who have demonstrated they have no remorse about killing thousands of innocent civilians."
White House officials said that the heads of the law enforcement and intelligence agencies had all agreed that the alert should be issued.
Attorney General John Ashcroft has taken the brunt of the criticism in the past for such warnings. But officials said the appearance by Mr. Ridge alone to announce the alert was not a move to deflect attention from Mr. Ashcroft. 
The attorney general was in Canada today to sign an agreement on border security, including more sharing of information between the two countries.
Now that Mr. Ridge had begun to settle into his new job, Susan Neely, the communications director of the office of homeland security, said, "It seemed more fitting that he speak on behalf of all the agencies in the homeland security council."
The last threat alert was issued Oct. 29, the one before it on Oct. 11. In both cases no attack followed and federal officials suggested that heightened vigilance might have helped to foil planned attacks.
On another issue, the puzzling anthrax death of Ottilie W. Lundgren, a 94-year-old Connecticut woman, Mr. Ridge could offer no definitive explanation. He said that while cross-contamination of the mail might be a plausible cause, swabs taken from places in her house where mail might have been deposited showed no traces of the deadly germ.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Delinquency Rate Hits 10-Year High 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
The percentage of homeowners behind on mortgages in the third quarter rose to the highest level in 10 years as layoffs and a shrinking economy left more families short of cash. 
 The mortgage delinquency rate, or the percentage of loans with payments overdue at least 30 days, rose to 4.87 percent, up more than one percentage point from a year earlier, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said. 
The rate rose from 4.63 percent in the second quarter and is approaching the 5.20 percent it reached in 1991 during the last recession. 
 The weakening gross domestic product and job losses in the technology and manufacturing sectors have affected homeowners' ability to keep their mortgage payments current, said Douglas Duncan, the Mortgage Bankers Association's chief economist. 
Countrywide Credit Industries, the No. 1 nonbank mortgage lender, said delinquencies in its mortgage portfolio grew to 5 percent in October, up from 4.40 percent in the same month last year. 
The weakening economy and the rise in delinquencies have also contributed to a slip in the median home price in October to $145,300 from $147,400, the National Association of Realtors said. The median home price has declined 5 percent since August. 
"There are some red lights from this report," said Dale Westhoff, head of mortgage research at Bear Stearns & Company. "The housing market is clearly in a period of contraction." 
The housing market had been one of the bright spots in the economy and home prices rose through August, helped by a series of rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

HEADLINE: Venezuela's New Oil Law Is Seen as a Risk to Growth 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
A sweeping law signed last month by the left-leaning government of President Hugo Chavez could put a damper on foreign investment for increasing oil production just as the United States' market for Venezuelan oil seemed about to expand, oil analysts and economists say.
 This country already provides 15 percent of American oil imports and, with the largest proven reserves outside the Middle East, has been positioned to become a more important supplier. The political instability of the Middle East might have been expected to make Venezuela, a short four-day tanker trip from the United States, an even more attractive alternative for foreign multinationals and American policy makers. 
 The new law, which nearly doubles royalty payments and gives majority control of projects to the government, may slow oil industry expansion plans and could eventually lead foreign multinationals to look for projects in other countries, analysts said. 
"There is a unique moment, an opportunity, where there is a consensus -- movement away from dependence on the Middle East," said Lawrence Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation Inc., an industry-supported consulting group in New York. "Given the long history of Venezuela and the United States, it is an opportunity I think they are missing."
This could prove disabling for Venezuela, because oil revenues account for 50 percent of government revenues and 80 percent of exports.
Already, tumbling oil prices are seen as a bad sign for Venezuela's economy. The value of the country's oil has fallen 40 percent since last year, and the worldwide economic slowdown could ensure that prices remain low. 
That is especially worrisome for the Chavez government, which has promised to improve the lives of the poor by funneling more money to social programs, schools and clinics. Last year, government spending increased by 42 percent, bankrolled largely by high oil prices. Now, future spending is in doubt.
"If oil prices go down and investment goes down, he is going to be looking at a shrinking pool of resources," said Sondra Scott, who analyzes the Latin American oil industry for Cambridge Energy Resources Associates, a Massachusetts consulting company.
Government officials, however, said the new law would increase much-needed revenues and unify a series of unwieldy oil laws that go back nearly 60 years. 
Under Alvaro Silva, the energy and mining minister, the administration has been determined to offset earlier agreements that officials here believe gave too much away to foreign multinationals. Administration officials also contend that the state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, will be able to pick up the increasing costs expected for future exploration and production projects.
Those who helped draft that law said foreign companies would always be lured here by Venezuela's choice offerings: 77 billion barrels of proven oil reserves and perhaps hundreds of billions of barrels of heavy oil, more than the proven reserves in the Middle East.
"This is normal, normal, to hear complaints," said Mazhar al-Shereidah, an oil economist who worked on the government's committee that studied the law. "If I am a giant multinational, and I hear the terms are going to change, then it is in my interest to foment criticism, to say I am going to go away."
Government officials also say critics of the law, like Venezuela's powerful business groups, are motivated by their hatred of Mr. Chavez. The former army paratrooper and coup plotter has turned Venezuela on its head by toppling corrupt political parties, writing a new Constitution and taking control of the legislature.
"We have a national policy for the development of the economy," said Tarek William Saab, chairman of the foreign relations committee of the National Assembly. "And that is to confront the neo-liberal system, where everything is in the name of private capital, and nothing is for the country." 
In this politically charged country, though, opponents of the law see it and other economic legislation in apocalyptic terms. 
"Forget about future projects," said Robert Bottome, a harsh Chavez critic and editor of a respected economic journal, Veneconomia. "They're just dead." 
Many analysts, like Ramon Espinasa, former chief economist for Petroleos de Venezuela, do not go so far. Still, Mr. Espinasa, who is now a consultant at the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington, calculated in a recent report that future investment could fall, costing $52 billion in lost exports in the next decade.
Ms. Scott's consulting company downgraded its assessment that Venezuela would increase its daily production to five million barrels a day by 2010. The new projection is four million barrels daily. Currently, the country exports 2.6 million barrels daily, about 1.5 million of which go to the United States.
The impact of the law will be most keenly felt in the region considered most vital to Venezuela's future -- the Orinoco belt of eastern Venezuela, where ExxonMobil, TotalFinaElf of France, the Phillips Petroleum Company and other large multinationals have in recent years signed contracts to pump difficult-to-refine heavy oil.
To lure companies to undertake the highly expensive refining of the tarlike oil, the government of President Rafael Caldera signed deals in the mid-1990's that provided royalties of 1 percent, and a 34 percent tax rate. 
But under the new law and other legislation, royalty payments rise to from 20 percent to 30 percent for companies that produce heavy crude, while taxes rise to 50 percent. Outside this region, the royalty rates would increase to 30 percent from 16.7 percent, though taxes would fall to 50 percent from 67 percent.
"I think the government's message is they don't want" the multinationals, said Rafael Sandrea, president of the oil committee of the Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry.
The oil companies have been more diplomatic, with Jerome Auzenne, general manager of Phillips Petroleum's operations here, saying his company is "a guest in someone else's home," adding, "We won't tell them how to run their home."
Still, Mr. Auzenne noted that the Phillips project, with ChevronTexaco and Petroleos de Venezuela as partners, was made more palatable by the earlier agreements, which would not be affected under the new law. 
But future projects will have to be carefully considered, he said, noting that most other oil-producing nations are trying to improve terms of possible agreements to lure investors. "We have a lot of opportunities," Mr. Auzenne said.
