HEADLINE: At $92.60 a Vote, Bloomberg Shatters An Election Record 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Sixty-eight million, nine hundred sixty-eight thousand, one hundred eighty-five dollars.
 That's how much Michael R. Bloomberg spent from his personal fortune on the election that made him the mayor of New York City, according to documents his campaign filed yesterday with the city's Board of Elections. It breaks all records for spending in municipal elections by tens of millions of dollars. 
 It is just $2 million less than Ross Perot spent on his 1992 presidential campaign, and it is more than the $48.6 million Steve Forbes spent on his 2000 presidential campaign, and the $63 million Jon S. Corzine spent on his record-breaking campaign for one of New Jersey's United States Senate seats in 2000. 
And it means that Mr. Bloomberg, a Republican, wound up spending $92.60 for each of the 744,757 votes he won in the Nov. 6 election against Mark Green, a Democrat. (Mr. Perot, by contrast, spent about $3.59 per vote in the 1992 presidential race.)
"You know how they talk about how being mayor of New York is the second toughest job in the country?" asked Larry Noble, the executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit group that studies money and politics. "It's now the second most expensive job as well."
Mr. Bloomberg, a billionaire, spent his own money on the campaign, choosing to ignore the city's campaign finance law, which seeks to restrict the influence of money on politics by requiring candidates to limit the amount of money they raise and spend in order to qualify for public matching funds. Mr. Green, his opponent, who participated in the program, spent roughly $16.5 million, his campaign said.
The Bloomberg campaign was the Rolls-Royce of campaigns. It spent more money on television advertisements and mailings in the last two weeks of the campaign than the Green campaign spent on the whole race. The filings show that from Oct. 23 on, the Bloomberg campaign spent $8.4 million on television, $6.4 million on polling and, in a surprise, $9.6 million on glossy color campaign mailings -- more than it spent on television ads -- in that final stretch.
It is more money than Mr. Bloomberg apparently envisioned spending earlier in the campaign. Last spring New York magazine reported that Mr. Bloomberg had said that he would not spend as much as $30 million on the race, quoting him as saying, "At some point, you start to look obscene."
In the summer, when it became clear that he would probably spend more than $30 million, Mr. Bloomberg told The New York Post that he did not remember saying it would be obscene to spend that much. "My recollection is that I said you could not spend on New York City's race what was spent on the last Senate race here or the Senate race in New Jersey," he was quoted as saying.
But the campaign filings show that he spent more than was spent on either race. Rick A. Lazio spent $40.5 million in his unsuccessful bid against Hillary Rodham Clinton, who spent $29.8 million. And Mr. Corzine spent $63 million in the Senate race in New Jersey.
Bill Cunningham, a senior Bloomberg campaign strategist, said that he did not think it was fair to compare Mr. Bloomberg's spending with Mr. Corzine's, because the figures had not been adjusted for inflation. 
"You know, we always talked about spending what was necessary to get our message out, and ultimately, that's exactly what we did," Mr. Cunningham said.
The nearly $69 million Mr. Bloomberg spent is more than 10 times what a candidate typically spends running for United States Senate, and roughly 97 times what a candidate spends, on average, running for the House of Representatives, according to Mr. Noble of the Center for Responsive Politics. It is more than half the $133 million -- not counting soft money -- that Al Gore spent running for president in 2000. (George W. Bush spent $193 million, according to the center.)
The previous record for spending on a New York City mayoral race was set by Ronald S. Lauder, who spent $14 million in 1989, when he lost the Republican primary to Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Mr. Perot, who was previously Exhibit A in the billionaire candidate category, spent $63.5 million of his own money in his 1992 race, which raised an additional $7.5 million from others. And Mr. Forbes spent $38.7 million of his own money in the 2000 race, raising another $10 million.
Mr. Bloomberg spent only his own money. Despite his decision not to participate in the city's campaign finance program, he was endorsed by Senator John McCain, a leading advocate of campaign finance reform, who said that the issue should not be a "litmus test."
Mr. Bloomberg's millions allowed him to saturate the airwaves with well-produced television advertisements. The campaign even bought some of the most expensive time on television, during the World Series. An analysis by the Wisconsin Advertising Project at the University of Wisconsin at Madison found that Mr. Bloomberg ran roughly 6,500 television ads and Mr. Green 2,500.
The money also allowed the Bloomberg campaign to send out many glossy color mailings, on hard paper stock, praising his endorsements and attacking Mr. Green. In the final week, the campaign sent out a mailing suggesting that Mr. Green would raise taxes and roll back the Giuliani administration's successes in fighting crime. Still, it was highly unusual for a campaign to spend more money on mailings than television advertisements in the final weeks of a campaign.
Mr. Green's campaign manager, Richard Schrader, accused Mr. Bloomberg of buying the election. "He bought it fair and square, and by spending a historic amount on television ads he controlled the airwaves and altered people's perception of reality," Mr. Schrader said.

HEADLINE: The Weaknesses Of Science For Profit 

BYLINE:  By Harold Varmus; Harold Varmus, a Nobel laureate in medicine, is president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and former director of the National Institutes of Health.

 BODY:
Last week Americans briefly diverted their eyes from Afghanistan to consider the announcement by a small New England biotechnology company that it had created human embryonic clones. President Bush expressed grave concern, and some members of Congress made renewed calls for legislation to ban the practice outright. One might think that a cloned human baby had been born.
 In truth, what the investigators did was much less significant, and it was undertaken for a different purpose. They attempted to adopt one step of the process used for cloning animals -- the transfer of a cell nucleus -- as part of a strategy to develop human embryonic stem cells. They removed the nuclei from several human cells and placed each one in another cell, an egg cell. In a very few instances, the reconstructed cell went through one or two divisions, generating no more than six cells -- not enough to allow the derivation of stem cell lines. 
 Many of us in the scientific community criticized the company's report as premature because it showed little experimental progress and advanced no new ideas. Supporters of medical science lamented the company's naivete because the announcement precipitated an unnecessary political firestorm and provoked the threat of new barriers to potentially beneficial research.
So why did the company make its announcement? Although its executives claimed to be excited about the findings and said the information would promote educational debate, the actual reasons may be more self-serving. Biotechnology companies are dependent on investors, and investors like publicity.
Such behavior is, of course, both legal and expected, but it is one of the unhealthy aspects of confining certain kinds of research to the private sector. Our country is notable for doing this in areas of ethically sensitive science. In Britain and most other countries with major investments in science, a national decision is made at the outset about whether to allow such work to be done at all, regardless of who pays for it. In contrast, Americans tend to focus our debate on whether it is permissible to use federal funds -- taxpayers' dollars -- to finance the work.
This odd strategy does have the benefit of allowing such work to proceed in at least one venue: commercial labs. For example, over the past two decades, federal financing for in vitro fertilization -- as a therapy for infertility or as a topic for research -- has been prohibited. But this policy has not kept the private sector from pursuing in vitro fertilization as a practical solution to infertility; tens of thousands of new parents and their babies have been the beneficiaries.
Thus the policy achieves two goals: it does not offend taxpayers who oppose the use of federal money to support work that violates their ethical standards, yet it allows researchers to pursue innovation on the frontiers of science -- so long as it's privately financed.
On the other hand, because this policy prevents academic investigators from studying in vitro fertilization with funds from the National Institutes of Health, it compromises efforts to learn the fundamental principles of fertilization and to improve the basic technology. Moreover, it leaves the field largely in the hands of the for-profit sector -- where commercial realities must be considered along with scientific progress, where full disclosure is not the norm, and where oversight is limited.
Last week's episode further illustrates the importance of involving federally financed scientists in work that is permitted in the private sector. The "nuclear transfer" strategy pursued by the company in question is not intended to produce cloned human beings ("reproductive cloning"), a goal that nearly all agree is unacceptable. But the approach is excluded from federal financing by a provision in the N.I.H.'s annual appropriations bill, and federal money could not even be used to study any resulting stem cells, since President Bush's Aug. 9 directive prevents the use of federal funds for research into any stem cells not already in existence at the time of his speech.
Still, stem cells made by nuclear transfer could have substantial advantages over existing stem cell lines for studying basic processes of human development. This is an aspect of the work more likely to be pursued by academic scientists than by those working in industry, because its commercial uses are much less certain, although extraordinary discoveries might be made.
Nuclear transfer has more obvious value, both economic and medical, as a method to make stem cells for therapy: such cells would not be rejected if returned to the original donor of the cell nucleus (or to others with a similar genetic makeup). This is one of the potentially viable means to overcome immune barriers to cell-based therapies for a variety of dire diseases.
Such research is vital not just to biotechnology companies and their investors, but to the nation as a whole. By structuring our system so that only those with private funds or a commercial motive do this pioneering work, we curb our full capacity to expand our scientific understanding.

HEADLINE: Congress Pushes for School Reform 

 BODY:
George W. Bush's promise to end "the soft bigotry of low expectations" that permits minority children to fall permanently behind at school seemed destined to go nowhere after Sept. 11. Even before then, the House and Senate appeared hopelessly tied up in bickering over the federal government's proper role in aiding local schools. But now the leaders of both parties have quietly reached tentative agreement on a ground-breaking bill that holds the states accountable as never before for rescuing failing schools and closing the achievement gap between rich and poor students. The only danger is that the federal government will deluge the schools with new mandates while providing too little money to get the job done. 
 The most valuable part of the plan is a requirement that the states conduct annual testing in reading and math for students in grades three through eight. These tests would allow parents to learn how their children's schools stack up against others in the state, and how they are progressing year to year. Faced with a conservative backlash against the idea of national tests, Congress came up with a sensible compromise, in which the government will use a well-established national assessment system to make all the different results comparable. 
 Many lawmakers had been nervous about setting strict timetables for closing the achievement gap between minority and non-minority students. They were worried that setting standards too high would lead to the failure of hundreds of their own local schools. The latest version of the plan, which gives the states 12 years to close the gaps, should calm those fears without sacrificing the interests of poor and minority students. This latest bill sets reasonable achievement levels that will be raised gradually over time.
Congress has dropped Mr. Bush's idea of giving vouchers to students in failing schools. A school that makes no progress for two years would receive various forms of extra help. After three years of no progress, children would be allowed to transfer to another public school in the district. After four years, the school would be forced to provide supplemental instruction and curriculum. After six years, the school would be radically restructured, its staff and leadership changed. The conferees have called for increased spending on after-school programs and more money for Title I, the federal project targeted at the country's poorest districts and students.
Taken together, these provisions have the potential to improve public schools dramatically all across the United States. They are not a cure-all. Some are already in place in New York City, which is far from a perfect school system. They are only a start, and even the start will not be much help without proper funding. The national recession has already caused the states to cut billions of dollars from state education budgets. The leaders of the House-Senate conference committees seem to understand that these reforms cannot be taken seriously without substantial federal aid. But they still need to do some work in convincing the White House and their own colleagues.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: DRAGNET IN EUROPE; 
Spain Pursues Terrorists Among Its Muslim Immigrants

BYLINE:  By SAM DILLON with EMMA DALY

DATELINE: MADRID, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
Until recently, Madrid's Muslim community was so small that most Arabs knew each other. One was Ahmad Mardini, who emigrated from Syria three decades ago, married a Spanish woman and built a conservative life as a shopkeeper. He even phoned the authorities once to complain about graffiti scrawled on a neighborhood wall praising Spain's home-grown Basque terrorists.
 But in the last decade, Spain's Islamic population has exploded. Today it is a sea of strangers, as Mr. Mardini learned the hard way. A bearded young Arab who had recently arrived in Spain asked to buy his watch repair shop. Mr. Mardini agreed to sell, but something did not seem right. "He had fat fingers, so how was he going to fix watches?" Mr. Mardini wondered. 
 His premonition proved correct on Nov. 13, when as part of an antiterrorism dragnet, the police arrested Mr. Mardini and the buyer. Mr. Mardini has since cleared himself and been freed, but a Spanish judge has accused the man who bought his business of belonging to a sleeper cell loyal to Osama bin Laden. 
Like Mr. Mardini, many Muslims in Spain are feeling burned by the dawning realization that their community has become a busy logistical rear guard, apparently humming with Islamic terrorists.
Mohamed Atta, a suspected coordinator of the Sept. 11 suicide hijackers, visited Spain twice in the months before the attacks, and the police have carried out three roundups in six months of men accused of belonging to Mr. bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda. Officials say Islamic militants have sunk roots into an Arab immigrant population growing so fast that it is now 15 times as large as it was a dozen years ago.
An overwhelming majority of the newly arrived immigrants are law-abiding North African laborers, although many lack valid work papers. But a terrorist fringe appears to pose a threat that some authorities acknowledge was underestimated before the Sept. 11 attacks. 
The police are monitoring about 200 Arab immigrants suspected of working with 20 Islamic terrorist cells, a senior Spanish law enforcement official said in an interview.
"If we don't take out their infrastructure now, there'll be another major attack," the official said. "It's that simple."
Spain's No. 1 security concern continues to be the Basque group known as E.T.A., whose initials stand for Basque Homeland and Freedom.
Islamic terrorists have mounted only one major attack in Spain, the bombing of a restaurant near an American air base outside Madrid in 1985 that killed 18 Spaniards. E.T.A. has committed countless atrocities that have left 800 dead over 30 years, and just last month killed two traffic police officers and exploded a car bomb in Madrid that wounded 100.
Security forces have devoted fewer resources to combating Muslim terrorists, although during one period in the mid-1990's the police carried out sweeping arrests of Algerian extremists after linking them to bombings in the Paris subway.
But in the five years since, the Algerian groups have rebuilt their networks, and other Islamic militants from across North Africa and the Middle East have recruited new terror cells among the growing Muslim population, said Fernando Rei nares, a counterterrorism expert at the University of Burgos. 
Mr. bin Laden's apparent success in persuading several previously autonomous terror cells operating in Spain to cooperate with Al Qaeda has been even more worrisome, he said.
"They're hiding in the Arab immigrant communities," Mr. Reinares said. "We're seeing the globalization of Islamic groups in Spain, which before were only concerned with events in their home countries. Now they cooperate with terrorists all across the world."
The timing of the most recent roundups in the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks has led some analysts to conclude that Spanish authorities could have acted earlier. An extensive analysis published recently in Madrid's largest newspaper, El Pais, described the strategy of Spain's security forces toward Islamic militants before Sept. 11.
The policy was to "watch them, listen to them and keep quiet," El Pais said. "Don't wake up the lioness as long as she remained inactive in our territory, but use the information obtained about them to alert other countries when their security appeared in danger, and exchange it for information useful to Spanish security." 
"But all that has changed," the paper said, because the ferocity of the Sept. 11 violence convinced the Spanish authorities that "now it is not only the E.T.A. that must be combated."
The director of Spain's National Police, Juan Cotino, denied any recent change in policy. "We've been detaining Islamic fundamentalists for many years, not just since Sept. 11," he said recently. "The environment has changed internationally, but our investigations in Spain were under way long before." 
The new terrorists can hide in a community that has swelled. During the economic boom that followed the death of Franco in 1975 and Spain's entry into the European Union in 1986, the immigrant flow became a torrent. Spain had plenty of jobs at a time when other European countries were limiting migration.
By the mid-1980's there were perhaps 30,000 Muslims in Spain. Today an estimated 500,000 Muslim immigrants live and work alongside Spain's 40 million people, said Gemma Martin Munoz, a sociologist of Arab culture at the Autonomous University of Madrid.
The immigrants have returned to a land their ancestors once ruled. The armies of Muhammad conquered the Iberian Peninsula in the eighth century, and their descendants stayed for 700 years, weaving an extraordinary cultural legacy that continues to be vibrant. 
Al Andalus, as the Islamic civilization in southern Spain is known to Arabic speakers, remains seared in the minds of millions of Muslims worldwide.
In Mr. bin Laden's Oct. 7 videotaped message from Afghanistan that was broadcast around the world, his deputy, Ayman al-Zawahiri, vowed that "the tragedy of Al Andalus" would not be repeated.
Mr. bin Laden and one of his brothers, Tarek, visited Alhambra -- the palace, overlooking Granada, of the last Muslim rulers of Spain -- in the early 1980's, renting the salons of an adjacent luxury hotel, according to news stories written at the time in Granada's main newspaper, Ideal.
Mr. bin Laden's visits came as Islam was flowering anew in Spain. In 1982, Arab donors financed construction of the first mosque built in Spain in five centuries, in the Mediterranean beach resort of Malaga. In 1992, a grand new mosque was inaugurated in Madrid, and now 3,000 Muslims pray there each Friday.
Ahmed Elmejjaoui, 40, a Moroccan who moved to Spain in 1988, is a security guard at that mosque. His views on the recent arrests of Islamic militants seemed to mirror those of a silent majority of Muslim immigrants, who in no way approve of terrorism. "I think it's fine they took these people in," Mr. Elmejjaoui told a visitor to the mosque one recent day. "If they weren't obeying the law, they deserved arrest."
Mr. Elmejjaoui, like Mr. Mardini, the shopkeeper, also feels a bit burned. His next-door neighbor in a southern Madrid housing project was Jasem Mahboule, a moody Syrian who rarely said hello and was, to Mr. Elmejjaoui's astonishment, detained and charged with terrorism on Nov. 13.
Other arrests in the last six months illustrate how the militants have discreetly insinuated themselves into the fabric of immigrant life.
Muhammad Bensakhria, 34, an Algerian lieutenant to Mr. bin Laden, had lived in a comfortable neighborhood in Frankfurt, living the life of an affluent businessman. 
But after the German police broke up most of his cell a year ago, Mr. Bensakhria fled to Alicante, a port on Spain's Mediterranean coast that has ferry service to Algeria. When the police arrested him in Alicante in June, Mr. Bensakhria was living on the street.
On Sept. 25 the police arrested six Algerians accused of taking part in plans to bomb the American Embassy in Paris. 
They were seized in immigrant settlements all across Spain, in places like Almeria, the southeastern province where thousands of Muslim immigrants work as laborers on coastal truck farms; Murcia, where migrant laborers harvest lettuce and work in vegetable canning factories; Valencia, where Arabs pick oranges; and Huelva, where North Africans harvest strawberries.

HEADLINE: Mayor Submits $766 Million In Cuts to Balance City Budget 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a $1.3 billion modification to the city's budget yesterday that included $766 million in cuts to various city agencies. The mayor had called for 15 percent cuts from almost all the agencies -- save uniformed forces and the Board of Education -- in October, citing a large budget gap caused largely by the terrorist attack in September.
 The resulting cutbacks, which require the approval of the City Council, could leave the city with a surplus of roughly $500 million at the close of the fiscal year in July, the mayor said. But the new budget does little to address the budget gaps of roughly $4 billion projected in the following two years that Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg will face. 
 Mayor Giuliani offered scant details yesterday about specific programs or services that would be affected by the budget cutbacks. 
He insisted that city services would not suffer, and that most of the trims were made by eliminating or reducing programs that were in the works for the end of the year. He also said that he did not see a need for layoffs.
Last night, the City Council staff and officials at the agencies said that they had yet to see the details of what was being cut. Agencies were asked to submit their trims last month, and all of those cuts were subject to the mayor's approval. In some cases, he said, he added back money, and in other cases, he removed even more. 
He expects to submit the substance of the budget to the Council today, which will then negotiate the cuts with him. The Council has 30 days to vote on the measure; otherwise it goes to the incoming Council.
Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said yesterday: "The Council will ensure that the burdens are shared equally by all New Yorkers during these tough fiscal times. It is vital that the mayor works with the Council so as to leave the city's fiscal house in order." Mr. Giuliani expressed confidence that the Council would approve his cuts, though many within the agencies and the Council believe that most cuts will affect pet programs of the Council. 
Although the mayor had called for 15 percent cuts from all except uniformed services, where he required 2.5 percent cuts, the trims were not uniform. Some agencies, like the Department of Sanitation, made close to 5 percent trims, while the Health Department had only 3 percent cut. Libraries, which had already reduced services in many branches, will receive a 10 percent cut. 
"The New York Public Library is still looking at what Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's reductions will mean in terms of service," read a prepared statement from the public relations office of the New York Public Library. Someone at the library with knowledge of the its financial situation said it was doubtful that many branches would be able to continue Saturday hours. 
Several agencies helped close the $1.2 billion budget gap created after Sept. 11 by producing fresh revenues, often as a result of reimbursement from the federal or state government for expenses related to the attack. 
For instance, the Police Department brought in $200 million in November, while Citywide Administrative Services brought in $29 million. The mayor's office, which trimmed less than 1 percent from its budget, said that it had contributed $89 million to the city's coffers in November. As a result, the city ended up with $26 million more in its coffers than it had anticipated. 
It is clear that most of these cuts will do little to aid Mr. Bloomberg as he faces union negotiations and a possible continued soft economy over the next few years. According to the mayor's projections yesterday, in the 2003 fiscal year beginning in July, the next mayor will face a $3.5 billion budget gap, growing to $3.9 billion the following year.

HEADLINE: Some Skimp on Tinsel as Others Splurge 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
This year, many managers are cutting back or canceling office parties, but Alfred Portale is not one of them.
 Mr. Portale, chef and co-owner of Gotham Bar and Grill in New York, plans to close his Greenwich Village restaurant on Super Bowl Sunday for a postholiday gathering that will include more than 400 employees and their family members. 
 Santa will be there. As will Winnie the Pooh, some characters from "Toy Story," a host of Pac Man and air-hockey machines, five large-screen televisions, gift bags for the children, and an open bar and lavish spread for the adults. The annual event is the only time that many employees, from dishwashers to food servers, feel comfortable coming into the restaurant as patrons, Mr. Portale says. 
"The show must go on," he said, adding that he "wouldn't dream in a million years" of abandoning a tradition he began 16 years ago.
Around half of all companies are pooh-poohing the idea of skimping on holiday gatherings this year. A survey last month by Battalia Winston International, an executive search firm, found companies split on the issue. Of those changing their plans, 82 percent said their holiday parties would be smaller or less expensive than in years past, and the remaining 18 percent will have no parties. Many gave the weak economy and the war on terrorism as rationales.
But for Mr. Portale and others like him, it is more important than ever to hold holiday parties, both to bolster employees' spirits and to defy the terrorists.
"We have all been through a lot of bad stuff this year," he said. "We need this party more now than we ever have before." The event will set him back more than $8,000, not counting the thousands in lost revenue from closing the restaurant for the day.
Michael Silver, president of Equis, a commercial real estate firm in Chicago, shares that sentiment. Not only is the Equis Chicago branch holding its regular holiday dinner at one of the city's most expensive restaurants, Naha, but for the first time it is inviting its 150 employees to bring along spouses. The five-hour party will include live entertainment and top-shelf liquor, even though profits are down 8 percent.
"I don't care if the economy's bad," Mr. Silver said. "I want our employees to feel a sense of community right about now." He derided managers who have canceled holiday parties this year as Scrooges. 
Companies going ahead with elaborate celebrations are often tapping into nationalism awakened by Sept. 11.
"We're seeing a huge pro-America sentiment in the corporate parties we're planning," said Carey Smolensky, chief executive of Carey Smolensky Productions, an event-planning and promotions company in Wheeling, Ill. Mr. Smolensky said he had had an "unusually high number of requests" for items like flag pins and Christmas trees painted red, white and blue. At a party for a jewelry company, he had a large group of vocalists light candles and sing "God Bless America," he said.
"Everyone's looking not just to party, but to send employees a message that's more poignant and heartfelt," he said.
The HomeBanc Mortgage Corporation in Atlanta briefly considered canceling its festivities but decided to go ahead to bolster employee morale. The party in Atlanta, held on Monday, had 1,800 guests. HomeBanc also scheduled parties in late November and early December in Tampa, Orlando, Palm Beach and Davie, Fla., in some cases expanding the guest lists by more than 40 percent from last year, according to Andrea Back, vice president for marketing.
"We have an awful lot to celebrate this year," Ms. Back said, noting that the company surpassed $4 billion in sales for the first time. "And many of our competitors are canceling their events, so this is our time to really shine." The theme was "home for the holidays," she said, and 18-wheeler trucks were commissioned to ship components of a life-size house to each event to serve as decor. Live bands played underneath a fake fireplace, and enormous windows and columns lined each ballroom.
In between feasting on chocolate fondue and made-to-order pasta, guests in floor-length gowns and tuxedos were asked to contribute to Habitat for Humanity, one charity the company supports. "Even though the events are huge, they're very touchy-feely this year," Ms. Back said.
Other companies are putting together holiday festivities with the notion that next year's might not be as glamorous -- or happen at all. In San Diego, one dot-com, an automotive financing start-up, has booked On Broadway, a restaurant that is available for parties, for its holiday get-together for more than 300 employees. The start-up was recently purchased by a larger firm, and company executives fear this might be their final chance to have a party together. 
At the $30,000 event, employees will nibble on shrimp and crab claws and have a chance to win a free trip to Las Vegas. "They're going all out," said Jackie Martinez, director of sales for On Broadway.
Not all employees are leaping at the prospect of holiday gatherings. Last month, Martha Stewart e-mailed 65 employees at her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, asking them to volunteer to be hosts of an intimate holiday gathering in their homes in lieu of the large party the company gave last year, according to one employee who asked not to be identified. She offered each taker $300 to help defray catering costs, but said that the host would not be able to choose who would attend: each would be assigned a guest list of 10 employees, selected at random.
When few people offered to play hosts, Ms. Stewart sent another e-mail message telling employees that "the terrorists have succeeded if so few of you participate."
But the employee said, "She still didn't have many takers." 
Susan Magrino, a spokeswoman, confirmed the account and said the company has since scrapped the idea of the home-based get-togethers and is considering several other options, including a holiday lunch.

After briefly considering canceling its holiday gatherings, the company decided to go ahead with the celebrations to help employee morale. In some cities, it expanded the guest list. (Alan Mothner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK; 
Anxious? Sleepless? In a Survey, Your Mom, Again, Tells You Why

BYLINE:  By LISA BELKIN; This column about the intersection of jobs and personal lives appears every other week. E-mail: Belkin@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
JUST when you were re-evaluating your life-work equation in the context of a changed world, and now that you are worrying that the career you were so proud of might evaporate in this sagging economy, a researcher at the University of Michigan has proof of what you already suspected: your mother thinks you have your priorities out of whack.
 Deborah Carr, a sociologist at the Institute for Social Research, analyzed data on 200 Wisconsin mothers from the class of 1957. She found that while nearly two-thirds say their daughters are more successful in their careers than they were, they also say their daughters are less happy. "The mothers think the daughters are stressed out," she says. "They're juggling work and family, or, even worse from the mother's point of view, they're too busy to get married." 
 Her study quotes Janice, a bank teller whose daughter is a junior high school teacher. "At her age," Janice says, "I was married, I had a house, had a husband. She's single, no boyfriend, she lives in an apartment by herself. I'd say it's better for her to be married, but that's just my opinion."
My own mother has been telling me something like this for years. In the world according to Mom, the ideal timetable for life is to have kids in your 20's, then move full steam into a career when they are grown. In other words, the way she did it.
I have a most unusual mother. She collected two master's degrees and a Ph.D. during those "downtime" years while her three children were young, and she graduated from law school when I graduated from high school. She is emblematic of her generation, however, in that she did things serially, while me and mine are hell-bent on doing it all simultaneously.
One can argue that women plunge into the work force straight from school because they have more challenging options than their mothers did. Dr. Carr found the daughters in her study were better educated than their mothers, and it only makes sense that they are eager to put that education to use.
"If I had gone through all those years of training and didn't use it, I would have thought it was a major waste of time, money and effort," says Karen Allendoerfer, a Princeton graduate who earned a Ph.D. in neurobiology from Stanford University and who is now the mother of a toddler.
Dr. Allendoerfer and I know each other from an Internet news group which spends each day debating and discussing everything about parenting. Lately, the online talk has been about why professional women wait to have children. Some of the most eloquent voices agree with my mother.
"My daughter was born when I was 33," says Sister Smith Amsbary, who earned her master's degree in English at Middlebury and who has put off a Ph.D. while she cares for her 2-year-old full time. "Physiologically, the optimal average age for a woman to have a child is about 25. Nevertheless, these days, most well-educated women I know choose to postpone until their 30's."
Ideally, Dr. Allendoerfer agrees. "Women should be able to have children in their 20's and then go to med/grad/law/vet school in their 30's, rather than the other way around, which is how most of us are currently doing it."
No one, not even Mom, thinks life will go back to the way it was -- and for good reason. The entire feminist movement was about allowing women into professions that require an early start. As careers for women went from exception to expectation, however, we gained most of the benefits of a man's world, and all of the negatives. The working world is built around a male life cycle, and women see themselves with no choice but to cram their own lives into it.
Dr. Allendoerfer, who turns 36 this week, is one of those women. Intellectually, she believes in having children early, even if it means postponing a career. But, she says, "I wasn't brave or enterprising or something enough to try it myself -- not to mention the fact that I hadn't met the person I wanted to have children with."
The reality of her life as a scientist, she says, is that "there's an especially damaging stereotype that scientists do their best work while they're young." The specter of job discrimination alone, she says, is reason to plunge immediately into work.
Which is why we are all feeling stressed. And which is why our mothers are worried about us.
But if it helps at all, there is another message to be found in Dr. Carr's study: your mother is proud of you. And if you'd find a spare moment to return her phone calls, she would probably tell you so.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Randall Enos)

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Seeking a Business Degree, Across the Pond

BYLINE:  By VIVIENNE WALT 

 BODY:
A few years ago, David Pagliaro stumbled into an M.B.A. school fair at the Grand Hyatt New York, skirted past the students mobbing the Harvard and Stanford desks and headed for a stand with no visitors -- the one for the London Business School.
 "I'd never heard of them," he said, "but they were pretty condescending. They said: 'We're one of the best schools in the world and you'd be lucky to get in.' So of course I decided I had to get in." 
 Mr. Pagliaro, 27, graduated from the school last year with a master's degree in business administration and now works as a consultant for the London office of Booz Allen Hamilton.
For years, Europe's top business schools -- the London Business School; Insead in Fontainebleau, France; and the International Institute of Management Development, known as I.M.D., in Lausanne, Switzerland -- maintained a low profile. After all, they had government financing, and more than enough candidates to choose from all across the globe. They saw no need to market themselves aggressively, and people like Mr. Pagliaro stumbled upon them almost by accident.
But that is now changing. The schools, which have minuscule endowments by American standards, are facing a cash squeeze as cost-conscious governments stem the flow of subsidies. So for the first time, they are starting a sustained recruiting effort in a place where they can hope for a long-term financial payback: the United States.
"For Americans, the tradition of alumni donations is very strong, it's a very generous community," said Nick Barniville, marketing manager for Insead, which accepts about 725 M.B.A. candidates a year in two groups. "If we can get the number of American students up, we will also have much better international visibility and be able to attract top-flight faculty." Mr. Barniville has spent several weeks this year promoting Insead in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco and other American cities.
His efforts are paying off, too. The 46 American students entering Insead's M.B.A. program in January are double that of last January, at about 11 percent of the class. Likewise, the proportion of Americans beginning M.B.A.'s at the London school last September was the highest yet, at 18 percent of the class, up from 13 percent a year earlier. At the much smaller I.M.D., American representation has remained about the same, at around 7 percent.
The schools' main draw is the international character of their student bodies and course work, a mix that holds a huge advantage in the global economy but that is largely absent in America's elite institutions. Although all three M.B.A. programs are taught in English, no nationality dominates, not even that of the host country. Only about 10 percent of students at Insead are French, and just 3 of I.M.D.'s 85 students are Swiss; the others come from 35 countries.
There are other big inducements, those interviewed say. Unlike American two-year M.B.A. programs, both Insead and I.M.D. offer intensive one-year courses, trimming students' costs and the time spent building a career. With the average age of students around 30, about five years older than that of most American classes, the length of study is an important consideration.
Now, the renewed interest in business schools among young adults -- prompted by the terrorist attacks, the collapse of the dot-com world and the recession -- is adding to the appeal of foreign schools.
"Since Sept. 11, I've had calls from four people in New York City saying their job had either gone or was threatened, and that they were considering coming to Europe," said Katty Ooms Suter, the M.B.A. admissions director at I.M.D. With sympathy for New Yorkers running high, Ms. Suter waived the Sept. 1 deadline for applications for them.
American students at the European schools say that since Sept. 11, their friends, too, have begun calling to quiz them about Europe. "Most people I've spoken to in America viewed the U.S. as a safe haven," said Jon Koplin, 27, who will complete a one-year M.B.A. at Insead this month. "Now the economy's down and there is terrorism, and they are more open to coming to Europe to work or live."
It is not just the new recruiting effort by the European schools that has raised their visibility in the United States. They got a big boost last year when Business Week magazine's influential M.B.A. rankings listed foreign schools for the first time. The magazine placed Insead top among non-United States business programs, with London Business School second, the University of Navarra's I.E.S.E. graduate school of management in Barcelona third and I.M.D. fourth. 
Other new moves are intended to strengthen American ties. Insead announced an alliance with the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania last May, with exchange programs that will tap directly into American talent; it also opened a Singapore campus this year.
And starting in January, the London school's new dean will be Laura D. Tyson, President Bill Clinton's economic adviser and now dean of the Haas School of Business at the University of California in Berkeley.
But that does not mean the schools are losing the international diversity that sets European schools apart from their American cousins. Philip Rosenzweig, who left his faculty job at Harvard Business School five years ago to teach strategy and international management at I.M.D., says he is still startled by the differences.
"At Harvard, one-third of our students were from abroad -- and half of those had done undergraduate work in the United States -- and we used to say: 'Gee, look how global we are,' " he said. "Here, I walk into class and there are people from all countries in the Middle East, Asia, Latin America, you name it."
For many students, simply living in Europe is seductive enough.
"Here I am sitting looking across Lake Geneva at the Alps," said Garrick Hileman, 28, from Seattle, who joined the M.B.A. program at the International Institute after leaving a high-technology incubator company in San Francisco. "I spend weekends in Italy. I go skiing in Chamonix, France. I mean, this is a little slice of heaven."

(Olivia Gay for The New York Times); (Jonathan Player for The New York Times); (Samer Mohdad for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sydney, the Next Wave 

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia 

 BODY:
JUST as they are in New York, times are tough for restaurateurs in Sydney -- "tougher than tough," as one of the local superchefs said.
 Overexpansion for the Olympic Games last year, followed by the onset of a worldwide economic slowdown and a new sales tax here, followed by the events of Sept. 11, has resulted in the closing of some of the city's best-known restaurants, the scaling back of ambition at others and a sea of empty tables at still others. Clearly, the high-powered Aussie culinary bandwagon has lost some momentum. 
 A famished visitor arriving in Australia for the first time would barely notice, though. Demonstrating conclusively that Sydney's ascent during the last decade into the top ranks of the world's restaurant cities, right up there with Paris, New York and London, was no passing phase, exciting new places are opening and somehow flourishing, or at least surviving, and established stars are rehoning their skills. 
Wockpool, a glass-fronted pan-Asian pleasure palace overlooking Darling Harbor, is no more. Christine Manfield's Paramount, where a dozen or more disparate ingredients cohabited happily if improbably on a dinner plate, has closed, as has David Thompson's pioneering Darley Street Thai.
Things got so slow at MG Garage, home away from home for the hip and well heeled, that the chef and proprietor, Janni Kyritsis, began offering a single dish and a glass of wine at lunch for $15. At that price, he said, "we don't make any money, but at least it makes a joyful restaurant."
Julie Pignolet, an editor whose husband runs Sydney's best bistro, Bistro Moncur, said, "I'm afraid Sydney had too few consumers for too much creativity." 
But what's to fret about when you can tuck into dishes like Mr. Kyritsis's beef steamed in dough made with bone marrow, with a smear of tapenade inside to fight off blandness, or his finely balanced desserts, never too sweet, made with the tropical fruits that come so easily to hand on this fertile continent -- cedar lemons, passion fruit, kumquats and mandarin oranges?
Kylie Kwong, the gifted young chef who helped put Wockpool on the map, is packing them in at Billy Kwong, where the tables are smaller and the decor is plainer but the food is every bit as good. Mr. Thompson, who claims to have learned his trade from "those old biddies in the markets" in Bangkok, has decamped for London, where he now runs the acclaimed restaurant Nahm, but one of his proteges, Martin Boetz, carries the Thai banner high here.
As usual, Neil Perry, the ebullient, pony-tailed butcher's son who defined the New Australian cuisine with dishes like his luscious stir-fried blue swimmer crab omelette, is at the center of the story. Not long ago, he was running not only Rockpool, his flagship, but also Wockpool, Bistro Mars, Cafe Fish, Star Bar & Grill and so many other enterprises that he nearly lost count.
Rockpool was aswarm with customers during the Olympics, serving dinner to 250 people a night in a room that usually accommodates 150. Mr. Perry, a kind of antipodean Wolfgang Puck, cooked until 2 every morning. Well-fed sports writers from around the world mentioned him in dispatches.
"But right afterwards, business started drying up," Mr. Perry, clearly a chastened man, said. "I had 440 people on staff -- 440! I was heavily involved in developing new in-flight meals for Qantas. I could feel myself losing control. The moment had obviously come to clean out."
So Mr. Perry pared his operation to the minimum, selling or closing all the restaurants except Rockpool and concentrating on that, Qantas and (to a lesser degree) a casual new spot called XO, featuring Wockpool-esque dishes like a crispy pork hock with caramel, chili and lime sauce. He himself went back to the stove more or less full time, developing smashing new dishes like a sweetbread tarte Tatin and a tremblingly light custard tart with dates.
The upshot? Australian Gourmet Traveller, the country's leading food magazine, made Rockpool, now a dozen years old, its restaurant of the year for 2001, with this comment: "Since Perry returned to the kitchen of Rockpool we have found again what we loved when it first opened -- a surprising, complex, innovative, always memorable and complete dining experience."
Whew! But it's still true: You can eat badly in Sydney, but only if you work at it. In the best restaurants, like Tetsuya's and Salt, Banc and Claude's and MG Garage, about which I have reported previously, you can eat as well, and with more sheer glee, as almost anywhere.
On our most recent trip to Australia, my wife, Betsey, and I returned to old favorites, of course, but we also scouted some new places. Notes on four of the best of those follow, along with updates about three other places, which, like Rockpool, seemed to us to have raised their already high standards in the last two or three years. There are also a few words on a most unlikely "discovery" -- a delightful cafe in a botanical garden in the Blue Mountains.
This is by no means a definitive list. Local foodie friends told us we had made a mistake by not visiting Marque, whose chef, Mark Best, was trained by Alain Passard at l'Arpege in Paris and by Raymond Blanc near Oxford in the English countryside, to taste his boudin blanc with lentils. We also missed the prawn ravioli, "as seamless as a Savile Row suit," in one critic's view, at Celsius, a downtown restaurant newly opened by Peter Doyle, a veteran at the stove and on a surfboard.
Even we have limits.
VII, at 7 Bridge Street, was created by Eng Joo Ang, a local businessman, and he hired not one but two chefs to get it started: Harunobu Inukai, who worked for Joel Robuchon in Tokyo, and Noriyuki Sugie, who worked for Charlie Trotter in Chicago. The room is formal for Sydney, with iron columns and an exceptionally high pressed-tin ceiling.
Ambitiously conceived, the food is cooked with verve and arranged on the plate with surgical precision. With Premier Bob Carr of New South Wales and his wife, Helena, we ate for three hours, working through 13 dishes, and except for one slightly overcooked vegetable, everything was exquisite.
Highlights: A tiny cucumber "cup," filled with gazpacho, that shattered satisfyingly when I bit into it. A savory steamed custard, topped with bonito jelly, served in a pullet-egg shell. Sweet corn soup with a basil emulsion (the colors!). A seafood hotpot: bouillabaisse with a gingery Asian accent. Marbled beef, with an oxtail-stuffed onion and wasabi-flavored meat jus.
The food gave me goose bumps, and I was not exactly indifferent to the wines (a juicy 1996 Bannockburn SRH chardonnay from Victoria and a 1993 Paringa Estate pinot noir from the same state, which tasted like Mom's cherry pie).
Kylie Kwong's name sums up the new Australia. It's an Australian- Chinese hybrid, just like her cooking. I would eat in her little kingdom, BILLY KWONG, once a week, I swear, if it weren't a 20-hour flight away. You sit elbow-to-elbow on Aalto-style stools, beneath a big Noguchi-style light fixture, with a very urban, very happy, very noisy crowd that has stood in line to get in. You buy your wine, if you want any, at the carryout across the street.
All of which I usually hate, grouch that I am, but not here.
We left it to Ms. Kwong, a smile-wreathed 32-year-old, to order our dinner. Six of us polished off dish after dish, each delivered rat-tat-tat to our table as soon as we had finished its predecessor: a tart and refreshing tofu salad with rice wine, pickled vegetables and black fungus; steamed oysters with a dipping sauce of ginger, shallots and nuoc mam; steamed prawn wontons with chili oil and black vinegar; chive crepes with a delightfully complex caramelized eggplant salad; fillets of King George whiting -- my favorite Australian fish, always dependably firm, never soggy -- steamed to an ethereal turn.
It was enough to make me swear off meat, but that might have denied me the crisp-skinned duck, served with a sauce made from ruby grapefruit. So I chowed on, agreeing at every bite with my friend Bruce Wolpe across the table, who had warned us when we arrived, "You come here to eat, not to dine."
The bill was $50 Australian a head (or $26 American). It would have been a bargain at $50 American.
Acoustics at LONGRAIN can be terrible -- it opened 18 months ago in an old industrial building filled with hard edges -- but that's the only complaint I have. Service by youngsters in gray shirts and black trousers (still colors of choice in Sydney) is knowing and gentle; the long, 16-person communal tables are perfect for sampling what your neighbor ordered, and Martin Boetz's cooking is agreeably light, with more sour and vegetal flavors and fewer fiery and fishy ones than Mr. Thompson's.
Eggnets are the chef's showpiece -- webs of fast-fried egg, wrapped around pork, prawns, peanuts and sprouts, dabbed with sweet vinegar. Yummy. The green chicken curry with green beans, kaffir lime leaves and lime-size sour "pea" eggplants, served on rice noodles, also had that exquisite balance among hot, sour, sweet and salty tastes that marks great Asian food.
Everything is irresistibly fresh, even the braised shin of beef with red chili and bunches of coriander and mint. Sam Christie's short, keenly priced list of rieslings and semillons harmonizes well. If you finish with coconut ice cream and bananas roasted over coals -- sweet, smoky, the very essence of bananahood -- you will leave, as we did, with a clean palate and a spring in your step.
Sydney's greatest joy is its many-armed harbor, and OTTO takes advantage of it like no other restaurant. Otto is built on a pier in the resoundingly named neighborhood of Wolloomooloo. Makes SoHo sound a bit tame, doesn't it? Most of the year, the weather is warm enough to sit outdoors in Philippe Starck chairs, take in the skyline, gawk at the stars and smell the salt breezes. (We were there in August, equal to our February, and it was fine.)
The place is named after the Italian word for "eight," not for Otto Kahn or Otto Preminger or some other worthy. Maurizio Terzini is a maitre d' of textbook silkiness, but the waiters, who look like models for Dolce & Gabbana, push too hard and know too little.
As for the food, it just missed. A fine fritto misto was marred by excessively large chunks of vegetables; too much blood orange obscured the sweet delicacy of beautifully seared sea scallops. But a thinly cut, quickly grilled steak with plenty of lemon juice hit the spot, as did a pear poached in Campari and grenadine, served with mascarpone. We loved the discreet note on the menu: "Please call to book our berth when you are arriving by boat."
Two things, both good, have happened to TETSUYA'S, the most innovative of Sydney's restaurants. It has moved from a humdrum, 1,000-square-foot building in the outer suburbs to a 21,000-square-foot building downtown, where indoor waterfalls and rock gardens evoke the mood of dinner in the Ginza.
Except it's better. You can always tell when Tetsuya Wakada's oysters are coming; the briny scent hits your nostrils before you see them. You sense his innovative gifts, rooted in Asia, when you taste his confit of Tasmanian ocean trout, moist, sweet, delicate, accented by its own roe and by salsify. A leg of lamb, slow-roasted for six hours, shows his mastery of the classical European idiom; so does a floating island that floats right off the plate.
When I first ate Tets's food, I was bowled over, but I thought it a bit overwrought, like that of his chum Charlie Trotter. This time it was simpler, stripped of excess gestures, but still elegant, still delectable.
Serge Dansereau had just got started when we first visited the BATHERS' PAVILION, a restored Art Deco bathhouse on Balmoral Beach. Now he has hit his stride. There can't be many places on this planet better for a jolly Sunday lunch on a sunny day, as a rowdy bunch of us found. We ate nothing but seafood, all first class, especially a tuna, scallop and cuttlefish sashimi with sea urchin sauce -- tip-top ingredients enlivened by a clever idea.
"Your average ocean shark hasn't eaten as much fish or had as much fun as I have today," said our old pal Tony Clifton of Newsweek magazine. 
Lunch or dinner, no matter what the weather is, Damien Pignolet's BISTRO MONCUR is a lively, civilized urban rendezvous. Along with down-home French classics like house-made Lyonnaise pork sausages, Provencal fish soup and duck braised with green olives, all immaculately realized, the menu always lists a few modern items, like seared tuna with gnocchi, beets and anchovies. The sirloin steaks come with that vintage treat, Cafe de Paris butter. 
Bistro Moncur has been a Sydney institution since it opened, and it keeps improving, without losing its personality. Like Allard in Paris, the ur-bistro of my salad days, it proves that fancier is not always better.
The MOUNT TOMAH BOTANICAL GARDEN, 65 miles west of Sydney, 3,000 feet up in the Blue Mountains, is a paradise of cool-climate flowers. The proteas are world famous. But I had a lot of trouble keeping my mind on horticulture after lunch in John and Lidia Henriksen's restaurant overlooking them.
Fearing tea-room banality, we sat down instead to plump grilled langoustines, their sweet flavor punched up with lemon juice, butter, basil and garlic, and a gutsy Balinese-style pork curry, rich with turmeric, lemon grass and palm sugar. Who knew? We should have. Lucky Sydneysiders have grown accustomed to finding vividly flavored food wherever they wander, even in a garden.
First of four reports from Sydney and the west.

HEADLINE: In a Stressed City, No Room at the Bar 

BYLINE:  By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
THEY were three deep at Guastavino's bar last Thursday night, downing flirtinis, cucumber martinis and patriots, a red, white and blue martini suitable for the times. Bartenders kept up a steady beat -- mix, mix, mix -- while waiters rushed to deliver trays of frothy daiquiris and coffee martinis. 
 It wasn't unusual. 
 Almost three months after the terrorist attacks, New Yorkers are drinking more than ever. Even as restaurants struggle with empty seats and fewer diners willing to pay high tabs, liquor sales are climbing at bars, restaurants and some liquor stores throughout the city.
At a few places -- a diverse list including Pravda, the Regency Hotel and McSorley's -- liquor sales were 25 percent higher last month than they were in November 2000. And as the holiday season gets into full swing, the numbers are bound to increase. 
"People who were drinking three drinks are now having four or five," said Richard Schertzer, a senior bartender at Pastis, the brasserie in the meatpacking district. "They are drinking more martinis and fancy cocktails than before, even late at night, at 1 or 2 in the morning."
"The mood is different," he added. "Once people get out and see a few smiling faces around, they take it as a nice escape and use it to have a bit more fun."
Whether people are drinking to relieve anxiety and stress, as psychiatrists believe, or because they want to socialize more and drinking is part of that, all over town bars are fuller and livelier. There's more hard liquor and less high-end wine; more big groups and fewer singles. People are staying later, locked in late-night conversation rather than giddy revelry.
The dramatic rise in consumption of alcoholic beverages immediately after Sept. 11 was a nationwide phenomenon, liquor distributors and others in the business say. But nowhere was it more evident than in New York. After the first couple of weeks, there was a significant drop -- until last month, when business came back, with a vengeance. Not only was it up in Manhattan and in some of the boroughs but also in nearby Long Island and Connecticut suburbs. 
Discus, the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, plans to release national consumption figures next year. But ACNeilsen, which also tracks national retail sales of wine and spirits, reports that the sales volume of alcoholic beverages has been up every week since Sept. 11 compared with last year. For the week ending Nov. 3, the most recent figure available, volume rose 4.2 percent.
"At first, people felt a little uneasy and didn't want to appear to be celebrating -- now I think there is a certain nervous fatigue that propels people," said Kurt Eckert, the wine director for Jean-Georges Vongerichten's five New York restaurants, where liquor sales were up 3 to 4 percent. "People are a bit relieved, but the recent plane crash, anthrax in addition, have left people a bit shaken. There has been a drop in the number of people dining, but they are ordering more wine."
At Guastavino, business in the restaurant is down, but business at the bar last month was up 10 percent compared with a year ago. The restaurant is staying open later on weekends and has installed a disc jockey. At McSorley's, where the average customer drinks 8 to 10 glasses of ale, business has picked up substantially in the afternoons, according to Matthew Maher, the owner.
"If you walk into Smith & Wollensky, you think it's a great night because you can't get near the bar," said Alan Stillman, chairman of the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, "but the restaurant is not full. More liquor is being consumed by fewer people."
And at many places, the cast of characters is quite different. Guastavino, for example, was long known as one of the best pickup spots in town. Since Sept. 11, the revelers have been coming in groups of three or five, even eight, eager to be with their friends. 
Like Karla Koontz, 27, who is unemployed. "I think I'm hanging out more because I want the company," she said. "It's not so much partying at clubs late, it's more good conversation."
Many, who at first laughed nervously when asked if they were drinking more, and wanted to make certain no one thought they were drinking too much, eventually acknowledged that their consumption had increased, if only because they were going out more. For a lot of people -- even 20- and 30-somethings, who in the past thought they were immortal -- Sept. 11 was an awakening. 
"I used to be health-conscious," said Mark Booker, a 36-year-old real estate investor, sitting at a table in the Pastis bar. "I used to work out; now I don't give a damn. I used to go out twice a month; now I go out twice a week. It's friends coming together to embrace each other. And the reason I am drinking more is because I'm out more."
Sitting with two friends at Guastavino's bar, Marty Majchrowicz, 33, the president of a medical education company in New York, said he was spending a lot more time with friends. "I'm feeling less inhibited and feeling less guilty about going out and drinking," he said. "I'm feeling an obligation to spend more money in the city. I'm eating out more often, about four nights a week, and drinking more cocktails, two or three."
Others say they are drinking to relieve stress. "Boy, are you at the right table," said Esther Gweft, 51, a lawyer who does public relations for Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. "I'm a two-glass-of-wine person at home, but now it's three, three and a half glasses. My staff is stressed. Everything makes them anxious because of 9/11. I have two kids, and my son got very anxious. You get stressed trying to keep everyone else cheerful."
At the Regency Hotel, "people are coming at 5 o'clock and staying all evening," said Clark Wolf, a consultant to the hotel. "Since Oct. 1, sales have been hard core: cocktails, manhattans, bottles of wine, vodka on the rocks and martinis -- no flavored martinis, just the real stuff."
At Excelsior, a bar in Brooklyn, "people are definitely drinking more," said Richard Kennedy, the owner. "Our figures are up 8 percent over last year."
Jean-Claude Baker, the owner of Chez Josephine, is stunned that his bar business is up 25 percent over last year. "The past two months have been the best ever in 15 years," he said.
Retail sales in New York are less uniform. Michael Aaron, chairman of Sherry-Lehmann, the East Side wine merchant, said that even though sales in September were down 25 percent from last year, and in October were down 20 percent, they were up 15 percent in November. And he said he was selling much more expensive wines than a year ago, which flies in the face of what is happening in restaurants. 
At Acker, Merrall & Condit, a West Side merchant, the number of people buying wine and spirits is up 15 percent for October and November. But at Gotham Wines and Liquors business is flat, and at Garnet Wines and Liquors, Marty Laufer, an assistant sales manager, said: "It definitely is not what it was last November -- we are seeing more hard liquor but not so much high-end wine."
Based on interviews with alcoholic beverage distributors who sell to markets around the country, the picture is mixed elsewhere. The overall impression is that the precipitous drop in sales in New York immediately after Sept. 11 was felt in a few cities, particularly those dependent on tourists and business travelers, but that those places have rebounded and that business has remained strong elsewhere. 
Kerri Madigan, president of Rosenthal Wine Merchant, said business was very good in November. "Retail and restaurants finished off very strongly compared to last year in New York. The East Coast was way ahead of last year, up about 15 percent on both coasts. The middle of the country stayed very strong."
And some distributors have noted that in places where restaurant and bar sales are off, sales at retail stores are up.
Lee Schrager, director of media for Southern Wine and Spirits in Miami, the largest distributor in the world, said he did not think Sept. 11 had as much impact on the rest of the country as it did in New York.
It is hardly surprising. New Yorkers have been through a lot. 
For certain people, like recovering alcoholics, the problem can be very serious. Joseph Califano, president of the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, is worried about them. "With a more traumatic and intense tragedy than Oklahoma City, I am concerned that we will have a greater increase in alcohol abuse in New York than was experienced in Oklahoma City," he said. "And that was substantial."
People do a variety of things to ease discomfort, said James Bernard, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in New York. "Drinking or self-medicating is just one of the behaviors," he said. "One of the central ingredients in people I've seen is a feeling of helplessness, which is one of most intolerable feelings for most people."
Dr. Gail Saltz, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who is chairman of public information for the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, said she had seen a definite increase in alcohol use in her patients. "People aren't often aware when they self-medicate for anxiety," she said. "They are also using it because they can't sleep, and the reason they can't sleep is anxiety."
At Pastis, Chris Horn, 43, a casting director, ordered a second bottle of wine while the first was still half full. He said he was definitely consuming more these days.
"When you sit down to relax and start talking, you don't realize it," he said. "Usually we have one and a half bottles. A year ago, it was one bottle."

HEADLINE: U.S. Students Are Middling On Test Given In 32 Nations 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
An examination measuring practical knowledge in math, science and reading among students in 32 industrialized nations shows that those in Canada, Finland and New Zealand lead the world in all three categories, with American students performing at only average levels.
 The exam, administered to a quarter-million 15-year-olds by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, measured reading, science and math skills with questions that approximated real-life situations. It was meant to gauge the ability of students to operate in the world as they neared the end of their time in elementary and secondary school. 
 As in reading exams administered nationally and in earlier international tests in mathematics, American students as a whole performed unspectacularly. Of the 28 O.E.C.D. member nations that took part in the testing -- 4 participants were not members of the organization -- only Greece, Portugal, Luxembourg and Mexico performed significantly worse than the United States in science. And only those countries plusItaly did substantially worse in math.
The United States education secretary, Rod Paige, said he was disappointed that American students had not stood out. "In the global economy," Dr. Paige said, "these countries are our competitors. Average is not good enough for American kids."
An analysis of the test results by the Paris-based organization showed that at least in reading, as many American students performed in the top percentiles as did students in the highest-performing countries. The problem was that there were also large numbers of American students who read in the lowest percentiles. Barry McGaw, the organization's deputy director for education, said these results suggested that the United States could improve its standing by directing help at its lowest-performing students. 
Dr. McGaw added that although educators had long debated whether schools could succeed despite instability or poverty in a child's home, the report accompanying the test results showed that some countries, like Finland, had done well at educating students of all backgrounds; poor home conditions in other nations, including the United States and Germany, pose a greater obstacle to student achievement, he said. 
The report also showed a variety of differences in performance by sex. In every nation, girls did significantly better than boys in reading. In half the countries, boys did much better than girls in math, a subject in which girls did not perform significantly better anywhere. In science, boys did much better than girls in three countries, although girls in New Zealand performed significantly better than boys there.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Commerce Comes Calling In the Park

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS

DATELINE: PLAINFIELD, N.J. 

 BODY:
IT may have lawns, benches, winding pathways and frolicking children, but whatever you do, don't call the four-acre greensward in downtown Plainfield a park.
 A municipal sign anointing it Roberto Clemente Memorial Park has been removed. To clear up lingering confusion, city officials recently dismantled the Victorian gazebo that once graced its center. 
 Set in the heart of this bedraggled city, the Park-Madison site, as officials prefer to call it, may soon sprout a four-story complex of stores, county offices and parking. The deal will earn Plainfield $1 million and inject desperately needed life into a city that has been floundering since the late 1960's, when school busing and race riots fueled the familiar scourge of white flight and economic decline. 
There is only one problem. Under state law, any land that has been used as a park must remain a park. Of course, there are loopholes. Municipalities can claim that bureaucrats mistakenly designated a space as parkland. Even though Plainfield spent $300,000 in federal money making the place look more like a park, and despite the fact that dozens of permits are given out for carnivals and community fund-raisers -- officials are saying that the Park-Madison site was never a park.
"It was a clerical error," said Dan Damon, a spokesman for the city, which has a population of 48,000, explaining why the plot was placed on a New Jersey open spaces inventory. Although state officials insist on calling it a park, the site's future rests with Robert C. Shinn, New Jersey's commissioner of environmental protection, who is expected to decide in the coming weeks.
The land, which was cleared 35 years ago, was originally part of a federal urban renewal project that died when financing evaporated. Mayor Albert T. McWilliams said the improvements, which started a decade ago, were meant only to turn an embarrassing eyesore into a temporary urban amenity. "To us, that land has always been a symbol of Plainfield's inability to progress," Mr. McWilliams said. "The only reason we put grass there was to keep the dirt from blowing all over the place."
TELL that to Myrna Rivera, 32, an office cleaner from Ecuador, who was taking her 2-year-old daughter, Vivian, for a stroll on a recent warm afternoon. "We love this place," she said. "We would be very sad if they took it away."
Although Plainfield's growing Hispanic population stands to lose a cherished swath of greenery, it is the city's wealthier residents who are battling the backhoes. In a city that is 83 percent minority, Plainfield officials privately say that that the most vociferous proponents of keeping the site green are white. Mr. Damon calls them "the newcomers."
Deborah Dahl, a consultant to nonprofit organizations, has been leading the charge. She believes that Plainfield is making a grave error by paving over what they call the village green. "The health and economic vitality of a town is shaped by its center," said Ms. Dahl, who bought two rambling mansions here two years ago and is converting one into corporate apartments. "When potential home buyers or employers come here, the first thing they see is this beautiful open green. It says: 'This is great place for children. This is our soul.' "
The debate, tinged by talk of racism and underhanded politics, has become rancorous. Ms. Dahl says the city tried to secretly push the project through the approvals process. Mr. Damon accuses her of spinning lies. Others complain that the project, anchored by social services, is less than ideal. Downtown, they point out, is littered with empty buildings begging for revitalization.
"The city has no foresight," said Murray Roberts, who moved here in 1968, when most middle-class residents were fleeing. "To me it sounds like a political deal, the perfect place for patronage. If they really want to develop downtown, they should improve the park and then enhance the area."
At its core, the dispute is a clash between visions of how to revive a wounded city. Ms. Dahl said the future of Plainfield, blessed with one of the country's largest collection of Victorian architecture, lies in drawing affluent homesteaders, people much like herself. 
But Mr. McWilliams believes the elixir for Plainfield's woes are lower property taxes, a feat that can only be achieved by luring more commerce. Sure, downtown is littered with empty buildings, he says, but so far, no one is clamoring to buy them.
"These people are just sitting on the sidelines saying, 'Do this, do that,' " he said. "But bring me an interested developer and I'll be happy to listen."
