HEADLINE: The Latest Blow to Buffalo: A Layoff of Hundreds at Schools 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Dec. 2 

 BODY:
Diana Seifert wants to stay in Buffalo even though, by her count, she has lost five jobs in the past eight years because of layoffs in the health care field. So this year, she began teaching in the city's public school system because she loved children and heard that there was a shortage of good teachers.
 But now, Mrs. Seifert is out of a job for the sixth time. 
 "It's heartbreaking," Mrs. Seifert, 41, said Friday afternoon as she tearfully hugged her students at the Waterfront Elementary School. "I told them that I'm not sick, I'm not dying, but you know, they don't understand. It's hard for me to understand how it could reach such a drastic point." 
The Buffalo school district is expected to lay off 557 of its 7,000 employees -- including 433 teachers -- this month in a desperate effort to reduce a $28 million shortfall in its current budget. The widespread job cuts in the state's second-largest school district have led to demonstrations by hundreds of students, parents and teachers in the past two weeks, and forced most of the 78 schools to increase class sizes and eliminate programs mid-year.
"This is the worst disaster we've ever had in this school district," said Marion Canedo, the Buffalo superintendent. "I'm just sick about it. There isn't a school that isn't affected."
The school layoffs are the latest setback for a historic waterfront city of nearly 300,000 that is engulfed in its worst financial crisis in years. Long accustomed to last-minute infusions of state aid, school and city officials here say they were caught by surprise in October when their request for an additional $54 million -- $31 million for the city and $23 million for the schools -- was turned down by state political leaders. 
By then, the anticipated money had already been counted and spent in Buffalo. The school district and city government have separate budgets, and separate operations, though they share revenue from city taxes and fees. The school district does not have separate taxing authority.
School and city officials say the drawn-out state budget process forced them to use estimates of state aid -- rather than actual amounts -- to pass their own budgets on time, and then the Sept. 11 terrorist attack in New York City changed everything because it caused a steep drop in state revenues that would have normally been used to help struggling cities.
"In Buffalo, 450 miles away from the scene, we're being very negatively impacted," said Mayor Anthony M. Masiello, a Democrat and the city's chief lobbyist in Albany. "Traditionally, we always get close to what we ask for. We would have made it work without the pain we're in now."
City officials laid off 75 workers last month, and are considering layoffs of police officers and firefighters, among others, as part of a financial recovery plan to be released later this month. The mayor said he might propose selling off city assets, combining some city and county services, and transferring parks, baseball stadiums, art galleries and theaters to the county's control.
But many longtime city residents and others say that Buffalo had chronic financial problems long before the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, and that the steady flow of state money had only propped up a sprawling, inefficient government. 
"The city was never doing fine," said Joseph Bernat, 54, a dentist who moved to Buffalo in 1964. "It's very inefficient with a lot of bloated services, and a lot of union-driven contracts that are too expensive for a city of our size."
Joel A. Giambra, a Republican who is the Erie County executive, said he had been advocating a leaner city government since serving as the city comptroller in the mid-1990's. "It's easy to blame the state," he said. "But crisis breeds opportunity, and this is the tough love that this community has needed."
Though cities and towns across New York are struggling with less state aid than expected, things are particularly bad in Buffalo because it has become so dependent on the state's largesse in recent years. The city and its suburbs in Erie County are considered a key swing district in statewide elections, and have benefited from the patronage of powerful state leaders, including Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
For instance, in a recent report about Buffalo's financial problems, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall noted that state aid to the city government had increased 76 percent to $102 million in 2000-2001 from $58 million in 1995-1996, even as revenue from the city's property taxes shrunk to $141 million from $148 million because of the declining population and eroding tax base.
Mr. Masiello said he had been disappointed that state political leaders had not come through with more state aid for Buffalo during its current crisis. "These people have helped us in the past, and we appreciate it, but now all of a sudden to walk away from the problem and leave it in our laps is unconscionable."
Suzanne Morris, a spokeswoman for the governor, said Mr. Pataki had acted last week to speed up the release of $48.6 million in previously approved state aid for Buffalo to ease its cash flow problems. "Keeping in mind that in the wake of Sept. 11, the state is facing major fiscal challenges, including a projected $9 billion shortfall in revenue," she said, "we will continue to look for additional ways to help."
But no new state money is expected for Buffalo, at least for now, state political leaders say. "I think all local governments need to be aware that the downturn in the state's economy is going to have consequences for them," said State Assemblyman Paul A. Tokasz, a Democrat who represents part of Buffalo and is the majority leader in the assembly. 
The reality of less state aid has shocked the Buffalo school district, where state money has come to pay for nearly three-quarters of its operations. According to State Education Department figures for 1999-2000, 73 percent of the district's budget came from state revenue sources, compared with 66 percent in Syracuse, 62 percent in Rochester and 44 percent in New York City.
Ms. Canedo, the superintendent, said that her schools simply did not receive enough from city taxes to make up the shortfall in expected state aid this year. "It's not like we're being foolish and putting all our eggs in one basket," she said. "But where else do we get the money from?"
The school district has slashed spending on equipment and supplies, and may have to close three or four schools next year. The single biggest savings -- the layoffs -- will shave only $18 million from the district's $28 million budget gap. (The district also had to offset more than $5 million in unplanned expenses for charter schools after a larger number of students enrolled than expected).
The school layoffs have united city and school officials, union leaders, teachers, parents and students in a massive campaign to lobby for more federal and state aid. They have flooded state politicians with angry letters and staged rallies almost daily across the city. Hundreds of students have walked out of their classrooms in protest.
For teachers like Tina Paoliello, the layoffs have been devastating. Ms. Paoliello, 28, spent four years teaching in Charlotte, N.C., so that she would have enough experience to get hired back home in Buffalo. She worked at the Waterfront Elementary School for just three months before being laid off on Friday.
"My goals are just squashed," she said. "I wanted to buy a little house, and that's not going to happen for a while. Everything's on hold. I feel real helpless, I don't know what to do."
At the same school, Mrs. Seifert was packing up what was left of her classroom on Friday afternoon. Her chalkboard had been washed clean, her posters taken off the walls, and all 19 of her students reassigned to other classes. Even the tables and chairs were being rolled away.
"I really wanted to teach in the city, even though I grew up in the suburbs," she said wistfully. "Because I felt the city needed good teachers. I don't have any regrets because it was a wonderful experience."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Technology Issues Give Equities Enough Legs to Climb

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Strength in the technology sector sent stocks soaring yesterday in a rally that gave investors hope the market's post-Sept. 11 advance still had momentum.
 The Dow Jones industrial average had a triple-digit advance, as buying gained intensity late in the session. 
 But analysts were skeptical that the market was beginning another extended run upward and noted that there were only a few signs that business and the economy were stabilizing. 
The Dow closed up 129.88 points, or 1.3 percent, at 9,893.84. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 58.20 points, or 3.1 percent, at 1,963.10. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 14.90 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,144.80.
"I'm not seeing any news today that is specifically causing this, but it looks like investors are anticipating better times ahead and saying that we better own stocks because the tide is getting ready to turn," said Bill Barker, an investment strategy consultant with RBC Dain Rauscher.
"It also could be seasonality. December historically is a pretty good month for the market, and we usually do get a year-end rally," he said.
The market also got a lift from comments by President Bush, who, speaking in Florida, demanded action from Congress on an economic stimulus package.
Cisco Systems rose 66 cents, to $20.52, after its chief executive told analysts that orders met expectations in November, although he also implied that the company's outlook had not changed.
Enron rose 47 cents, or 118 percent, to 87 cents, on speculation that up to $1.5 billion in new financing from J. P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup would help rescue the energy company, which filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday.
J. P. Morgan Chase gained 67 cents, to $37.22, while Citigroup advanced 92 cents, to $47.83.
 --------------------

Treasuries Are Higher
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as investors said they expected the employment data on Friday may show that the jobless rate rose to a five-and-a-half-year high in November.
A surge in the unemployment rate would bolster expectations the Federal Reserve would follow an expected interest rate cut next week with another in January. 
The 10-year Treasury note rose 9/32, to a price of 102 21/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.66 percent from 4.69 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond climbed 20/32, to 102 18/32. The bond's yield declined to 5.20 percent from 5.24 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Whitman Says PCB Dredging Will Proceed 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
The federal Environmental Protection Agency's administrator, Christie Whitman, said yesterday that the agency would move forward with a nearly $500 million dredging plan to remove PCB pollution from the upper Hudson River. In doing so, the agency rejected General Electric's efforts to scale back the cleanup.
 The E.P.A. plan, which would be one of the largest and most complex environmental cleanup projects in the nation's history, is essentially identical to the government's initial proposal, issued in August. Environmentalists said the decision to stay the course was a major victory. 
 It comes at a time of deep economic and political uncertainty, and without being complicated by new technical requirements that many experts said could have delayed or derailed the project.
"This is everything we were hoping for," said Ned Sullivan, the president of Scenic Hudson, a conservation group that has pushed for the river's cleanup for decades.
General Electric, which is largely responsible for the PCB's, which were spilled from its electrical component plants north of Albany, has argued that dredging is an environmental risk in itself. In a huge advertising and lobbying campaign, the company contended that PCB's now buried in the river's mud could be "resuspended" by dredging, thereby released to pollute the river all over again.
Ms. Whitman said in a statement that questions related to resuspension, along with other details about the work, would be addressed in the final project plan, but that they would be explored in a public process simultaneous with the design phase, and would therefore not slow down the project.
"We are going ahead," she said. "We will do so with a continuing open process."
A spokesman for G.E., Mark L. Behan, said the plan had not yet been forwarded to the company and that until G.E. officials had an opportunity to read it thoroughly, they would not comment.
One of the leading opponents of dredging in Congress, Representative John Sweeney, a Republican who represents the upper Hudson region, said that while he still does not like the plan, the E.P.A.'s promise to keep the public involved could go a long way toward avoiding what he called a "big-dig mess."
"This means my constituents will have their views and concerns considered central, and until now they've been neglected," he said.
G.E. used PCB's -- polychlorinated biphenyls, oily yellow insulating material -- for more than 30 years at its factories in Hudson Falls and Fort Edward, N.Y., until the manufacturing and use of the chemicals were banned in 1977. During the time PCB's were used at the plants, an estimated one million pounds or more of the toxic material, which can accumulate in the tissues of fish and has been linked to cancer risk in humans, leaked or was dumped into the river, some of it under state permits.
The cleanup plan, which focuses on a 40-mile stretch of the river between the Troy Dam and the Thompson Island Pool, near Schuylerville, would dredge about 2.65 million cubic yards of river bottom in an effort to remove 150,000 pounds of PCB's.
Much of the pollution, environmental experts say, was dispersed broadly into the environment and cannot be recovered, however.
Environmentalists also caution that simply ordering the cleanup of the river still leaves many questions. The project's design phase alone is expected to take up to three years. During that time, issues including what type of dredging technology should be used and what kind of methods should be employed to prevent resuspension of PCB's will have to be worked out.
Plants to remove water from the dredged mud will also have to be built. And the dredging itself could take five years or more.
The work is being conceived as a two-phase project, with a public report and evaluation to be made after the first phase of dredging is complete. Environmentalists say that one of the issues to watch will be how much dredging is contemplated in each phase, since a break could alter or delay the rest of the work.
"We're all going to need to be really vigilant," said Katherine Kennedy, a senior attorney at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a New York-based conservation group. She praised Gov. George E. Pataki for his support for the dredging plan, but said that continued attention and support by the state, through the years to come, will be crucial.

HEADLINE: Honda Opens a U.S. Factory and a Front Against the Big 3 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: LINCOLN, Ala., Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Top executives of Honda Motor criticized the Big Three today for what they view as a double standard on fuel economy. The executives said that domestic manufacturers were not willing to face the environmental implications of becoming increasingly reliant on sales of pickups and sport utility vehicles.
 "Business and some social obligation have to be equally applied to the whole company," said Koichi Amemiya, chief executive of Honda's American operations, who was in Alabama to open a minivan assembly plant. 
 "They're getting a big profit," from truck sales, he added, referring to the Big Three. "That's why they're shifting more to light trucks. Then, it comes to fuel economy, and they say 'we're a truck manufacturer, and it's not fair.' " 
On Thursday, the Senate Commerce Committee will hold a hearing on fuel economy standards, the first significant policy debate on automotive fuel economy since the Sept. 11 attacks. Congress has not significantly increased fuel economy requirements since the 1980's. Environmental groups would like to see standards for pickups and sport utilities increased.
There is some concern among officials at Honda and other foreign manufacturers that if regulators set any change to fuel economy standards -- a considerable if -- the Big Three would lobby for an across-the-board increase in mileage of, say, 5 or 10 percent, rather than a goal to reach specific mileage targets.
A percentage goal would hurt Toyota Motor and Honda, because they already have fleets with higher average gas mileage. Hiroyuki Yoshino, the president of Hondo, said, "What I'd like to have is fair treatment." He added that a percentage-improvement requirement for a company already ahead in fuel economy would be unfair.
It has been one of the best years ever for automobile sales -- despite the recession. Sales have been driven by a wave of interest-free financing deals offered by the Big Three since Sept. 11. It is also expected to be the best year for sales of sport utilities, despite violence in the Middle East and renewed debate about American fuel consumption.
"Americans are always, the bigger the better," Mr. Yoshino said. "For Japan and Europe, sometimes it's the smaller the better." Mr. Yoshino said many fuel economy goals would not be as difficult to reach as competitors had implied.
"Twenty or 30 years ago, there was already the idea of air bags, but most people thought it was unfeasible," Mr. Yoshino said. But today, he pointed out, they are everywhere.
Most automakers expect that a device called a fuel cell will eventually supplant the internal combustion engine and be a silver bullet solution to oil consumption. A fuel cell generates electric power by separating hydrogen electrons from protons, using the electrons to create a current and then recombining them with protons and oxygen. Fuel-cell-powered vehicles, ideally, emit only water.
While most automakers have prototypes of such vehicles, they are still at least a decade, and possibly much longer, away from mass production. Until then, Toyota and Honda have taken aggressive intermediate steps, for example selling small numbers of hybrid gasoline- and electric-powered cars. Next year, Honda plans to introduce a hybrid version of its popular Civic.
Ford Motor and General Motors have said they will produce hybrid vehicles of their own, but gas consumption will remain hard to improve so long as large vehicles increase in popularity, and as foreign makers crowd the market. Next year, Honda plans to roll out a new S.U.V. that will be a sister version of its Acura MDX.
Honda's larger vehicles do tend to be more efficient than the Big Three's. Honda's light trucks averaged 24.9 miles a gallon in model year 2001, according to a projection from the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental group. Each of the Big Three's truck fleets averaged from 20.5 to 20.7 m.p.g. by comparison, while Toyota was 22.1 m.p.g.
Strong auto sales have not helped profitability for the Big Three, because they are propelled by costly incentives. While G.M. is expected to report a profit, Ford and Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, are expected to report losses this year.
Sales at Honda have remained strong even though it has not offered interest-free financing deals.
That has been a boon to Alabama. Today, Honda said that it would increase its projected annual pace of production for the Lincoln plant to 150,000 Odyssey minivans next year, from 120,000. It also intends to hire 2,300 workers, up from 1,500. And, it was cheered by its new workers at a time when unemployment is rising and the Big Three are talking about closing plants.
Phillip Sherrell, 39, left a job making cabinets in nearby Birmingham to take a job in August casting cylinder heads for the Odyssey. "The plant, right now, they can't produce enough," he said.

HEADLINE: Debate at Harvard Asks If Its A's Are Too Cheap 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 3 

 BODY:
When Yann Kumin, a sophomore at Harvard, received a B on a recent 10-page term paper, he felt that he did not deserve that good a grade. Mr. Kumin, 19, said he had spent little time on the assignment, which he submitted in one of the core courses that is required of all Harvard undergraduates.
 "I know I can do minimal work in some classes and get good grades," said Mr. Kumin, a history major, as he dragged on a cigarette outside the university's main library. "I think there's an attitude at Harvard that you've gotten in, and that it's tough to get in, and so you're going to get an easier time once you're here, almost as a reward. Kids take advantage of that attitude." 
 Thoughts like Mr. Kumin's are getting a more public airing these days as the Harvard campus engages in a broad debate over what a grade of A, B, C or D should mean at perhaps the nation's most elite and influential private college. 
The discussions were stoked most recently by a report issued late last month by the dean of the faculty of arts and sciences that disclosed a striking statistic: about half of the grades awarded in recent years to Harvard undergraduates were either A's or A-'s, a sizable increase from a generation ago. 
The debate over how many A's are too many is being closely monitored at other colleges grappling with so-called grade inflation, as well as at the graduate schools and corporations that must make sense of such homogeneous transcripts. 
On one side of the discussion are those professors who believe that Harvard has cheapened what it means to receive an A or an honors degree and has made little effort to distinguish good work from excellent work from great work. 
Harvey C. Mansfield, a longtime professor of government who specializes in political philosophy, said he believed that his colleagues were awarding so many A's because they feared discouraging students who had been accustomed to getting A's all their lives. Professor Mansfield, whose middle initial has been rechristened "C-" by critics, believes that no more than 10 percent of the students in his classes should receive an A or A-, regardless of the relative quality of students.
"If we're giving students the same grades they got in high school, we're saying that Harvard is no better than high school," said Professor Mansfield, who received a bachelor's degree from Harvard in 1953 and has been teaching here since 1962. "But these students aren't in high school anymore. They're in the big leagues. They should have to compete with each other."
He has also injected a racial component into the discussion by contending that white professors tend to avoid giving bad grades to black students, perhaps because they worry that such students might then be inclined to flee Harvard. 
"There's a feeling that you shouldn't pass judgment in a way that might hurt someone's self-esteem," said Mr. Mansfield, who is white.
While few here support the notion that one of every two grades issued by the university should be an A or A-, many professors believe that the quality of work undertaken by most Harvard students may well be deserving of a high grade -- regardless of how many other Harvard students receive that same grade.
That more A's are being awarded than a generation ago, they argue, is often a reflection of how much better the pool of students has become. (A quarter of the students admitted to this year's Harvard freshman class, for example, scored a perfect 1600, or just below it, on the SAT's.)
Harry R. Lewis, the dean of Harvard College, who has been teaching computer science at Harvard for 20 years, said he had noticed that "problems that used to be really hard for a majority of the students are now hard for the minority."
In contrast to Mr. Mansfield's contention that grade inflation began in earnest in the late 1960's, when blacks were first admitted in considerable numbers, Dean Lewis has assembled data showing that the number of A's at Harvard has been increasing at a fairly steady rate since the 1920's; if anything, the trend was relatively flat from 1969 to 1985. "A lot of the increases are a result of applying the same standard to better academic work," Dean Lewis said.
In contrast to years past, when few changes in policy emerged from such hand-wringing, there are indications that this round may be different. Harvard's new president, Lawrence H. Summers, the former treasury secretary, is "very concerned about both honors inflation and grade inflation and believes very strongly in the importance of high and rigorous standards," said Joe Wrinn, a spokesman.
In distributing last month's report, Dean Susan Pedersen wrote that a faculty-wide panel would take up the matter in the spring, with an eye on proposing "concrete action." Dean Pedersen said she already sensed "some measure of agreement" that "we were in a healthier situation about 15 years ago," when a smaller proportion of grades -- roughly one-third -- fell in the 'A' range.
But imposing a more uniform grading standard on professors who have been encouraged to think independently will not be easy. One potential end-run being discussed would expand the information on a student's transcript to provide graduate schools with a numerical indication of how other students in the same class were graded. Dartmouth and Columbia have provided similar information in recent years. 
But Emily Leithauser, 18, a freshman contemplating a major in Middle Eastern studies, believes that the only real solution lies with Harvard students themselves. "I really believe Harvard students don't always challenge themselves," she said. "And I don't know that they take criticism as well as they should."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 7, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Harvard data showing that nearly half of all undergraduate grades in recent years have been A or A-minus omitted a reference to the news report that brought the situation to public notice. (The Lessons column the same day, about the issue of grade inflation, also omitted such a reference.) The university's acknowledgment followed a two-part report in The Boston Globe in October disclosing that 91 percent of Harvard graduates received honors in June, far more than at other elite universities.

HEADLINE: News of Ford Cutback Surprises Edison, Both Plant and Town 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Many of the older workers at the Ford Motor Company plant remember 1982, when a poor economy and flagging demand for the Escort model assembled here led to a cutback to one daily shift, from two. 
 So Monday, when veteran workers heard the surprising news that the same kind of cut, with the loss of 600 jobs, was planned for February, they reacted first with shock and indignation and then with sober and pointed questions about how long the cutbacks would last, the role of seniority and what benefits they would keep. 
 For the younger workers, the shock has yet to ebb. Some, like 24-year-old Robert Harrigan of Bricktown, who has worked in the plant's body shop for five years assembling the popular Ranger pickup truck line, the anger was still welling up. 
"I don't have seniority and so I'm definitely gone," he said during a break today as he sat in the parking lot of the offices of Local 980 of the United Automobile Workers Union. "And my wife and I just had a baby."
While he and others were angry at the company, the economy and those who had seniority, they were also angry at the union, since the leaders had given them no warning, they said. The workers also complained that even as company officials were outlining the cutbacks in meetings on the plant floor, those union officers were being curiously quiet.
"They usually talk to us, but they haven't been around much," said Anthony San Martin, an eight-year employee. "I think they think we'll be jumping down their throats."
Outside the plant, the concern is growing in Edison Township as well. Township Mayor George Spadoro noted that ever since Ford started construction in Dearborn, Mich., of a large state-of-the-art Ranger factory with its own power plant, there have been fears that the older, smaller plant in Edison was headed for mothballs. It was the start of the Ranger line at the Edison plant in 1989 that had returned the factory to a full two shifts.
"These cuts will have a ripple effect on the local economy," the mayor said of the possible loss of a shift and nearly 42 percent of the 1,425 workers. "I had been feeling comfortable about the long-term prospects for the plant, but if you make it less productive, it is more likely that it will be seen as expendable down the line."
The announcement of the cutbacks Monday was part of a package of companywide changes, including reduced health and retirement benefits for 45,000 salaried workers and the elimination of merit pay increases for top executives. Those changes, as well as the production cutbacks at Edison, were part of the company's response to sagging sales of most product lines. 
Steve Girsky, an analyst who follows Ford for Morgan Stanley, said the company suffered in particular from "excess capacity" in its Ranger pickup line. 
"I can't speak to the future, but this could be a prelude to things to come," he said. "Older plants tend not to be as efficient as newer plants, and this is an older plant."
Union local officials, like the president, Bob LaPoint, and the chairman, Richard Linn, have been hearing that line of thinking for years from corporate plant managers, and they say that they have worked hard with management to increase productivity and to improve the quality of the trucks assembled here. 
At one time, it cost $800 more to assemble a Ranger here than in other Ford plants, Mr. Linn said. 
They managed to get that down to $200 while improving quality, he said. "It's very difficult to close a top-quality plant and have shareholders and the public accept that," Mr. Linn said, hinting at the campaign that the U.A.W. local plans to mount against the cuts. 
Already, he and Mr. LaPoint have reached out to elected officials like Mayor Spadoro, United States Senator Jon Corzine and Governor-elect James E. McGreevey to begin talks on government incentives to Ford to keep the plant operating at peak levels. Mayor Spadoro said there was a good possibility of tax incentives.
Unionized workers' pay can range from $22 to $27 an hour, he said. 
As the morning shift was ending, older workers, like Robert Dockery, 55, with 31 years at Ford, said they were sure they would keep their jobs but unsure for how long. He had hoped to hold out for five more years before retiring, but the elimination of a shift convinced him that it was "just a matter of time" before the entire plant closed. 
Mr. LaPoint, the union local president, said that despite the company's talk about declining demand for the Ranger, shifts at the Edison plant were still 10 hours, not 8 hours, and Saturday was scheduled as a mandatory overtime day. 
Then, with resolve, he said, "But you always have to have hope that something will work in your favor."

HEADLINE: During a Blue-Collar Upswing, Labor Seeks a Lift 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
The theme of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s convention is written in huge letters behind the ballroom's podium: America's Workers -- Heroes Every Day.
 Those words aim not only to honor the firefighters and others who died responding to the Sept. 11 attacks, but also to capitalize on the improved standing of millions of blue-collar and government workers. 
 The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s leaders want to use this new-found respect to lift the embattled labor movement, but that will not be easy. Unions have failed to reverse their decline in membership, they face an often-hostile president and House of Representatives, and the war, the recession and the surge in layoffs have combined to weaken labor's hand in bargaining. 
Aggravating labor's problems are internal rifts, including the decision by the carpenters' union to quit the A.F.L.-C.I.O., a federation of 66 unions representing 13 million workers.
While facing these problems, John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, is trying to push labor forward but with mixed results partly because many individual unions refuse to follow his lead. At the convention at the Paris Hotel, he has prodded unions to organize more workers and to mobilize their members to lobby Congress on trade. 
When Mr. Sweeney was elected to labor's top post in 1995, his main goals were increasing labor's voice in politics and making union ranks grow after decades of decline. Unions are certainly more vocal in politics than before. But Mr. Sweeney has not succeeded in his other major goal. Union membership as a percentage of the work force has fallen to 13.5 percent, down from 14.9 percent in 1995.
Mr. Sweeney acknowledged problems. "The American labor movement is failing to help new members organize at anywhere near the level we need to," he said.
A dozen unions have embraced his call to devote 30 percent of their budgets to recruitment, and several more have promised to do so. He has also urged unions to be more aggressive in organizing immigrant workers, including janitors, hotel housekeepers, nursing home workers and fruit pickers.
Despite his prodding, unions, although they have tripled their organizing efforts since 1995, remain at less than half of his long-term goal of organizing one million workers a year.
"Given the difficulty he continues to face, where unions can pretty much decide to go their own route," said Richard Hurd, a labor relations professor at Cornell University, "I think Sweeney's doing an admirable job." 
Last spring, Douglas McCarron, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, rocked the A.F.L.-C.I.O. by pulling his 300,000-member union out of the federation. Mr. McCarron said he was unhappy that the federation was not doing more to organize workers, but many union leaders said he betrayed the goal of solidarity and was stingy about contributing money to federation activities. 
With the former labor secretary John T. Dunlop serving as an intermediary, Mr. Sweeney is negotiating with Mr. McCarron to bring the carpenters back in. 
That is far from labor's only rift. Angering labor's allies in the environmental movement, the Teamsters and a dozen building trades unions have lobbied Congress to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling. Those unions say the drilling will create hundreds of thousands of jobs. But three other powerful unions -- the service employees, steelworkers and communications workers -- have lobbied against drilling, saying it will hurt the environment and create few long-term jobs. 
While labor's chieftains are meeting here, their lobbying lieutenants are locked in two huge battles in Washington. Unions hope to persuade Congress and President Bush to revamp the economic stimulus package passed by the House so it gives far less money to corporations, extends unemployment insurance benefits and subsidizes health insurance for the unemployed.
In an unusual move, the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. began running broadcast advertisements in Washington this week, saying New York workers already suffered from the terror of Sept. 11 and should not have to face the terror of losing health coverage and not being able to pay bills.
After years of blocking fast-track trade legislation, labor leaders are worried by plans to hold a House vote on fast track this Thursday. Such legislation would make it easier for Mr. Bush to negotiate free-trade agreements by not permitting Congress to amend the deals, allowing only a yes or no vote.
An oft-voiced complaint here is that Congressional Republicans and Mr. Bush are exploiting the war and Mr. Bush's popularity to push through pro-business legislation. In his keynote address, Mr. Sweeney said the president was doing an excellent job fighting terrorism, but he condemned Mr. Bush for "waging a vicious war on working families."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A memorial panel dedicated to fallen union members was displayed yesterday at the Paris Hotel in Las Vegas. (Lori Cain for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Merrill to Use Fewer People For Same Amount of Research 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
When the realigning of Merrill Lynch's research department is finished at the end of the year, there will be just as many hats but fewer heads to wear them.
 The research department is shrinking along with the rest of Merrill, which is eliminating thousands of jobs to cut costs sharply. The trick for the department's new managers will be trying to trim the number of analysts, strategists and support staff members without diminishing the value of Merrill's research to investors. 
 The value of Wall Street investment research has repeatedly been called into question in the last few years as analysts rationalized the unsustainable prices investors paid for technology stocks. That skepticism found new support when Enron collapsed as analysts scrambled to retract their "strong buy" ratings on its shares. 
The Merrill analyst who followed Enron and other energy companies, Donato Eassey, is among those who have either quit or been dismissed in recent weeks. But Merrill officials did not link Mr. Eassey's departure to his analysis on Enron, just as they said Henry Blodget had not been encouraged to resign.
Mr. Blodget, who made a name for himself as a true believer in a long list of Internet stocks, was one of 2,600 Merrill employees who accepted a buyout offer the firm extended last month. He and Christine A. Callies, who was Merrill's United States investment strategist, have been the biggest names to depart. Others include Thomas Kraemer, who covered I.B.M. and other big computer makers, and Sandra Flannigan, who covered regional banks.
For now, to fill the voids, Merrill is giving some of its remaining analysts and strategists more work. Steven Milunovich, the technology strategist, will pick up coverage of Mr. Kraemer's stocks. Judah Kraushaar, who already follows big banks and brokerage stocks, will take on the regional banks, too.
"There are certain sectors where the world just changed, leaving us with too many resources in certain places, and in other places we didn't have enough," said Robert J. McCann, a senior vice president who was recently named director of Merrill's global research and economics group.
So the biggest companies that Mr. Blodget covered will fall to other senior analysts: Christopher Shilakes will again cover Microsoft, and Jessica Reif Cohen will follow AOL Time Warner. One of Mr. Blodget's junior analysts, Justin Baldauf, will cover Internet stocks like eBay, Yahoo and Amazon, said Deepak Raj, Mr. McCann's deputy.
Mr. Raj said he thought all the criticism of analysts was related to the boom and bust of the technology market and would die down. He said he and his fellow managers encouraged analysts to think independently.
"We view equity research to be at the core of the value proposition we offer clients," Mr. McCann said.
Mr. McCann said he also planned to add the firm's analysts of high-grade corporate bonds to those of high-yield, or junk, bonds to form industry teams.
Despite the cuts, Mr. McCann said that in January he and Mr. Raj would start looking for senior analysts at other firms to hire in certain crucial sectors, including food, beverages and other consumer products.
As evidence of the freedom his analysts have to speak their minds, Mr. McCann cited Richard Bernstein, who will become Merrill's chief domestic investment strategist while retaining his role as chief quantitative strategist. Mr. Bernstein is less bullish than Ms. Callies, his predecessor, but Mr. McCann said that would not be a problem.
"Some of the brokers may not like that," Mr. McCann said. "I don't think we have to have a singular voice. But I thought that our voice wasn't as clear or as tight as we'd like it to be."

HEADLINE: A New Health Plan May Raise Expenses For Sickest Workers 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Pressed by employers, some of the nation's biggest insurers are introducing a new kind of health plan that would significantly change the way employees are reimbursed for ordinary medical expenses. 
 Most working families, who have relatively low medical bills, could save money under the plans. But those with several thousand dollars in medical expenses could wind up paying much more. 
 Few experts on health care are familiar with the plans. But some health benefits experts who do know of them warn that they could be more unfair than current plans to people who are sick and that they could discourage people who need care from getting it. 
The insurers preparing to offer the plans within a year include Aetna, Humana, Cigna, the UnitedHealth Group and Wellpoint Health Networks. Some are already testing the new plans on their own employees or even with a few companies. And several small insurance companies began offering the new plans at a few companies earlier this year. 
The new plans typically require a family to pay an annual premium of $1,000 to $1,400, slightly lower than the cost of traditional managed care. Families then receive an allowance of $2,000 to $3,000 each year to spend on medical expenses, including drugs. 
But after they have spent that, they have to cover every cost above that cap, sometimes up to $5,000 or more. After the higher amount is reached, the employer picks up most of the bills.
In addition, instead of covering all but a few dollars of the cost of each drug prescription, some of the new plans will require employees to cover a much bigger portion of the cost. 
The difference between the new plans and those currently covering many Americans is striking. 
As one example, a family of three with $5,000 in medical bills and chronic medical conditions requiring several widely used prescription drugs could pay $5,634 themselves, compared with $3,420 under a traditional managed care plan, according to industry consultants.
"The effect will be to shift more of the costs into the pockets of the sick people," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton University. "The insurance industry has decided that if you are sick, you ought to eat the costs. It's a very dubious social policy."
The plans also offer online information to help consumers make their own medical decisions, including descriptions of different diseases and treatments, data on the costs of numerous treatments, and a network of doctors and hospitals that employees can use to keep their medical costs down.
A family that keeps its medical bills lower than the allowance can roll over any unspent money to pay medical bills in future years.
But for a family that uses up the allowance, the plans stop paying entirely until a ceiling is reached. At one company offering the new plans, employees who use only network doctors are responsible for a deductible of $1,000 to $5,000 in medical expenses beyond their allowance of $2,000, depending on the premium they are willing to pay. If they go to doctors outside the network, their deductible could rise even higher.
For employees whose medical expenses exceed the allowance and the deductible, the plan typically covers all medical costs provided by a network of doctors and hospitals. Employees who go to doctors and hospitals outside the network are covered for 70 to 80 percent of charges up to $1,000. After that, the plans typically cover all expenses. 
Prescriptions often become a much heavier expense. Currently, employers usually offer a separate drug plan that covers all but a few dollars of a medication. Under some of the new plans, employees must draw on their allowance to buy medications, whether they are the low-priced generic drugs or expensive brand name medications. After they exhaust the allowance, employees have to cover the full cost of any drugs until the deductible is met.
For example, a year's supply of Serevent, a widely used asthma treatment, could be nearly $800 instead of the $120 to $360 that is an employee's current share in many drug plans. An employer would begin to pay more only after an employee had used up the health care allowance and deductible. 
The insurers say the plans are intended to help companies save money at a time when their employees' medical costs have been surging, up 10 to 15 percent or more in each of the last two years. 
Many companies are seeking ways to transfer to employees more of the costs, especially of drugs, which have been the fastest-rising medical cost. 
Kenneth Sperling, a consultant at Hewitt Associates, said many employers were using the plans to shift a greater percentage of health costs to employees with the highest medical expenses. "As health care costs go up, it becomes a choice between hitting the users of the system or hitting everybody," he said. 
Insurance executives say that some of their largest customers are clamoring to try the new health plans, which offer savings for future costs for the majority of people, who have few medical costs in any given year. According to a study by William M. Mercer, a consulting firm, 75 percent of all working people account for just 15 percent of employers' medical costs, with each working family spending $1,000 to $1,500 itself each year.
Employers say that the new plans can reduce medical costs because employees have more of a financial incentive to, say, choose a generic medicine or to avoid a test or treatment that their doctor says is not necessary.
If the average person knew that a specialized scan cost $600 or $700, "it might have an influence" on whether she listens when her doctor says the scan is unnecessary, said Dr. Jack Mahoney, health planning director at Pitney Bowes, which is considering one of the plans for 2003.
But Deborah Chollet, an economist at Mathematica, a nonprofit research concern, said the new plans could be a barrier to needed care for some people. The plans would leave families essentially without insurance until they have spent several thousand dollars, she said. "Uninsured people don't consume much care" because they may have difficulty deciding whether care is necessary or not, she said.
"This is taking coverage away from people," said Ms. Chollet, a health insurance specialist. "And it is obviously a greater hardship for the lower-income workers." 
Insurance and insurance rates are usually designed around the idea of a pool of risk -- the chance that a few members of a group will have high claims that can be covered by the premiums paid by everyone else. But the new plans move away from that notion, effectively penalizing people with higher medical costs and rewarding those with lower expenses.
Indeed, when employers offer both the new plans and traditional managed care, the new savings accounts may attract largely young, healthy members, while sicker people stick with plans that cover more of their medical costs. "There are still huge numbers of unanswered questions," said Tony Kotin, a consultant in Chicago with William M. Mercer, the benefits consultant.
Eventually, however, consultants expect many employers to offer only the new type of plan.
Humana said it began offering one of the new plans to its 14,300 employees in July and would add outside customers next summer. 
Aetna, the largest health insurance company, is offering its new plan as an option to its own 38,000 employees for 2002. It plans to extend the offer to large national customers with a total of more than eight million employees for 2003, said Ronald A. Williams, executive vice president of Aetna. "We view this as a product, not an experiment," he said.
Wellpoint said it would offer one of the new plans to groups with three million members in California next year. Cigna said it would begin offering "a health savings account product" next year. UnitedHealth said that a Fortune 100 company had asked it to offer a pilot plan, which will include a health savings account and a "high deductible" of $2,500.
A handful of start-up companies specializing in the new plans, including Definity Health, Lumenos Inc., Destiny Health and Health Markets Inc., began testing the market earlier this year and are accepting both renewals and new orders for 2002. 
Several large employers, including Medtronic Inc., a medical device company; Charter Communications, a television cable group; and Textron Inc., a diversified financial services and manufacturing company, are already offering Definity plans to their employees. 
"We can't bear 12 to 14 percent inflation year after year," said Don Broecker, director of benefits for 17,000 employees at Charter Communications, based in St. Louis.
Lumenos, based in Alexandria, Va., has sold its version to several drug companies for their own employees, including Novartis, Abbott Laboratories and Pharmacia, and more than 100 smaller companies.
"I liked their spin on health care," said Bruce Gorman, 48, a shipping manager in Phoenix at Wincup, a plastic cup manufacturer that began offering the Lumenos plan on Aug. 1. He used most of his health savings account this year, but does not expect to do so next year. 
Destiny Health has signed up 3,000 employees since August at 125 companies in Illinois and is adding 1,000 a month, according to Ken Linde, the chief executive of Discovery Health, which owns Destiny.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: LIBERTY AND SECURITY -- Political Memo; 
Few in Congress Questioning President Over Civil Liberties

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Even in peaceful times, defending civil liberties is rarely a crowd-pleasing cause. As Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, puts it, "Take free speech: most of the tough cases on free speech involve very unpleasant people saying very obnoxious things."
 So it should come as no surprise that in deeply unsettled times -- like these -- the political defense of civil liberties would be careful and constrained, many analysts say. 
 Recent public opinion polls suggest that a worried public is willing to give the administration wide latitude in the pursuit and prosecution of suspected terrorists. 
There is a small but vocal group of elected officials and activists, on the left and on the right, expressing concern about the administration's recent moves, like allowing the creation of military tribunals to try foreigners suspected of terrorism and the widespread questioning of recent Middle Eastern immigrants.
But the issue has yet to galvanize the rank and file -- or, for that matter, the leadership -- of either party. Indeed, the issue is being treated very gingerly by politicians eager to demonstrate their full commitment to the fight against terrorism.
"Traditional civil libertarians are upset, but the American people are not," said John Feehery, a spokesman for the House speaker, J. Dennis Hastert. "This is no time politically to be soft on terrorists. That's where most of our people are." 
In the Senate, one Democratic strategist said, "This is one area of public policy where politicians feel pretty much the way the public does."
Asked about the impact of the polls, the strategist added, "Sure, most politicians aren't all that eager to fly in the face of three-quarters of public opinion, but I sense sincerity more than I sense cowardice."
In the House, the Judiciary Committee has been privately briefed by administration officials on these issues but has no immediate plans to hold public hearings, a spokesman said. In the Senate, the Judiciary Committee is holding hearings, including today's sessions on military tribunals and the hundreds of detainees, but few expect legislation this year to rein in the administration on these issues.
Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota and majority leader, has largely confined his criticism of the administration to economics and the budget. 
"I think the issue of civil liberties is very, very important to every member of our caucus," he said when asked about the subject at a news conference today. "We're trying to find the right balance, of course, between protecting civil liberties and ensuring that law enforcement has the tools it needs to do its job."
He noted, however, that it was hard to come to any definitive conclusion about matters like military tribunals when the administration had yet to furnish details.
Senator Byron L. Dorgan, the North Dakota Democrat who is chairman of the Democratic Policy Committee, said "there has not been a great deal of internal discussion" of civil liberties issues among Democrats since the passage of the counterterrorism bill in October. It is simply too soon, he said, adding, "I think there's still a sense of shock here, not only in the Congress but in the country, about Sept. 11, and a grim determination to go after these terrorists and bring them to justice."
These are treacherous waters for elected officials. At today's Judiciary Committee hearing, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the senior Republican on the panel, scoffed at the "alarmist rhetoric" about military tribunals and suggested that the committee ought to be focused on "getting behind our president" in fighting terrorism.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat who was running the hearing, replied coolly, "No one's trying to impede our president."
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the committee, who has pushed hardest for hearings and Congressional oversight, is increasingly becoming a target to some conservatives. The journal Human Events this week described him as "Osama's Enabler in Congress," arguing that he was raising civil liberties questions "not because he has legitimate complaints -- he doesn't -- but because he has a partisan and ideological ax to grind into John Ashcroft's back."
Still, some pollsters, including Geoffrey Garin, a Democrat, argue that this issue may not be as dangerous as it seems. Citing the case of Senator Russell D. Feingold, the Wisconsin Democrat who cast the lone vote in the Senate against the counterterrorism bill, as well as Mr. Leahy, Mr. Garin argued, "Only two people have tested the edges of the envelope here and neither of them have been harmed in the process. What the public wants and expects on this is a serious probing of the issues."
But Neil Newhouse, a Republican pollster, argued, "When you have 80 percent of Americans believing there will be another terrorist event on U.S. soil, you have a pretty good sense of why people are saying, 'Yeah, let's take care of some things.' "
He added, "What this means for politicians is, there may be little sacred when you invoke the cause of fighting terrorism."
Civil liberties groups say that the debate is really just beginning, that it will take time to sway public opinion to their side. Advocates hope that support from conservatives like Representative Bob Barr, Republican of Georgia, and Republican moderates like Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania will help take any partisan edge off the debate.
But Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director, suggested that the Congressional criticism of recent weeks has turned out to be more about the need to consult Congress than the merits of the administration's proposals.
And Mr. Frank, a longtime member of the Judiciary Committee, suggests that this is a complicated case to make, politically. The measures under debate, he said, generally involve noncitizens, so the average American feels less of a stake in the discussion. And, he added: "The rights of people who have done terrible things are hard to defend. You have to keep pointing out, the question is the process to determine whether they've done the terrible things."
Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat whose district includes a large Arab-American community, said the politics of civil liberties were inherently hard. Asked how many of his fellow members were concerned, he replied, "I hear a lot of members saying they're concerned, but not many willing to say it publicly."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NUCLEAR SECURITY; 
Safety of Nuclear Plants Again Raises Concerns

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Some people here never liked the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant, worrying about accidents and radioactive waste. Others always thought it was a reliable, cheap and clean source of electricity. Over 30 years of arguing, they had mostly run out of new things to say and bored the general public with their arguments. But that was before Sept. 11.
 Now discussions about Vermont Yankee, and other reactors around the Northeast, are drawing big crowds. There were 600 people here on Monday night, in the auditorium of Brattleboro Union High School, not counting the 20 federal, state and local officials on stage to answer their questions. They were at it for four hours, and a while longer in the parking lot. 
 "This is a small town, in a small state," said Representative Bernard Sanders, who convened the meeting, marveling at the turnout. "People are very, very concerned."
Last month there were hearings near the Pilgrim plant, in Plymouth, Mass.; the Seabrook plant, in the New Hampshire town of the same name; and the undamaged reactor at Three Mile Island, near Harrisburg, Pa.
There was also a hearing near the Maine Yankee plant, in Wiscasset, Me., which was shut down five years ago, but where radioactive spent fuel is still stored. Next week in White Plains, a committee of the Westchester County Board of Legislators plans a hearing on whether to revoke approval of the emergency plan for the Indian Point reactors. A hearing about the dangers of spent fuel is planned for the Shearon Harris plant in North Carolina. 
"Sept. 11 has been the biggest challenge to nuclear power since Chernobyl," said David Lochbaum, a nuclear engineer at the Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit group that frequent criticizes government oversight of nuclear safety. "Congressmen who have had very little interest in nuclear power in the five years I've been at U.C.S. are suddenly competing with each other to examine security issues at the plants." 
Although it is not clear how seriously local governments or members of Congress can threaten the future of licensed reactors, the industry hardly welcomes the discussion. 
Until Sept. 11, the outlook for the nation's 103 nuclear power plants was improving. The years since the 1986 accident at Chernobyl have been mostly quiet, with no significant unusual radiation releases in the United States, and rising reliability. Reactors were beginning to look more attractive given the increasing demand for electricity. Several have recently won 20-year extensions on their 40-year licenses, and others have met the first challenge of deregulation of the electricity business, having sold at prices higher than analysts expected. 
But since Sept. 11, public officials have mused publicly about whether a nuclear plant would withstand the crash of a jet any better than the World Trade Center did, and the technology's opponents have found a wider audience. 
"We have handed our enemies a radiological weapon, a target of opportunity," said Ned Childs, one of dozens of people who spoke at the hearing last night. Mr. Childs lives in Dummerston, Vt., 10 miles from the plant in Vernon.
State officials have voiced the same concern. Kate O'Conner, chairwoman of the Vermont Terrorist Task Force, said Sept. 11 had prompted Gov. Howard Dean, who is a doctor, to seek a stockpile of a drug to protect the public against radiation-induced thyroid cancer, something that has been debated nationwide for 20 years.
The industry does not relish the attention. At the Nuclear Energy Institute in Washington, Angelina Howard, a spokeswoman for the industry's trade group, said some people in New York and New England had always shown "skittishness" about nuclear power. But elsewhere, she said, there were anecdotal reports that more tourists were stopping by the visitor centers at the plants, or at least those centers that were still open after Sept. 11. 
"When the public has a concern and they go look into it, usually they come off feeling better about it," she said. Opinion polls commissioned by her organization show growing approval of nuclear power since Sept. 11, Ms. Howard said.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has defended the design of the plants. Hubert J. Miller, the commission's administrator for the Northeast, said that while Vermont Yankee's designers did not have an attack by a Boeing 767 in mind when they designed it, the building is "very robust," and that nuclear plants are among the strongest buildings of any kind.
Defending Vermont Yankee's security preparations is somewhat harder. On Aug. 23, it was the plant's turn for a mock attack by federal agents playing terrorists, and the evaluators found so many deficiencies that they graded the plant "yellow," in a grading system that runs green, white, yellow and red. It was the lowest grade in the industry. 
But Mr. Miller said the problems had been corrected.
At the town meeting, calls for conservation and renewable energy drew applause, although this being Vermont, at the mention of windmills, one strong voice shouted, "They're bird killers."
Ross Barkhurst, the chief executive of the Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corporation, stood his ground on reasons of safety and economics. Speaking of wind power, he said: "As long as we have the ability to compete, bring it on. Right now my best friend is the renewable energy we have in the state -- it costs about two and a half times what mine does."
Public officials here and elsewhere have described the risk of terrorist attack on a reactor, especially by big planes, as remote, though some members of the public doubt the government's ability to pick what the next target might be.
"I know the opinion of many of you is that the best thing to do is not to have a plant down here," said Edward von Turkovich, the director of Vermont Emergency Management, to loud applause. But he added, "We're going to coexist with a plant. The best thing to do is to have a plan in place."

Boisvert for The New York Times); The Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant in Vernon, Vt., is more than 30 years old, but renewed discussions about its safety are drawing crowds. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PRESIDENT; 
President Tries to Give Florida, and Its Governor, a Boost

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 4 

 BODY:
George W. Bush today confronted a growing vulnerability of his presidency, the languishing economy, by promoting a government program for laid-off workers and blaming the Democratic-controlled Senate for a deadlock in Washington over an economic stimulus bill.
 But he also made time for overt Bush family politics, publicly suspended since Sept. 11, by talking up his younger brother, Gov. Jeb Bush. The Florida governor is facing more than $1 billion in state budget cuts and a re-election fight next year, probably against Janet Reno, President Bill Clinton's attorney general. Mr. Bush himself narrowly lost the surrounding Orange County to Al Gore in the 2000 presidential election. 
 "I hurt, coming into the holiday season, that you're not working," Mr. Bush told unemployed workers at a local job center, Operation Paycheck, one of 1,200 such facilities nationwide that is financed by federal money and run by the states. "But I admire your courage for going out to try to improve yourselves so you can find jobs around here." 
He also said Democratic senators "need to stop fussing and stop talking and get something to my desk that will take care of the workers and provide stimulus to this economy."
A short time later, to an enthusiastic crowd of more than 4,000 people at a town hall meeting at the Orange County Convention Center, Mr. Bush laid the credit for Operation Paycheck directly at the feet of his smiling sibling. "It's a program that Jeb has put in place to help displaced workers," Mr. Bush said.
Orlando, home of Walt Disney World, has been hard hit by the Sept. 11 attacks as people remain nervous about traveling. The tourism industry here has been ailing and has laid off thousands of workers. The Florida Agency for Workforce Innovations said that in Orange County, 4,703 people filed first-time claims for unemployment in November, compared with just 1,753 a year ago. 
Tourism is Florida's largest industry, bringing in $50 billion a year in gross sales.
"I recommend people from outside of Florida to come and take a look at Florida," Mr. Bush said at the convention center. "It's a nice place to visit and a great place to live. One reason why is because you've got a great governor."
Operation Paycheck will be financed out of the $3.4 million national emergency grant that Florida received to cope with higher unemployment since Sept. 11. The Orlando area lost about 2,000 jobs, most of them related to tourism, since the attacks. The $3.4 million is only a fraction of the $35 million that Jeb Bush asked for. 
When a reporter asked Jeb Bush if he had asked the White House for more than he thought he would get, he said, "Of course we did. "What are you doing, playing me for a fool?"
President Bush was asked 19 questions at the hourlong town meeting, his first solo one as president. Participants had been given tickets by the local Republican Party, the Chamber of Commerce and Hispanic organizations. Most questions focused on the economy, but a third grader, who gave his name only as Jordan, asked Mr. Bush how he felt when he first heard about the Sept. 11 attacks.
The president responded by talking more personally about his thoughts on that day, when he was at a school in Sarasota, Fla. "I was sitting outside the classroom waiting to go in, and I saw an airplane hit the tower -- the TV was obviously on," Mr. Bush said. "And I used to fly myself, and I said, 'Well, there's one terrible pilot.' I said, 'Must have been a horrible accident.' "
Mr. Bush then recounted that Andrew H. Card Jr., his chief of staff, told him that a second plane had hit the other tower. "And I started thinking hard in that very brief period of time about what it meant to be under attack," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Bush was animated and gregarious throughout the town hall meeting, and at one point made light of his mother, Barbara Bush. When he was asked by a young woman, Caitlin, if he ate his meals together with his family when he was a child, the president responded, "I did eat with my family, so long as my mother wasn't cooking."
When the crowd laughed, Mr. Bush said, "Wait a minute. Just kidding, Mom. She was one of the great fast-food cooks of all time. Just kidding, Mom. We ate a lot together."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Trying to Lure Zimbabwe to Democracy 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Adding to growing international pressure on Zimbabwe, Congress approved incentives today intended to persuade President Robert Mugabe to halt government abuses and undertake market reforms.
 The House offered $26 million in aid, forgiveness of some of Zimbabwe's debt and a promise to help promote trade and investment if Mr. Mugabe created conditions for fair elections next spring. The Senate approved similar language in August. 
 Some House Republicans, eager to send a strong message to Mr. Mugabe, the socialist who has ruled Zimbabwe since independence in 1980, said they had considered sanctions. But American aid has already been curtailed and lawmakers voiced concerns that punitive actions would compound the misery of ordinary Zimbabweans.
"The Zimbabwean government responds to the cries of its people and its political opposition with harassment, intimidation and murder," said Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Republican chairman of the international relations committee.
The country suffers food shortages, a foreign debt of more than $890 million, an AIDS infection rate of 25 percent and the turmoil over farm seizures, which were supported by Mr. Mugabe to redistribute lands held by mostly white farmers since the colonial period. 
Zimbabwe's Supreme Court ruled today that the government had taken adequate steps to enforce the rule of law in commercial farming areas and should continue redistributing land from white farmers to blacks. The ruling was sharply criticized by the leading opposition party and by white farming groups, who say that violence is continuing on farms occupied by black squatters. 
The Zimbabwe Democracy and Economic Recovery Act, which passed the House in a 396 to 11 vote, also urges President Bush to deny visas and freeze the assets of those "responsible for violence and the breakdown of the rule of law in Zimbabwe."
The Bush administration had worked closely with Congress in preparing the legislation. The assistant secretary of state for African affairs, Walter Kansteiner, is to visit Zimbabwe this weekend and emphasize Washington's hope to see the restoration of human rights and an end to political violence.
But some administration officials said Mr. Mugabe, who is 77, seems determined to remain in power at all costs. "No one's quite sure what to do about it, how to make Mugabe listen," said one State Department official. "Everyone's frustrated. He's going to try to weather the storm and get re-elected and say, 'O.K., now you're stuck with me.' "
Polls show Mr. Mugabe trailing the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change. American officials say he has increasingly sought to maintain his grip by intimidating journalists, packing the Supreme Court and using veterans from the fight for independence to threaten opponents.
The European Union has threatened to impose trade sanctions unless democratic rights are restored. And Zimbabwe's neighbors, increasingly worried over the prospects for violence, a refugee exodus or economic collapse, plan to dispatch their foreign ministers to the capital, Harare, next week.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 On the Ground, on the Air

PREPARING FOR A SIEGE -- The marines advanced from their Afghan desert base in preparation for the siege of Kandahar, scouting enemy movements from armored vehicles and helicopters, and setting up checkpoints to keep the Taliban from reinforcing -- or from escaping -- their largest stronghold. A1

MARINES WIDEN PATROLS -- Having established significant firepower on the ground in southern Afghanistan, the marines are probing deeper toward the chaotic swaths of territory that are still under the control of the Taliban. B2

NETWORKS SUPPORT WAR EFFORT -- The major broadcast networks are producing short television messages that convey season's greetings to troops stationed overseas. B3

INSIDER INFORMATION -- John Walker Lindh, the 20-year-old American who was captured with Taliban soldiers in northern Afghanistan could provide a bounty of useful intelligence about the recruiting methods, hideouts, supply routes and lower-level command structure of the Taliban military, senior Pentagon officials say. B3

The Afghan Future

A NEW GOVERNMENT -- After eight days of talks in Germany, agreement appeared near on the makeup of an interim Afghan government, tentatively scheduled to take power on Dec. 22. B1

A SECURITY FORCE -- Afghan leaders appear to have agreed that an international security force can be deployed, but only in Kabul, to maintain stability as a new transitional government takes power. It remains unclear whether it will be a potent military force or a largely symbolic presence. B2

ANTI-WESTERN PASSIONS -- Saudi Arabia's government grapples with the issue of how to deal with influential conservative clerics who espouse harsh anti-Western opinions and urge Muslims to fight against America. B1

REMNANTS OF VIOLENCE -- The crude metal noose said to have killed the mujahedeen commander Abdul Haq -- executed by the Taliban in October -- still hangs from a tree half a mile from one of Osama bin Laden's largest terrorist training camps. B4

Civil Liberties and Security

The experience left many feeling shaken, bitter and vulnerable to suspicions of a terrorist crime that has not been connected to their country. B6

HEADLINE: Mayor Commits $24 Million To Lincoln Center Rebuilding 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday authorized the city to allocate the first installment of a $240 million commitment for Lincoln Center's $1.2 billion redevelopment plan, several people associated with the project said.
 The mayor's approval secures $24 million from the city's capital budget, the first part of a 10-year commitment the mayor made before Sept. 11 toward a redevelopment program that was originally estimated at $1.5 billion. 
 The city's approval is an important vote of confidence for the project, which has been plagued by infighting at a time of economic uncertainty that will likely make fund-raising more difficult for cultural organizations. 
The allocation is particularly welcome for Lincoln Center, given that on Monday the mayor announced a $1.3 billion modification to the city's budget that included cuts of $766 million for various city agencies.
Anthony P. Coles, the deputy mayor who was the point person for the city on the Lincoln Center project, could not be reached for comment.
Lincoln Center's redevelopment plan calls for an extensive upgrade that includes a wide range of projects, from a $326 million rebuilding of Avery Fisher Hall to a $58 million redesign of entrances and lobbies at the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi E. Newhouse theaters to a $10.5 million expansion of the facilities of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
Disputes about various aspects of the project have yet to be resolved, and the particulars could change in the coming months. Each of the 11 constituents participating in the plan -- including the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic, the New York City Ballet and Jazz at Lincoln Center -- has the right to a veto. As a result, the plan has been rife with conflict, a situation many believe forced Marshall Rose, the chairman of the redevelopment project, to resign in October. Gordon J. Davis, the former president of Lincoln Center, resigned just a few weeks before Mr. Rose.
Ms. Sills declined comment through a spokeswoman, Janice Price. Ms. Price said that it was up to the mayor to make any announcement and that she thought the plan still had to go through a formal approval process.
But one Lincoln Center executive involved in the redevelopment said that any subsequent approval was merely a formality, given that the city has had the plans for 10 days. "It is tantamount to approval," the executive said. "The mayor responded enthusiastically and asked for the appropriate documents to proceed forthwith."
Among the issues that have yet to be decided is the future home of the New York City Opera. Building a new house for City Opera in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center was strong opposed by the Metropolitan Opera's general manager, Joseph Volpe, and by Ms. Sills.
As a result, the master plan submitted to the city allocated $240 million for a 2,200-seat opera house outside the center's West Side campus. If City Opera chooses to stay at the New York State Theater, which it shares with the New York City Ballet, the plan calls for spending up to $87 million to improve the acoustics.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 6, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's approval of $24 million for Lincoln Center's redevelopment plan, the first installment of a $240 million commitment by New York City over 10 years, included an organization erroneously among the participating groups. They do not include Jazz at Lincoln Center.

HEADLINE: An Echo of Big Dreams Of a World With Big Steel 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
The business executives gathered for a dinner on a brisk December evening in New York City's exclusive University Club. The speaker was the guest of honor, the young ambitious president of the nation's leading steel company. His chosen topic: his vision of the steel industry at the dawn of a new century. 
 He argued that United States steel makers suffered from destructive price wars and excess capacity. The companies are susceptible to economic downturns because their profit margins are being squeezed, he added. 
 He proposed a solution: the merger of several companies so they could combine operations while cutting costs. The resulting steel behemoth would be a competitive force in world markets. 
The proposal may sound a lot like what the steel industry is now proposing, but that evening was on Dec. 11, 1900. Charles Schwab, president of Carnegie Steel, was the speaker, and J. Pierpont Morgan, chairman of Federal Steel, sat in the audience with an unlighted cigar dangling from his mouth. The scene is recounted in United States Steel's commissioned centennial history. 
A dance of negotiation thus began between two of America's most prominent business personalities. The aging Andrew Carnegie was eager to devote his time to philanthropy. His price for Carnegie Steel was $480 million, an amount that Mr. Morgan accepted without any debate. 
Within months, the United States Steel Corporation became the first billion-dollar corporation through the merger of 10 steel companies. The new company controlled over 60 percent of the domestic steel market and 29 percent of the world market. Critics called United States Steel a monopoly, especially since the domestic steel market was protected by high tariffs. 
The new company owned hundreds of factories, employed 168,000 workers and controlled six sizable railroad lines. It controlled the steel-making process from beginning to end through a combination of furnaces, ore deposits and transportation companies.
But United States Steel became saddled with debt as a result of its merger. That constraint on its growth allowed smaller, nimbler competitors, like Bethlehem Steel, to gain market share. 
"They needed to run businesses as cash cows," said David Hounshell, a history professor at Carnegie Mellon University, so United States Steel became a lumbering, inefficient company. 
The company tried to milk its dominant market position for as long as it could, but it could not compete with the immediate onslaught of domestic competitors and with international rivals after World War II.
A century later, United States Steel, part of the USX Corporation, remains the nation's largest steel maker, although it produces only marginally more steel than it did in its first full year in business. 
"If it had been an efficient producer, it would not have lost market share," Professor Hounshell said. "But it systematically lost market share throughout the 20th century."
