HEADLINE: Co-op and Condo Brokers Have More to Sell This Year 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
With the economy settling into a recession and Manhattan apartment buyers hesitating, the number of condominiums and co-ops for sale in New York has increased significantly from the same period a year ago.
 Jonathan Miller, the president of Miller Samuel, one of the largest appraisal firms in the city, said yesterday that although prices had declined 5 to 10 percent, the number of apartments on the market was 40 percent higher than it was a year ago, but it was still lower than it was three years ago. At the Halstead Property Company, the firm's exclusive listings were up 31 percent compared with those of a year ago. 
 The increase in inventory is caused by "the combination of the economy and the fear factor," said Lawrence Sicular, a real estate analyst who is preparing a new market report for Brown Harris Stevens, a big New York real estate brokerage firm. "Right now, we don't know which is more or less responsible for the jump in supply." 
Yesterday, the Corcoran Group reported that the number of new listings of co-ops and condominiums across Manhattan -- not just the company's own exclusive listings -- had more than doubled from the same period last year. During the last week of November, 317 owners put their apartments up for sale. In the same week a year ago, Corcoran said, 138 owners decided to sell.
Altogether, there are 8,208 apartments listed for sale in Manhattan below 96th Street, Corcoran said, up from 5,828 on Dec. 5, 2000.
Nevertheless, Barbara Corcoran, the chairwoman of the company, refused to say that the statistics represented the advent of a buyer's market.
"No, it doesn't mean a buyer's market because properties are selling for maybe 10 percent less than a year ago -- and there are still bidding wars," she said last night. In a buyer's market, she said, properties sell for "14, 15, 16 percent less."
Most brokers who were interviewed agreed, in general, that the buyers were not in the driver's seat -- yet. But Frederick W. Peters, the president of Ashforth Warburg, a brokerage firm, said that a couple of Manhattan neighborhoods were veering that way.
For example, Mr. Peters said, Carnegie Hill, which encompasses parts of the east 80's and 90's, was very hot two years ago, but is not so hot anymore. And it is not just that one neighborhood.
"It's the whole family market," he said. "Many families have just put it on hold." 
Nevertheless, brokers said, the market for one- and two-bedroom apartments is still strong. 
That is because rents have risen so high that, even as the overall economy has declined, many prospective renters are still deciding that it is cheaper to buy than to rent. Although rents have come down from their peak, many people are still eagerly buying the smaller apartments.
"If it's a toss-up whether to buy or to rent, the customer is buying," Mr. Peters said. And who is the customer? "The single career person, couples, empty nesters, rich older people," he replied. And they are buying in different neighborhoods: Sutton Place, in the 50's near the East River, which fell out of fashion five or six years ago, and Park Avenue in the high 50's and low 60's, whose time went by 15 years ago as families moved uptown.
Roberta Benzilio, who manages offices both uptown and downtown for William B. May Company, said that the Upper West Side, once sizzling hot, had slowed. At the same time, Murray Hill, only a few years ago a stepchild of the much-hotter Gramercy Park, has become a favorite with Midtown professionals.
In New York City real estate, brokers and statisticians agree that the market is invariably a case of supply and demand. And prices are already drifting lower. For example, Mr. Sicular found that the current appraisal value of one nine-room co-op on the Upper East Side was 10 to 13 percent less than it was before Sept. 11.
Paul Purcell, the president of Insignia Douglas Elliman, said he was not sure where the market was going because the World Trade Center attack had made the current market difficult to assess. "We can assess the market," he said, "when there is a market to assess." At Elliman, listings have risen to 1,050 today from 700 in August. For comparison with the last economic downturn, Mr. Purcell said, the number of listings was at least 25 percent higher in the early 90's.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Japan's dominant agency is looking overseas, but it will find that world to be much less congenial.

BYLINE:  By Ken Belson

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
IT was an inauspicious start to the second century in business for Dentsu. After 100 years as Japan's dominant advertising agency, Dentsu made its trading debut last week as investors clamored for its shares. The celebration, however, fizzled quickly after an errant "sell" order sent the new shares skidding.
 The trade was sorted out, but the damage was done. The shares finished the day up 12 percent, far below expectations. 
 The initial public offering glitch may serve as a warning about the difficulties that await Dentsu as it now looks beyond Japan, where it controls a quarter of the $50 billion advertising market. 
At home, the company has cornered big accounts like Toyota Motor, Matsushita Electric Industrial and Suntory. Its cozy connections in the political and business world have helped it win plum deals like the exclusive rights to Japan's half of the 2002 World Cup soccer tournament in June; Japan will share the rights with South Korea. Dentsu has more than 40 percent of the Japanese television commercial market, which it helped build in the 1950's. 
"Dentsu has risen along with the growth of television," said Yoshihiro Saito, president of the Advertising Economics Research Institute, whose statistics show that Dentsu is larger than its next four domestic competitors combined. "They're everywhere."
Everywhere, it seems, but overseas. The company has offices in more than two dozen countries, yet just 5 percent of its $14.8 billion in fiscal 2000 sales was earned overseas.
Dentsu may be vulnerable as the huge global agencies that have formed over the last decade -- like the WPP Group of Britain and the Interpublic Group of Companies of the United States -- extend their reach. Interpublic's McCann-Erickson subsidiary and WPP are making inroads in Japan, chipping away at Dentsu's position. These global agency companies also work with Japanese companies overseas, raising the odds that corporate giants will choose them for a global branding campaign.
"Dentsu has a unique approach that works well at home, but forget about them overseas," said Hirotaka Maeda, an analyst with HSBC Securities in Tokyo.
Now that Dentsu is publicly held, rival agencies may even try to buy stakes in the company, though the number of available shares is still limited.
"We're looking for investors, and if WPP wants to buy Dentsu shares, we can't stop it," the president of Dentsu, Yutaka Narita, told The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading financial newspaper.
Dentsu relies on two main international partnerships. The company formed a venture with Young & Rubicam in 1981 that focuses mainly on Asia; Young & Rubicam is now owned by WPP. In March 2000, Dentsu also bought a 20 percent stake in the Bcom3 Group, an agency company that includes Leo Burnett and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. The details of the partnership are murky, but Dentsu hopes to earn a greater share of billings with Japanese companies in the United States and Europe.
The money that Dentsu raised from its offering also makes other investments likely.
Even so, the company remains a creature of its home market. Dentsu originally distributed news and ad space, and it brought the United Press wire service to Japan in 1908. The government seized half the company in 1936 and turned the news service into the military's propaganda mouthpiece.
After World War II, Dentsu hired the sons of leading businessmen and politicians, a tactic that helped it win big accounts. The Dentsu groups' client list -- an incredible 6,000 companies long -- is a corporate who's who. The company is so powerful that rivals like Toyota, Honda Motor and Mitsubishi Motors all do business with the agency -- ties that would not be tolerated by industry rivals in the United States.
Dentsu also has a unique position in Japan because it controls ad space through ownership stakes in the media and produces the creative work, a dual role that would usually be considered a conflict of interest in the West.
In Japan, marketers also typically assign a bigger share of their advertising budget to one agency. That allows Dentsu to worry less about losing major accounts, particularly in television, where it holds a 40 percent share. In the West, marketers usually try to spread their advertising money around and can change agencies often, practices that would make it harder for Dentsu to apply its winner-take-all strategy overseas.
Dentsu is also heavily reliant on income from advertising, which makes up two-thirds of its revenue. Big European and American agency companies generally earn less than half their income from traditional advertising, with the rest coming from public relations, direct marketing and other services.
While it fumbles for a formula to compete in the West, Dentsu faces a tough battle at home. While the advertising industry nearly doubled in size between 1985 and 1990, it has grown less than 10 percent in the last decade. The company has benefited from the miniboom in advertising generated by Internet companies and the deregulation of the financial and telecommunication industries.
But as dot-coms fail and the financial markets sour, Dentsu expects revenue to remain flat this year at best. Noriko Manabe, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities in Tokyo, said that with the economy in yet another recession, he expected ad revenue to slip another 5 percent next year.
That's hardly the centennial celebration Dentsu had hoped for.

HEADLINE: Energy Traders Continue to Prowl The Floor That Enron Helped Build 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Melissa Beckett checks prices on three computer monitors, fingers a microphone on her telephone and calls a broker in New York.
 "What's going on Billy?" says Ms. Beckett, 29, spinning in her seat on the Entergy-Koch energy trading floor here and pressing for details about the electricity market. "I'm at 30," she barks, meaning that she wants to sell power at $27.30 a megawatt. 
 No one is buying, the broker tells her, but Ms. Beckett can afford to be patient. She has already completed 16 trades, many of them profitable, and it is just 11:20 a.m.
"This has definitely been a good business," she says. "You have your losing days, but generally things have gone very well here."
That, of course, is why the Enron Corporation, until recently the world's largest energy trader, is working so hard to revive its trading business after filing for bankruptcy protection on Sunday. 
Though lower energy prices have weakened the market, rival firms and their thousands of young traders still find the prospects alluring. In Enron's wake, they have made Houston, once the corporate center of the Texas oil patch, into an energy trading capital that in its own way rivals the brokerage houses on New York's Wall Street and the futures pits in Chicago.
"There was this original idea that you could set up your energy business around trading and diminish your reliance on hard assets, like natural gas pipelines," said Michelle Michot Foss, director of the energy institute at the University of Houston. "That's what Enron said it was trying to do. And that's what other energy companies are now doing."
The trading floor at Entergy-Koch Trading -- a joint venture of Koch Industries, a privately held conglomerate in Wichita, Kan., and Entergy, a utility and power company in New Orleans -- is typical for this Wall Street of the Southwest. It is packed with casually dressed traders scanning computer screens, statistical charts, weather maps and electronic tickers pegged to the world's energy markets.
They arrive as early as 6 a.m. to read the financial tea leaves and trade power and natural gas in a burgeoning market that Enron virtually invented by aggressively pushing for deregulation in the 1990's.
In its simplest form, energy trading consists of buying a utility's excess power and selling it to another utility. But most of the trading is more complex, as utilities, power generators, banks and others seek to profit from, or hedge their bets on, shifting energy prices. 
If a fertilizer company, for example, has long-term contracts to sell its fertilizer at a fixed price, it might try to lock in long-term supplies of natural gas at, say, $5 a British thermal unit. But just in case the price drops to $2, giving some competitors the advantage of buying cheaper gas, it might buy put options, which would pay like an insurance plan.
A typical transaction could involve a chain of trades connecting 10 or more parties. So Company A sells power for delivery next month to Company B, which in turns sells it to Company C, which also hedges against the high price by making a deal with Company D. And on and on, with the trading firm taking a commission every step of the way.
In the old days -- before Enron and its allies pushed in the 1980's and 90's to deregulate first the natural gas supply business and then the electricity generation industry -- there were fewer risks to hedge against, and profits were based on government fiat. 
"The old game was you incur a cost to your business and you'd have to get those costs approved by regulators," said Andre Meade, an energy analyst at Commerzbank Securities. "The new game is you decided to build a power plant, but you have to manage the risks over the cost of getting the gas supply to operate it.
"Now you have to assure that your income will cover the cost of your capital expenses and give you some earnings," Mr. Meade said. "So when prices are in your favor, you try to lock them in. You can forecast power for 30 years, but everyone knows you're going to be wrong."
A huge share of the energy trading market involves speculation on the direction of energy prices, whether by utilities or the trading firms, analysts say. 
At Entergy-Koch, speculative trading accounts for up to 70 percent of the volume. To speculate, energy trading companies have amassed teams of analysts, traders, statisticians and even meteorologists, hoping to outsmart other market participants and take advantage of volatility in the prices of power and natural gas.
"We've taken on a Wall Street model," says David Sobotka, the president of Entergy-Koch and a former Wall Street executive. "We have a trading arm, a sales arm and an analytical side."
Energy trading has become so important to Houston that a new breed of wildcatter has shown up in the region in recent years -- freshly minted M.B.A.'s, Wall Street traders like Mr. Sobotka and mathematical wizards who had not seen a place for themselves in the traditional oil and gas business. Colleges in the area, including Rice University, the University of Houston and Texas A&M, have developed energy trading centers with big grants from companies like Enron and Reliant Energy.
With Enron in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, there are worries about whether the market it pioneered will continue to thrive. Most industry experts say it will.
"It's clearly viable," says Mr. Meade at Commerzbank Securities. "Enron didn't collapse because of energy trading. It took the good money it made in energy trading and invested in broadband, water, pulp and overleveraged its business. If they had only stuck to energy trading and marketing, they would have been a viable company today."
At Entergy-Koch, business has slowed with the economy. But Ms. Beckett is still getting up at 4:30 a.m. to commute to the trading floor. Arriving at the office, she sits down at her bay of computers, logs onto weather.com and, for good measure, engages in online chat with her company's meteorologist, who sits a few rows away.
Today's forecast: 54 degrees in Chicago, unseasonably warm. She expects a slow day, but this morning, the trades are going her way.
"I've sold a lot," she says, fidgeting. "I'm just waiting for the price of this one to get up to 35."

C1); Darrell Antrick, left, with Michael Dehaven, center in back, and Todd Sumner, right, on the Entergy-Koch energy trading floor in Houston. (Patty Woods for The New York Times)(pg. C4)

HEADLINE: De Niro Plans a TriBeCa Film Festival to Help Lift Spirits Downtown 

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY

 BODY:
Robert De Niro and the film producer Jane Rosenthal say they are ready to start a film festival in their neighborhood, TriBeCa, an event intended to bring some economic and emotional relief to the beleaguered southern tip of Manhattan.
 Their TriBeCa Film Festival is to begin on May 1 with about 40 world premieres of independent and studio films, which will be eligible for jury awards, said Ms. Rosenthal, who founded TriBeCa Productions with Mr. De Niro in 1988. The films have not yet been chosen. The festival, which is to run for four days, had long been in development, she said, but was accelerated after the Sept. 11 attacks immediately turned much of TriBeCa into a ghost town. 
 Mr. De Niro and Ms. Rosenthal's effort has attracted some high-profile supporters with strong New York roots, including Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax Films; Jeffrey Katzenberg, a founder of DreamWorks; and the director Martin Scorcese.
"We'd been thinking about doing a film festival for a long time that reflected the fabric of the neighborhood," Ms. Rosenthal said. "Then when Sept. 11 hit, our neighborhood was devastated by those attacks. We both felt we could do something that would help rebuild the vitality of Lower Manhattan."
That has not been an easy task. Cultural institutions and restaurants south of 14th Street have been particularly hard hit in the aftermath of the attacks, with patronage falling off steeply in neighborhoods nearest to the World Trade Center. 
Mr. De Niro's connection with the neighborhood, where he lives, is particularly strong. In addition to his film company, which has produced recent hits like "Meet the Parents" and "Analyze This," Mr. De Niro also opened the TriBeCa Film Center, which houses more than a dozen film companies, in an old coffee warehouse in 1990. He opened the TriBeCa Grill the same year in the same building with the restaurateur Drew Nieporent. 
The festival also has the backing of Gov. George E. Pataki and Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, who said yesterday that his organization would help promote the festival through its "I <heart> New York" campaign in addition to offering logistical support. 
"Anything that brings some economy into New York, we're behind," Mr. Gargano said, adding that the festival would be especially welcome because it "is right in the World Trade Center area, and it's very important to show confidence in that area."
Details of the festival are still coming together, but it stands to be fairly ambitious. In addition to the 40 feature-length films, the festival is to offer about 20 original short films, as well as entries in documentary and student categories. While the TriBeCa Film Center will likely act as festival headquarters, screenings are to take place all over the neighborhood, as well as farther downtown. Plans are also under way for a day of panel discussions and a free outdoor screening. 
The festival's executive director is to be Trina Wyatt, the chief executive of TriBeCa Entertainment, the umbrella organization of Mr. De Niro and Ms. Rosenthal's production company. Selections will be chosen by a jury, not yet chosen, of New York film professionals; submissions will be accepted as of March 1. The festival is to be open to the public, though organizers have yet to set ticket prices or expectations for attendance. 
The festival is establishing a Web site, www.tribecafilmfestival.com, which is still under construction.
Some of the films in the festival could well deal directly with Sept. 11, said the organizers, in the form of home movies or shorts made since the attacks.
For Mr. De Niro, whose decision to base his film company in TriBeCa is credited by many with jump-starting the neighborhood's growth, the festival is a chance to give back. 
"This was not only an experience in my neighborhood, but an experience in my city and my country," Mr. De Niro said in a telephone interview. "It's just a way of helping, you know."

HEADLINE: Giuliani to Negotiate With Council Over New, Lower Budget 

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW and MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration agreed last night to negotiate with the City Council over $766 million in the current year's budget of $38 billion, after Council leaders threatened to vote down the package outright unless the mayor compromised. 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose budget proposal included cutbacks in programs for women, children and the elderly whose financing had already been approved by the Council, must now give the Council some alternate proposals for reductions. Because the Giuliani budget proposal is a modification to the current fiscal year budget, the 51-member Council would have to approve the entire package before the end of its term Dec. 31, with no line-item vetoes. 
 Before the administration agreed to re-examine the budget proposal, part of a plan to close the $1.2 billion budget gap left by the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and a drooping national economy, Council members had said the package was unacceptable. The reductions included deep cuts in some current and planned programs, like library programs, child care, mental health services for the elderly and school maintenance, as well as savings that various city agencies said they could achieve through more technical budget alterations. 
"We look forward to working with the administration," said a Council spokesman, Jordan Barowitz. 
Details of Mr. Giuliani's budget plan, which reflected a list of possible cuts and savings submitted to him from most city agencies and was handed to the City Council Tuesday night, emerged yesterday.
The mayor plans to resubmit his proposal to the Council next Tuesday, officials said yesterday, and the Council would then have 30 days to approve it. However, because both the mayor and many of the Council members are leaving office at the end of this month, it is likely the Council will vote on the proposal by Dec. 31. 
Mr. Giuliani's budget proposal reflected a 15-percent budget reduction to most city agencies, except uniformed forces. There were some exceptions, including the Board of Education, which is facing a 2.5 percent reduction, and the city library system, facing a 10 percent reduction. More details of Mr. Giuliani's plan, which was handed to the City Council Tuesday night, emerged yesterday. 
It is unclear how many of those programs will survive the budget negotiations, but officials with several city agencies said they had scoured their budgets for savings and trims and in some cases were not sure where else to look. 
Among the proposed reductions that stirred the most criticism from the Council yesterday were eliminating a $5 million program to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs and a $3.5 million program to place social workers in 68 centers for the elderly. Both programs had been financed by the City Council but had not begun. The mayor's plan would also cut $2.2 million from an infant mortality prevention program in the city's 10 poorest areas and reduce by half a $5 million H.I.V. prevention program. 
It would cut $1.2 million for extra garbage collections in crowded residential neighborhoods, and $2.1 million from a public education campaign on how to dispose of garbage. It would eliminate a program to take mentally retarded children to the parks and cut a program that trains residents to prune trees on city streets.
The plan would cut $9 million from the City University of New York, scaling back several scholarship programs, including one that cut tuition in half for two years for students who graduate from high school with a B average or better.
The Board of Education would face $1 million in cuts to a program that pays to put two teachers in overcrowded middle-school classes in some of the city's most troubled schools, as well as a $20 million cut in a maintenance program that includes painting classrooms, replacing curtains in auditoriums and replacing light fixtures.
But school officials said the board would not eliminate the middle-school teacher program, under way since September, and would instead find another source for the $1 million.
Under the mayor's plan, the Department of Cultural Affairs would face a $15 million reduction. 
A plan to expand subsidized day care, adding up to 10,000 children on a waiting list, would be dropped under the proposal, which would eliminate $119 million from the Administration for Children's Services, an agency that was facing one of the steepest cuts. Several after-school programs would also be eliminated.

HEADLINE: The Forest, the Trees And the Gas Below; 
Finger Lakes Residents Debate Plan For Drilling on National Woodlands

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: HECTOR, N.Y. 

 BODY:
A quilt of forgotten apple orchards and tangled pastures, the Finger Lakes National Forest, the only national forest in New York, is an anonymous 25 square miles in the lush woodlands upstate, and a speck compared with the vast acres of wilderness in the West.
 Yet over the last year, the national forest and villages around it, like Hector, have been engulfed by the same disputes about opening federal lands to oil and natural gas drilling that have swirled around places like Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. 
 Several companies seek to tap the estimated 16 billion cubic feet of gas below the Finger Lakes forest -- a small reservoir that could, according to the United States Forest Service, provide energy for 20 years to the 33,000 residents of Seneca County, where part of the forest lies.
Congress recently approved a one-year moratorium on drilling here, but the Forest Service, which favors limited drilling, is proceeding with an environmental study and expects to decide within the next two weeks whether the forest should eventually be opened to gas production.
Opponents of gas drilling here worry the reprieve will be fleeting. Rising tension in the Middle East has stirred enthusiasm about developing domestic energy reserves. 
"They've taken advantage of the fervor of patriotism and giving the president the chance to do what he wants," said Irene Brown, a former Hector Town Board member and an opponent of drilling. "I don't like the decision personally," she said of the temporary moratorium, "but we have to face reality." She said she would have preferred an outright ban.
The debate over economic gain versus environmental good has sheared through Seneca and Schuyler Counties, among the poorest in New York and home to the national forest. Many New York officials have protested, including Gov. E. George Pataki, a Republican; Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, both Democrats; several members of Congress and hundreds of local residents. But other townspeople quietly say that many would welcome gas development as a potential source of jobs and taxes.
Opponents of drilling fear that limited drilling could expand to swallow much of the national forest. "Once the rights are handed over to private companies, once their foot is in the door, it's a pretty big foot," said John Compton, 29, a cabinetmaker here who is opposed to drilling.
Gas companies already produce natural gas in southwestern New York. But they are moving farther east, signing leases with landowners in Finger Lakes counties.
The Finger Lakes forest, which lies between Seneca and Cayuga Lakes, was patched together from farms the federal government bought in the 1930's. It was declared a national forest in 1986 at the urging of local residents, who fought a federal initiative to sell the land.
Yet as the dairy farms that supported Schuyler County for years now wither, many people are seeking new sources of income. "If you haven't noticed in your driving around here," said Louis Rosbaugh, a retiree who lives across a road from the forest and favors drilling, "this is Appalachia."
Opponents of drilling say the community, despite its poverty, lopsidedly favors preserving the forest. Most people who responded to the draft environmental impact statement were against drilling, said Chris Zimmer, a Forest Service ranger.
But conversations in offices and on farms, with people removed from the activism, suggest a more varied picture, marked by differences in class and origins. Jane Ike, the Schuyler County clerk, says she thinks many want drilling but are shy about speaking up, convinced that the government will do what it wishes. David Poyer, a Town Board member, says the discussion has been shaped by outsiders, like students and faculty members from nearby Cornell University in Ithaca and recent arrivals who rely on the growing tourism and wine businesses.
Of those opposed to drilling, Mr. Rosbaugh said, "their view is we don't want anything but a playground for the rich."
The difference may lie with the way people thought about the forest before drilling became an issue. For Mr. Rosbaugh, it is an unsightly wall of trees that obscure resources that could provide for his family.
For others, the forest is a dense weave of symbol and memory. One sunny afternoon, Mr. Compton stood at the edge of Teeter Pond and watched a blue heron rise from the water. Mr. Compton grew up by the forest, losing himself in it every day after school. He still explores the land restlessly and readily shares the small truths he gathers: that the lady-slipper, an antidote to itching, grows next to poison ivy and that cherry bark will always catch fire as kindling. And the forest's smallness, he said, makes it utterly fragile.
"The forest is only two miles wide," Mr. Compton said. "You can't come in here and do anything without a serious impact."
Yet drilling opponents have succeeded by arguing economics more than environment. Drilling advocates in the West assert that fossil fuel production on federal land creates revenues. But here, drilling opponents say, income to Schuyler County would be a pittance -- just 2 percent of the royalties -- and taxpayers would have to finance repairs to roads damaged by heavy trucks. Drilling proponents disagree but have apparently won few converts.
Businesses that could revive the local economy rely on the forest. Small vineyards unscroll downhill from the forest toward the edge of Seneca Lake. The spring water Richard Fiegel uses to make his chardonnay and pinot noir at the Silver Thread Winery is fed by the watershed of the national forest, and he is alarmed by the chemicals used in producing natural gas.
"Almost everybody acknowledges that drilling will happen on private land," Mr. Fiegel said, suggesting what many think is the best compromise. "And that way, more money will stay in the community."
The Forest Service and others argue that drilling in the northeastern part of the forest, which is mainly pasture, would be the best solution. But Mr. Zimmer conceded that under the Forest Service plan for limited drilling, the rest of the forest would still remain open to leasing and so, to drilling.
What drilling entails can be seen on Barney and Mary Broz's farm in Chemung County, about 20 miles southeast of the forest. On half an acre, there is a seven-foot-tall steel pipe that marks the gas well. A few yards away, the industrial jungle gym of the production unit, all tanks and pipes, heats the gas and separates it from fluid.
That fluid is siphoned away to a tank next to pits, lined with plastic and now covered with grass, holding the chemicals and shavings from drilling. From the production unit, the gas flows into a pipeline that vanishes downhill under a broad lawn between two copses. The trees scraped away to install the pipeline lie in a heap to the side.
Mr. Broz is pleased that long-fallow land might now bring income. But as he drives from his well to a neighbor's, looks at the crushed rocks on the ground and listens to the pipes clanging like an outsize radiator, he ponders what such changes would mean for the national forest.
"I don't know if the drilling would hurt the forest so much, but having swaths cut out of it would certainly mean it would be less beautiful," Mr. Broz said. "As we deplete the energy resources in the world, the question is, at what cost?"

HEADLINE: $25 Billion to Aid the Jobless Is Backed by House G.O.P. Leaders 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 

 BODY:
House Republican leaders offered to spend about $25 billion to aid the unemployed today as the two main economic issues before Congress -- trade powers for the president and stimulating the domestic economy -- merged in furious end-of-session horse trading.
 Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the House Way and Means Committee, offered to support far more spending to aid jobless workers and help them pay for health care than Republicans favored as recently as October. Mr. Thomas also unveiled a separate measure, which he valued at over $2 billion, to aid workers who lose jobs because of imports or the attacks on Sept. 11. 
 The concessions, which were endorsed by House Republican leaders, were a late bid to lure crucial Democratic support for a bill to grant President Bush the authority to negotiate trade deals with minimal Congressional interference. The bill is scheduled to come before the full House on Thursday.
"If anyone didn't believe that we were ready to respond to those in need, this is clear evidence," Mr. Thomas said.
Whether or not the promise of increased welfare spending helps the chances of the trade bill, it may help bridge the gap between Republicans and Democrats on stimulating the slumping economy.
The Democratic-controlled Senate wants to spend far more money to help workers than the Republican-controlled House, but Mr. Thomas's proposals narrowed their differences considerably. Prospects for compromise on a stimulus plan also seemed to improve today when Senate Democrats edged closer to the Republican position on tax incentives for corporations.
Administration officials and top Republicans in the House have acknowledged that they lacked the votes to pass trade promotion authority, giving the president the right to negotiate trade agreements that Congress can approve or reject, but not amend.
But an administration official said today that supporters had come closer to "winning the war" after Mr. Thomas's proposals were unveiled and President Bush spent a second day lobbying Republicans and Democrats at the White House. 
The trade vote is shaping up as the biggest test of the Bush administration's economic priorities since Sept. 11. Mr. Bush and his top aides have argued that he must have enhanced trading powers to open markets around the world as an antidote to terrorism. The administration says America might not be able to participate in both global and regional negotiations to reduce trade barriers unless Congress cooperates.
Even some generally pro-trade Democrats, like Representative Adam Smith of Washington, say they are inclined to vote against granting trade powers to the president. They say Republicans have done too little to help workers who have lost their jobs because of the recession or increased competition from abroad.
Mr. Smith, who along with 25 other Democrats met with Mr. Thomas to discuss trade and worker welfare measures, said the "numbers were right" in Mr. Thomas's proposal today, but that he would not vote yes on the trade bill unless the House first passed more worker aid.
House leaders say they intend to vote on one aspect of worker aid, known as trade adjustment assistance, before the vote on trade authority on Thursday. But the bigger part of the stimulus spending measure is caught up in negotiations between the House and Senate.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Chief of AOL Time Warner Planning to Retire in May
AOL Time Warner announced that Gerald M. Levin, the company's chief executive, would retire in May. He will be succeeded by his protege, Richard D. Parsons, the company's co-chief operating officer.
 The surprise change of the guard, engineered by Mr. Levin, comes less than a year after America Online, the dominant company in cyberspace, acquired Time Warner, the biggest media company. Page A1. 

Russia Agrees to Deeper Oil Cuts
Russia agreed to reduce crude oil exports by 150,000 barrels a day, a decision that could prompt production cuts by OPEC members and other nations and break a deadlock. C4.

Hearst Chief Plans to Step Down
After 23 years as chief executive of Hearst, Frank A. Bennack Jr., left, announced that he would step down at the end of May. Mr. Bennack, 68, has held the position since January 1979, longer than any other chief executive of the family-owned corporation except William Randolph Hearst, its founder. Mr. Bennack, who has worked for Hearst for 40 years, will be succeeded by Victor F. Ganzi, 54, the corporation's chief operating officer. C9.

Rivals Criticize Steel Makers' Plan
The proposal by big steel makers to have the government pick up billions of dollars in retiree health costs was greeted with skepticism in Washington and among other industries. C9.

European steel producers championed the effort by big American rivals to combine into a single company. World Business, Section W.

Taubman Convicted in Auction Case
A. Alfred Taubman, the controlling shareholder of Sotheby's, was found guilty of conspiring with rival Christie's to fix fees charged to auction house sellers. A1.

Argentine Rebound Is Promised
The results of Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo's unorthodox brew of policies in Argentina has so far been anything but sterling, but he predicted that the entire economic panorama will change in the next three months. A18.

Consumers Pessimistic in Japan
As Japan's economy struggles, the nation is experiencing deep consumer pessimism, in contrast to the United States. A3.

Ford Loss to Exceed Forecasts
Ford Motor said that its loss for the fourth quarter would be five times greater than analysts had forecast. Ford officials attributed the performance to a tide of car repossessions and delinquent loans that resulted from the recession and rising unemployment. But financial analysts and professional investors openly questioned the company's overall strategy. C5.

Bids In for German Tobacco Company
An auction for Reemstma Cigarettenfabriken, a large German tobacco company, is reaching an advanced stage, people close to the discussions said. World Business, Section W.

Service Sector Shows a Rebound
Business at service companies expanded unexpectedly in November, reversing a slump that came after the September attacks. C2.

Two Chip Makers Raise Their Prices
Two chip makers in South Korea, Samsung Electronics and Hynix Semiconductor, raised prices. World Business, Section W.

A Case Against Fuel Standards
Fuel-economy standards do not do a particularly good job at lowering gasoline consumption, and that goal itself is questionable. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: War on Terrorism Brings Plan To Cut Smithsonian Financing 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON with JAMES GLANZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 

 BODY:
In a sign of its intention to pare spending to pay for the war on terrorism, the Bush administration has proposed substantial cuts in the Smithsonian Institution's budget, enraging scientists who said the reductions would effectively gut the institution's research capabilities.
 The White House Office of Management and Budget informed the Smithsonian last week that it wanted to hold the institution's budget next year to $470.2 million, a reduction of $27 million, or 5.4 percent. 
 Scientists within the Smithsonian and members of Congress said the budget plan would imperil three of the institution's crown jewels: its astrophysical observatory, its tropical research institute and its environmental research center. 
Under the plan, financing for all three research operations would be transferred to the National Science Foundation, which would decide how much, if any, money the institutes would receive. The proposed financing for the three agencies next year is $35.7 million. 
The White House budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., said last week that the administration would concentrate money on the war and domestic security in drawing up its next budget and would "make all the necessary adjustments in order to fund those new imperatives." 
The spending proposal for the Smithsonian -- and the likelihood that the administration will seek cuts in many other domestic programs -- is already drawing protests from Democrats. 
They said important programs are being squeezed because President Bush forced through a $1.35 trillion tax cut earlier this year. Democrats warned at the time that the tax cut passed that it would leave the government with no financial buffer should the economy deteriorate or the nation face an emergency.
"This would be pretty devastating for the Smithsonian," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, who is a regent of the Smithsonian.
The administration proposal would provide $38.3 million in additional money to the Smithsonian for salaries and general expenses. But that increase would be more than offset by a $9.6 million cut in money for repairs and restorations, a $20 million cut in the construction budget and the plan to move financing for the three research institutes to the National Science Foundation.
A senior administration official said that aside from moving the scientific financing to another agency, the Smithsonian would actually receive a budget increase. The administration wanted to move financing for the scientific research to the National Science Foundation, the official said, because it has a strong reputation for allocating money to the most worthy projects. 
"The N.S.F. doesn't do museums," the official said, "and possibly the Smithsonian ought not to be dabbling in random research." 
Supporters of the Smithsonian on Capitol Hill said the cutbacks would force the Smithsonian to halt work on one of its most prominent projects, renovation of the old Patent Office Building in Washington, which is to be the new home of the museum's American art collection. 
David Umansky, the Smithsonian's director of communications, said the institution had appealed the administration's budget plan on Monday night. He declined to comment further.
The shift of research funds to the National Science Foundation would immediately affect about 250 scientists working at three Smithsonian scientific institutes.

HEADLINE: Private Security's Gain Is Public Safety's Loss, Police Say 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
It usually happens in the 14th-floor offices of the New York Police Department's second-highest-ranking official. Dozens of officers will stop by to say goodbye and "thank you," and to share a bit of news with the boss about life beyond the blue wall. 
 Joseph P. Dunne, the first deputy police commissioner and No. 2 official, said he was increasingly hearing officers of all ranks say they plan to trade in their badges for jobs in the security industry. In recent weeks, Mr. Dunne lost a detective, a lieutenant and a captain who work under him to security jobs. And he, too, after a storied, 32-year career, hopes to take his experience to a security-related job in a private business, one of the many that have been fervently courting him. 
 "I don't have numbers, but anecdotally, I have a sense there is a lot more recruiting from our ranks and a lot more people poaching into our agency, absolutely," Mr. Dunne said this week of some of the more than 2,000 officers who have retired so far this year. "I think they are being lured. I have spoken to many lieutenants and captains and people at those ranks who are being approached by people in the security business, and they are offering them jobs." 
In the Sept. 11 disaster that never seems to stop exacting its toll, one of the subtler but more serious losses is a consequence of the booming private security industry, which is draining the department of some of its most desirable workers: the serious, smart and experienced senior officers the city needs most in a crisis.
Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor-elect, has been explicit about his concern over the latest threat to what he called the department's "best and brightest."
"I think the private sector is going to go after lots of members of the N.Y.P.D.," Mr. Bloomberg said shortly after his election. "Security is much more of a serious thing in the private sector. And one of my jobs is to try to retain as many as we possibly can."
Of course, the loss of senior police officials during a mayoral transition is typical, and the department has been hemorrhaging for months as scores of seasoned officers have left for a raft of reasons, including poor morale and the economic advantage of retiring after a year of unprecedented overtime.
But it appears clear that the heightened hunger for private protection in the aftermath of history's worst terrorist attacks is fueling the potentially destabilizing exodus.
Not all of the officers retiring en masse -- 30 a day on the darkest days -- are being extensively questioned about why they are leaving or where they are going. Thus no one can say for sure how many plan to take jobs with security companies or private enterprises that want to build up their security operations.
Nonetheless, some evidence is indisputable. A department supervisor who plays matchmaker between retired officers and security firms has been asked to provide hundreds of names to industry executives. Kroll Inc., a leading risk-consulting company with headquarters in New York that has always turned to the department for experienced help, has received hundreds of inquiries a week since Sept. 11 from companies suddenly nervous about security. 
And Richard (Bo) Dietl, who yesterday hired John F. Timoney, the former second in command of the New York police and current Philadelphia police commissioner, as his chief executive officer, has in the last two months hired more than 500 retired New York officers and detectives, at least 100 of whom put in retirement papers after Sept. 11, he said. So far this year, about 2,100 officers have retired, an 87 percent increase over retirements for the same period a year ago.
"The demand for the experienced, armed N.Y.P.D. officers and detectives is becoming more and more evident for corporate security, which is weaning away from the unarmed security guard," said Mr. Dietl, a retired New York detective perhaps best known for his 1988 autobiography, "One Tough Cop," who is chairman of Beau Dietl & Associates, a security investigation company on the East Side.
The list goes on. Michael Stapleton, who runs a specialized security firm in New York, has hired six officers from the elite bomb squad and the Emergency Service Unit since Sept. 11. And he is looking to hire more.
Lt. Stephen T. Collins, a Queens narcotics supervisor and 19-year veteran, formed Law Enforcement Second Careers Inc. in February to match officers with clients. He said that since Sept. 11, his phones had been ringing nonstop, both with security firms looking for experienced officers and with retiring officers looking for jobs.
"There is much more of a heightened awareness of the security field since Sept. 11," said Lieutenant Collins. "When the cops come in for their interviews with us they say, 'Well, there has to be more security jobs.' And the firms are looking for them because they have told us that."
Two security firms, Foreseeable Risk Analysis Center, with offices in New York, and EBS Consultants Ltd., based in Monroe, N.Y., recently asked Mr. Collins for the names of 300 officers willing to take security jobs at airports. Mr. Collins said the candidates would come from a database of 500 officers who attended a job fair he held in May. 
Also, Edward J. Bradley, the president of EBS, said he wanted Mr. Collins to provide up to 60 additional retired officers for jobs securing the electrical facilities owned by Orange and Rockland Utilities in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. In the wake of Sept. 11, the utility has decided to use only retired officers and to pay them much higher entry-level salaries than a "low-bid contractor" would pay its guards, said Mr. Bradley, who is also a retired New York police officer.
"The utilities are high-profile targets if you think of it," Mr. Bradley said. "And you know what? You couldn't give a security guard the training a cop has in 20 years."
The path from law enforcement to private security is well worn. Demand has always been especially high for the top brass. Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner-designate, is himself leaving a job at Bear Stearns, where he is head of global security, to reclaim the job he left in January 1994.
But private security's reach seems to be going deeper into the ranks of the department's talent these days, many say.
Mr. Kelly, who cites the overtime earnings and their effect on retirement pensions as the main incentive for officers, has said he supports legislation that would allow police officers with at least 20 years of service to bank their annual benefit payments and stay on the job.
Part of the reason Mr. Timoney is leaving the public sector as of January, he said, is that there is a new level of importance for security directors in America. He said the pull of private security can be an alluring, if disruptive, factor for those in lower ranks as well.
"You don't mind bloodletting, that is fine, that is actually good," Mr. Timoney said of regular turnover at police departments. "But when you get hemorrhaging, it is not good. The issue is losing a lot of people all at the same time, really talented people, and the inability to replace them quickly enough. So it creates a major disruption within the organization."
Mr. Timoney then paused, took a breath and invoked the name of his friend Mr. Kelly.
"The good part is, you probably have the most qualified man in America to handle those things," he said. "If he can't handle them, nobody can."

HEADLINE: CHANGING THE GUARD: THE OVERVIEW; 
AOL TIME WARNER GETS A NEW CHIEF AS LEVIN DEPARTS

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL and GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
The chief executive of the world's biggest media company, AOL Time Warner, surprised his company and his industry yesterday by announcing that he would retire in May. The executive, Gerald M. Levin, will be replaced by his hand-picked successor, Richard D. Parsons, who will face the daunting job of making a merger conceived in the soaring Internet economy come of age during an economic slump for old-line and online media companies alike.
 News of the handoff comes less than a year after America Online acquired Time Warner in a $165 billion deal that was supposed to have created a behemoth capable of exploiting the growth of the Internet while remaining a powerhouse in film, television and magazines. 
 That strategy has had mixed results, as growth has slowed at the AOL online unit even as a recession in the advertising market has hit AOL Time Warner's magazines and television businesses. But yesterday's announcement was nonetheless a victory for Mr. Levin -- who had been chairman and chief executive of the former Time Warner -- to the extent that the change at the top answers the question of which company really took over which in the America Online-Time Warner merger. 
The takeover of Time Warner might not have even been possible if America Online's share price had not soared along with other Internet stocks in the late 90's. Only a few months after the deal was announced in January 2000 the Internet bubble popped, at which point it might have been Time Warner doing the acquiring. In any case, it is now Mr. Parsons, a former Time Warner executive, who will hold the top day-to-day job at the combined company.
Despite the implicit corporate politics, Mr. Levin said he had entirely personal reasons, at age 62, to turn over the company to his protege. "This is not some kind of corporate act," Mr. Levin said yesterday. "I must be destined to do additional things. So I pull the trigger and walk away from what is probably the best job in corporate America."
The executive who appeared to be Mr. Parsons's main rival for the chief executive job was Robert W. Pittman, who came from America Online. Mr. Pittman, who had been co-chief operating officer with Mr. Parsons, will now report to him as the company's sole chief operating officer.
Stephen M. Case, America Online's 43-year-old former chairman, will remain chairman of AOL Time Warner, where he primarily oversees the company's technology, policy and charitable operations, while leaving daily oversight of the company to the chief executive. Mr. Case said Mr. Parsons and Mr. Pittman had complementary skills that would "perfectly position the company for the next phase of growth."
At AOL Time Warner's far-flung divisions, which include the Warner Brothers film studio, the Time magazine empire, the CNN cable television operation and the AOL online service, executives and workers were generally positive about the planned transition.
Around the industry, competitors assessed the implications of Mr. Parsons's ascent. Mr. Parsons, 53, an African-American and a Republican with close ties to the White House who is known for his diplomatic skills inside and outside the business world, is considered well-equipped to handle the close political and regulatory scrutiny that his company attracts as the industry's dominant player.
The news of Mr. Parsons's appointment was perhaps not as surprising to many media executives and Wall Street professionals as the fact that Mr. Levin, at age 62, was voluntarily stepping aside -- or that the tough, driven Mr. Pittman, 47, was apparently willing to go along with the new pecking order.
Mr. Levin, a lawyer who had joined Time Inc. in 1972 and worked his way through a series of mergers and internal power struggles, is known as an obsessive worker, eager to spend hours toiling in his office on the 29th floor of the company's Manhattan headquarters. Few would have expected him to simply walk away now, and a company spokesman said there was no problem with Mr. Levin's health.
Mr. Levin said yesterday that the move had been months in the planning and was a decision he had actually been moving toward since 1997. 
That was the year his son Jonathan, a teacher at a high school in the Bronx, was murdered by a former student. At that point, Mr. Levin inserted a clause into his employment contract that allowed him to step down before his contract expired at the end of 2003, as long as he gave six months' notice.
Once the America Online-Time Warner deal was formally completed in January, Mr. Levin said, he turned in earnest to the task of preparing for his successor. Through last spring and summer, he said he discussed plans with the company's board to make Mr. Parsons chief executive and Mr. Pittman the chief operating officer overseeing all of the company's business units.
Mr. Levin said the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 had provided the final push to complete his retirement plans, which he did in a November meeting with the board's nominating committee. At that meeting, the committee, led by Fay Vincent, a former Major League Baseball commissioner, tentatively approved Mr. Levin's recommendations and his plan to step down at the company's annual meeting in May. The full board subsequently approved the plan. The six-month notification clause in his contract was the reason for announcing the decision yesterday.
"Sept. 11 I know has affected everybody," Mr. Levin said in an interview yesterday. "It's affected me very deeply because of the sudden violent death. It tears my heart out to see these widows and children. So it has affected me emotionally in ways that are quite profound.
"It's very hard to articulate, but these emotions have a lot to do with what I thought I was doing by having this provision," Mr. Levin said of his early retirement clause. "It's a sacred provision for me. I put it in because of my son."
Mr. Levin said that he planned to give speeches and perhaps write a novel after he retired. 
Many media executives said they had not expected Mr. Pittman to agree to report to his former corporate peer, Mr. Parsons. Mr. Pittman had been a highly visible and active executive at both America Online and AOL Time Warner, and he is widely viewed as exceedingly ambitious. Yesterday, several former Time Warner executives said that they could never believe that Mr. Pittman did not want to run AOL Time Warner himself. 
But in an interview yesterday, Mr. Pittman said that he had always kept his eye on the chief operating officer's job, a position that gives him considerable day-to-day influence and direct power over the company's divisions. The chief executive from each of the company's operating units will report to Mr. Pittman. Mr. Pittman, and so-called staff executives, like the chief financial officer, will report directly to Mr. Parsons.
"I definitely saw myself in the operating role," Mr. Pittman said. "It's the one I both like and think I'm most qualified for. Dick, I think, is probably more qualified for the C.E.O. role," he said, referring to Mr. Parsons.
Moreover, Mr. Pittman said that he had no interest in a job at another company or even in becoming chief executive of AOL Time Warner after Mr. Parsons.
"When Dick is ready to retire," he said, "I'll retire with Dick. I have no desire to be next at bat."
But it was not clear whether Mr. Pittman's preferences had any bearing on Mr. Levin's choosing Mr. Parsons. Yesterday, Mr. Levin said of Mr. Pittman, "He knew that I wanted them to work together." Mr. Pittman "could tell from my body language," what decision was coming, Mr. Levin added.
A financial industry executive who saw Mr. Pittman and Mr. Parsons walking down Fifth Avenue together earlier this week, before the moves were announced, said yesterday that he was struck by how well the two men seemed to get along.
If Mr. Parsons and Mr. Pittman are getting along, it may be because getting along is what Mr. Parsons is known for -- a man able to carefully pick his way through even the thorniest negotiations, using bonhomie and a shrewd sense of people.
"Dick has a people orientation, a political positioning, a way of his external presence," Mr. Levin said, adding that Mr. Pittman "is the best operating executive in the business. 
"The key for me in the last year and a half was to see if they could work together," Mr. Levin said.
Mr. Parsons, for his part, was self-deprecating in an interview yesterday.
"It sounds goofy and it sounds naive, but people want to be thought well of," he said. "If you give them the opportunity, their behavior will rise to their own expectation of self."
"Bob Pittman has insight into consumers, how they think, how they act, what they want, that for a company like ours that's focused on consumers, is invaluable," Mr. Parsons said. "And he's also a better operating guy than me by far. Bob likes to make the trains run on time."
One challenge facing Mr. Parsons and Mr. Pittman is that subscriber revenue growth at the AOL online unit has slowed in the recent quarter, raising the question of how aggressively that unit will continue to perform. 
According to the corporate strategy, the subscription businesses -- online service and cable television -- were to buffer the company from the vagaries of the advertising market on which magazines, for example, are dependent. Additionally the company is set to pay about $7 billion for the half of AOL Europe it does not own, and now Mr. Pittman must oversee that growth as well.
Moreover, AOL Time Warner, currently the nation's No. 2 cable company, is currently in the bidding to acquire all or part of AT&T Broadband, the biggest cable company in the land. If AOL Time Warner wins that contest, the company will have the challenge of selling the deal to regulators in Washington next year. If the company loses -- to Comcast, to Cox or to some variation of a partnership involving Microsoft -- it could find itself suddenly facing a much more formidable competitor in one of AOL Time Warner's core businesses.
But Mr. Levin expressed confidence in the team he will leave behind to grapple with such issues.
"It's not the fact that there was no HBO, no cable company, no Warner Communications, no AOL when I joined," he said. "For me, it's the people -- that we have these people in place. Why would I walk away from this job unless they were there?"

HEADLINE: U.S.-Canada Tomato War Heats Up 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
Americans' appetite for tomatoes is turning out to be both a blessing and a curse for Jack van der Kooy. Five years ago, Mr. van der Kooy sold his family's dairy farm and used the proceeds to start growing tomatoes near Simcoe, Ontario, on the northern shore of Lake Erie. His company, SunChoice Produce, now has 3.5 acres of greenhouses producing more than 1.2 million pounds of tomatoes a year.
 SunChoice, and the Canadian tomato industry in general, have grown phenomenally since the mid-1990's, almost entirely because of burgeoning demand from the United States. And whenever flows of goods across the Canadian-American border begin to gather steam, it seems, trade disputes inevitably follow. 
 Responding to complaints from growers in Florida and Texas, the United States Commerce Department imposed heavy antidumping duties this fall on greenhouse tomatoes from Canada. One British Columbia grower must deal with a 34 percent tariff; most others face a 24 percent levy.
The tariff "is causing a lot of distress, to put it mildly," Mr. van der Kooy said.
Mention antidumping duties to any Canadian exporter, and you are likely to get an earful. Despite a bilateral free trade deal signed in 1988 and the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994, which also includes Mexico, Canadian exporters say they are as troubled as ever by American protectionism in the form of antidumping actions.
"It's the soft underbelly of the Nafta," said Alan Alexandroff, a Toronto trade lawyer. "Notwithstanding efforts to bring about economic integration, it's galling that you still have these issues."
As Canadians see it, Washington uses antidumping and countervailing duties unfairly to hobble foreign goods that compete successfully against American products. In theory, antidumping duties are intended to penalize imports "dumped," or sold below the cost of production, while countervailing duties are supposed to offset subsidies provided by the exporter's government. But Canada and other nations say America often cries "dumping" on grounds that have more to do with politics than fair trade.
Not that Canada is above using antidumping measures itself. In fact, Canada has accused United States growers of dumping tomatoes -- field-grown ones this time -- in Canada. 
The United States-Canada trade relationship is the biggest in the world and rapidly growing. Canada now sends 85 percent of its exports to its southern neighbor. And its greenhouse tomatoes mirror the overall trend, with exports to the United States ballooning from 136 million pounds in 1998 to 224 million pounds last year, according to government figures. Canadian tomatoes have taken market share away from imports from Belgium, the Netherlands and elsewhere, and now command more than 43 percent of the market.
The Canadian government has argued for scrapping antidumping and countervailing duties in its trade deals, as they have been among members of the European Union. But Washington insists on retaining them, both within Nafta and in its trade dealings with the larger world through the World Trade Organization.
"Congress wouldn't stand for any watering down, and certainly not any elimination, of those protections," said William Ince, managing partner at Cameron & Hornbostel, a Washington law firm that has represented many Canadian exporters.
United States producers have filed dozens of complaints under Chapter 19 of the Nafta treaty, which spells out a procedure for adjudicating disputes over antidumping and countervailing duties. The complaints cover everything from raspberries to pork to steel.
One of the most intractable disputes involves softwood lumber, one of Canada's biggest exports to the United States. Twice this year, the Commerce Department has accused Canadian sawmills of unfair trade practices and imposed duties of 32 percent on their shipments. The Canadians say these actions have harmed an already weakening economy, forced mills to close and wiped out thousands of jobs, especially in British Columbia.
For their part, Canadian businesses have also filed numerous complaints against American imports.
As for Canadian tomatoes, the International Trade Commission, the United States body that rules on dumping complaints, concluded in May that "significant and increasing imports" were depressing prices in the United States and having "a significant adverse impact on the domestic industry." 
That hardly means they are guilty of dumping, the Canadians say. Rather, they say, they are being penalized for their success in improving efficiency and bringing down costs. "Fairness is just out of the window," said James Colasanti, a partner in Red Zoo Marketing, which has 50 acres under greenhouses in southwestern Ontario.
For example, Mr. Colasanti said, the cost of keeping tomato greenhouses cool in Texas and Florida is five times that of heating them in Ontario. And the market for greenhouse equipment is more competitive in Canada, saving growers money.
Mr. van der Kooy said that because almost his whole crop went to the United States, he could not survive for more than a few months if he sold there below his production costs, as his American rivals say he does.
Mr. Ince, the Washington lawyer, sees some good emerging from all the dumping disputes. Binational panels of experts set up to adjudicate them have generally been "more thorough and reasoned" than the International Trade Court, to which trade disputes are normally referred, he said. Furthermore, he said that growing cross-border investment might reduce the number of disputes in the future, as companies with interests in both countries "sort out their differences in some other way."
For the time being, though, Canada's tomato growers seem to see no alternative to an old-fashioned trade war. They have formed a Tomato Trade Alliance to defend themselves against the anti-dumping allegations in Washington, and to press their own complaints against low-priced American imports.
Bemoaning the expense of hiring a small army of lawyers, Denton Hoffman, general manager of Ontario Greenhouse Vegetable Growers, an industry group based in Leamington, Ontario, said, "You get bigger, and all of a sudden people take shots at you."

HEADLINE: Guaranteed Profits: The Fiction of PensionAccounting 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
HERE'S one explanation for the rising stock market as 2001 nears an end: Some companies are locking in profits for next year by buying stocks this year.
If that sounds ridiculous, it is. Whether profits will be made on stocks bought now is unknowable. No reasonable accounting system would let you book profits just because you bought the stocks. 
 But we are not dealing with a reasonable accounting system. We are dealing with pension accounting, American style. The amount of expense, or profit, that companies report from their pension systems are not based on the actual profits earned by investments in the pension fund. Instead, companies report profits as if the pension investments earned what was assumed when the year began. 
 That's where the current buying comes from. Many companies assume they will make 9 percent or more on pension investments, with some forecasting more than 11 percent. With interest rates as low as they are now, they clearly can't make anything like that on investment-grade bonds, which make up a significant proportion of most pension portfolios. Adding more stocks is the only way to make such an optimistic number possibly believable. Otherwise, they would have to reduce the assumption -- and next year's reported profits.
Whether pension plans will earn those returns over the long term is debatable. They did better during the late 1990's bull market. Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, says in the current issued of Fortune magazine that he would love to "make a large bet" that returns will be lower.
A survey by Bear Stearns shows that in 2000 the median company in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index assumed that its pension assets would earn 9.2 percent, with some much higher. In fact, the average return was 5 percent. 
That means corporate profits were overstated in 2000. If companies are assuming similar returns now, as Patricia McConnell, the Bear Stearns accounting guru, says is likely, there are more overstatements this year.
Over the long run, corporate books will show the reality of what the pension plans really earn. But with the various smoothing mechanisms built into the accounting rule, that can take decades. By then, the bosses making the current optimistic assumptions will have collected bonuses based on those assumptions and retired.
"It's a coming flash point in accounting," Thomas E. Jones, the vice chairman of the International Accounting Standards Board and a retired executive vice president of Citicorp, said this week. "We're kidding ourselves" by reporting results under the American rule, he added.
This is a case where accounting clearly does affect behavior. In Britain, a new accounting rule forces companies to show the actual results of their pension plan investments. Boots, a big drugstore chain, responded by selling all the stocks in its pension plans. 
A new international rule would probably require companies to show actual returns on their pension fund investments, although the returns would be reported on a different line from operating profits.
Opponents will say that would discourage stock market investments and therefore reduce long-term returns for the funds. But if companies believe that stocks are good investments, they should be willing to report the real results and to explain to investors why the risks are worth taking. There is no good reason to report fictional profits.

HEADLINE: Japanese Consumers Revel In Deflation's Silver Lining 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
In a country once better known for its $10 melons and $100 steaks, McDonald's now sells hamburgers here for 52 cents, a new discount chain offers eyeglasses for $40, and clothing stores compete to sell fleece jackets for $8, down from $25 two years ago. Meanwhile, men's suits, the sober uniform of the Japanese salary man, are the prize in a heated price war, putting imports from China and North Korea on store racks for as little as $72.
 With cheap prices Japan's new mantra, 5,000 people lined up recently outside a 15-story discount mall in Osaka, eagerly awaiting the grand opening. In Gotemba, 55 miles west of Tokyo, the 82-store Premium Outlets mall has proved so popular that the owners plan to open six to eight more soon across Japan. 
 For nearly three years, Japan has been in the grip of deflation, a broad and potentially devastating drop in the prices of goods and services that many economists see as the greatest threat to Japan's hopes for pulling out of recession. 
As long as prices keep falling, experts say, many Japanese will hoard their cash and postpone purchases on all but essentials, making the current recession even worse. Companies are reluctant to invest and debts are becoming harder to manage.
But the dirty little secret here is that Japanese consumers are reveling in their newfound spending power, welcoming the chance to buy goods at prices similar to those they once found only on overseas shopping trips. "The key thing about deflation is that it is popular," said Robert A. Feldman, chief economist for Morgan Stanley Japan.
Indeed, in a survey conducted in September by the Bank of Japan, 45 percent of the respondents said falling prices were desirable. Only 18 percent said they were undesirable; the rest were undecided.
As Japan's long-closed economy lowers some dikes to a flood of cheap imported goods, this increased competition is finally driving many prices here toward rest-of-the-world levels. The introduction of modern, highly efficient retailing is also helping to cut prices to the bone.
The cost of living in Tokyo, long one of the world's most expensive cites, is finally moving closer to other places. In 1993, it cost roughly 43 percent more to live as well in Tokyo as in New York; last year, Tokyo's premium had shrunk to 22 percent.
Many economists, who long twitted Japan for its sky-high costs and uncompetitive domestic economy, see some positive benefits in the deflation that consumers have enjoyed here since early 1999.
"Most of Japanese deflation is good rather than bad," Peter Morgan, senior economist for HSBC Securities Japan, argued in a report issued late last month.
"Good" deflation, he said, reflects increased economic efficiency in making and distributing consumer products. "Bad" deflation, he contended, comes from reduced demand pulling down housing and land prices.
This year's official deflation rate is running around 0.7 percent, although many economists say it is really at least twice as much. Last year, the government reported, food prices fell 2.5 percent, clothing prices dropped 5 percent and computers were 6.5 percent cheaper.
"Deflation is why Japanese consumption doesn't fall off the cliff," said Tetsufumi Yamakawa, chief economist for Goldman Sachs Japan. "Consumers are huge winners; they are not losers."
Leading the charge toward lower prices is the chain of 100 Yen Plaza stores, which has mushroomed to more than 2,000 outlets. As many as 40,000 items -- everything from plastic Santas to TV dinners to false eyelashes -- sell there for 100 yen, or 80 cents, each.
Started in 1990, the 100 Yen chain has boomed through Japan's decade-long stagnation, taking advantage of the new bargain-hunting mood to reach sales last year of $1.64 billion, the equivalent of 2 billion 100 yen coins. Negotiating directly with manufacturers, ordering in huge lots, controlling its own warehouses, and importing heavily from China, the chain manages to offer a wide variety of goods for one low price.
On the ground floor of one store here, Hideyuki Kimura, a Japanese chef living in Rome, was working his way down a list his girlfriend had prepared. "In Italy, they have 1,000 lira stores," he said, already having put a radish grater, a soup spoon and a towel rack in his shopping basket, "but the choice and quality is much better here."
The founder of 100 Yen stores is Hirotake Yano, a failed fish merchant, whose chain was recently ranked by one magazine as second in customer satisfaction, behind Tokyo Disneyland.
Mr. Yano is one of several heroes in a battle to give Japanese consumers access to goods at prices that Americans have long taken for granted. In contrast to the lifetime employment stereotype of Japanese executives, many of these entrepreneurs have fallen flat on their faces with early bankruptcies, only to pick themselves up and try again.
Teruhiro Ueno, for example, failed on his first try to bring discount eyewear to Japan but now owns Zoff, a chain that sells fashionable eyeglasses at three simple prices: $40, $56 and $73.
Best known here is probably Yanai Tadashi, president of Fast Retailing, who aggressively turned to China to supply his Uniqlo brand, transforming his father's clothing store into Japan's largest discount apparel chain, with about 500 stores.
When a business magazine asked him if he was hurting Japan by importing clothes, he retorted: "Consumers who previously spent 10,000 yen for clothes pay only 2,000 to 3,000 yen if they buy Uniqlo. Doesn't that make them better off?"
Largely fueled by imports, falling clothing and food prices are responsible for 70 percent of Japan's deflation in 2000, according to HSBC.
"I can buy my clothes cheaper in Tokyo now than in Toronto," said Paul Baylis, a Canadian journalist. 
Overseas travel originally exposed Japanese consumers to the forbidden fruit of low prices. Last year, 17 million, or roughly 15 percent of all Japanese adults, traveled overseas.
But with price deflation at home, fewer travelers are returning with bags stuffed with foreign goods. Last month, Kae Tokor, a Tokyo coffee shop worker, returned from a two-week vacation in the western United States. There, she limited her purchases to one fanny pack.
"Before Japanese tourists rushed to the U.S. to buy things at much cheaper prices," Ms. Tokor said at a Uniqlo in the Shibuya neighborhood. "Nowadays, I feel prices in Japan are going down and America is no longer cheaper."
Deflation's front lines are clearly evident in what newspapers here call the cheap suit battle.
In a back and forth between supermarket giants, men's suits have retailed for as little as $66. Currently, Daiei has fixed its price at $72, vowing to sell 300,000 this year, or one for every 200 Japanese men.
Other efficiencies are being gained through deregulation. After the government stopped stipulating minimum air fares, ticket prices drifted down to American levels. When the government dismantled gasoline import controls, prices fell, too. 
But most of the savings are occurring in bare-knuckle price competition long considered unseemly here. After McDonald's cut its weekday hamburger price in half, to 52 cents, sales surged from 250,000 a day to 1.25 million. Taking up the challenge, a local competitor, Yoishinoya, cut the price of its standard beef and rice bowl to $2.26, well below the prices it charges in its American outlets.
Yet as Japanese businesses battle to bring their domestic prices down, economists worry about deflation's downside. With interest rates near zero and Japan's central bank reluctant to pour more cash into the banking system, monetary policy appears powerless to jump-start growth. Many people simply store cash at home, depriving the economy of its lifeblood.
Deflation is also squeezing the government, depressing tax receipts even as its debt load becomes effectively heavier. Explaining its recent decision to downgrade Japan's domestic debt rating, Vincent Truglia, managing director of sovereign risk at Moody's Investors Service, said, "There is little reason to expect a major shift in deflationary pressure in Japan."
Rents and housing prices, which reached outlandish levels in the late 1980's, continue to fall in most of Japan.
In what may be deflation's cruelest toll, many Japanese now make payments on home mortgages that are far bigger than the diminished values of their houses.
And with prices still drifting downward, consumers may welcome the decline but they are also waiting for even better bargains, adding to Japan's economic woes.
"Deflation means that a lot of people stay out of the market," said Mark Fields, president of Mazda Motor, "because they think, "Next month, it's going to be cheaper.' "
