HEADLINE: In Iran, an Angry Generation Longs for Jobs, More Freedom and Power 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN

DATELINE: ISFAHAN, Iran 

 BODY:
In the Garden of the Eight Paradises, Samaneh and Pirouz are browsing at a book fair and watching their backs. As girlfriend and boyfriend -- terms they sputter nervously -- they are subject to the zeal of the Komiteh, or morals police, for being together without being engaged. 
 "I want more freedom," said Samaneh, a student of English translation who wears thick makeup and a smart trench coat, with her hair partly exposed. She wants more money, too, but believes her economic prospects are as dim as her dreams are grand. "If I want to travel to the United States, I will need lots of money for expenses," she said. She can barely afford a restaurant meal in Iran. 
 Mohsen Sadrai, 20, is also browsing books, trying to satisfy his love of learning here because he could not attend university. He is a metal worker who considers himself lucky to have a job, and he is angry. He describes being harassed by the security forces simply for gathering with his friends, and the hatred inside him gathers steam. 
"I must say that if not all, at least 90 percent of young people are unhappy," he said. "We have no freedom, no opportunity for work." His friends have turned to drugs; he has turned to smoking. "If we had a healthy freedom," he said, "we wouldn't have to do these things." 
Iran's youth seem to be living in a perpetual season of discontent, pessimistic about their economic futures, resentful of the Islamic government that came to power before many of them were born. Even many youths who describe themselves as personally religious say they see religious government as an unworkable oxymoron. 
But while young people here would seem to have the power to effect change themselves -- about two-thirds of the population is 30 or under -- for now they seem unlikely to reform a system they chafe against, let alone bring forth a new revolution. 
They may have helped propel a reformist president, Mohammad Khatami, to consecutive landslide election victories, but many of his ambitions -- and theirs -- have since been thwarted by the conservative clerics who continue to hold sway. 
Given the chokehold a minority has over power -- not least economic power -- they see real political change as the only hope. The frequently echoed sentiment about the religious government: "We never voted for this regime." 
At the same time, they fear repeating the bloody past, and they have been cowed by 20 years of repression, so much so that many fear speaking honestly if their full names are used. 
Still, their discontent rises. In ever greater numbers, they have poured into the streets after soccer matches to celebrate -- and to protest -- suggesting a coiled anger that may take little to unleash. Even in this city of famous mosques, they have chanted "death to the mullahs" and torn up pictures of the country's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. 
The fall of the Taliban in Afghanistan also seems to have deepened their frustration -- and their sense that freedom is possible, if only someone will bring it. 
"We need the U.S. Army," one young man went so far as to say. "The Afghan people are very lucky." 
But given the Gordian knot that conservative clerics have tied around Iran's political structure, young people feel powerless. They have no leader -- many student leaders have been imprisoned or co-opted over the last two years. They have no real ideology -- other than an abstract desire for more freedom. 
While they do not remember, in most cases, the 1979 revolution, they lived through an eight-year war with Iraq, and so abhor violence more than they want change. They sometimes fear their traditionalist parents, on whom many must depend for income, as much as they fear the government. 
That fear of the government is strong. Just ask Samaneh, who still has the marks on her legs from where state-backed vigilantes beat her with chains for joining the soccer protests. 
The beating soured her on the antigovernment expatriates who, via satellite television, had urged young people to take to the streets. "They don't care about what happens here," she said. "They are using the excitement of young people for their own purposes." 
But she has soured, too, on President Khatami, who promised the rule of law and freedom of expression. While some restrictions have been loosened, Sameneh and others said they still awaited the real change he promised. 
"All the university students voted for him, because they thought they would have a bright future," she said. "Now they think he's just a puppet moved by the other one." She meant Ayatollah Khamenei, who controls the most powerful institutions: the judiciary, the military, the security forces and thus, many young people believe, Mr. Khatami. 
Reformists, who saw the young as their natural constituency, now worry about their disillusionment. 
"The strategy we have adopted is to avoid clashes" with the government, said Abdullah Ramezaanzadeh, one of Mr. Khatami's cabinet secretaries, "but it is hard to pursue that strategy in a society that is so young, that wants speed in change." 
The changes they want are clear: better economic prospects, more political freedom, an easing of religious restrictions. 
Iranian young people see themselves as overeducated and underemployed in an economy that is wary of foreign investment and is struggling to create jobs. The official unemployment rate is 13.8 percent, the true rate probably 20 percent. Mr. Khatami said recently that 42 percent of those trying to enter the work force each year could not find jobs. 
Placing their hopes on more education, young people study obsessively for the university entrance exam. Only about 200,000 of about 1.5 million applicants are accepted, and many of those slots are reserved for children of war victims and other special categories. 
Even being accepted often means being steered to a field where there are no jobs. "I will spend four years going to university, then I will graduate and sit home," said Khatereh, a 20-year-old geology student. 
Young people speak of the "three P's" -- three Persian words starting with P that mean money, connections and support -- as the only way to get work. And even those who do find work say the jobs are not good. Muhammad, 23, said he was an educated person with a job who did not earn enough to move out of his parents' home and in with his young wife, adding, "God help those with no education and no job." 
As a result, many young people are leaving to work or study in Canada, the United States or elsewhere and not returning. The "brain drain" has become a matter of serious concern, as many of those leaving are the best and brightest. Those educated people who left last year number 220,000 by some counts. 
Ayatollah Khamenei recently called the problem an example of "forgetting the responsibility toward national development and honor." Mr. Ramezaanzadeh, the cabinet secretary, called the exodus understandable. "We cannot expect people to have a political commitment to stay here when they can live better elsewhere," he said. 
Young people complain that the government's inattention to their economic problems is matched by overattention to political and religious control. 
"The youth have no freedom, no political freedom," said Maryam Baghani, 20, as she sat outside at the Khavaran Cultural Center in Tehran. "If they try to protest, they are arrested, tortured, and beaten. I think this regime proved that religion and the state are not compatible, that they don't work together, and it's time for them to be separated." 
A malaise hung over the center's outdoor plaza, where males and females, forbidden to socialize, lounged on opposite sides. "We can't even walk to the girls' side," said Ali Ahamadi, 18, a reminder that sexual frustration may play its own role in undermining the government's ability to maintain its hold. 
Nearby two young men sat in a lazy stupor. One, Mehrdad Amiri, 22, said he had a high school education, and had not worked in two years; his friend had not worked in six months. They had turned to drugs, they said, like many jobless youths. As Mr. Amiri matter-of-factly put it, "When you have nothing to do, you do drugs." 
For some, hashish; for others, a prince. Searching for a savior, some young people have settled on the Shah's exiled son, Reza Pahlavi. Aziz Ayoub, 19, had heard Mr. Pahlavi talking about democracy via satellite television, and said he made "a lot of sense. We need a leader right now, and he's the only leader we have," Mr. Ayoub said. "People are fed up with this regime. They don't want a religious government anymore." 
A striking number of young people described religion as a tool of repression. Saideh Khoshkoo, a 19-year-old actress, said that when she applies for acting jobs, she is told to tone down her makeup, cover all her hair, wear a longer coat: "They make such interference into people's personal lives. It disgusts me." 
Religion should come from inside, she said: "If we are doing anything that makes God unhappy, we are responsible to God. I think Islam has become mixed with what people wear, and what people wear has become an instrument for some to rule others." 
At the shopping mall where Mohammedreza Jamshidi, 22, works, security forces come to make sure no neckties, a sign of Western influence, are put on the mannequins. No wonder, he said, that given a chance to break free, as with the soccer celebrations, young people did: "It's as though we are getting out of prison." 
But ask young people how the system will change, and the answer is a blank stare. They see neither their votes as power enough, nor any other hope. 
At a shopping mall in affluent North Tehran, two university students whispered their grievances, but pointed out that when their parents had overthrown the shah, the result had been far worse. 
Twenty years of Islamic rule, which had emboldened neighbors to comment on others' morality, also meant that people no longer trusted one other enough to unite.
And they were afraid. "The clerics don't have mercy on each other," said one, offering the example of Ayatollah Hosein-Ali Montazeri, a cleric who has been put under house arrest for criticizing the government. "Why would they have mercy on us?"

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Warming Up To the Notion Of Warming

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IF you've been enjoying 72-degree weather in December, you may appreciate Robert O. Mendelsohn's new analysis of global warming. He, too, concludes that it's not such a bad deal for New York.
 Global warming has been the most notorious environmental menace since the summer of 1988, which was so miserably hot in New York and Washington that the resident journalists looked for a villain. The greenhouse effect made front-page news and the cover of Newsweek. "Danger: More Hot Summers Ahead," warned the cover, which showed a family sweating profusely inside a glass dome amid a cracked, parched plain. 
 But there's another side to global warming, even if the recent weather hasn't inspired a cover story headlined, "Good News: More Pleasant Autumns Ahead." Warmer weather is not something that Americans dread -- to the contrary, people and businesses have been migrating south. They apparently see benefits to climate change, and so does Dr. Mendelsohn, an economist at the Yale University School of Forestry and Environmental Studies.
He is the editor of a new book, "Global Warming and the American Economy" (Edward Elgar Publishing), featuring detailed projections by economists and climate scientists. The bottom line is that the economic benefits of global warming seem likely to slightly outweigh the overall costs in America, and that Northerners will especially benefit. The best guess, which assumes a four-degrees-Fahrenheit rise in temperature and a one-foot rise in sea level over the next century, is that the net annual benefit will be $20 billion. 
"Scientists originally thought there were going to be horrific results from climate change, but we're not seeing that," Dr. Mendelsohn said. 
The biggest beneficiaries will be farmers, who will have longer growing seasons and crops that grow faster, thanks to the extra carbon in the air. "Crops will move north," Dr. Mendelsohn said. "It will be easier to grow food in Connecticut, and New Jersey will have fresh vegetables longer. You could have tree plantations of Southern pine in the mid-Atlantic region."
Some maple trees might leave southern New England, which would be a noticeable loss in foliage season. "There will be changes that offend people," Dr. Mendelsohn said. "But it appears that they will be more gentle than we thought. Scientists had feared that we'd go from some intact forests to moonscapes, but that's not likely to happen. We'll go from one type of ecosystem to another, which for most people will not be that dramatic."
For Northerners, the savings in heating bills will offset the higher air-conditioning bills in the summer, Dr. Mendelsohn said, but Southerners will see their energy costs increase. Southern coastal dwellers will be more affected by the sea-level rise because there's more low-lying land in the South. Northern skiers will have their own problems.
"SKIING in New York State will undoubtedly be worse," Dr. Mendelsohn said. "But in fact, most outdoor recreation happens in the summer, so there would be a large increase in outdoor recreation from global warming. More people would be hiking and playing golf all fall, as they did this year."
There's no way, of course, to put a dollar figure on some effects of global warming, like the loss of species or the pain people feel on being dislocated. Most Americans would probably prefer not to see any change in the climate, and Dr. Mendelsohn is sympathetic to their view.
"If it were cheap to do, I'd keep the climate constant," he said. "But it's not cheap. For every dollar we spend on mitigation, at most we would get 10 cents back, and it could only be 1 cent. To me, it looks like a very bad investment. I'd rather spend the money on programs today to cut pollution, improve public health and establish zones for protecting biodiversity. We'd get larger benefits, and we wouldn't have to wait 100 years for them."
In other work, Dr. Mendelsohn has found that the worldwide economic costs and benefits of climate change would roughly balance out. Again, most of the benefits would be in the North, while farmers in the tropics would suffer.
"There's a definite inequity," Dr. Mendelsohn said. "The losers are the poor tropical countries, not the rich industrialized countries that have done the most polluting. Even if it's not worth trying to stop this climate change, I think we have a responsibility to make things right for the tropical countries. We should be helping them right now to develop economically. The more developed they are, the better they can adapt."

HEADLINE: Bridging a Collegiate Gulf; 
Hugs and Pledges of Unity for Columbia and N.Y.U.

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
When Lee C. Bollinger, who is to be the next president of Columbia University, walked through the door of a private Manhattan club last week, John Sexton, the next president of New York University, was there to greet him. Mr. Sexton bounded over, knelt down and grabbed Mr. Bollinger's hand as a sign of respect. Then he gave Mr. Bollinger one of his trademark hugs. Mr. Bollinger, a more measured man, eyed his hugger warily, and then grinned. He was willing to be friends.
 Although the two universities are less than six miles apart, in some ways, the distance might as well be 600 miles. Their professors socialize. Their graduate students cross-register. But their top officials tend not to be buddies. Think of Macy's and Gimbels, or the Mets and the Yankees. 
 John Brademas, N.Y.U.'s president from 1981 to 1991, said that he and Michael I. Sovern, his counterpart at Columbia, met more often in Washington than in New York. Martin Lipton, chairman of N.Y.U.'s board of trustees, put the matter bluntly: "I think Columbia has essentially disdained N.Y.U. over the years," he said. 
That frost may be about to thaw. Last week, the incoming presidents of both universities pledged more cooperation. Although they were short on specifics -- neither takes office for six or seven months -- they said that closer collaboration could benefit New York City, society and themselves. 
"It would be sinful not to seize the opportunity to be cooperative rather than competitive," Mr. Sexton declared in a joint interview. 
He said that if both schools were competing for the same top professor and N.Y.U. lost out, he would rather have the professor at Columbia -- to add to the intellectual capital of New York and help attract other intellectuals -- than in Colorado or California. "It is not a zero sum game," he said.
Mr. Bollinger pointed to the Boston area, where Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology run joint programs in the health sciences and in real estate, and California, which has created a whole system of top-rated research universities, as examples of regions where having cooperative universities works for everyone. 
The timing for a stronger alliance may be auspicious. Historically, the two universities have operated on different tracks. Columbia was the elite, national Ivy League institution, N.Y.U. the local commuter school. 
But now N.Y.U. has built itself into a highly competitive university and is drawing closer to Columbia in its selectivity. Last year it received 30,750 applications for about 3,000 seats in its first-year class while Columbia received 16,559 applications for about 1,300 spots. The average SAT score for Columbia's admitted students was about 1,430, compared with 1,357 at N.Y.U. 
While Columbia and N.Y.U. do not compete significantly for undergraduates at this point, they do sometimes compete for faculty, as when they found themselves tussling over the historian Linda Gordon a while ago. (She went to N.Y.U.) Columbia has an engineering school, while N.Y.U. does not, but their law schools and medical schools are clear rivals. And while N.Y.U.'s Tisch School of the Arts is one of the most prestigious in the United States, Columbia's film program is also beginning to make a name for itself.
The weakening economy could give the universities a greater incentive to team up. Mr. Bollinger suggested two disparate opportunities: the acquisition of sophisticated research equipment and working with cultural groups like Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company.
"In the coming years, New York City will have many many questions that need answering," Mr. Bollinger said, suggesting that the universities might serve as clearinghouses, finding useful people and bringing them together for ideas on how to help.
The occasion for the unusual amity was a kind of coming out party for the two presidents-elect sponsored by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, an association of scholars, artists, business executives and others based in Cambridge, Mass. The meeting drew nearly 200 curious members of the academy and guests, eager for a chance to size up the two newcomers.
Professors at the gathering generally applauded the idea of togetherness, although some expressed doubts that it would continue once the two men took office. "I think there was general skepticism about how long this love fest will go on," said one professor. 
But a public university official who did not attend the meeting expressed concern that the two private universities might indeed team up to lobby for more state aid at the expense of the public universities. 
If closer ties are possible, Mr. Sexton and Mr. Bollinger would seem strong candidates; they have a surprising amount in common. Both graduated from Ivy League law schools -- Mr. Sexton from Harvard and Mr. Bollinger from Columbia. Both clerked at the Supreme Court for Chief Justice Warren E. Burger (and were noticeably to the left of him). Both were law school deans, Mr. Sexton at N.Y.U. and Mr. Bollinger at the University of Michigan, where he is now president. And both teach undergraduate courses.
Perhaps the most important similarity is their shared conviction about the importance of being open to outside views. It is the principle that drove Mr. Bollinger to be a foreign exchange student in Brazil during high school and to defend affirmative action at Michigan. And it is one of the principles behind Mr. Sexton's global law program, which has brought a constant flow of legal experts from around the world to be visiting professors.
Despite these commonalities, the two men differ sharply in style. Mr. Bollinger is smoother, both more polished and more reticent. Mr. Sexton is more pastoral, a genial salesman ready to embrace everyone and make them comfortable.
At the meeting last week, Mr. Sexton talked of how he admired Mr. Bollinger. He said that he had served on a peer review panel to assess the University of Michigan Law School when Mr. Bollinger was still dean there. Mr. Sexton said that after reading the school's self-study, he concluded that "my life will be worthless because what I want to create was already here."
"Of course, the idealized version wasn't there," he added, as the audience chuckled, "but the idealized dean was, in Lee Bollinger."
Mr. Bollinger, who discussed his legal battles in defense of affirmative action and other issues in higher education, returned Mr. Sexton's compliments. He assured the audience that Mr. Sexton was wonderful and irrepressible and that his modesty was overstated.
"Clearly it is a good thing to have competition, because it is very stimulating," Mr. Bollinger said. "On the other hand, we also have to find ways to work together, and that is the role of the university president and the deans."
Not everyone believes that the notion of greater cooperation is far-fetched. Thomas Bender, an N.Y.U. historian and author of "New York Intellect: A History of Intellectual Life in New York City, from 1750 to the Beginnings of Our Own Time" (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1988), suggests that not only are there opportunities, but there are also precedents. 
Just look at Cambridge, Mass., he said. "M.I.T. and Harvard have cooperated for years."

HEADLINE: Newest Data Bolster Hopes For a Rebound 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
The number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits fell for the fifth week in the last six and business equipment orders rose in October for the first time since January, signs the economy is beginning a rebound.
 First-time jobless claims fell to 475,000 in the week ended Saturday from 493,000 the previous week, the Labor Department said. 
Claims have fallen since surging to a nine-year high in the last week of September, when the terrorist attacks caused job cuts. Factory orders rose 7.1 percent in October, reflecting a jump in bookings for computers, automobiles and weapons, the Commerce Department said. 
 The reports reinforce other evidence of a rebound. Business at service companies expanded in November, consumer spending surged a record 2.9 percent in October, and construction spending unexpectedly increased that month, government and industry figures show.
Still, the level of claims suggests unemployment will keep rising in coming months. The government is expected to report on Friday that the jobless rate rose in November to 5.6 percent, a five-and-a-half-year high.
In a separate report, the Labor Department revised down the gain in worker productivity for the third quarter. The measure of how much an employee produces for each hour worked rose at a 1.5 percent annual rate from July to September, compared with 2.7 percent reported last month. Productivity grew at a 2.1 percent pace in the second quarter.
Factory orders are rebounding from the disruptions of the September terrorist attacks and after a decline in inventories encouraged some automakers and aircraft manufacturers to restock.

HEADLINE: Newark Airport Innovations Receive a Public Unveiling 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
In muted ceremonies, Newark International Airport today showcased two new features that had been scheduled for a grander unveiling until the terror attacks provoked a greater concern for airport security.
 One is a new rail-link station that connects New Jersey Transit commuter lines and Amtrak trains with a one-mile-long monorail spur leading into the airport's passenger terminals. Opened with no fanfare on Oct. 22 by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the connection is the first train-to-plane service at any of the region's three major airports. 
 The other new feature is a terminal expansion at Continental Airlines' Terminal C, a three-level glass and plexiglass expanse that increases gate space at the airline's hub here by nearly 50 percent. Service started today at the new section.
"The rail link, along with Continental Airlines' improvements at their terminal, will change the way people think about Newark Airport, which is the most significant and busiest airport in the entire region," said Ronald Shiftan, the acting executive director of the Port Authority, which manages all three of the region's major airports.
But that optimism was clouded by the shocks that the region and the airline industry have felt from the Sept. 11 attacks and the economic downturn. Gordon M. Bethune, the chairman of Continental, said that the lucrative business travel segment was down 15 percent and overall passenger loads were between 70 and 80 percent of what they were last year.
Despite that, he said, the investment in the expanded terminal was an indication of the company's confidence in the future.
"We're like the canary in the mine shaft," Mr. Bethune said, speaking from a platform at the new Gate 123, where Flight 23 for Los Angeles was waiting to take off. "We get sick first. We're going to have a behavioral shift among air travelers, but we see some restoration of passenger levels."
Ceremonies marking the opening of the terminal expansion had been scheduled for late September, and were to have been a star-studded affair with Broadway figures like Nathan Lane and Bebe Neuwirth. But John E. Walker, Continental's senior vice president for communications, said those plans were dropped because of the terror attacks, and because construction work stalled when workers left to help with the cleanup in Lower Manhattan.
At $1.4 billion, the expansion cost about the same as the new American Airlines terminal that is nearly completed at Kennedy International Airport.
There was no publicity last month for the opening of the rail-link terminal and the start of service that can bring train passengers from New York City and South Jersey directly to the airport. 
But in the month since, Mr. Shiftan said, the rail link has carried more than 60,000 passengers, or 1,500 a day. Most of those riders have found out about the service from the airlines or from New Jersey Transit.
Among the riders today were Dave and Colleen Patzer, a couple from Milwaukee who arrived at Newark and were headed for Manhattan. They had planned to spend $40 to $50 on a taxicab into Manhattan, until they talked with a Continental ticket agent.
"He told us that there were three alternatives: bus, cab and train," Ms. Patzer said. "But then he said that he would take the train if he were us because it has been getting pretty good reviews."
Two tickets for the 20-minute trip to New York's Pennsylvania Station cost them $22.30.

HEADLINE: Retailers Post Dismal Sales For November 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN and STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
The holiday shopping season started with a whimper and then got worse. 
 It was clear several months ago that the economic downturn would make this a difficult Christmas, but temperatures in the Northeast and Rocky Mountain states that have been more like the South Seas than the North Pole have layered insult upon injury for retailers. 
 Yesterday, the nation's merchants reported sales growth for November that was below already low expectations, as not even desperate pre-holiday price slashing enticed consumers to pick up one more wool turtleneck or leather blazer. 
The numbers that indicated continued softness in consumer spending contrasted with news -- a drop in jobless claims, strong auto sales and a bottoming in manufacturing activity -- that seemed to promise an early end to the economic downturn. 
"It is a mixed bag," said Carl Steidtmann, chief economist at Deloitte Research. "I think we've hit the bottom and we are bouncing up, but it is coming way too late for retailers this season."
Sales at stores opened at least a year, a closely watched measure of industry health, grew 2 percent in November, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail index. Even that tepid number was inflated by a quirk in the calendar that moved a week of the selling season to November from December. While many stores did adjust their numbers to compensate for this quirk, a handful of large stores including Federated Department Stores, May Department Stores, Kohl's and Target did not, and most of them expect that to depress sales growth for December. When the retailers report December numbers, the average of two months will give a clearer picture of the success of the season.
Even with the early start to the holiday season, many companies reported lower-than-expected sales. "Certainly retailers weren't expecting anything great," said Jeff Feiner, a stock analyst with Lehman Brothers, who lowered his annual profit expectations for a half dozen chains, "but for many it was even worse than was expected."
One of the most dismal reports came from Gap Inc., which posted a 25 percent year-to-year sales decline for November, below Wall Street's expectations. The apparel chain, which has been struggling because of overly aggressive expansion and fashion missteps, showed serious strain across all divisions. Sales at Banana Republic were down 11 to 13 percent, and Old Navy sales were off 31 to 33 percent.
Gap said it was forced to put more on sale than it had expected and predicted that losses would continue throughout the year. "It is reasonable to expect that the current negative trends in comparable-store sales and gross margins could continue," said Heidi Kunz, the chief financial officer, in a statement.
Although it was the most remarked upon, Gap was hardly the the only chain to miss its November sales targets. At May Department Stores, which owns Lord & Taylor's, sales declined 0.6 percent as opposed to an expected increase of 3 percent. Sales increases at J. C. Penney stores, which had been showing signs of a bit of a turnaround, failed to reach management's target of at least 1 percent. Specialty retailers like American Eagle Outfitters, down 9.6 percent; Limited Inc., down 7 percent; and Abercrombie & Fitch, down 5 percent, all took it on the chin as mall traffic remained thin across the country.
Even the giant discounters, which have been roaring past the department stores and apparel chain stores, had sales that came in on the low end of Wall Street's expectations. Wal-Mart Stores, which had a record $1.25 billion in sales the day after Thanksgiving, had year-to-year sales growth for November of 4.3 percent, compared with expected growth of 4 to 6 percent.
The one exception to the dismal environment was the ever-glowing Kohl's. The department store and discount store hybrid proved that it was possible to grow by selling apparel, racking up a nearly 26 percent sales gain for the month. That was substantially better than the 18 percent growth it had predicted because of the extra week of sales.
Although there was no shortage of reasons for bad sales, unusually balmy temperatures were widely blamed for depressing consumer interest further than had been anticipated. "It ruins the atmosphere," said George Strachan, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. "It is hard to get excited about hanging Christmas lights and present shopping when it is 72 degrees."
Bad weather is a perennial excuse when retailers miss sales targets, but given the magnitude of the swing in temperatures this year, there may be some justification. On average, the weather across the nation was 8.51 degrees higher in November than it was last year and 4.88 degrees higher than normal, according to the National Climatic Data Center.
In New York, where temperatures hit a record high yesterday, November temperatures were 5.2 degrees higher this year than in 2000, and in Denver, an important market for coat and outerwear makers, they were 16.8 degrees higher than last year and 8.1 degrees higher than normal.
"The weather has been a real demon this year," said Richard N. Baum, senior retail analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Mr. Baum and others say stores like American Eagle Outfitters, Gap, Abercrombie & Fitch, Lands' End, L. L. Bean and other retail companies that feature a wide selection of coats, scarves, mittens and hats will have a hard time if the weather does not change soon.
"The weather definitely had an impact on our business in November, which was flat when we had expected an increase compared to last year," said Michael Collins, a spokesman for Recreational Equipment Inc., which makes and sells a variety of outdoor wear.
Eventually, it will get colder, but analysts doubt that a reversal of fortune for sellers of apparel, like department stores and specialty chains is anywhere on the horizon. "We will see a continuation of the trends into 2002," Mr. Strachan said. "The consumer will spend, just not in the malls."

HEADLINE: Japan Is in Recession Again, With U.S.,as Germany Slips 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
The economy of Japan, the world's second largest, officially entered a recession today as figures showed the gross domestic product contracting for a second consecutive quarter.
 In the third quarter, which ended in September, the government said, the economy dropped 0.5 percent, or an annualized decline of 2.2 percent -- worse than the most recent decline in the United States. 
 Darkening the nation's outlook, the government also sharply shifted downward the second-quarter drop to 1.2 percent, from 0.7 percent, making for an annualized rate of 4.8. It also said personal consumption in the third quarter fell 1.7 percent. 
With the figures released today, the world's two largest economies -- the United States and Japan -- are in recession. And Germany, the third largest, is expected to follow.
The data follow a procession of statistics that point to a hard winter in Japan. In the first half of this year, the flow of foreign direct investment into Japan contracted by 19 percent and corporate earnings slid by a third. And the trade surplus is forecast to drop 40 percent this fiscal year, which ends in March.
"The current economic downturn could end up being Japan's worst ever," Mikihiro Matsuoka, an economist at Deutsche Securities in Tokyo, warned recently.
That assessment was echoed in New York by the Economic Cycle Research Institute, a private research group that studies 26 economic indicators for Japan, many dating back to the 1950's.
"They are set up to have their worst recession on record," Laksman Achuthan, managing director of the institute, said in an interview on Thursday. "This one will beat the mid-1970's recession, and that one was related to the oil shock."
Richard Katz, senior editor of The Oriental Economist newsletter, said here: "Japan never really recovered from the 1997-1998 recession. My fear is a constant economic corrosion."
Economic shrinkage or stagnation will bedevil Japan through early 2004, according to a forecast released this week by Japan's Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy, a government group headed by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.
Only four years ago, Japanese government bonds enjoyed the world's highest ratings. But in the last two weeks, the three major ratings agencies have downgraded Japan's government bonds to the lowest levels of the major industrialized countries.
Japan is largely immune to foreign investor nervousness about its bonds because it is a net creditor and because about 95 percent of the bonds are held by Japanese investors. But the downgradings expose a serious weakness of the Japanese economy.
In the 1990's, Japan's national debt more than doubled, but lowered interest rates have allowed debt service payments to hover around 10.4 trillion yen (now $8.5 billion) for the last 15 years. Today, however, tax receipts are shrinking, making borrowing increasingly costly.
Japanese government bond prices "are a ticking time bomb," David Roche, a London-based investment adviser, wrote recently, predicting that interest rates will rise and bond prices will fall, further eroding the weak assets of Japan's troubled banks.
If poor credit ratings cause interest rates to rise from their rock-bottom levels, Japan could start feeling the cost of a decade of heavy borrowing.
"If ratings go on skidding, it might trigger plunges in government bond prices, thus inducing a state of the economy similar to a depression," Hiroshi Okuda, chairman of the Japan Federation of Employers Associations, said on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Giambi Deal Is Expected, But No One Says When

BYLINE:  By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
The courtship of Jason Giambi, which had been whispered about hopefully around the Yankees for more than a year and blossomed into to a feverish recruitment as soon as it became legal for George Steinbrenner to pursue him, continued gradually yesterday. Giambi is eventually expected to sign a seven-year contract that will pay him around $17 million a year, but Yankees officials and Arn Tellem, Giambi's agent, stressed that the agreement was still not completed.
 Both sides expressed optimism that Giambi, a free-agent first baseman, would sign with the Yankees, a deal that has been anticipated for several days, yet they were still cautious about the elements that needed to be completed. 
 One of Giambi's friends would not specify what obstacles remained, but said they involved contract issues and more than Giambi's simply undergoing a physical examination. "From what I call tell you from our end," one Yankee official said, "it's not done yet." 
Some baseball officials suggested that the Yankees had tempered their negotiations with Giambi in deference to Commissioner Bud Selig, who spoke before Congress yesterday about Major League Baseball's economic situation. It could be awkward for Selig if the Yankees signed Giambi to a huge contract while he was trying to convince legislators that 25 of the 30 teams are losing money.
Two people with knowledge of the discussions said it might be several days before the Giambi deal was officially completed.
While the Yankees moved toward signing the 30-year-old Giambi away from the Oakland Athletics, they have agreed to a four-year contract for about $22 million with Steve Karsay, they are having serious discussions with Sterling Hitchcock and they are interested in David Wells. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, is scheduled to have lunch with Wells in the Tampa area on Monday, which could be a precursor to Wells's return. They were supposed to meet yesterday, but Steinbrenner postponed it because of a family illness. 
The right-handed Karsay, a reliever for the Cleveland Indians and the Atlanta Braves last season, passed a physical on Wednesday, and his signing will most likely be announced today.
In effect, Karsay is a late replacement for Jeff Nelson. The Yankees did not adequately replace Nelson, a right-handed setup man, once he signed as a free agent with Seattle after the 2000 season. The Yankees stood firm on a three-year, $9 million offer and lost Nelson to the Mariners for $1.5 million more. The Yankees tried Jay Witasick and Mark Wohlers in the setup role, and both failed last season.
Nelson was amused that the Yankees were paying the 29-year-old Karsay more than twice what it would have cost to retain him.
"I don't know how established he is," Nelson said in a phone interview. "He did a good job for Cleveland in 2000, but that's a lot of money. It is funny that the Yankees played hardball with me and I'd been there five years. Now they're giving the money to a guy whose never played in New York. Well, he's from New York, but he's never had to deal with the everyday situations of being in New York. It's great for him if he can get it."
Hitchcock, one of the players the Yankees traded to Seattle to get Nelson and Tino Martinez before the 1996 season, is eager to pitch for the Yankees. The Yankees have spoken to Tommy Tanzer, Hitchock's agent, about a two-year deal and will surely offer the left-handed Hitchcock arbitration today to give them more time to negotiate.
If Hitchcock signs with the Yankees, it is logical to believe that he signed with them only after he was guaranteed a spot in the rotation. If Hitchcock returns, it will increase the likelihood that Orlando Hernandez, who is also expected to be offered arbitration by the Yankees, will be traded. Wells and Ted Lilly would then be the candidates for the fifth spot in the rotation.
"There are other clubs interested, but I think he really wants to pitch for the Yankees," Tanzer said, referring to Hitchcock. "Not that the Yankees have to blow him away. Even if the Yankees aren't the highest, he'd probably want to pitch for them."
Gregg Clifton, Wells's agent, said the Braves, the Arizona Diamondbacks and the Texas Rangers had contacted him about his client, whose season was cut short by a back injury. But Wells has insisted that he wants to return to the Yankees, something he will undoubtedly tell Steinbrenner before the waitress takes drink orders at their Monday lunch meeting.
"He's not going to pitch for nothing, but he's willing to show people that's he's ready to do what he has to do to earn his money," Clifton said. "He wants a deal where he'll earn his money if he pitches his usual 220 innings."
Moments before the Yankees returned to the clubhouse after losing Game 7 of the World Series to the Diamondbacks, Steinbrenner barked, "There will be changes." None of the players heard his vow, but it was obvious that the Yankees needed offense and it was just as obvious that signing Giambi would be their main priority.
There has been some question about whether the A's would add a seventh year to their six-year, $91 million offer to Giambi and if that could sway him to remain with the only team he has played for. But the A's have apparently not budged from their longstanding offer, and Giambi will soon officially replace Martinez as the Yankees' first baseman.
The Yankees are understandably antsy about their negotiations with Giambi, with some in the organization still concerned that Oakland could make a late bid.
Three years ago, the Yankees pursued a slugging free agent and reached an oral agreement. Fifteen minutes later, the player changed his mind. Who was it? Albert Belle, who signed with Baltimore. That is another reason the Yankees will wait until every aspect of a contract with Giambi has been completed before publicizing it.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-16

Hamas and Fatah in Truce After Clashes Kill Militant
Yasir Arafat's Fatah faction and the extremist group Hamas appeared to reach a fragile truce after overnight clashes left a Hamas activist dead. Officials of Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority, which governs Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, said they would arrest anyone who violated the cease-fire with Israel. Hamas has taken responsibility for three suicide bombings last weekend that killed 25 Israelis and provoked a severe Israeli military response. A16

Egypt's foreign minister, Ahmed Maher, made a rare visit to Jerusalem, where he met with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and later with Mr. Arafat, urging both sides to pull back from the brink before it was too late. A16

Daoud Abu Sway, a 46-year-old father of eight, who managed to kill only himself in a suicide bombing in Jerusalem on Wednesday, was praised as a hero by his wife and children in his village, near Bethlehem. The militant group Islamic Jihad said Mr. Abu Sway had been acting in its name. A16

Russians Foil Uranium Sellers
Russian television said the police had arrested seven men accused of trying to sell more than two pounds of weapons-grade uranium for $30,000 at a roadside cafe in the town of Balashikha, just southeast of Moscow. If confirmed, the seizure would be Russia's first acknowledged case of stolen weapons-grade material. A6

Yachtsman Killed by Robbers
Sir Peter Blake, 53, one of the world's leading yachtsmen, was reported to have been shot and killed by a gang of masked robbers known as the Water Rats who boarded his yacht near the mouth of the Amazon River. Sir Peter, who led the New Zealand crew that won the America's Cup in 1995 and 2000, was in Brazil on an expedition to explore the Amazon River and two of its tributaries. A3

The House voted, 215 to 214, to give the Bush administration a stronger hand in negotiating trade deals. If the bill is passed by the Senate, where support is firmer, Mr. Bush will have what is called trade promotion authority, allowing him to reach foreign trade agreements that Congress can accept or reject but not amend. A disgruntled employee wielding a shotgun killed one co-worker and injured six others, one seriously, at a small factory in Goshen, the police said. HEADLINE: The Meaning of an 'A' at Harvard 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Richard Rothstein (Lessons column, Dec. 5) is right. Grade inflation at Harvard and other colleges would not be a problem if it indicated that students were learning more. 
The problem is that we can't be sure that it does.
 That's because of the way college classrooms are managed. They are virtually the only places in America where the person producing a product is the sole judge of its quality. 
 Few businesses would allow that. Good managers assign independent inspectors to assure the public of the quality of their product. Why can't colleges do that?
If they used independent inspectors to determine what students had learned and to assign grades, both learning and teaching would probably improve. And we could finally believe those reports that tell us that all our children are above yesterday's average.

PETER KUGEL
Cambridge, Mass., Dec. 6, 2001

The writer teaches computer science at Boston College.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Wesley Bedrosian)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INVESTIGATION; 
Mail at Federal Reserve Tests Positive for Anthrax, but Cause Is Still Unclear

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
A batch of mail delivered to the Federal Reserve on Wednesday tested positive for anthrax today, the central bank said, raising further concern about cross-contamination among letters in the postal system or the possibility of new anthrax letters.
 The discovery became public as law enforcement officials said that the anthrax-contaminated letter sent to Senator Patrick J. Leahy was identical in its language to the anthrax letter mailed to Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader. 
 Federal Reserve officials said a small bin containing 100 to 150 letters had tested positive when it was subjected to routine screening in a trailer that was set up outside the central bank's headquarters to handle mail after the first reports of anthrax-laden letters this fall.
The officials said the mail was delivered to the Fed on Wednesday. They said they did not know which letter in the bin might contain anthrax or whether any letters were similar to those received by other government officials, including Senators Daschle and Leahy. 
In a news release, the Fed described the test as preliminary and said further tests would be conducted to confirm the finding. In a conference call with reporters tonight, a representative of the company hired by the Fed to screen its mail said the test sometimes gave a false positive reading for anthrax but that this result did not appear to be in error.
The representative, Mark Brown, an industrial hygienist for Applied Environmental of Reston, Va., said the test had been conducted several times and been positive each time.
One postal official cautioned tonight against rushing to a conclusion on whether the mail contained anthrax, saying there had been several cases in which mail that at first tested positive turned out to be not contaminated. 
"We've been down this road quite a few times with the preliminary test," said the official, Daniel Mihalko, a spokesman for the Postal Inspection Service. "Let's hope this is a false alarm." 
Federal Reserve officials said the batch of mail that had tested positive had been handled by three employees at the Fed and by three outside contractors, all of whom were wearing protective suits for the routine screening. 
Michelle Smith, a spokeswoman for the Fed, said the employees were meeting with their doctors to decide whether testing or antibiotics were necessary.
Ms. Smith said that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and other agency officials had been informed of the test late this afternoon. She said that because the mail had never entered the Fed's headquarters, no one there was being tested or given antibiotics.
She said the Fed had decided to cancel a public board meeting scheduled for Friday. But Fed officials said the central bank would otherwise be open for business as usual, and they planned to proceed with a Tuesday meeting of the panel that sets short-term interest rates.
Fed officials said they had notified the Federal Bureau of Investigation after the positive test. They said the agency had asked the Fed and Applied Environmental to continue testing the suspicious mail and, if the tests continued to be positive, to set aside any letters found to contain anthrax. F.B.I. officials would not comment tonight.
There has not been a confirmed case of a new anthrax-contaminated letter since Nov. 16, when officials discovered the letter to Mr. Leahy postmarked Oct. 9. But officials have traced at least one letter that appeared to have been cross-contaminated at the mail-sorting operation in Trenton, N.J.
Mr. Brown of Applied Environmental said the preliminary testing of the mail at the Fed did not give any indication of whether anthrax was present in trace amounts or larger quantities. He said no powder was visible in the bin holding the letters.
Earlier today, investigators provided an update on the anthrax-contaminated letter to Mr. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, which was removed on Wednesday from its envelope by forensic scientists at an Army biomedical research laboratory in Fort Detrick, Md.
Scientists are expected to conduct a series of tests on the envelope and letter to Mr. Leahy and on the powder found inside, which officials said appeared to be the same lethal form of anthrax sent to Mr. Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota.
"Investigators are hopeful that the results of those tests -- expected in the coming days and weeks -- will yield clues which will bring us closer to identifying who is responsible for the anthrax attacks," the Federal Bureau of Investigation said in a statement posted on its Web site.
The Leahy and Daschle letters appeared to be photocopies of the same letter. They contained the same phrases, like "You die now," "We have this anthrax" and "You can not stop us," and conclude with "Allah is great."
The Leahy letter was addressed in the same handwritten block lettering found on three other anthrax letters, the one to Mr. Daschle and ones to NBC News and The New York Post. Each of the four was postmarked at the Trenton postal center. Investigators said they were certain that the same person wrote all four.
